column1: 125::https://coinatory.com/cryptocurrency-news/ripples-ceo-criticizes-u-s-14876/::Coinatory::article::Ripple's CEO Criticizes U.S. Crypto Regulations::Brad Garlinghouse
column2: CEO of Ripple
column3: recently voiced strong criticism against the U.S. regulatory::In a series of recent comments
column4: Ripple‚Äôs CEO
column5: Brad Garlinghouse
column6: expressed strong disapproval of the U.S. regulatory framework for cryptocurrencies
column7: particularly criticizing SEC Chair Gary Gensler. This tension could spell trouble for investors in Ripple‚Äôs cryptocurrency
column8: XRP. Let‚Äôs delve into Garlinghouse‚Äôs remarks and explore the latest forecasts for XRP‚Äôs value. Brad Garlinghouse was forthright in his critique of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and its leader
column9: Gary Gensler. Speaking at DC Fintech Week
column10: he accused the SEC and Gensler of misdirecting their efforts by pursuing legal action against Ripple and engaging with figures like Sam Bankman-Fried. Garlinghouse suggested that this focus might have contributed to overlooking fraud within the broader cryptocurrency market. He also targeted the SEC over speculation that they were in talks with Grayscale about the possibility of converting the Grayscale Bitcoin Trust (GBTC) into a spot Bitcoin exchange-traded fund (ETF). Garlinghouse contrasted the U.S. regulatory approach with that of other countries that are more actively engaging with the crypto industry
column11: implying that the SEC‚Äôs current strategy under Gensler‚Äôs leadership is politically detrimental. In another interview
column12: Garlinghouse expressed frustration with the U.S. government‚Äôs unclear position on cryptocurrencies. Although Ripple has recently achieved a partial legal victory over the SEC
column13: Garlinghouse emphasized that American banks are still reluctant to incorporate XRP
column14: owing to the persistent regulatory uncertainties. He noted that despite the court win
column15: the U.S. government‚Äôs stance towards cryptocurrencies remains unwelcoming. Garlinghouse specifically mentioned the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) as being opposed to cryptocurrencies

column1: 127::https://theconversation.com/bitcoin-isnt-a-currency-and-unless-it-becomes-one-it-could-be-worthless-88656::The Conversation::article::Bitcoin isn‚Äôt a currency ‚Äì and unless it becomes one it could be worthless::If you can‚Äôt use Bitcoin to buy anything then it has no intrinsic value.::Bitcoin is in decline. Not its price
column2: which has increased 900% this year and (at the time of writing) stands at over US$12
column3: 000 per unit
column4: but its actual use as a currency. And this makes its rapid appreciation all the more puzzling. A few years ago
column5: enthusiasts triumphantly shared announcements from businesses that had started accepting Bitcoin. Over the last couple of years
column6: such announcements have become scarce. Instead
column7: businesses that once accepted the currency have begun to drop it. The BBC contacted ten businesses in London that once advertised accepting Bitcoin. Four no longer accepted it
column8: and two that did said they hardly ever received payments in Bitcoin. The same is even true online. The Wall Street Journal
column9: citing a report by Morgan Stanley
column10: recently reported that Bitcoin is now accepted by just three of the top 500 global online merchants
column11: down from five last year. If growing adoption as a currency can‚Äôt justify Bitcoin‚Äôs rapid appreciation
column12: what can? Many enthusiasts have started to promote the idea of Bitcoin as a store of value. In economics
column13: this is usually defined along the lines of ‚Äúan item that people can use to transfer purchasing power from the present to the future‚Äù. In simple terms
column14: it‚Äôs somewhere safe to invest your wealth that won‚Äôt lose its worth over time. Apples can be used to barter services from a neighbour while they‚Äôre still fresh
column15: but their purchasing power will disappear as they rot. The purchasing power can be retained into the future by exchanging the apples for money
column16: gold
column17: government bonds or some other store of value. Some items have attributes that make them better stores of value than others
column18: whether we are talking about physical items or digital objects. Gold is a good store of value because it‚Äôs durable. Electronic bond certificates are also durable as long as banks‚Äô systems don‚Äôt fail
column19: and have the added benefit of being easier to secure than physical valuables. Money
column20: both physical currency and digital bank money
column21: has the advantage of being very liquid
column22: so it‚Äôs easy to convert into a purchase when needed. Bitcoin does share many of these attributes of a good store of value. It also offers potentially high levels of financial privacy
column23: somewhat similarly to the offshore banking system. This is an important attribute of a store of value for some people
column24: although it also creates a lack of accountability and the potential for tax evasion. But the most important attribute of a store of value is that it‚Äôs valuable. Gold is valuable because it has many industrial and decorative uses. Its price can fluctuate because of speculation on financial markets
column25: but it can never fall to zero. There will always be someone willing to accept gold because it‚Äôs a useful commodity. Similarly
column26: US government bonds are ultimately valuable because they entitle the owner to a relatively secure flow of interest payments. Dollars and euros are valuable because they are widely accepted as a means of payment
column27: and will continue to be so in the foreseeable future. In contrast
column28: the future acceptability of the Venezuelan bolivar is in doubt
column29: so people are desperately trying to exchange it to better stores of value. Is Bitcoin valuable? It has no industrial or decorative uses
column30: and it doesn‚Äôt entitle the holder to receive interest. It was intended to be valuable as a currency that is accepted the world over
column31: but that doesn‚Äôt seem to be happening. The only major value that Bitcoin has now is its exchange value. Many people are willing to pay a lot of money today to get hold of some Bitcoin. But what they are getting for their money is simply the hope that another buyer down the line will pay even more money for the coins. Once the music stops
column32: there is no fundamental value to prevent the coins‚Äô price from falling close to zero
column33: save for their tenuous position as the currency of choice in the online drug trade and grey-area gambling. The idea that Bitcoin is valuable because it‚Äôs a store of value is upside down. In reality
column34: something becomes a store of value because it‚Äôs valuable. In the 1990s
column35: people started to trade Beanie Babies on eBay. Prices of these limited-edition plush toys rose to thousands of dollars
column36: and by 1997 they made up 6.6% of the entire site‚Äôs transaction volume. Some people invested their life savings into Beanie Babies
column37: fully expecting their value to be preserved and more. But eventually people came to their senses and the market bombed. Beanie Babies are useful as toys and collectables
column38: but that doesn‚Äôt justify thousand-dollar valuations. My advice to individuals and institutions tempted by the headlines is to keep their savings away from Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies and ‚Äúinitial coin offerings‚Äù (ICOs). I know serious blockchain developers won‚Äôt mind me saying this
column39: because they see speculative bubbles and bursts as a distraction. For Bitcoin to truly function as a store of value
column40: it first has to gain acceptance as a currency.::2017-12-06T11:22:50Z::Bitcoin

column1: 128::https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2024/04/04/ripple-developer-behind-xrp-ledger-enters-stablecoin-fray-vs-tether-usdc/::CoinDesk::article::Ripple
column2: Developer Behind XRP Ledger
column3: Enters Stablecoin Fray vs. Tether
column4: USDC::The token will be "100% backed by U.S. dollar deposits
column5: short-term U.S. government Treasuries and other cash equivalents
column6: according to the company.::Ripple, the enterprise-focused blockchain service and creator of the XRP Ledger, is introducing its own stablecoin pegged to the price of the U.S. dollar. The stablecoin market is over $150 billion today and is forecasted to exceed $2.8 trillion by 2028
column7: Ripple said in a statement shared with CoinDesk. There‚Äôs clear demand for stablecoins that deliver trust
column8: stability and utility." The company said the token
column9: which it plans to release "later this year
column10: will be 100% backed by U.S. dollar deposits
column11: short-term U.S. government Treasuries and other cash equivalents." The stablecoin will be deployed onto Ripple's institution-focused XRP Ledger along with the Ethereum blockchain to start out
column12: and it will be based on Ethereum's ERC-20 token standard. Ripple's announcement comes as stablecoins have proven one of the most popular types of digital assets among crypto traders
column13: free (in theory) from the price volatility witnessed in larger cryptocurrencies like bitcoin (BTC) and Ethereum's ether (ETH). Read more: What is a Stablecoin? "What we think is going to be our differentiator is going to be the fact that the assets are going to be in dollars
column14: Treasuries ‚Äì rock solid
column15: Ripple CTO David Schwartz told CoinDesk in an interview. We're not trying to juice the last couple of decimal points out of this. We're looking to conquer the market and be in it for the long term." As for why Ripple ‚Äì still battling an enforcement case brought by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission ‚Äì has decided to jump into the stablecoin game
column16: Schwartz said that the decision
column17: in part
column18: came down to simple "dollars and cents." "Part of it is just opportunistic. It's a growing market
column19: he said. You could be a bank that pays no interest. That seems like a pretty good business opportunity." Schwartz said the new stablecoin could also help breathe some life into the XRP Ledger's decentralized finance ecosystem
column20: which has a decentralized exchange but relatively low usage relative to other chains. According to Schwartz
column21: transparency ‚Äì historically a key point of scrutiny for stablecoin issuers ‚Äì will be a key focus for Ripple as it rolls out its new token. "We're gonna have public audits on a monthly basis
column22: hopefully by a top-tier accounting firm and will disclose more on that later
column23: said Schwartz. We're aiming for complete transparency. You know
column24: we'll do whatever we need to do to address those issues." Beyond the promise of transparency
column25: Schwartz emphasized that the potential growth of the stablecoin market ‚Äì currently dominated by Tether's USDT token and Circle's USDC ‚Äì serves as a disincentive for Ripple or any other stablecoin provider to act dishonestly. Coinbase
column26: the publicly traded U.S. crypto exchange
column27: is an investor in Circle. "In the early days of Tether
column28: people were expecting it to blow up any day
column29: and they felt like it was really sketchy
column30: said Schwartz. But now, if you're Tether
column31: it wouldn't make sense for you to run off with people's money
column32: said Schwartz. Even if that was your plan
column33: you'd wait to do it" because "the market is only growing." In Ripple's case
column34: "we're not trying to squeeze a couple of extra pennies out ‚Äì we don't need to
column35: said Schwartz. Our balance sheet is rock solid." The Ripple CTO said his token will be aimed primarily at enterprise customers and banking institutions
column36: organizations for whom "those kinds of practical arguments aren't really prescient because they have to justify their decisions" to "stockholders and to regulators and so on." To satisfy the needs of this market segment
column37: Ripple says it is using U.S. banks to hold its reserves and is taking what it terms a "compliance-first mindset." USDC is currently the market leader among compliance-oriented stablecoin consumers
column38: but Schwartz said he doesn't see it as "a winner takes all" environment. "If we were a solid number three and the market grows 12x
column39: that's not a failure scenario
column40: said Schwartz. Obviously we would like to do better than that
column41: but that's not a failure case
column42: that's still pretty gosh darn good." Edited by Bradley Keoun. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column2: including web3
column3: can be a challenge. This guide equips you with the skills to navigate this.::We use cookies to improve your experience. We make every effort to ensure our content is factually accurate

column5: and informative. We do this by:  Ensuring author integrity: All our authors are well-versed in the crypto sector. Our team adheres to strict ethical and editorial standards to ensure we publish high-quality

column8: please proceed to our verification methodology page When stepping into a web3 job or any high-tech industry
column9: it‚Äôs crucial to negotiate your salary. This ensures fair compensation when accepting a new job offer and helps set expectations for your skills and contributions. This guide offers strategies for negotiating salary expectations
column10: ensuring you secure a compensation package that reflects your true value. These tactics will help prepare you to navigate salary discussions with confidence. Discussing your salary is pivotal
column11: especially when transitioning into new fields like web3 jobs or moving from non-tech jobs to tech roles. These discussions also promote workplace transparency
column12: especially in web3
column13: where standard compensation packages are still being developed. Importantly
column14: clear salary discussions aid in personal financial planning
column15: which may benefit people who are transitioning careers. This issue of fair compensation also intertwines with the gender pay gap
column16: often due to different negotiation tactics between genders. A study by the Pew Research Center indicates that most U.S. workers
column17: except those self-employed
column18: did not negotiate for higher pay than their last job initially offered. Nevertheless
column19: men are slightly more likely than women to have asked for higher pay
column20: with 32% of men versus 28% of women reporting they negotiated for more than the offer. This disparity highlights the importance of encouraging proactive salary discussions across all sectors to reduce discrepancies and ensure a more equal working environment. Securing the salary you deserve requires a well-prepared approach to negotiation. Here are a few steps to get you started: Before you even start negotiating
column21: it‚Äôs essential to have a clear understanding of what your skills are worth in the current market. This involves researching salary ranges for web3 jobs and similar positions within your geographic area and industry. Websites like Glassdoor
column22: PayScale
column23: and LinkedIn Salary can provide insights into what others in your field earn. Next
column24: a thorough self-assessment is equally important. List your skills
column25: experiences
column26: and accomplishments
column27: especially those rare and in high demand. This will help you understand your market worth and enable you to articulate these during negotiations. Once you have a clear picture of the market and your worth
column28: set a realistic salary target based on this data. Setting a range rather than a single figure is often useful
column29: giving you flexibility and room to negotiate. When negotiating salaries
column30: especially in web3
column31: tailor your pitch to highlight how your unique skills and experiences align with the company‚Äôs needs and goals. Be prepared to discuss specific examples of how your contributions could benefit the organization
column32: perhaps by mentioning similar accomplishments or demonstrating an understanding of new technologies and trends in web3. Using concrete data to demonstrate your value can be highly persuasive. For instance
column33: if you‚Äôve led projects that exceeded goals or significantly improved efficiencies
column34: quantify these achievements in terms of time
column35: money saved
column36: or revenue generated. ‚ÄúWhen negotiating
column37: highlight your skills and how they align with the role
column38: and be clear about which parts of the package you are discussing
column39: including salary
column40: benefits
column41: and work flexibility. Always aim for a mutually beneficial agreement and keep the door open for future discussions as you demonstrate your value.‚Äù Timing can significantly impact the outcome of your salary negotiation. Ideally
column42: discussions about salary should come after you‚Äôve received a job offer but before you accept it. This is when you have the most leverage
column43: as the company has already indicated they want you but hasn‚Äôt locked down the terms of your employment. When discussing salary
column44: avoid admitting to being underpaid. Instead
column45: convey that you're highly sought after. Frame it so that compensation seems secondary
column46: showcasing your market desirability. Regardless of how negotiations unfold
column47: maintaining a professional demeanor is crucial. This not only helps preserve your current relationships within the company but also sets a positive tone that could benefit your future interactions. It‚Äôs often advantageous to ask for a slightly higher salary than your target. This gives you some room to maneuver during negotiations and can result in a higher final offer than initially anticipated. Remember
column48: salary is just one part of your compensation package. Benefits such as health insurance
column49: retirement contributions
column50: flexible working conditions
column51: and professional development opportunities can also be negotiated and add significant value to your package. Arina Kogalenok
column52: HR Director at BeInCrypto
column53: highlights the importance of taking an extra step in your career
column54: be it in web3 or any tech role: ‚ÄúI had an employee who took the initiative to outline a set of tasks he would like to take on in addition to his current role and indicated the desired salary level for this work. This greatly facilitated my decision-making process regarding his promotion. I view this approach as highly professional and would be happy to discuss options with such an individual.‚Äù Be prepared for potential objections and have appropriate responses on standby. This might include justifications for your salary request based on your research or alternative compensation options if the employer cannot meet your salary expectations. If the salary offered is non-negotiable
column55: consider other areas where you can agree on beneficial terms
column56: such as a sign-on bonus
column57: extra vacation time
column58: or remote work days. Securing an appropriate salary requires preparation
column59: strategic timing
column60: and clear communication. Understanding and articulating your value can enhance your chances of securing a compensation package that reflects your worth
column61: especially in the web3 sector. Negotiation is not just about pushing for more but about finding a mutually beneficial agreement that fosters long-term career fulfillment and growth. Researching industry standards for your role and assessing your experience and achievements can help you establish a realistic salary range. If your counteroffer significantly exceeds the initial offer
column62: consider revising it and inquiring about future growth opportunities within the company. Negotiating rather than accepting the first offer outright is advisable
column63: as initial offers often include some room for negotiation. Ultimately
column64: it‚Äôs important to follow your intuition
column65: and if you feel the need to do so
column66: you can ask for advice from a close friend or colleague in the same industry. If the salary is fixed
column67: you can still negotiate other aspects of your compensation
column68: like benefits
column69: work flexibility
column70: or a signing bonus. However
column71: the scope of negotiation may vary depending on the conversation‚Äôs context
column72: so it‚Äôs crucial to gauge the discussion‚Äôs tone and flow. Even in conservative sectors
column73: using a factual and data-driven approach to demonstrate your value can bolster your negotiation. Tailor your tactics to emphasize mutual benefits

column1: 130::https://blockworks.co/news/crypto-blockchain-not-synonymous::Blockworks::article::Crypto and blockchain are not synonymous::Opinion: In other words
column2: one should not judge the merits of an entire technology based on how much BONK they lost.::In other words
column3: one should not judge the merits of an entire technology based on how much BONK they lost Artwork by Crystal Le Crypto ‚Äî like any speculative asset ‚Äî experienced its fair share of volatility this year. After plummeting to lows of $16
column4: 000 following the collapse of FTX in November 2022
column5: bitcoin surpassed $43
column6: 000 in December 2023 as part of a rally that some say is just beginning. But my hope is that crypto‚Äôs persistent reputation for volatility doesn‚Äôt tarnish the perceived value of blockchain‚Äôs underlying technology. As we go into 2024
column7: I‚Äôm optimistic that the inherent capabilities of distributed ledger technology will extend beyond mere market action. Assessing blockchain‚Äôs worth solely through the lens of profit performance overlooks the broader utility and transformative potential of Web3. In other words
column8: one should not judge the merits of an entire technology based on how much BONK they lost. In September
column9: blockchain data company Chainalysis released its 2023 Global Adoption Index. The purpose of this report was to recognize ‚Äúleaders of grassroots crypto adoption
column10: ‚Äù and to identify the countries where average
column11: everyday people are putting the greatest share of their wealth into cryptocurrency. The results were promising. Of the 20 countries listed
column12: many belong to emerging market economies transitioning from lower incomes and rates of development toward rapid expansion of trade and investment flows. Personally
column13: I‚Äôd like to believe that the growing adoption of digital currencies reinforces the technology that underlies it. What‚Äôs all the hype about? You lean into it. You go from having a MetaMask wallet and visiting a Bitcoin ATM to reading a few articles and understanding the properties of blockchain that afford secure
column14: public transactions of data and information. You learn about Satoshi‚Äôs motivations behind digital assets not as a way to make the rich richer
column15: but to disrupt power-hungry institutions standing in the way of autonomy and democratic financial access. Yes
column16: blockchain is typically associated with its range of financial use cases. But the decentralized
column17: permissionless and non-sovereign technology has
column18: at its core
column19: a social and reformist potential. My hypothesis is that greater grassroots adoption and understanding of crypto assets generates room for uses that capitalize on blockchain to effect change beyond the strictly financial realm. In looking beyond bitcoin rallies and new exchange offerings
column20: other dynamic applications of blockchain come to life. Chainalysis‚Äô 2023 index signals the presence of audiences keen to engage and capture the broader social value that blockchain offers ‚Äî highlighting Web3 projects that are exceeding blockchain‚Äôs financial boundaries to drive cultural and socioeconomic transformations around the world. Nigeria: Akowe
column21: meaning ‚Äúclerk‚Äù in Yoruba
column22: is a one-man Lagos-based startup using blockchain to issue and verify academic records. Almost all certificates issued by Nigerian tertiary institutions are physical hard copies. Coupled with high unemployment rates
column23: certificate forgeries have become increasingly commonplace. Employers and HR firms bear the brunt of high verification costs needed to ensure the credibility of academic records
column24: resulting in verification processes taking anywhere between two weeks to six months. Akowe‚Äôs mission is to introduce digital certificates to educators and Nigerian learning institutions
column25: using blockchain to facilitate a tamper-proof and easily verifiable system of digital academic records. While Akowe previously operated using permissioned blockchain Hyperledger
column26: Agboola is now exploring Amazon‚Äôs new ledger database solution QLDB
column27: which allows organizations to create centrally managed records. The startup has piloted its project with two institutions and is actively engaged in discussions with 15 other universities
column28: indicating a growing interest in the blockchain-based verification solution to reduce complexities within the current education sector. India: Web3 middleware SaaS start-up Airchains is partnering with West Bengal‚Äôs New Town Kolkata Development Authority (NKDA) to digitize land ownership using NFTs. The presumption of land ownership in India is complicated by different jurisdictional processes. Conflicting title investigations and lost paperwork creates glaring inconsistencies in the maintenance of land records
column29: impeding the Indian real estate market and often making land the subject of long and tedious litigation. Airchains uses blockchain to develop unique NFTs that serve as land ownership proofs under NKDA‚Äôs jurisdiction. This system allows property registration certificates and land records to be digitally recorded and traced
column30: eliminating tedious paperwork and promising to facilitate the lifetime tracking of ownership. Physical copies of NFTs are available in card format
column31: while digital QR code certificates are used to ensure quick access after relevant authentication processes. Digitizing proof of land records in this way is also crucial to counteract ownership often made on the basis of customary claims. Airchains‚Äô agenda is testament to the blockchain revolution to ‚Äústeadily penetrat[e] and disrupt a plethora of traditional sectors.‚Äù Crucially
column32: the project remains uninvolved with crypto transactions
column33: choosing easier
column34: gasless methods to interact with users. Airchains‚Äô user base has soared by 150% in the past two quarters
column35: alluding to a widespread consensus about replacing traditional bureaucracy with a transparent and secure digital system of land ownership. The team plans to introduce 500
column36: 000 NFTs deployed on Polygon Supernets to expand the land mutation process across 27
column37: 000 acres
column38: as reported by Forbes. These examples illustrate why blockchain and crypto cannot be conflated ‚Äî and why people shouldn‚Äôt be quick to point to market volatility as a reason to dismiss both. Once you distinguish a technology from its dominant applications

column40: sure. But it is irresponsible and inaccurate to correlate an asset‚Äôs volatility to its legitimacy

column1: 133::https://theconversation.com/how-can-criminals-manipulate-cryptocurrency-markets-97294::The Conversation::article::How can criminals manipulate cryptocurrency markets?::Cryptocurrencies like bitcoin are susceptible to fraud and price manipulation
column2: just like any other type of investment.::Cryptocurrencies like bitcoin are based on systems that are supposed to be inherently protected from fraud. Yet the U.S. Department of Justice has opened a criminal investigation into manipulation of bitcoin prices. How is that sort of activity even possible? From researching blockchain and cryptocurrencies for the past three years
column3: I know that blockchain systems have some immutable security features. For instance
column4: if I sent you some amount of bitcoin
column5: and that transaction were recorded in the blockchain ledger
column6: I couldn‚Äôt force the system to give that money back. The technology itself prevents the transaction from being reversed. But that is only true if transactions happen within the system. And there are other elements of cryptocurrency technologies that actually make fraud easier. Some of the problems the Justice Department is investigating appear to have arisen because bitcoin enthusiasts are not treating cryptocurrencies as a means of payment like dollars. Rather
column7: they‚Äôre behaving as if bitcoins and their ilk are speculative assets like stocks and bonds. So they‚Äôre placing orders to buy bitcoin in advance
column8: only later completing the deal. One type of fraud investigators are looking into is called ‚Äúspoofing
column9: ‚Äù in which people place orders but cancel them before the deal is finalized ‚Äì often without even having to pay a service fee. That makes it look like there‚Äôs more demand for bitcoin than there actually is
column10: driving up the value of each bitcoin. That sort of manipulation is possible with almost any type of asset. Bitcoin is more susceptible than stocks or bonds because so few people hold large amounts of bitcoin. The largest 1
column11: 000 bitcoin accounts hold 40 percent of all the bitcoins in existence ‚Äì with almost 20 percent held in just 100 accounts. Many of the people who own large amounts of bitcoin have been in the cryptocurrency community for a number of years and know each other. They can take coordinated actions to increase or decrease prices ‚Äì and because there‚Äôs no real regulation of cryptocurrency markets
column12: it might not even be illegal for them to do so. There are fewer protections for cryptocurrency trading
column13: in part because it‚Äôs so new. For instance
column14: a high volatility in stock prices would trigger ‚Äúcircuit breakers‚Äù in the U.S.
column15: halting trading and resetting prices to limit investors‚Äô losses. Cryptocurrency markets have no such built-in mechanisms. Another type of fraud the Justice Department is investigating is called ‚Äúwash trading
column16: ‚Äù in which one person sets up what looks like a legitimate purchase-and-sale deal
column17: but actually does the deal with himself or herself. That makes it look like there is more activity in the market than there actually is
column18: artificially increasing demand and value. Anyone can have as many cryptocurrency accounts as they wish to set up. And many blockchain-based systems keep users‚Äô identities anonymous. The transactions themselves ‚Äì if they actually happen ‚Äì are recorded and publicly viewable
column19: but the accounts involved are only identified with bitcoin addresses
column20: which are long alphanumeric codes like ‚Äú1ExAmpLe0FaBiTco1NADr3sSV5tsGaMF6hd.‚Äù That anonymity can make it very hard to prove that wash trading is happening and challenges law enforcement to identify and catch fraudsters. At a June 2017 congressional hearing a former federal prosecutor told of cryptocurrency investigations revealing an account set up by a person claiming to be ‚ÄúMickey Mouse‚Äù living at ‚Äú123 Main Street.‚Äù Some countries are starting to regulate cryptocurrency markets
column21: either under existing regulations or new ones. In 2015
column22: for instance
column23: a federal investigation found that the U.S. cryptocurrency company Ripple Labs had not properly followed anti-money laundering laws and rules about getting accurate customer identification information. In May 2018
column24: 40 jurisdictions including U.S. states
column25: Canadian provinces and national regulators in both countries launched a formal probe dubbed ‚ÄúOperation Cryptosweep
column26: ‚Äù to crack down on fraudulent cryptocurrency trading. They opened as many as 70 investigations and warned roughly 35 companies about potentially violating securities laws. The vast majority of cryptocurrency trading
column27: however
column28: happens in countries with few regulations and lax enforcement. For instance
column29: from early 2014 to early 2017
column30: about 90 percent of global bitcoin trading happened through Chinese cryptocurrency exchanges. At least some of those businesses allegedly falsely inflated trading volumes to attract new customers. China has since banned online cryptocurrency trading
column31: but people are finding loopholes. The problems will likely shift to other countries that lack strong rules
column32: which highlights the importance of international cooperation in investigations. Cryptocurrencies are a global phenomenon; the world‚Äôs nations ‚Äì especially those with lots of trading activity ‚Äì will have to work together to protect consumers.::2018-05-31T10:44:24Z::Cryptocurrency::Nir Kshetri::Home::https://images.theconversation.com/files/221027/original/file-20180530-120514-16z31os.jpg?ixlib=rb-4.1.0&rect=0%2C527%2C5501%2C2750&q=45&auto=format&w=1356&h=668&fit=crop

column1: 134::https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2024/04/05/ethereum-foundation-researchers-proposal-to-slow-eth-issuance-draws-pushback/::CoinDesk::article::Ethereum Foundation Researchers' Proposal to Slow ETH Issuance Draws Pushback::The proposal
column2: introduced in February
column3: could harden Ethereum's native cryptocurrency
column4: ether (ETH)
column5: as a form of money ‚Äì by reducing the inflation of new supply. But some members of the community say if it's not broke
column6: don't fix it. Reduction in ETH staking yield What is the role of the Ethereum Foundation?::Earlier this year
column7: a pair of Ethereum Foundation (EF) researchers put forth a proposal to reduce the pace of new issuance of ether (ETH) tokens. It was part of a concerted plan to reduce incentives for new stakers ‚Äì the investors who lock cryptocurrency into the blockchain as a way of helping to secure the network. The freshly minted ETH is a crucial component of the rewards these investors hope to receive
column8: in the form of staking yields. As the researchers' thinking went
column9: there's already enough stakers to provide effective security for the blockchain
column10: and in fact any additional increases in the level of participation could enable the unwanted dominance of fast-growing third-party staking platforms like Lido. A side benefit of the proposed changes would be to harden ether as a form of money
column11: since the total supply of the cryptocurrency wouldn't grow as quickly ‚Äì effectively tapering ether's inflation rate. Now
column12: though
column13: some members of the community are pushing back
column14: questioning whether there's really a need to change the tokenomics of ether and
column15: in the extreme
column16: whether the Ethereum Foundation plays an outsize role in influencing code upgrades on the decentralized network. The proposal was initially introduced in February by Ansgar Dietrichs and Caspar Schwarz-Schilling
column17: both researchers at the EF. It suggests setting the blockchain's parameters so that the annual issuance of new ETH would not exceed 0.4% ‚Äì a step change lower than the current effective limit of 1.5%. The big idea is that top Ethereum researchers are satisfied with the number of stakers already working to secure the network
column18: so it might make sense to reduce the incentives for newcomers. The change would also avoid extra dilution for ETH investors. The current issuance rate "dilutes ETH holders beyond what is necessary for security
column19: the researchers wrote. They estimated that the proposal would reduce ETH staking yields by nearly a third. Some members of the Ethereum community argue that the proposal is being rushed ahead without enough time for outside feedback. Viktor Bunin, a protocol specialist at Coinbase Cloud, wrote on the social-media platform X, ‚ÄúIf it's not broke don't fix it.‚Äù ETH staking is the main way the Ethereum network stays secure: Ethereum's proof-of-stake" consensus model lets users deposit ("stake") ETH with the network in exchange for yield
column20: and to help run the chain. The substance of Dietrichs and Schwarz-Schilling's concern is that too many ETH tokens are getting staked with the network via third-party liquid staking services like Lido ‚Äì crypto protocols that stake on behalf of users
column21: and then issue derivative assets called "liquid staking tokens" (LSTs) representing their users' underlying deposits. The EF researchers say they're concerned that LSTs like Lido's stETH token ‚Äì the most-traded asset on Ethereum other than the ETH token itself ‚Äì could eventually replace the blockchain‚Äôs native currency as the network's de facto money
column22: making the entire system less secure. Ethereum's security model needs ETH to be valuable in order to work
column23: and a chief concern driving the new proposal is that if the cryptocurrency were to fall behind LSTs
column24: it could go down in price relative to other assets. Mike Neuder
column25: another researcher at the EF
column26: expanded on the initial proposal by explaining that
column27: as ‚Äúreal yield from staking goes to zero
column28: stakers will need to rely on exogenous rewards for profitability.‚Äù Reducing the ETH issuance rate could enhance Ethereum's economic model by making ETH scarcer
column29: potentially increasing its value. Some community members
column30: however
column31: are pushing back on the argument that changing the tokenomics of the blockchain will improve Ethereum‚Äôs economic model. Jon Charbonneau
column32: co-founder at crypto investment firm DBA
column33: wrote on X that ‚Äúthese tweaks try to solve an unsolvable problem of fundamental tradeoffs in PoS.‚Äù PoS stands for "proof-of-stake
column34: which is the core process or consensus mechanism" used to secure the blockchain. Paul Dylan-Ennis
column35: a lecturer and assistant professor at the University College Dublin School of Business
column36: wrote that ‚Äúit seems to me it's not really issuance that is at stake
column37: so much as people have a sense that EF-associated devs and researchers appear to have an outsized power.‚Äù He added that ‚Äúthey are not engaging in the appropriate level of 'rough consensus' from the wider set of stakeholders.‚Äù The skepticism elicted responses from key figures within the Ethereum ecosystem
column38: and at the Ethereum Foundation specifically. Notably
column39: Vitalik Buterin
column40: the influential co-founder of the Ethereum blockchain
column41: is one of three members of the executive board of the Ethereum Foundation
column42: according to its website. The organization is described as a "non-profit that supports the Ethereum ecosystem
column43: and part of a larger community of organizations and individuals that fund protocol development
column44: grow the ecosystem and advocate for Ethereum." Tim Beiko
column45: protocol support lead at the foundation
column47: arguing that ‚Äúit's pretty empirically untrue that 'core devs' or 'the EF' are uncontested re: governance. this current conversation is a clear example.‚Äù "Core devs" is shorthand for the broader
column48: group of developers ‚Äì drawn from multiple companies and organizations
column49: as well as individuals ‚Äì who participate in regular discussions over the network's rules
column50: code
column51: upgrades and strategy roadmap. Beiko added that: ‚ÄúI think core devs + researchers generally treat ethresearch+ethmag as a place to post WIP ideas/proposals
column52: whereas the broader community tends to perceive it as a place where the Official Roadmap gets shared after it's ~final.‚Äù Dietrichs
column53: the co-author of the initial proposal
column54: responded that the "intention was purely to propose this change for consideration to the community." ‚ÄúOf course any change to such a sensitive part of the protocol requires broad community buy-in
column55: Dietrichs wrote. We tried to be clear about that from the beginning
column56: but could certainly have done a better job.‚Äù Read more: Ethereum Finalizes 'Dencun' Upgrade

column6: please proceed to our verification methodology page Vitalik Buterin has played a major role in the crypto space as the co-founder of Ethereum. Buterin‚Äôs vision and technical expertise have not only brought success to the Ethereum network but also helped to shape the entire blockchain landscape. Read on to learn about Buterin and his contributions and visions for the future of Ethereum. Vitalik Buterin is the co-founder of the Ethereum network
column7: a decentralized blockchain and development platform. Born in Kolomma
column8: Russia
column9: on Jan. 31
column11: Vitalik‚Äôs family left for Canada to seek better employment opportunities. At the time they left
column12: he was six years old. Vitalik Buterin‚Äôs skills saw him enrolled in a gifted program in the third grade at a Canadian primary school. He had distinct programming skills and an early interest in economics. Buterin demonstrated remarkable mathematical prowess. Despite his academic talents
column13: he was distant from social events and extracurricular activities
column14: earning him the reputation of a math prodigy. Outside academics
column15: Buterin enjoyed playing World of Warcraft from 2007 to 2010. However
column16: his experience with the game was altered when the game‚Äôs developer
column17: Blizzard
column18: nerfed his highly prized favorite character. That was when he realized flaws in centralized systems
column19: prompting him to quit. Following high school
column20: Buterin enrolled at the University of Waterloo
column21: pursuing advanced courses and serving as a research assistant for Ian Goldberg
column22: a known cryptographer. Goldberg
column23: known for co-creating Off-the-Record Messaging and his involvement with the Tor Project
column24: mentored Buterin during this time. In 2012
column25: Buterin achieved further recognition by winning the bronze medal at the International Olympiad in Informatics held in Italy. Vitalik‚Äôs net worth primarily stems from his cryptocurrency holdings
column26: which reportedly exceed $866 million at the current market value. Notably
column27: most of his wealth is attributed to his ETH holdings. Buterin holds a substantial amount of ETH
column28: totaling 278
column29: 426 ETH and 248 WETH ($919K). This makes him one of the largest holders of ETH
column30: constituting approximately 0.23% of all ETH in circulation. However
column31: determining Buterin‚Äôs exact net worth is challenging due to undisclosed non-crypto assets and potential undisclosed crypto holdings. Vitalik Buterin has achieved a lot throughout his career. In 2014
column32: Buterin was awarded the Thiel Fellowship
column33: a prestigious grant that allowed him to focus on developing Ethereum. The following year

column93: Buterin decided to leave university. Buterin traveled the world researching various altcoins. He deduced that existing projects were too narrowly focused and lacked versatility. He recognized the potential for generalizing the protocols already in place and used Turing-complete programming languages to develop the idea of Ethereum. column115: secure
column116: and scalable platform that has had technical challenges. Some of these that Buterin has addressed are ensuring smart contract security
column117: achieving scalability in handling high transaction volumes

column119: user privacy has also been a major point of discussion. Balancing the need for transparency with the desire for anonymity has been an ongoing effort. The Ethereum blockchain developed use cases such as decentralized applications (DApps) and decentralized autonomous organizations (DAOs). However
column120: it faced a significant setback with the launch of the DAO in April 2016. Intended to revolutionize crowdfunding
column121: the DAO quickly raised around $150 million in ETH. However
column122: vulnerabilities in its codebase led to an exploit
column123: resulting in the theft of 3.6 million ETH
column124: roughly $50 million at the time. In response
column125: Vitalik Buterin decided to fork the Ethereum network to stop the hack and restore the stolen funds. The inability to reconcile these differences led to the Ethereum blockchain splitting into two separate chains: Ethereum (ETH) and Ethereum Classic (ETC). Ethereum moved forward with the fork to recover the stolen funds
column126: while Ethereum Classic remained on the original blockchain. ETH became more popular over time and attracted the support of the Enterprise Ethereum Alliance
column128: including JP Morgan and Citigroup. Vitalik Buterin recognized that Ethereum‚Äôs proof-of-work (PoW) version led to soaring Ethereum gas fees
column129: making transactions too expensive for many users. This delay prompted Buterin to acknowledge that Ethereum‚Äôs transition to a proof-of-stake (PoS) consensus mechanism would take six years instead of the projected one. To address the need for improved transaction throughput and congestion management
column130: Ethereum adopted sharding as part of the Ethereum 2.0 upgrade (Merge). Sharding divides the network into shard chains
column131: distributing the load and aiming to boost transaction throughput and relieve congestion. The Merge integrated Ethereum‚Äôs original mainnet with its new proof-of-stake Beacon Chain. This transition eliminated energy-intensive mining and enabled the network to be secured through staked ETH. However
column132: Buterin and his team‚Äôs adoption of a more centralized approach has departed from the decentralized strategy previously favored by Ethereum community members. In addition
column134: viewing ETH as an investment asset rather than a decentralized currency. Did you know? The name Ethereum was inspired by a medieval theory about an invisible

He believes ENS offers solutions that many people overlook. Buterin is fascinated by Zero-Knowledge Succinct Non-Interactive Argument of Knowledge (zk-SNARKs)
column150: a cryptographic proof allowing a party to prove possession of specific information without revealing it. This eliminates the need for interaction between the prover and verifier. column1: 136::https://blockworks.co/news/music-industry-blockchain-bandcamp::Blockworks::article::The music industry could learn a few lessons from blockchain::Opinion: Digital ownership is inevitable
column2: but let‚Äôs be realistic about the problems it solves.::Bandcamp‚Äôs drama and community response has reminded us that the investments we make into centralized internet products are neither owned by us nor permanent Midjourney modified by Blockworks I spent twenty years building digital music applications and businesses
column3: most recently Beats Music and Apple Music
column4: previously with Yahoo!
column5: Winamp
column6: Topspin and Beastie Boys. Today
column7: I work at Ledger and espouse the utility of crypto instead
column8: so I‚Äôm often asked the question
column9: ‚ÄúWhat about music on the blockchain?‚Äù ‚ÄúMeh
column10: ‚Äù is my standard response. I don‚Äôt see the innovation or consumer need in asking people to buy digital music NFTs like they bought CDs
column11: or trying to shoehorn digital ownership into streaming services meant to compete with Spotify. Listening to music on the internet is a solved problem
column12: and music listeners don‚Äôt need the help of a blockchain to hear what they want. Just say
column13: ‚ÄúHey Siri
column14: play The Beatles
column15: ‚Äù to remind yourself just how far we‚Äôve come since Napster. The business of music rights is an oligopoly controlled by three major labels and four digital music services
column16: none of whom have an interest in open standards. But the two-sided marketplace of Bandcamp is a great place to consider the value blockchains can and will add to the artist/fan relationship
column17: and how that change will come slowly over the next fifteen years. Below is a thought exercise using Bandcamp to demonstrate where digital ownership can meaningfully change the paradigm without asking consumers to change their habits all at once. For music fans ‚Äî and in particular
column18: fans of niche genres such as heavy metal and contemporary jazz ‚Äî Bandcamp is beloved. The site launched in 2008 and bloomed slowly
column19: building a passionate community of music lovers over fifteen years. The functionality of Bandcamp.com is simple: Stream for free
column20: buy digital for around $10
column21: and often buy vinyl (Bandcamp actually bought a pressing plant to help the creator side of their marketplace press vinyl)
column22: as well as t-shirts or other physical collectibles from the artist. Artists receive a net average of 82% of every sale
column23: and Bandcamp has paid out around $1 billion to artists and labels selling on the site since its launch. But in March 2022
column24: Bandcamp was sold to Epic Games. ‚ÄúBandcamp will play an important role in Epic‚Äôs vision to build out a creator marketplace ecosystem
column25: ‚Äù Epic Games wrote in a statement. Bandcamp unionized in March 2023
column26: and when Epic Games announced it was laying off 16% of its total workforce in September
column27: a sale of Bandcamp to Songtradr was announced. Only 50% of the Bandcamp staff was retained and the community voiced its concern for the future of Bandcamp loudly culminating in this Pitchfork article: ‚ÄúIs Bandcamp as we know it over?‚Äù. Bandcamp‚Äôs drama and community response has reminded us ‚Äî like MySpace
column28: Flickr and so many other platforms before ‚Äî that the investments we make into centralized internet products are neither owned by us nor permanent. At the end of the day
column29: these are for-profit companies with investors looking for outcomes. Our investments into the platform are of value for them
column30: not for us. The digital albums purchased
column31: as well as the ‚Äúrelationship‚Äù between the artist and consumer
column32: are owned by Bandcamp. If they disappear
column33: so does the artist‚Äôs access to their fanbase and the listener‚Äôs backup of the music they‚Äôve paid for. With decentralized ownership
column34: this could be fundamentally different. If I were at the helm
column35: here is how I would modify Bandcamp: The ambitions could be set higher than I suggest above ‚Äî digital packaging and payouts to creative collaborators like Metalabel is building would be very useful in the Bandcamp context. Read more from our opinion section: You aren‚Äôt thinking hard enough about digital art You could also imagine artists earning ownership in Bandcamp based on performance and a revenue stream for artists where the profits of the platform are paid out based on this ownership (what Visa was for banks
column36: Bandcamp could be for artists). But I like the simple thought experience described in the bullet points above particularly because the changes are subtle and simple
column37: yet meaningful to both artists and fans
column38: without asking either to change their behavior overnight. But we should keep this in perspective ‚Äî the entire recorded music industry made $26 billion in revenue in 2022
column39: whereas Bandcamp has paid out just $1 billion to artists since 2008. Also
column40: the examples above speak to how application developers in categories beyond music will integrate digital ownership slowly and optionally for their customers
column41: rather than a Web3 ‚Äúbig bang‚Äù overnight. Digital ownership is inevitable
column42: but let‚Äôs be realistic about the problems it solves and how quickly this new paradigm is arriving to mainstream consumers. Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. The Lightspeed newsletter is all things Solana

column1: 139::https://theconversation.com/blockchains-focusing-on-bitcoin-misses-the-real-revolution-in-digital-trust-58125::The Conversation::article::Blockchains: Focusing on bitcoin misses the real revolution in digital trust::The transaction system underlying the bitcoin network has far broader uses than easing financial transfers ‚Äì including identifying people and tracking property ownership.::In 2008
column2: short of sending a suitcase full of cash
column3: there was essentially just one way for an individual to send money between
column4: say
column5: the United States and Europe. You had to wire the money through a mainstream financial service
column6: like Western Union or a bank. That meant paying high fees and waiting up to several days for the money to arrive. A radically new option arose in 2009 with the introduction of bitcoin. Bitcoin makes it possible to transfer value between two individuals anywhere in the world quickly and at minimal cost. It is often called a ‚Äúcryptocurrency
column7: ‚Äù as it is purely digital and uses cryptography to protect against counterfeiting. The software that executes this cryptography runs simultaneously on computers around the world. Even if one or more of these computers is misused in an attempt to corrupt the bitcoin network (such as to steal money)
column8: the collective action of the others ensures the integrity of the system as a whole. Its distributed nature also enables bitcoin to process transactions without the fees
column9: antiquated networks and (for better or worse) the rules governing intermediaries like banks and wire services. Bitcoin‚Äôs exciting history and social impact have fired imaginations. The aggregate market value of all issued bitcoins today is roughly US$10 billion. The computing devices that maintain its blockchain are geographically dispersed and owned by thousands of different individuals
column10: so the bitcoin network has no single owner or point of control. Even its creator remains a mystery (despite many efforts to unmask her
column11: him or them). Bitcoin‚Äôs lack of government regulation made it attractive to black markets and malware writers. Although the core system is well-secured
column12: people who own bitcoins have experienced a litany of heists and fraud. Even more than the currency itself
column13: though
column14: what has drawn the world‚Äôs attention are the unprecedented reliability and security of bitcoin‚Äôs underlying transaction system
column15: called a blockchain. Researchers
column16: entrepreneurs
column17: and developers believe that blockchains will solve a stunning array of problems
column18: such as stabilization of financial systems
column19: identification of stateless persons
column20: establishing title to real estate and media
column21: and efficiently managing supply chains. Despite its richly varied applications
column22: a blockchain such as bitcoin‚Äôs aims to realize a simple goal. Abstractly
column23: it can be viewed as creating a kind of public bulletin board
column24: often called a ‚Äúdistributed ledger.‚Äù This ledger is public. Anyone ‚Äì plebeian or plutocrat
column25: baker or banker ‚Äì can read it. And anyone can write valid data to it. Specifically
column26: in bitcoin
column27: any owner of money can add a transaction to the ledger that transfers some of her money to someone else. The bitcoin network makes sure that the ledger includes only authorized transactions
column28: meaning those digitally signed by the owners of the money being transferred. The key feature of blockchains is that new data may be written at any time
column29: but can never be changed or erased. At first glance
column30: this etched-in-stone rule seems a needless design restriction. But it gives rise to a permanent
column31: ever-growing transactional history that creates strong transparency and accountability. For example
column32: the bitcoin blockchain contains a record of every transaction in the system since its birth. This feature makes it possible to prevent account holders from reneging on transactions
column33: even if their identities remain anonymous. Once in the ledger
column34: a transaction is undeniable. The indelible nature of the ledger is much more powerful and general
column35: though
column36: allowing blockchains to support applications well beyond bitcoin. Consider
column37: for example
column38: the management of title to a piece of land or property. Property registries in many parts of the world today are fragmented
column39: incomplete
column40: poorly maintained
column41: and difficult to access. The legal uncertainty surrounding ownership of property is a major impediment to growth in developing economies. Were property titles authoritatively and publicly recorded on a blockchain
column42: anyone could learn instantly who has title to a piece of property. Even legitimate anonymous ownership ‚Äì as through a private trust ‚Äì could be recorded on a blockchain. Such transparency would help resolve legal ambiguity and shed light on malfeasance. Advocates envision similar benefits in blockchain recording of media rights ‚Äì such as rights to use images or music ‚Äì identity documents and shipping manifests. In addition
column43: the decentralized nature of the database provides resilience not just to technical failures
column44: but also to political ones ‚Äì failed states
column45: corruption and graft. Blockchains can be enhanced to support not just transactions
column46: but also pieces of code known as smart contracts. A smart contract is a program that controls assets on the blockchain ‚Äì anything from cryptocurrency to media rights ‚Äì in ways that guarantee predictable behavior. A smart contract may be viewed as playing the role of a trusted third party: Whatever task it is programmed to do
column47: it will carry out faithfully. Suppose for example that a user wishes to auction off a piece of land for which her rights are represented on a blockchain. She could hire an auctioneer
column48: or use an online auction site. But that would require her and her potential customers to trust
column49: without proof
column50: that the auctioneer conducts the auction honestly. To achieve greater transparency
column51: the user could instead create a smart contract that executes the auction automatically. She would program the smart contract with the ability to deliver the item to be sold and with rules about minimum bids and bidding deadlines. She would also specify what the smart contract is to do at the end of the auction: send the winning bid amount from the winner to the seller‚Äôs account and transfer the land title to the winner. Because the blockchain is publicly visible
column52: anyone with suitable expertise could check that the code in the smart contract implements a fair and valid auction. Auction participants would only need to trust the correctness of the code. They wouldn‚Äôt need to rely on an auctioneer to run the auction honestly ‚Äì and as an added benefit
column53: they also wouldn‚Äôt need to pay high auctioneer fees. Behind this compelling vision lurk many technical challenges. The transparency and accountability of a fully public ledger have many benefits
column54: but are at odds with confidentiality. Suppose the seller mentioned above wanted to conduct a sealed-bid auction or conceal the winning bid amount? How could she do this on a blockchain that everyone can read? Achieving both transparency and confidentiality on blockchains is in fact possible
column55: but requires new techniques under development by researchers. Another challenge is ensuring that smart contracts correctly reflect user intent. A lawyer
column56: arbiter or court can remedy defects or address unforeseen circumstances in written contracts. Smart contracts
column57: though
column58: are expressly designed as unalterable code. This inflexibility avoids ambiguity and cheating and ensures trustworthy execution
column59: but it can also cause brittleness. An excellent example was the recent theft of around $55 million in cryptocurrency from a smart contract. The thief exploited a software bug
column60: and the smart contract creators couldn‚Äôt fix it once the contract was running. Bitcoin is a proof of concept of the viability of blockchains. As researchers and developers overcome the technical challenges of smart contracts and other blockchain innovations
column61: marveling at money flying across the Atlantic will someday seem quaint.::2016-07-18T10:17:17Z::Bitcoin

column1: 140::https://www.coindesk.com/consensus-magazine/2024/01/26/which-is-the-best-self-custody-lightning-wallet/::CoinDesk::article::Which Is the Best Self-Custody Lightning Wallet?::Bitcoin educator Anita Posch tested the Blixt
