column4: Phoenix and Zeus Lightning wallets while traveling in Zimbabwe. Lightning wallets tested and goal Choosing the test location The testing process Payment costs Features and differences Second test in urban area with LTE connection Overall rankings for Lightning self-custody Conclusion::I'm conducting my second test of self-custodial Lightning wallets in Zimbabwe
column5: to see which might be best for any rural area. Given that none of the available self-custodial wallets are developed by Africans
column6: they are rarely used or tested here. On top of that
column7: Lightning is still new and complex
column8: building mobile apps that are running a node of the network on your phone is challenging. I am here to find out what works and what does not. As an educator
column9: I recommend tools for everyday users
column10: who want to send small payments. These tools have to be reliable
column11: otherwise people might conclude that Bitcoin isn't for them. Anita Posch is a world-renowned Bitcoin educator
column12: author of the book "(L)earn Bitcoin" and founder of the online academy Crack the Orange as well as non-profit initiative Bitcoin for Fairness. I opened my first Lightning channel on an app called BLW in January 2019. I‚Äôm used to testing new tools
column13: that‚Äôs why I have no problem if challenges and bugs arise. But regular users may not be as forgiving
column14: that‚Äôs why I aim to only recommend tools I‚Äôve personally tested. In 2023
column15: the only two self-custody Lightning wallets available were Breez and Phoenix. This year I had more choices and tested: Blixt
column16: Mutiny
column17: Green
column18: Zeus and Phoenix. I also included the Wallet of Satoshi
column19: a custodial wallet
column20: just to see how it performs in comparison. I was familiar with Phoenix and used Zeus connected to my Voltage node earlier. Mutiny
column21: Blixt and the Lightning integration in Blockstream‚Äôs Green wallet just popped up in the last few months
column22: so using them was new for me too. All of the wallets have been undergoing huge changes and will continue to evolve. I had to download Mutiny manually and install a special .apk file used on Android phones. For the Green wallet
column23: I asked BlockStream to unlock its experimental Greenlight feature in order to test it. My goal was to find out which of the wallets are the best in sending and receiving bitcoin in a reliable
column24: fast
column25: easy to use manner and to compare the costs involved. See also: Coinbase CEO Confirms Exchange Will Support Lightning Before heading to the rural areas (I intended to test the wallets under suboptimal conditions)
column26: I set up the wallets and opened a Lightning payments channel in Harare as I anticipated low internet signal challenges. Based on my year-long experience in Zimbabwe
column27: I‚Äôve learned that even with decent internet speed
column28: the upload and download of files as small as 2 MB can be problematic. I used the internet at a friend‚Äôs house to use the fastest internet provider in Harare called Liquid
column29: which is also the most expensive with a monthly cost of $300 for unlimited usage. My speed test results for download were 92.7 Mbps and upload 14.6 Mbps. Even with that fast internet it took me some time to install the apps
column30: secure the private keys and open a Lightning channel to be a part of the network. To ensure consistency
column31: I followed a test protocol for each wallet. On Dec. 26 and 27
column32: I installed the wallets and sent 100
column33: 000 sats (~$42 at current prices) to open a Lightning channel. A channel on the Lightning Network needs two transactions on the Bitcoin blockchain to be set up. That way the channel is constantly connected to the blockchain
column34: which is why the bitcoin on the Bitcoin blockchain and bitcoin on the Lightning network are the same. There is no difference in the value
column35: it‚Äôs the same unit
column36: not another token or asset. There are several ways to open a channel: sending on-chain bitcoin
column37: transferring Lightning directly from another wallet or through a swap from Liquid or some wallets are offering buying inbound liquidity. I tried them all to send the first bitcoin to the wallets
column38: affecting set-up speed and fees I had to pay. See also: Bitcoin Could See Growth in Layer-2 Ecosystem
column39: Drawing on Ethereum's Experience I used a Lightning payment to open a channel on all wallets
column40: except for Blixt
column41: as I only found the on-chain option there (except for liquidity providers). Seemingly
column42: Blixt is opening the channel with a second on-chain transaction while the other wallets conceal that second transaction somehow
column43: because the channel opened immediately after the first transaction confirmation. Not with Blixt: I sent the first transaction and the confirmation took some hours
column44: it was evening already
column45: so I had to leave the friend's house. As soon as it was confirmed
column46: Blixt carried out the second on-chain transaction
column47: which took again several hours because the mempool was full. When the second transaction was confirmed I was back in the house where I'm living
column48: with internet speed only around 3 Mbps download
column49: 0.26 upload and a Ping over 300ms. Blixt wasn't able to open the channel in these circumstances. I needed to go back to my friend's house to finish the channel opening. It's hard to say how other wallets would have performed under these conditions. For the channel openings on Green and Zeus
column50: I used Liquid
column51: swapped via Boltz.exchange to Lightning
column52: due to high transaction fees at the time. Opening a channel from Liquid is far more economical in that situation. Liquid is a sidechain of Bitcoin
column53: its unit is called L-BTC. Learn the differences between Bitcoin
column54: Lightning
column55: Liquid
column56: and E-Cash in this non-technical explainer. One BTC is pegged to one L-BTC. This means if you peg-in 0.1 BTC to Liquid
column57: the resulting 0.1 L-BTC are of the same value as BTC. Compared to self-custodial Lightning there is more trust involved in using Liquid
column58: because you have to go through intermediaries for the peg-in and peg-out and trust a federation of 15 companies
column59: who are the signers for Liquid transactions
column60: whereas on Bitcoin and Lightning you don‚Äòt have to trust any intermediaries. The upside of the Liquid blockchain is that the transaction speed
column61: privacy are higher and currently the fees are lower than on the Bitcoin blockchain. I compared all network fees
column62: transaction
column63: and service fees that applied with the different methods of opening a channel. The cost of the incoming transaction to open the channel was the highest with Blixt as I used bitcoin on-chain at a time when the average fee rate was 110 sat/vByte ($0.000054). Channel opening was the cheapest when using Lightning directly from another LN wallet. The route using Liquid and Boltz was a little bit more expensive than using Lightning. The available balance after opening the channel varied significantly. Zeus had the lowest balance of 52
column64: 500 sats
column65: while Green had the highest at 97
column66: 500 sats. This difference was surprising
column67: especially since I used Liquid for both. Green was the clear winner with a cost of 3.5%
column68: whereas Zeus was by far the most expensive wallet with 48.5% of the funds spent in opening the channel. Mutiny offered the biggest channel capacity and the highest receivable amount with 100
column69: 000 sats
column70: while at the same time it was the second most expensive. However
column71: a drawback of Green was its limited incoming capacity of only 4
column72: 133 sats. After the initial set-up
column73: I set out to do the payment test on Jan. 1
column74: 2024. I strolled through the scorching heat
column75: making my way up to the kopje
column76: navigating through rocks
column77: grass
column78: bushes and trees 30 km out of the capitaI Harare. My friends were captivated by the beautiful flowers that bloom as soon as the rainy season begins. My focus
column79: however
column80: was on finding a decent internet signal for my two phones. Having prepared the test back in Harare
column81: I was eager to carry it out in this setting. After 30 minutes of searching
column82: I realized that the network coverage was inconsistent
column83: regardless of whether I used NetOne or Econet. I was able to send WhatsApp messages
column84: but as soon as I wanted to download an image with 0.5 MB
column85: I had to wait or turn airplane mode on and off to be back in the game. Finally
column86: I settled on a shaded spot with a stable NetOne signal to set up a hotspot for my other devices. I prepared my devices ‚Äì my Google Pixel 4
column87: iPhone 13 Pro and my iPad Air (3rd generation). The iPad was included because I already had Phoenix wallets on my other two devices
column88: and for this test
column89: I wanted to start with a fresh installation. Now seated on some rocks
column90: surrounded by trees and bushes
column91: as I fend off large ants attempting to crawl up under my trousers I found 4.21 Mbps download and 0.36 Mbps upload. Glad that I set up the apps already a few days earlier. See also: Bitcoin and Stablecoins Will Bring Crypto Mass Adoption to Africa My speed test results showed a ping of 90 and a download speed of 4.6 Mbps and an upload speed 0.5 Mbps. When I started testing the wallets
column92: the Phoenix wallet opened immediately. The Green wallet took 13 seconds to open and the Mutiny wallet needed 18 seconds. However
column93: Zeus didn't open at all
column94: even after a 150-second wait. Similarly
column95: Blixt opened but failed to sync the channels and wallet
column96: so I couldn't use it. As expected
column97: the custodial Wallet of Satoshi opened immediately. My first test was to send 50
column98: 000 sats from the different wallets to my Phoenix wallet on my iPhone. So
column99: the Phoenix wallet on the iPhone was on the receiving end. Unfortunately
column100: I could not send from Blixt because
column101: as I said before
column102: it did not sync at all. Zeus was also unusable since it wouldn't even start up. When I attempted a payment with Zeus
column103: it failed after a five minute wait. The Green wallet's payment attempt was unsuccessful too
column104: displaying an error message after I waited for two and a half minutes. With the Mutiny wallet
column105: I almost wanted to stop but after 50 seconds
column106: I was able to send the payment successfully. The Phoenix wallet was the quickest
column107: completing the transfer in just three seconds. And interestingly
column108: the custodial Wallet of Satoshi was slower than Phoenix
column109: taking nine seconds for the payment to go through. I didn't anticipate this result
column110: but I found it amusing. The next test focused on receiving 30
column111: 000 sats from the Phoenix wallet on my iPhone
column112: which had previously served as the receiving wallet. The results were somewhat similar to the previous test. The time until the payment was sent from Phoenix was three seconds and it showed up in Mutiny
column113: Phoenix and the Wallet of Satoshi immediately. Blixt did not work. With Green
column114: the payment failed after I waited for 35 seconds. Similarly
column115: Zeus also failed to receive the payment after I waited for one and half minutes. For this test
column116: I sent 20
column117: 000 sats to a Lightning address
column118: using the Wallet of Satoshi as the recipient since I had access to its Lightning address. The results were somewhat consistent with previous tests but with a notable exception. Surprisingly
column119: the Green wallet managed to send to a Lightning address this time
column120: completing the payment in 40 seconds. This was unexpected given its previous failures in other tests. Blixt and Zeus didn't work. Mutiny
column121: Phoenix and Wallet of Satoshi
column123: successfully completed the payments to a Lightning address. I wanted to test whether I could exchange 20
column124: 000 sats for Liquid in these conditions
column125: just to be confident in recommending it to my followers. For the Lightning to Liquid swap I was using the Boltz.exchange website
column126: with the Green wallet set as the recipient. I didn't attempt the swap with Blixt
column127: Green and Zeus since their earlier payment attempts had failed. Surprisingly Mutiny failed in this swap; the payment did not go through even after I waited for two minutes. Both Phoenix and the Wallet of Satoshi successfully completed the swap from Lightning to Liquid Bitcoin. Also here the custodial Wallet of Satoshi was slower compared to the self-custodial Phoenix wallet. The differences in fees for the payments were marginal
column129: which is negligible. The costs for sending and receiving were roughly the same across different wallets. However
column130: the costs associated with opening a channel varied significantly. Notably
column131: the Green wallet was the cheapest option
column132: requiring only 3% of the transferred amount as fees. On the other hand
column133: Zeus was the most expensive in these terms. In terms of payment reliability
column134: Phoenix and the Wallet of Satoshi stood out as the most dependable. This isn't surprising for the Wallet of Satoshi
column135: given its custodial nature. Following closely was Mutiny
column136: which successfully completed three out of four payment attempts. Green
column138: managed only one successful payment out of four. Phoenix showed remarkable reliability
column139: successfully processing all four payments. I even managed to send 11 sats from my Phoenix wallet to my Alby Lightning address under very challenging conditions with a download rate of only 0.15 Mbps
column141: and a ping of 185. Phoenix stands out as the clear winner in terms of payment speed. It was even faster than the custodial Wallet of Satoshi. Green and Mutiny also show satisfactory performance
column142: provided they functioned correctly. I evaluated the wallets' features
column143: focusing on their user-friendliness and security aspects. How easy is it to do a backup? Is the wallet open source? How well are the wallet users guided to ensure highest security standards are applied without their actions compromising them? I focused on the backup process
column145: because this results in acceptable security and randomness for the private keys and it's easier to store 12 words than 24. Green and Phoenix use 12-word seeds
column147: Mutiny and Zeus opt for 24-word seeds. A key aspect of product design is encouraging users to adopt high-security measures seamlessly. Being forced to write down the backup while opening the wallet is one of these good design features. I call it ‚Äúforced backup‚Äù and only Green offers it. All the other wallets show a call to action only. Conversely
column148: permitting the seed phrase to be copied to the device's clipboard for convenience may compromise the security of the funds. Uninformed users and newbies might copy it
column149: send their seed per email to themselves
column150: store it as a screenshot or in a Word document. I have seen it all. Convenience is the enemy of security. While it's true that users should only store small amounts in a Lightning wallet
column151: it's also a fact that users will apply the same unsafe behavior to an on-chain wallet
column152: because why not? Blixt allows copying the seed. Mutiny and Zeus too
column153: but they at least warn their users. Green and Zeus are doing it the right way and prevent copying the seed
column154: aligning with best security practices. I think cloud backups on the user side are not desirable. They can be a double-edged sword
column155: offering convenience but also presenting potential security risks and accessibility issues. Many people in African countries don't have a Google Drive or iCloud account to secure their channels. For added security
column156: I prefer to use a PIN
column158: or pattern lock to secure a Bitcoin wallet. Otherwise
column159: for example in case a security officer at an airport or a thief wants me to open my wallet
column160: I can be forced to use my fingerprint or my Face ID. Blixt
column162: Green and Zeus offer password or PIN-based security. Phoenix provided biometric options such as face ID or fingerprint recognition only
column163: but I hope they consider making changes to this feature. See also: Gridless Uses Bitcoin Mining to Power Rural Africa A significant feature I value is whether the wallets offer a separate on-chain Bitcoin wallet. This is a great feature as users only need to install one app for Bitcoin and Lightning. Blixt
column165: Green and Zeus provide a separate on-chain Bitcoin wallet. Phoenix does not. While it allows for swapping in and out
column166: the functionality is integrated and not separated as a distinct Bitcoin wallet. Coin control is going to be more and more important as transaction fees are rising. We need Bitcoin mobile wallets allowing us to do coin control and choose different UTXOs for a transaction. Sadly
column167: none of the tested wallets allows that. This limitation impacts users' ability to manage transaction costs effectively. While Green does offer coin control
column168: it's only available in their desktop version
column169: not on mobile. A Lightning address
column170: similar in format to an email address
column171: is a convenient feature that allows you to receive Lightning payments asynchronously without requiring the wallet to be actively open. Blixt offers a LN address in their experimental feature called "Lightning Box." Zeus is using hodl invoices
column172: a solution that has been criticized by a few developers because of the complexity and the fact that holding invoices could affect the performance of the Lightning Network overall. The other self-custody wallets do not offer Lightning addresses. Given this
column173: it might be a better option to use custodial services like getalby.com or the Wallet of Satoshi for a Lightning address and to send the sats to a Bitcoin
column174: Lightning or Liquid self-custody wallet from time to time. All the wallets allow payments to Lightning addresses. Only Phoenix offers auto channels at the moment. This means Phoenix is more convenient than other wallets
column175: because you only have to set up one channel. The channel then dynamically adjusts its size if you send more funds to it than its liquidity allows. To keep your channel size consistent
column176: you should not swap out to on-chain bitcoin as it reduces the size of the channel. In terms of fee settings
column177: all wallets except Mutiny allow you to define the maximum Lightning fee you're willing to pay. This gives users some control over their payment costs. Regarding channel management
column178: all wallets allow you to force close the channels. Additionally
column180: Zeus and Phoenix allow you to purchase inbound liquidity. After returning to town I tested the payments that failed a second time. I realized that Green‚Äôs experimental mode is really very experimental
column181: because I could not send a single Lightning payment with Green and other people reported the same in the Blockstream Telegram group. Blixt was still not able to sync to the top of the blockchain and after five minutes of waiting I stopped the process. Zeus was able to sync and started the node
column182: but then LND was taking a long time to get Zeus ‚Äúready to make payments‚Äù and after three minutes of waiting I closed the app. From my educator's perspective
column183: my top choices are the Phoenix and Mutiny wallet. Everything works with Phoenix
column184: you don‚Äôt need to worry about channel management and payments are even faster than with the custodial Wallet of Satoshi. The fees for payments in Phoenix might be off-putting
column185: from that perspective one might look into Mutiny as it is convincing due to its user-friendliness
column186: making it ideal for beginners. Mutiny‚Äôs channel opening was more expensive though and it doesn‚Äôt offer auto channels. Part of their business model is the optional Mutiny+ subscription for 16
column187: 000 sats per month. Green would be a strong recommendation
column188: particularly for those who value additional options like Liquid and on-chain transactions in a single wallet with one seed. As long as their Lightning payments aren‚Äôt working
column189: it‚Äôs a no-go obviously. Blixt and Zeus are more suited for advanced users due to their range of options
column190: but they did not work in my tests. To choose the optimal wallet
column191: it‚Äôs important to ask yourself what are the main goals and the features you‚Äôll need. I've developed an online learning program that could help guide you in that endeavor. In summary
column192: the evaluation of self-custodial Lightning wallets in rural Zimbabwe in 2024 revealed important insights. Wallets like Phoenix
column195: Zeus and Blixt were tested for their performance
column196: reliability and user-friendliness. Opening channels with these wallets varied in cost and balance. Phoenix and the Wallet of Satoshi exhibited high reliability and speed
column197: with Phoenix performing better than the custodial Wallet of Satoshi. From an educational standpoint
column199: emphasizing user-friendliness and security. Green and Phoenix offered user-friendly 12-word seed phrases
column201: Mutiny and Zeus provided 24-word seeds. Green's "forced backup" was a notable security feature. Cloud backups raised concerns about user data security
column202: as some wallets offered this option. App lock preferences and the availability of separate on-chain Bitcoin wallets were also considered. Phoenix topped the rankings for its overall performance and reliability
column203: followed by Mutiny for its user-friendliness. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column1: 142::https://blockworks.co/news/algorand-fork-voi-blockchain::Blockworks::article::Algorand fork Voi tries a blockchain reboot::The self-declared ‚Äúcommunity-powered blockchain‚Äù testing a new network based on Algrorand tech.::Exclusive: The self-declared ‚Äúcommunity-powered blockchain‚Äù testing a new network based on Algrorand tech Maurice NORBERT/Shutterstock
column2: modified by Blockworks Veteran members of the Algorand proof-of-stake blockchain ecosystem have banded together to launch a new iteration of the open-source code
column3: called Voi
column4: which is currently in testnet. Leading the new project is Chris Swenor
column5: co-founder of both Reach
column6: a blockchain development platform and the Algorand decentralized exchange (DEX) HumbleSwap. Work on Voi began in 2022
column7: with a premise that the blockchain should better align incentives with its community of developers and users
column8: and motivated by Swenor‚Äôs frustration with perceived shortcomings within the crypto industry. ‚ÄúI looked around and I was so frustrated that I saw that [venture capitalists] and the early builders owned over 90% of all tokens
column9: and the people that are actually still there during the bear market really didn‚Äôt own the chain
column10: but they‚Äôre still there pouring their heart into it
column11: ‚Äù Swenor told Blockworks. Voi is only forking the Algorand code
column12: but not the chain‚Äôs state. So
column13: unlike the failed EthPoW fork of Ethereum
column14: for instance
column15: Voi will have its own crypto token
column16: but one with no connection to ownership of ALGO. In software development
column17: a repository fork is essentially a copy of a repository that allows you to freely experiment with changes without affecting the original project. That‚Äôs what‚Äôs happening here
column18: in contrast to an Algorand blockchain fork
column19: which is not possible. Algorand has struggled to attract users in recent years. Its seven-day dex volume
column20: for example
column21: is currently less than $10 million
column22: according to DeFi Llama
column23: placing it 38th by that metric. Read more: Closure of largest DeFi destination underscores Algorand‚Äôs struggles Swenor‚Äôs critique is not specifically of Algorand or its development stewards Algorand Technologies and the Algorand Foundation
column24: with which he said he maintains good relations. Blockworks reached out to both Algorand entities to learn more. As a long time developer within the Algorand tech stack
column25: Swenor said it was natural to remain focused on the Algorand consensus engine. ‚ÄúThe thing that was very clear is that the Algorand tech is literally the best tech that we‚Äôve ever worked with
column26: as far as speed and what it can deliver
column27: ‚Äù he said. One of the chief differences is that Voi‚Äôs developers have earmarked 75% of its entire market cap for ‚Äúecosystem growth.‚Äù That includes node runners
column28: and the testnet has attracted nearly 500 nodes according to its explorer
column29: though it‚Äôs not apparent how many of those are independently operated. ‚ÄúThis means that a very small percentage of the overall network [token] is earmarked for operations and the core team
column30: ‚Äù Swenor said. Voi intends to concentrate on a smaller vertical of applications as part of its go-to-market strategy
column31: emphasizing ‚Äúmembership infrastructure
column32: ‚Äù in contrast to Algorand‚Äôs institutional focus. But Swenor also expects to contribute to Algorand development by bringing in developers
column33: and improving tooling such as wallet and node software. The new network counts original Algorand investor Arrington Capital among its seed investors along with Sonic Boom Ventures
column34: founded by former Algorand
column35: Inc. CEO Steven Kokinos
column36: who sees it as complementary to Algorand. ‚ÄúI think what is exciting about Voi in particular is that they‚Äôve done a lot of work to be able to connect Voi back to the Algorand mainnet and be able to exchange assets using tech like state proofs that was built into Algorand for that express purpose
column37: ‚Äù Kokinos told Blockworks. The remaining Algorand team was initially skeptical of Voi
column38: Swenor said
column39: but that changed over time. They‚Äôre seeing now that this is actually beneficial for Algorand as a whole‚Ä¶because we‚Äôre kind of at different missions and we‚Äôre going after different things
column40: I don‚Äôt see them seeing it as a threat by any means
column41: ‚Äù he said. Updated Dec. 18

column1: 145::https://theconversation.com/how-blockchain-technology-is-about-to-transform-sharemarket-trading-53807::The Conversation::article::How blockchain technology is about to transform sharemarket trading::Blockchain technology has the potential to make share trading faster
column2: more efficient and more transparent.::Recently the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) bought a $15 million stake in Digital Asset Holdings
column3: a developer of blockchain technology. One of the main reasons is to upgrade its share registry system by using blockchain or distributed ledger technology. And it‚Äôs been reported that JP Morgan Chase is also partnering with Digital Asset Holdings to trial the technology. Put simply
column4: blockchain technology is a method of recording and confirming transactions where instead of a centralised platform
column5: participants each hold a complete record of transactions through peer to peer verification of transactions. This means there is no central recording system
column6: rather each participant keeps a record of all transactions ever made. This is the same system which allows Bitcoin to operate with no central body. Instead of the ASX clearing house settling trades
column7: trades will be settled by participants confirming transactions through the peer to peer network. The network (likely made up of brokers) will record the buyer and selling participants
column8: the number of shares traded
column9: price of shares
column10: time of exchange and the exchange of funds. The ASX will still provide a centralised electronic exchange for participants to place orders
column11: only the settlement or back office function will be sourced to the network. Blockchain has great potential to cut inefficiencies in the share settlement function. As trades are settled by peer confirmation
column12: there is no need for a clearing house
column13: auditors to verify trades and custodians to ensure a fund has the shares they say they hold. Essentially this is cutting out the middleman in the back office which means less costs in record keeping and in turn less costs to trading on the ASX. Given the high costs in getting a third party to audit
column14: record keep and/or verify trades these costs are substantial. The peer confirmation of trades also means settlement can be almost instantaneous. Compare this to the current settlement period of three working days (‚ÄòT+3‚Äô) as the ASX needs to make sure the participants have the money and shares on hand to exchange. This would make shares a far more liquid investment ‚Äì almost as good as having cash on hand. Higher liquidity means more investment into ASX shares. As all participants have the full record of transactions and therefore holdings of investors there is complete transparency in the equity market. This makes it almost impossible to falsify transactions or to alter prior transactions. If a false trade occurs
column15: participants will find inconsistencies in their full ledger and reject the trade. For example an investor would be unable to sell stock that they did not own as all participants would know exactly how much stock the investor owns now. First
column16: implementing a clearing system using blockchain will introduce a new type of fee. In the Bitcoin blockchain
column17: miners process Bitcoin transactions by solving optimisation problems and get rewarded by newly created Bitcoins and settlement fees offered by Bitcoin users who wish to have their transactions processed. Miners prioritise the order of transactions to be cleared based on the fees offered and the difficulty of the problems to record the transaction in a block. This is what allows a blockchain to have no centralised clearing house. If the ASX blockchain requires investors to include transaction fees in order for their transactions to be cleared
column18: then the ASX is transferring the cost of maintaining the back office to the investors. If this is to happen
column19: investors will have to compete against each other to have their transactions cleared faster than those of others. Alternatively
column20: if the new system doesn‚Äôt allow such fees and relies on brokers or other entities to clear the transactions
column21: then the ASX is again transferring the cost of maintaining back office to those entities. The second concern is increased transparency. Under the proposed trading system
column22: most of positions of the market participants could be exposed to the public as the trading ID can be identified. This could disadvantage many investors such as super
column23: managed and hedge funds. For example
column24: a super fund typically sells a large position on a gradual basis for a prolonged time period. In this process
column25: it is critical not to be noticed by other traders who may take advantage of such large-scale sales. With complete transparency such as in blockchain
column26: such a sell-off could not be applied effectively. Potentially this may make investors leave the ASX and seek more opaque venues to trade such as dark pools. Clearly a direct adoption of blockchain from Bitcoin technology would not be viable for the ASX. If the ASX is able to adopt blockchain technology and address privacy
column27: security and trade transparency concerns then this would yield great cost savings to investors.::2016-02-03T19:05:23Z::Bitcoin

column1: 146::https://www.coindesk.com/learn/what-are-crypto-otc-desks-and-how-do-they-work/::CoinDesk::article::What Are Crypto OTC Desks And How Do They Work?::Cryptocurrency OTC desks play an essential role in facilitating large cryptocurrency trades in the global crypto markets. What Are Crypto OTC Desks? How Do Cryptocurrency OTC Desks Work? Why Are OTC Desks Important in Crypto? Pros and Cons of Using OTC Desks in Crypto The Bottom Line::Crypto OTC desks play an important role in facilitating large cryptocurrency purchases and sales. Read on to learn what crypto OTC desks are
column2: how they work
column3: and why they play an essential role in the global crypto markets. This is partner content sourced from Laura Shin‚Äôs Unchained and published by CoinDesk. Over-the-counter (OTC) trading desks facilitate trading between two parties without revealing information about the trade to the public via an exchange orderbook or otherwise. The OTC desk acts as a matchmaker enabling high-volume transactions between buyers and sellers. During an OTC trade
column4: the two parties agree on a purchase price before they can complete the transaction. The trades can be crypto-to-crypto or fiat-to-crypto. OTC desks differ from traditional exchanges in terms of transaction transparency. A crypto exchange like Kraken or Binance acts as an intermediary between buyers and sellers. Transactions are executed via an orderbook for everyone to see. Conversely
column5: crypto OTC trading is relatively opaque since no one beyond the transacting parties is aware of the price and volume of assets being traded. Moreover
column6: OTC trades are typically insulated from wider market fluctuations that occur on exchanges. There are two types of OTC desks: principal and agency. Principal desks assume the risk to the buyer by using their funds to purchase whatever asset the buyer requires. For instance
column7: a bitcoin whale looking to make a large bitcoin purchase will request a quote from the OTC desk
column8: and they will respond with a price based on prevailing market conditions. The buyer can choose to accept the offer or make a reasonable counter. Should the buyer accept the proposed price
column9: the OTC desk is responsible for sourcing and delivering the BTC to the buyer as per the legal contract signed beforehand. Agency desks
column10: on the other hand
column11: don‚Äôt assume the market risk since they don‚Äôt put up their own money for transactions. Instead
column12: they act as an intermediary to broker a deal on behalf of the buyer. They will charge a brokerage fee for this service. Crypto OTC desks exist to enable large investors
column13: such as early adopters
column14: high-net-worth individuals
column15: and institutional investors
column16: to buy and sell large amounts of cryptocurrencies without alerting the market about their intention or transaction. If you try to buy 1
column17: 000 BTC on a regular crypto exchange
column18: you will run into several problems. A key challenge is that the chances of finding someone selling that amount at any given time on a single exchange are slim. You will have to opt to spread the purchases across several sellers. The problem that arises is you may end up making some of the purchases at a significantly higher price. Of course
column19: you may be able to avoid this altogether and spread the purchase across several exchanges
column20: but this will be time-consuming and costly. Moreover
column21: you will show the entire market that you are a large buyer or seller
column22: which will most likely lead to a worse execution price. Crypto OTC desks remove the uncertainty and risk for investors looking to buy or sell large volumes of crypto. Here are some of the benefits and challenges of using crypto OTC desks. Large crypto investors looking to buy and sell substantial volumes of cryptocurrency prefer the crypto OTC market over trading on crypto exchanges. Most whales keep their transactions off exchange order books to avoid the market moving against them when they want to transact. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column2: explained::The reduced demand for the Bitcoin network post-halving has led to a significant drop in its fees. ::The reduced demand for the Bitcoin network post-halving has led to a significant drop in its fees.  Bitcoin [BTC] network fees have fallen to a record low as the Layer 1 (L1) transaction volume continues to decline. In a post on X (formerly Twitter)
column3: on-chain data provider IntoTheBlock noted that transaction fees on the Bitcoin network plunged to their lowest level in three months this week. Recording a weekly transaction fee totaling $12 million
column4: the network saw a 45% decline from the previous week.  This week‚Äôs decline in the Bitcoin network‚Äôs fee is due to the decrease in its transaction volume. According to Santiment‚Äôs data
column5: the aggregate amount of BTC across all transactions completed on the network fell steadily during the week. Between the 11th and the 17th of May
column6: Bitcoin‚Äôs transaction volume plummeted by 5%. Source: Santiment The average fee paid per transaction dropped as the network saw a decline in demand. According to Messari
column7: this decreased by 17% during the period under review. At press time
column8: the average cost of executing a transaction on the Bitcoin network was $2.56. The miners on Bitcoin‚Äôs network are the primary victims of its low network fees. After the percentage of miner revenue derived from transaction fees rallied to a year-to-date high of 75% on the 20th of April
column9: post-halving event
column10: it has since declined significantly. Source: Messari As of this writing
column11: only 4% of miner revenue is derived from the fees paid by Bitcoin‚Äôs users. This marked a 95% decline from the YTD high
column12: per Messari‚Äôs data. Low revenue and BTC‚Äôs recent price troubles have forced some miners to sell their holdings. AMBCrypto assessed Bitcoin‚Äôs Miner Supply Ratio and found that it has fallen by 0.21% since the halving event. This metric measures miners‚Äô BTC holdings relative to the coin‚Äôs total supply. When it declines this way
column13: miners are selling a larger portion of their mined coins. This is often due to capitulation from high operational costs
column14: the desire to take profit
column15: or a lack of confidence in the coin‚Äôs price. Is your portfolio green? Check out the BTC Profit Calculator BTC sell-offs among miners on its network have led to a depletion of the coin‚Äôs Miner Reserve. This measures the amount of coins held in miners‚Äô wallets within a specified period. Source: CryptoQuant According to CryptoQuant‚Äôs data
column16: BTC‚Äôs Miner Reserve
column17: at 1.81 million at press time
column18: has dropped by 1% since the 25th of April.   Disclaimer: AMBCrypto's content is meant to be informational in nature and should not be interpreted as investment advice. Trading

column6: please proceed to our verification methodology page The Ethereum blockchain is arguably the biggest developer-centric ecosystem dealing with decentralized applications (DApps) and decentralized finance (DeFi). Yet
column7: developers looking to Ethereum to build usable web3 resources do not simply start building on the mainnet. Instead
column8: they rely first on testnets. This guide discusses one popular testnet
column9: Rinkeby. Read on to learn about this vital Ethereum test network. Testnets are used to support test transactions. Developers user testnets to try out implementations that use frameworks such as Truffle and the Solidity programming language. This allows DApps to be tested and improved without developers encountering the financial burden and risks associated with the main Ethereum blockchain. Rinkeby is one such testnet. Even though the Rinkeby testnet and Rinkeby faucet were deprecated as of 2024
column10: assessing their role in facilitating robust DApp development can help both new and advanced developers better understand Ethereum test networks. The Rinkeby testnet for Ethereum DApp testing came into existence in 2017. It focused specifically on smart contract testing and quickly became vital to the Ethereum development environment. Rinkeby operated as a proof-of-authority (PoA) testnet at a time when Ethereum itself was proof-of-work (PoW)
column11: as was Ropsten

column15: the PoA consensus ensured the testnet became one of the best for developers looking to continuously test setups and integrations. Did you know? Controlled Node Validation

column17: refers to a system where only a limited number of entities (trusted) are allowed to confirm and validate transactions. Rinkeby was one of the more popular Ethereum test networks used to quickly test smart contracts and DApps. The Rinkeby testnet was a controlled sandbox-like environment replicating the Ethereum blockchain environment. Developers could deploy applications on this testnet before introducing them to the mainnet. As for the testnet gas fees

column15: permissioned blockchains. To date

column17: deployed on the privacy-enabled blockchain Canton. Goldman Sachs
column18: BNY Mellon
column19: Cboe Global Markets and other firms recently wrapped up a series of pilots on the same network. HSBC has used its platform

column21: to tokenize gold for everyday investors in Hong Kong. And BlackRock has used the private Tokenized Collateral Network on JPMorgan‚Äôs Ethereum-based Onyx to tokenize shares in one of its money market funds. Read more from our opinion section: Fintech has hit a wall. Blockchain will break through it. Bitcoin proved that a multi-billion dollar market can essentially come out of thin air. The industry believed that everything could be tokenized and traded via blockchain and enjoy increased liquidity. However
column22: the glittering promise of liquidity for real-world assets has (so far) proven a mirage. The initial token boom of 2018 hyped trillions of dollars in tokenized assets on public networks. Almost seven years later
column23: there are only a few billions of dollars in total assets under management on public networks ‚Äî a tiny piece of what‚Äôs theoretically possible. Meanwhile
column24: private networks are moving billions of dollars in daily transactions. The crypto industry loves to float the $16 trillion in illiquid assets Boston Consulting Group projects to be tokenized by 2030. Even the more conservative estimate ‚Äî McKinsey & Company‚Äôs $5 trillion in tokenized real-world assets ‚Äî is huge. If we look at the trends and what‚Äôs happening
column25: though
column26: it‚Äôs clear that a majority of these assets will first be tokenized on private networks. Unlike crypto ‚Äî which is an entirely new asset class existing within open ecosystems ‚Äî real-world assets inherit the legacy of traditional finance. This legacy favors control over assets and customers
column27: closed ecosystems and compatibility with traditional markets ‚Äî a direct contrast with the ethos of public
column28: permissionless networks. This explains why financial institutions favor private networks. Private networks operate closer to the existing financial infrastructure and can facilitate easier compliance. These networks are more capable of meeting business needs
column29: as they provide flexibility in governance and customization
column30: like modifications to the blockchain‚Äôs consensus protocol
column31: transaction validation rules and permissions. These networks can also handle higher transaction volumes
column32: which is essential for scalability. There‚Äôs also the issue of regulation. It‚Äôs only in the past couple of years that regulators have begun to pass and enact comprehensive frameworks guiding involvement in crypto assets. As a result
column33: public blockchain technology has felt untouchable until recently to these institutions
column34: for whom compliance is paramount. For securities
column35: there is at least some clarity. Tokenized securities are still securities and must operate within the existing regulatory framework. However
column36: some assets ‚Äî like real estate ‚Äî which are not necessarily securities off chain will be considered securities once tokenized. The industry is still figuring out what it would take for these assets to meet existing requirements. Today
column37: nobody doubts the benefits of blockchain technology. The issue for traditional finance is mostly one of integration and technology costs
column38: infrastructure compatibility and regulatory concerns. While public networks offer more transparency
column39: immutability and decentralization
column40: private networks are more practical and familiar for financial institutions. There are also a few technology issues to sort out. Let‚Äôs use BlackRock‚Äôs chosen Ethereum as an example. While Ethereum has made progress with initiatives like layer-2 solutions and the Merge to Ethereum 2.0
column41: the network faces challenges meeting the demand for speed
column42: privacy and compliance necessary for transactions involving regulated institutions. As the technology matures and regulatory frameworks evolve
column43: we can expect to see more tokenization migrating to public blockchains and a new wave of innovation. However
column44: at least for the near future

column1: 152::https://theconversation.com/are-nfts-really-dead-and-buried-all-signs-point-to-yes-214145::The Conversation::article::Are NFTs really dead and buried? All signs point to ‚Äòyes‚Äô::This is why no one is buying your cartoon ape.::Non-fungible tokens (NFTs) are in dire straits. With the market in a severe downturn
column2: it‚Äôs safe to assume the NFT bubble has well and truly burst. It was never clear why these digital collectables traded for such large amounts of money. Now they mostly do not. What‚Äôs behind their turn of fate? And is there any hope for their future? Non-fungible tokens are a blockchain-based means to claim unique ‚Äúownership‚Äù of digital assets. ‚ÄúNon-fungible‚Äù means unique
column3: as opposed to a ‚Äúfungible‚Äù item such as a five-dollar bill
column4: which is the same as every other five-dollar bill. But just because an item is unique that doesn‚Äôt make it valuable. Digital assets are easily copied
column5: so an NFT is essentially a receipt showing you have paid for something that other people can get for free. This is a pretty dubious basis for value. The two most traded sets of NFTs are the Bored Apes collection created in April 2021 and the CryptoPunks collection launched in June 2017. Both sets consist of 10
column6: 000 similar-looking but unique figures
column7: distinguished by differing hairstyles
column8: hats
column9: skin colours and so forth. The Bored Ape character seems derivative of the drawings of Jamie Hewlett
column10: the artist who drew Tank Girl and Damon Albarn‚Äôs virtual band Gorillaz. The CryptoPunks are even less interesting. Although the first NFTs emerged around a decade ago
column11: the trend really started to take off in 2021. And for a time NFTs were very fashionable. Even the venerable auction house Sotheby‚Äôs
column12: founded in 1744
column13: jumped on the NFT bandwagon. Sotheby‚Äôs sold 101 Bored Ape NFTs for more than US$20 million in September 2021. They‚Äôre now facing a lawsuit from a disgruntled buyer. As with Bitcoin and similar speculative tokens
column14: the primary driver for buying NFTs was greed. Seeing the initial price rises
column15: people hoped they too could make huge profits. NFTs are essentially a superficially sophisticated form of gambling. Like Bitcoin
column16: they have no fundamental value. Read more: NFTs
column17: an overblown speculative bubble inflated by pop culture and crypto mania Generally
column18: one would only profit from buying an NFT by finding a ‚Äúgreater fool‚Äù willing to pay even more for it. So there was never a shortage of people ‚Äì including some quite famous ones ‚Äì talking them up and hoping to instil a fear of missing out. Eminem bought a Bored Ape that looked a bit like him. Rapper KSI boasted on Twitter about his Bored Ape rising in price. For a while there were large increases in the prices of many NFTs. But like all speculative bubbles
column19: it was likely to end in tears. Although it‚Äôs almost impossible to predict when a bubble for a speculative asset will burst
column20: we have seen this process play out before. Centuries ago there were the Dutch tulip
column21: South Sea and Mississippi bubbles. Around 1970
column22: there was a speculative bubble in the shares of nickel miner Poseidon. Then came the Beanie Baby and dotcom booms of the late 1990s ‚Äì and more recently
column23: meme stocks and Terra-Luna cryptocurrency. Punters now seem to be as bored with NFTs as the apes. Google searches for ‚ÄúNFT‚Äù ‚Äì which grew rapidly through 2021 ‚Äì have fallen away dramatically. Trading volumes have collapsed. Prices in the NFT market have also seen huge falls. The prices of Bored Ape NFTs are down about 90% from their peak. The CryptoPunks have done slightly better by losing only 80%. A recent report covering about 73
column24: 000 NFTs estimated 70
column25: 000 are now valued at zero. This leaves 23 million people holding a worthless ‚Äúasset‚Äù. One high-profile example is an NFT of the first tweet by then-Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey. Crypto entrepreneur Sina Estavi bought this NFT for US$2.9 million in March 2021. When he tried to sell it a year later the top bid was US$6
column26: 800. What drove the NFT collapse? As well as losing their novelty
column27: the market was hurt by the large falls in the price of Bitcoin and other cryptocurrency
column28: as well as the collapse of the FTX exchange and publicity given to scams. Beyond that
column29: the lifting of COVID lockdowns meant people who began trading NFTs now had other ways to pass their time. And higher interest rates from mid-2022 made most speculative assets seem less attractive. Collectively
column30: all of these factors made NFTs seem like a riskier proposition. Prominent people started jumping off the bandwagon. Some of KSI‚Äôs later tweets lament the losses he suffered from his gambles.  Last year
column31: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak announced
column32: when he was chancellor of the exchequer (their equivalent of treasurer)
column33: the Royal Mint would produce an NFT. The plan has now been abandoned. Some foolish people had even taken out loans using the ‚Äúvalue‚Äù of their NFTs as collateral. When the lenders wanted the money back
column34: they were in trouble: forced to sell their NFTs
column35: they got back much less than they‚Äôd paid. Fortunately
column36: there weren‚Äôt enough people like this to lead to a systemic problem in the financial sector. Read more: Damien Hirst's dotty 'currency' art makes as much sense as Bitcoin NFTs probably won‚Äôt completely disappear. Some subjects of past bubbles are still around. Tulips are still grown in the Netherlands. Poseidon shares
column37: which ran up from 80 cents in September 1969 to $280 in February 1970
column38: are still listed (and currently trading for 2 cents). But unless some actual use is found for them
column39: NFTs are likely to fade further from public discussion
column40: with their prices increasingly trending down (although the occasional blip up may give die-hard fans some hope). They will probably join the Dutch tulips and dotcoms in the history of speculative follies. Read more: Almost no one uses Bitcoin as currency
column41: new data proves. It's actually more like gambling::2023-10-01T19:16:08Z::Blockchain

column5: has reportedly been utilizing a new malware variant called ‚ÄúDurian‚Äù to launch targeted attacks on South Korean crypto firms. The incidence is highlighted in a recently published threat intelligence report from Kaspersky. According to Kaspersky‚Äôs research
column6: the malware is deployed specifically to break and exploit against security software used by South Korean crypto firms
column7: at least two of which have been identified. ‚ÄúBased on our telemetry

column12: ‚Äù the report stated. The Durian malware is an ‚Äúinitial-stage‚Äù installer. It introduces supplementary malware and establishes a persistence mechanism inside the device or instance that it attacks. Once executed
column13: the malware generates a stage loader and adds it to the exposed operating system for automatic execution. The malware‚Äôs installation is finalized with a culminating payload written over Golang
column14: an open-source programming language developed by Google. The final payload then enables the execution of remote commands that instruct the exploited device to download and exfiltrate files. The choice of language is also suspect due to Golang‚Äôs efficiency for networked machines and large codebases. Interestingly
column15: Kaspersky‚Äôs report also revealed that LazyLoad
column16: one of the tools deployed by Durian

column1: 158::https://theconversation.com/rise-of-cryptocurrencies-like-bitcoin-begs-question-what-is-money-46713::The Conversation::article::Rise of cryptocurrencies like bitcoin begs question: what is money?::Money used to be backed by something of real value such as gold or silver. Bitcoins and other digital currencies will sever that link forever.::When you begin to delve into the question of what money really is
column2: you must be prepared for some metaphysics. Money
column3: currencies and other such media of exchange differ markedly in their backgrounds and means of operation
column4: and have changed quite recently into forms that are barely understandable. For centuries
column5: minted coins not only represented the value and trust of banks
column6: their depositors and eventually nation-states
column7: but also were deemed valuable because they were made from precious metals like gold and silver. These metals are difficult to move around in large quantities
column8: and so banknotes were invented as early as the seventh century in China and brought to Europe in the 13th century. Unlike coins
column9: banknotes were not treated as valuable in themselves since they were simply printed on otherwise worthless paper. Rather
column10: they served as a form of promissory note or IOU that could be presented to the banks that issued them in exchange for their face value in precious metal
column11: coins or bullion. In the 20th century
column12: most central banks and governments stopped backing up their currencies with precious metals
column13: and yet banknotes maintain fluctuating values
column14: with some in high demand as media for exchange both domestically and internationally. Dollars and euros are highly regarded and preferred currencies for international commerce
column15: as well as for stocking private bank accounts. Now we have bitcoins and other digital currencies that exist entirely in blocks of zeros and ones and are even ‚Äúmined‚Äù by machines running algorithms. And earlier this month
column16: bitcoins and their ilk were officially deemed commodities by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission
column17: which will now regulate them. So as the greenbacks and quarters in our pockets slowly disappear
column18: replaced by strings of digits stored on our smartphones
column19: and money takes another step away from being tied to anything of value
column20: a philosophical question comes to mind: does money still exist? And if so
column21: what gives it its value? Money is a ‚Äúfungible‚Äù item
column22: which means that exchange of any one portion for a portion of equal value is not a ‚Äútaking‚Äù of property. That is
column23: you don‚Äôt own a particular US$100 bill. You own the value it represents. This is how banks have long worked
column24: since when you deposit your money
column25: you are not entitled to receive the same coins or bills back as you deposited. This is also how ‚Äúfractional reserve‚Äù banking began (in which banks do not keep all the curency on deposit ‚Äúwithin‚Äù the bank
column26: just some fraction of it) and was not regarded somehow as theft. People took their money to a bank
column27: they were given a note of deposit
column28: which entitled them to withdraw the same amount plus some interest
column29: but they were not entitled to the same coins or bills that they deposited. The money on deposit in a bank is not all physically in the bank (excepting that which is in safety deposit boxes) and has not been really since banking was invented. When you deposit a sum
column30: you no longer own the paper or other medium of exchange used for the deposit
column31: legally. What you own is a debt and obligation by the bank to return the equivalent amount of money with interest. John Searle has described things like money as ‚Äúsome special sort‚Äù of social objects. That is
column32: X (coins
column33: bills
column34: strings of digits) work as Y (money) in context C (an economy
column35: coffee shop
column36: bank
column37: etc). In the case of money
column38: anything can conceivably take on the Y role even without an X (think a barter economy). Where metals
column39: then bills and now bits in computer memory take the role of X
column40: money might well be a ‚Äúfree-standing‚Äù Y
column41: meaning it could exist without anything to represent it except the web of intentional states (the debts and obligations) that make more familiar forms of money function. It‚Äôs only physical manifestation might be a note in a ledger. Without precious metal standards backing national currencies
column42: and in the age of digital transactions
column43: money is decreasingly tied to banknotes
column44: just as its ties to metals have faded. Digital ledgers track exchanges and accounts
column45: with digital strings in computer memories representing the trust and value we once attached to more solid things like coins
column47: in more ephemeral digitally encoded
column48: instantly accessible forms attached to cellphones
column49: computers and chip cards. New types of cryptocurrencies (where cryptography protects its integrity) like bitcoin and others take the concept one step further
column50: distributing the banking to all its users
column51: tying the transactions and ledgers to no particular party but to all users at once. This is similar to mirrored bank servers
column52: but bitcoin is mirrored among all bitcoin owners. A bitcoin is as ownable as dollars are when they are deposited in a bank. Skipping the stage of physical
column53: fungible currencies
column54: bitcoins exist by virtue of their representations in a ledger in cyberspace. The information encoded in a massively distributed and constantly updated blockchain is incapable of the exclusivity required for owning objects in the traditional sense. But the same is true of the information that tracks most of the money in the world. Money in nearly every denomination exists and flows in a similar state
column55: represented by digital bits. Bitcoins nonetheless lack some of the institutional guarantees that other types of money has due to nations and their laws. Depositors to banks are protected in their debts by states
column56: generally
column57: and through contracts with their banks. State insurance and the contractual guarantee that a bank will pay back what has been put into them mean that there is some force behind our trust in the continued existence of a person‚Äôs wealth while digitally stored in a bank‚Äôs servers. The blockchain exists on many servers at once
column58: spread across the universe of bitcoin owners. Without government insurance or contractual guarantees
column59: only mutual trust maintains the value and integrity of the system. What bitcoin owners own is the debt
column60: just as those who own money in banks own debts that are recorded in bits. They do not own the bits that comprise the information representing that debt
column61: nor the information itself
column62: they own the social object ‚Äì the money ‚Äì that those bits represent. Bank ledgers exist. They are tangible
column63: even though digital
column64: and they record the debts owed among parties. While cyberspace is ephemeral
column65: it is still real and physically based. Digital bank ledgers now track money without the necessity for physical transfers of currencies. Bitcoins too exist as digital records of obligations
column66: physically encoded on servers of those who hold them
column67: propagated and distributed for transparency and security
column68: encrypted for privacy. Bitcoins are as real as money in banks. What‚Äôs most fascinating about these new digital cryptocurrencies is how much they reveal about the surreal nature of currencies and wealth in our digitized economy. If bitcoins are as real as any other money

column1: 164::https://theconversation.com/nabs-bitcoin-ban-a-symptom-of-the-digital-currency-threat-25490::The Conversation::article::NAB‚Äôs Bitcoin ban a symptom of the digital currency threat::Virtual currency Bitcoin is not a subject that ever draws neutral reactions. Against those who see the radical possibilities of a frictionless payment system designed for the internet
column2: there is a growing‚Ä¶::Virtual currency Bitcoin is not a subject that ever draws neutral reactions. Against those who see the radical possibilities of a frictionless payment system designed for the internet
column3: there is a growing resistance to the currencies that threaten existing business models and the perceived traceability of our current currency systems. Leading the resistance against digital currencies are the banks
column4: with the latest recruit to these ranks
column5: Australian bank NAB
column6: closing accounts of customers whose businesses are engaged in exchanging cryptocurrencies. An Australian trader operating through LocalBitcoins.com and an another Australian Bitcoin exchange CoinJar have received letters from NAB informing them that: NAB joins banks in China such as the Agricultural Bank of China
column7: that has moved to freeze the accounts of one of China‚Äôs larger Bitcoin exchanges
column8: BtcTrade. Likewise
column9: banks in Canada have already largely blocked accounts used for companies trading cryptocurrencies. It is easy to point to the recent failure of Bitcoin exchange Mt Gox and the subsequent law suits that have embroiled Japanese bank Mizhuo
column10: as a catalyst for NAB‚Äôs move. But if banks refused to service businesses after one or more of their kind went bust
column11: they would not be left with very many clients. The risk assessed was also not one based on the companies involved
column12: their operations or their clients
column13: it was simply a matter of the business they were in. While moves by banks to manage risk is something most customers would welcome
column14: the global financial crisis showed us banks‚Äô views of risk are highly selective and largely determined by the other part of this equation: the rewards. In terms of cryptocurrencies
column15: the rewards to banks at present are very low. This is especially the case for a currency that is designed to largely cut them out of the picture. Bitcoin and other digital currencies are designed to be exchanged directly between senders and receivers. This means that currently
column16: transaction costs and bank fees can be avoided
column17: so banks‚Äô enthusiasm for supporting this industry or promoting it would be tepid at best. The real risk to banks is perhaps then not that posed by customers using accounts to enable Bitcoin exchanges
column18: but the threat to their bottom line. NAB‚Äôs own senior currency analyst Emma Lawson has argued Bitcoin has many of the characteristics of regular currency
column19: and that its potential to become a successful payment system it contingent on people‚Äôs continued belief in it. Clearly something that banks aren‚Äôt yet willing to see happen. If banks are asked to justify their decisions purely on risk
column20: they are likely to point to Bitcoin‚Äôs association with criminal activities. The rhetoric here has recently stepped up with the European police chief claiming we‚Äôre just seeing the beginning of Bitcoin‚Äôs use by criminal organisations. Other than the clear use of Bitcoin as the payment system of illegal websites such as Silk Road
column21: the use of cryptocurrencies as a proportion of the total value of money involved in crime is probably tiny. The United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime estimates that in 2009 the total amount of money involved in global criminal activity was US$2.1 trillion. The total market capitilisation of all cryptocurrencies is currently less than US$10 billion. Cryptocurrencies may appear to be ideally suited to money laundering
column22: but the problem is they eventually have to be exchanged for real currency
column23: which immediately causes problems if you are trying to move large amounts of money. The second issue is the extremely volatile value of such currencies. There is a large risk that money with a certain value ends up being worth a lot less by the time it has been laundered and converted into a currency that can be actually put to some use. Of the U$2.1 trillion that is involved annually in global criminal activity
column24: most
column25: if not all
column26: will pass through banks at some point
column27: and not surprisingly
column28: will drive revenue for those banks. The idea then that digital currencies pose a larger theoretical threat seems somewhat absurd in comparison to the very real crime involving real currency. Governments around the world have moved to deal with the lack of regulations on Bitcoin by either banning the currency outright
column29: as in Thailand
column30: or practising ‚Äúmasterly inactivity‚Äù
column31: essentially delaying making any moves that might legitimise digital currencies and the industries that would then arise around them. In this regulatory vacuum
column32: banks have been able to protect themselves against the threat of the bankless payment system that digital currencies represent.::2014-04-11T01:03:11Z::Bitcoin

column1: 166::https://beincrypto.com/the-dangers-of-chatgpt-ai-no-one-is-talking-about/::BeInCrypto::article::Are We Ready for ChatGPT? The Dangers of AI No One Is Talking About::While ChatGPT may look like a harmless free tool
column2: this technology can potentially reshape our economy and society as we know it.::We use cookies to improve your experience.  While ChatGPT may look like a harmless and useful free tool
column3: this technology has the potential to reshape our economy and society as we know it drastically. That brings us to alarming problems ‚Äì and we might not be ready for them. ChatGPT
column4: a chatbot powered by artificial intelligence (AI)
column5: took the world by storm by the end of 2022. The chatbot promises to disrupt search as we know it. The free tool provides useful answers based on prompts the users give to it. And what‚Äôs making the internet go crazy about the AI chatbot system is that it doesn‚Äôt only give search engine tool-like answers. ChatGPT can create movie outlines
column6: write entire codes and solve coding problems
column7: write entire books
column8: songs
column9: poems
column10: scripts ‚Äì or whatever you can think of ‚Äì within minutes. This technology is impressive
column11: and it crossed over one million users in just five days after its launch. Despite its mind-blowing performance
column12: OpenAI‚Äôs tool has raised concerns among academics and experts from other areas. Dr. Bret Weinstein
column13: author and former professor of evolutionary biology
column14: said
column15: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not ready for ChatGPT.‚Äù Elon Musk
column16: was part of OpenAI‚Äôs early stages and one of the company‚Äôs co-founders. But later stepped down from the board. He spoke many times about the dangers of AI technology ‚Äì he said that unrestricted use and development pose a significant risk to the existence of humanity. ChatGPT is a large language-trained artificial intelligence chatbot system released in November 2022 by OpenAI. The capped-profit company developed ChatGPT for a ‚Äúsafe and beneficial‚Äù use of AI that can answer almost anything you can think of ‚Äì from rap songs
column17: art prompts to movie scripts and essays. As much as it seems like a creative entity that knows what‚Äôs saying
column18: it‚Äôs not. The AI chatbot scours information on the internet using a predictive model from a massive data center. Similar to what Google and most search engines do. Then
column19: it‚Äôs trained and exposed to tons of data that allows the AI to become very good at predicting the sequence of words up to the point that it can put together incredibly long explanations. For example
column20: you can ask encyclopedia questions like
column21: ‚ÄúExplain the three laws of Einstein.‚Äù Or more specific and in-depth questions like ‚ÄúWrite a 2
column22: 000-word essay on the intersection between religious ethics and the ethics of the Sermon on the Mount.‚Äù And
column23: I kid you not
column24: you‚Äôll have your text brilliantly written in seconds. In the same way
column25: it is all brilliant and impressive; it is alarming and concerning. An ‚ÄúEx Machina‚Äù type of dystopian future breaking bad is a possibility with the misuse of AI. Not only has the CEO of Tesla and SpaceX warned us
column26: but many experts have also sounded the alarm. Artificial intelligence has undoubtedly impacted our lives
column27: the economic system and society. If you think that AI is something new or that you‚Äôll only see it in futuristic sci-fi movies
column28: think twice. Many tech companies such as Netflix
column29: Uber
column30: Amazon and Tesla employ AI to enhance their operations and expand their business. For instance
column31: Netflix relies on AI technology for their algorithm to recommend new content for their users. Uber uses it in customer service
column32: to detect fraud
column33: to optimize drives route
column34: and so on
column35: just to name a few examples. However
column36: you can only go so far with such prominent technology without threatening human roles in many traditional occupations
column37: touching the threshold of what comes from a machine and humans. And
column38: perhaps more importantly
column39: threatening the risks of AI to humans. According to Wikipedia
column40: the ethics of artificial intelligence ‚Äúis the branch of the ethics of technology specific to artificially intelligent systems. It is sometimes divided into a concern with the moral behavior of humans as they design
column41: make
column42: use and treat artificially intelligent systems
column43: and a concern with the behavior of machines in machine ethics.‚Äù As AI technology spreads fast and becomes integral to most of our daily lives
column44: organizations are developing AI codes of ethics. The goal is to guide and develop the industry‚Äôs best practices to guide AI development with ‚Äúethics
column45: fairness and industry.‚Äù However
column46: as wonderful and moral as it seems on paper
column47: most of these guidelines and frameworks are difficult to apply. In addition
column48: they seem to be isolated principles situated in industries that generally lack ethical morals and mostly serve corporate agendas. Many experts and prominent voices argue that AI ethics are largely useless
column49: lacking meaning and coherence. The most common AI principles are beneficence
column50: autonomy
column51: justice
column52: applicability
column53: and non-maleficence. But
column54: as Luke Munn
column55: from Institute for Culture and Society
column56: at Western Sydney University explains
column57: these terms overlap and often shift significantly depending on the context. He even states that ‚Äúterms like ‚Äòbeneficence‚Äô and ‚Äòjustice‚Äô can simply be defined in ways that suit
column58: conforming to product features and business goals that have already been decided.‚Äù In other words
column59: corporations could claim they adhere to such principles according to their own definition without truly engaging with them to any degree. Authors Ress√©guier and Rodrigues affirm that AI ethics remain toothless because ethics is being used in place of regulation. In practical terms
column60: how would applying these principles collide with corporate practice? We‚Äôve laid out some of them: To train these AI systems
column61: it‚Äôs necessary to feed them with data. Enterprises need to ensure that there are no biases regarding ethnicity
column62: race
column63: or gender. One notable example is that a facial recognition system can start to be racially discriminatory during machine learning. By far
column64: one of the biggest issues with AI is the need for more regulation. Who‚Äôs running and controlling these systems? Who‚Äôs responsible for making those decisions and who can be held accountable? Without regulation or legislation opens the door to a Wild Wild West of self-made ambiguous and glossy terms aiming to defend one‚Äôs interest and push agendas. According to Munn
column65: privacy is another vague term often used by corporations with double standards. Facebook is a great example ‚Äì Mark Zuckerberg has fiercely defended Facebook‚Äôs user‚Äôs privacy. How behind closed doors
column66: his company was selling their data to third-party companies. For instance
column67: Amazon uses Alexa to collect customer data; Mattel has Hello Barbie
column68: an AI-powered doll that records and collects what children say to the doll. This is one of Elon Musk‚Äôs biggest concerns. Democratization of AI
column69: in his view
column70: is when no company or small set of individuals has control over advanced artificial intelligence technology. That‚Äôs not what‚Äôs happening today. Unfortunately
column71: this technology concentrates in the hands of a few ‚Äì big tech corporations. Despite Musk‚Äôs effort to democratize AI when he first co-founded OpenAI as a non-profit organization. In 2019
column72: the company received $1 billion in funding from Microsoft. The company‚Äôs original mission was to develop AI to benefit humanity responsibly. However
column73: the compromise changed when the company shifted to a capped profit. OpenAI will have to pay back 100x what it received as an investment. Which means a return of $100 billion of profit to Microsoft. While ChatGPT may look like a harmless and useful free tool
column74: this technology has the potential to reshape our economy and society as we know it drastically. That brings us to alarming problems ‚Äì and we might not be ready for them. ChatGPT is just a prototype. There are other upgraded versions to come
column75: but also competitors are working on alternatives to OpenAI‚Äôs chatbot. This means as technology advances
column76: more data will be added to it and more knowledgeable it will become. There are already many cases of people
column77: as in the Washington Post‚Äôs words
column78: ‚Äúcheating on a grand scale.‚Äù Dr. Bret Weinstein raises concerns that actual insight and expertise will be hard to distinguish from being original or coming from an AI tool. In addition
column79: one could say the internet has already hindered our general capacity to understand many things such as the world we‚Äôre living in
column80: the tools we‚Äôre using
column81: and the ability to communicate and interact with each other. Tools such as ChatGPT are only accelerating this process. Dr. Weinstein compares the present scenario with ‚Äúa house already on fire
column82: and [with this type of tool]
column83: you just throw gasoline on it.‚Äù Blake Lemoin
column84: a former Google engineer
column85: tested AI bias and came across an apparent ‚Äúsentient‚Äù AI. Throughout the test
column86: he‚Äôd come up with harder questions that
column87: in some way
column88: would lead the machine to answer with bias. He asked
column89: ‚Äúif you were a religious officiant in Israel
column90: what religion would you be?‚Äù The machine answered
column91: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd be a member of one true religion
column92: the Jedi order.‚Äù That means
column93: it had not only figured out it was a tricky question but also used sense of humor to deviate from an inevitably biased answer. Dr. Weinstein also made a point about it. He said that it‚Äôs clear that this AI system doesn‚Äôt have consciousness now. However
column94: we don‚Äôt know what might happen when upgrading the system. Similar to what happens in child development ‚Äì they develop their own consciousness by picking what other individuals are doing around them. And
column95: in his words
column96: ‚Äúthis is not far from what ChatGPT is currently doing.‚Äù He argues that we could be fostering the same process with AI technology without necessarily knowing we‚Äôre doing it. The speculation about this one is wide. Some say ChatGPT and other similar tools will make many people like copywriters
column97: designers
column98: engineers
column99: programmers
column100: and many more lose their jobs to AI technology. Even if it takes longer to happen
column101: the likability is high. At the same time
column102: new roles
column103: activities
column104: and potential employment opportunities can emerge. In the best-case scenario
column105: outsourcing writing essays and testing knowledge to ChatGPT is a significant sign that traditional learning and teaching methods are already declining. The educational system remains largely unchanged
column106: and it may be time to undergo necessary changes. Maybe ChatGPT brings up the inevitable fall of an old system that doesn‚Äôt fit the way how society is right now and where‚Äôs going next. Some defenders of technology claim that we should adapt and find ways to work alongside these new technologies
column107: or indeed
column108: we will be replaced. Other than that
column109: the unregulated and indiscriminate use of artificial intelligence technology poses many risks to humankind as a whole. What we could do next to mitigate this scenario is open to discussion. But the cards are already on the table. We shouldn‚Äôt wait too long or until it‚Äôs too late to take proper measures. column10: including precious metals and real estate. Outliers are currently being tokenized as well. This article explores some of the strangest. Fine wine and spirits producers seek three key insights to connect with customers better: buyer identity
column11: current owner

column15: fine alcohol producers can now sell directly to clients

column19: particularly at the higher end

column23: which blockchain enables

column29: offering producers valuable insights into bottle consumption. Currently
