column1: 170::https://theconversation.com/japan-the-yen-plunges-to-34-year-low-despite-interest-rate-hike-221478::The Conversation::article::Japan: the yen plunges to 34-year low despite interest rate hike::Raising interest rates can‚Äôt stop Japan‚Äôs currency from sinking to a record low.::The Bank of Japan (BoJ) raised interest rates for the first time in 17 years on March 19
column2: bringing an era of negative interest rates to an end. The key rate was hiked from ‚Äì0.1% to a band from zero to 0.1% ‚Äì a token effort to offer some tightening after decades of loose but unsuccessful monetary policy. Despite the adjustment
column3: Japan remains the major economy with the lowest interest rates in the world. In my opinion
column4: the move is not designed to end Japan‚Äôs monetary policy dilemma; instead
column5: it confirms the central bank‚Äôs role in supporting the US dollar. Negative rates were ostensibly adopted to stimulate the economy
column6: based on the idea that lower interest rates lead to higher growth. But the negative rates were never a stimulus to the economy. They served as a tax on the reserves held by commercial banks at the central bank. Under negative rates
column7: banks had to pay the central bank
column8: squeezing their profit margins as soon as the rates were imposed (in 2016 in Japan). Since banks in Japan never extended negative rates to deposits made by bank customers
column9: they passed this penalty onto borrowers. This was relatively easy to do as small Japanese firms have been desperate for more bank loans for 30 years. As a result
column10: lowering rates into negative territory actually raised borrowing rates for loan customers. Due to the squeeze on bank profits
column11: the years of zero and negative rates (the BoJ had already reduced interest rates to 0.001% in the 1990s) have also forced thousands of small banks in Japan (likewise in Europe) to merge with bigger banks. Central planners love the idea of a concentrated banking system with a few big banks. But it is small firms and the middle class that get crushed. Research has found that bigger banks lend less to small firms
column12: thus economies are most vibrant when they boast many small banks. Bank lending provides the fuel for economic growth. So the BoJ‚Äôs low and negative interest rate policies have harmed the Japanese economy by suppressing bank credit growth for decades. Is the small rise in interest rates a step in the right direction? Barely. Zero rates are still bad for the economy. Rates should have been raised much more and much earlier. But the BoJ is not interested in supporting the domestic economy and national interests
column13: nor even explicit government policy. Consider the exchange rate. It is often thought that the low rates have contributed to a weak yen
column14: since investors could earn higher interest by investing in other currencies. But the yen has fallen in value since the rate rise was announced. Before interest rates were raised
column15: the yen stood at ¬•149 to the US dollar. One week later
column16: it had slipped to ¬•151 to the dollar. And on April 15
column17: the yen fell past ¬•154 per dollar ‚Äì its weakest in 34 years. Forecasters have predicted that the yen would bounce back given the prowess of Japanese manufacturing. They are also aware of the hawkish rhetoric of the Japanese Ministry of Finance
column18: which is legally in charge of official currency intervention and deploys this to stop yen weakness. However
column19: the BoJ is independent and has a long history of sabotaging the plans of the Ministry of Finance. The BoJ usually sterilises any intervention ordered by the Finance Ministry to pursue the opposite goal. It has
column20: for instance
column21: aimed to prolong the recession in order to force through structural change. The sterilisation is why the yen has weakened further since the recent policy announcement
column22: and so far there is no change in sight. The BoJ has been expanding credit creation faster than the US Federal Reserve. Faster money printing in Japan will weaken the value of the yen against the US dollar. These factors are more important than interest rates
column23: which tend to simply follow the economy. The US dollar had been threatened by the Fed‚Äôs extraordinary monetary policy of March 2020
column24: when it implemented the Blackrock plan. This was the plan proposed by American asset management firm Blackrock in 2019 to create inflation via a version of quantitative easing. This plan was actually based on a proposal of ‚Äúquantitative easing‚Äù that I had developed in Japan 30 years ago to help the country stage a swift recovery from its incipient banking crisis. It was a policy designed for deflationary economies with shrinking bank credit
column25: namely for the central bank to purchase assets from the non-bank sector. However
column26: bank credit growth in 2020 was already more than 5% in the US when the Fed added fuel to the fire and doubled bank credit growth to 11%. That‚Äôs why I had been forecasting in 2020 that we would see significant inflation 18 months later
column27: which is what happened in those countries that followed the Fed‚Äôs money printing. Read more: Why central banks are too powerful and have created our inflation crisis ‚Äì by the banking expert who pioneered quantitative easing Since then
column28: the BoJ has been given the job of propping up the US dollar. In an era when the Brics countries (Brazil
column29: Russia
column30: India
column31: China and South Africa) are challenging the dominance of the dollar and even Saudi Arabia is selling oil against the Chinese currency
column32: the US has enlisted its allies to support the dollar. The BoJ continues to expand credit creation faster than the Fed
column33: and while that happens
column34: the yen will stay weak no matter what the Ministry of Finance says or does. As Henry Kissinger said in 1972 with reference to South Vietnam: ‚ÄúIt is bad to be America‚Äôs enemy. It‚Äôs fatal to be its ally.‚Äù::2024-04-16T15:43:16Z::Bank loans

column7: the legislative measure is now heading to the desk of President Joseph Biden
column8: who has vowed to veto it in a show of solidarity with the SEC. Although a number of high profile Democrats
column9: including New York Sen. Chuck Schumer
column10: voted in favor of overturning the bulletin
column11: the Senate‚Äôs 60 to 38 vote on Thursday failed to cross the threshold to override a presidential veto. It‚Äôs hard to read the tea leaves of the vote
column12: which almost suggests something of a realignment among legislators willing to pass decent crypto regulations (or at least repeal the bad). Then again
column13: there are a number of reasons why it‚Äôd make sense to ditch SAB 121
column14: not the least of which is that the nonpartisan Government Accountability Office found the SEC forced it through without proper congressional oversight. Of course
column15: perennially antagonistic crypto skeptic Sen. Elizabeth Warren voted to keep the rule in place
column16: arguing ‚ÄúThe unique risks of crypto can create liabilities that seriously impact a company's financial condition. SAB 121 simply clarifies how companies should account for those risks in their financial disclosures.‚Äù But still
column17: is the bipartisan support a good sign for other legislative efforts
column18: like the proposed stablecoin and market structure bills under consideration? Views are split: ‚ÄúHate to be a downer here
column19: but I don't think D support to rescind crypto accounting rule means a veto won't happen. I think the D 'ayes' on the anti-SBA 121 vote were cast because they know the White House is going to veto it. It's the cart
column20: not the horse
column21: ‚Äù James Wester
column22: director of crypto and co-head of payments at Javelin
column23: said on X. Apparently it‚Äôs easier to vote for something you know will ultimately get showdown? Meanwhile
column24: Columbia Business School associate professor Austin Campbell said that Thursday‚Äôs vote proves that crypto is bipartisan. ‚ÄúThis is a American issue
column25: not a partisan one
column26: ‚Äù he said. See also: Will Biden Get the Final Say Over a Controversial Crypto Rule? | Opinion Whatever the case
column27: it is worrying how precarious crypto legislation is. A rule that two pluralities vote in favor of
column28: that is widely criticized by industry actors and has even been called ‚Äúidiotic‚Äù by knowledgeable actors like Nadine Chakar
column29: often called one of the most important women in finance who helped found State Street Digital and is now running DTCC‚Äôs crypto unit
column30: (and who is speaking at Consensus 2024)
column31: will likely remain in place. This isn‚Äôt even just purely an academic issue
column32: because the SAB 121 ‚Äì though technically ‚Äúnonbinding‚Äù ‚Äì is already having an effect on financial institutions ability to enter into the crypto custody business
column33: according to an open letter signed by the Bank Policy Institute (BPI)
column34: American Bankers Association (ABA)
column35: Financial Services Forum (FSF) and the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association (SIFMA) in February. See also: Crypto Industry Rallies Behind U.S. House Bill As it Heads to Final Vote I mean
column36: this is a bit of a counterfactual
column37: but how far advanced would sectors like stablecoins and interbank blockchain rails be had clear regulations been written years ago? It seems trivially true that regulatory uncertainty (and more recently
column38: hostility) has prevented firms from experimenting with crypto. For instance
column39: certainly some big custodians would be interested in custodying all that ETF bitcoin
column40: as Fortune‚Äôs Jeff John Roberts recently wrote. It‚Äôs interesting that 12 Dems in the Senate could come together to help vote down a harmful rule
column41: but I‚Äôm not sure the SAB 121 story is really all that encouraging. Edited by Benjamin Schiller.  Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column1: 172::https://beincrypto.com/what-you-can-and-cant-trust-in-crypto/::BeInCrypto::article::What You Can And Can‚Äôt Trust In Crypto::Crypto users must think carefully about trusting smart contracts
column2: trusting laws
column3: and trusting people to keep their digital assets safe.::We use cookies to improve your experience. Over the past year
column4: some of the crypto world‚Äôs biggest companies have collapsed
column5: from Celsius and Voyager to BlockFi and FTX. The one constant in all these failures has been the massive breach of trust for everyone involved ‚Äì from retail investors to crypto institutions. I think it‚Äôs important to reflect on how and why this happened. Let‚Äôs think back to the innovation that launched the entire crypto industry ‚Äì the Bitcoin white paper. The very first sentence of that paper explains that the central problem of online commerce is trust. Internet payment infrastructure ‚Äústill suffers from the inherent weaknesses of the trust-based model‚Äù
column6: the pseudonymous author Satoshi Nakamoto wrote
column7: ‚ÄúWhat is needed is an electronic payment system based on cryptographic proof instead of trust.‚Äù But recent events provide a stark reminder that when dealing with crypto assets in practice
column8: investors still need to think carefully about who and what they trust. I believe there are three important categories of trust in crypto ‚Äì you can trust the code
column9: you can trust the law
column10: or you can trust the person. I‚Äôd like to explain each of these
column11: and offer some advice on how to think about protecting your digital assets. The Bitcoin white paper invites us to trust the code
column12: and because of this
column13: Bitcoin and similar crypto assets are often referred to as a ‚Äútrustless‚Äù system. In certain limited scenarios
column14: it is possible to rely on this trustlessness. This has given rise to the maxim: ‚Äúnot your keys
column15: not your coins‚Äù
column16: suggesting that only those who self-custody their own crypto have true ownership of their assets. It‚Äôs true that more centralized methods of holding assets involve some level of trusting an institution
column17: just like you trust your local bank to keep your paycheck and retirement accounts safe. Of course
column18: that doesn‚Äôt mean that self-custody ‚Äì choosing to exclusively trust the code ‚Äì is the right option for everyone. For one thing
column19: not everyone has the technical savvy to do this successfully and safely. Even those who do will often still find themselves using centralized institutions to trade and access advanced products
column20: so some level of dependence on trust is hard to get away from. There are a host of DeFi protocols that offer a service that is more code-governed than a traditional centralized financial institution run by people. Trusting these protocols
column21: however
column22: requires that you personally verify that the code does what it says it does
column23: or alternatively
column24: trust the people who programmed it. We have seen throughout the course of 2022 that some of these decentralized protocols come with their own significant risks to investors. We need to remember that a lot of the time
column25: when we are told to trust the code
column26: we‚Äôre really placing our trust in people. Just look at FTX. In public
column27: FTX touted its automated liquidation engine as the ultimate risk management tool. In reality
column28: FTX management appears to have secretly exempted Alameda Research
column29: a huge trading firm personally owned by its founder
column30: from that protocol. Alameda failed
column31: and now the exchange itself is insolvent. At the end of the day
column32: if you are asked to ‚Äòtrust the code‚Äô to protect your assets
column33: you either need to be very certain that you understand the code yourself
column34: or you need to think about whether you trust the people behind the code. In everyday life
column35: we largely trust the law to protect our interests when we rely on banks and other financial institutions to make transactions and save our hard-earned wealth. Fraud and financial crimes do happen
column36: of course
column37: but legal protections limit the impact on individual customers. In the United States
column38: for example
column39: even if a consumer bank were to become completely insolvent
column40: the US government insures account holders to the tune of $250
column41: 000. In addition
column42: there are well-developed laws and regulations as well as stiff civil and criminal penalties for financial misconduct in most parts of the world
column43: which go a long way toward deterring bad actors. Thanks to these legal protections
column44: people generally have very good reason to trust retail bank deposits
column45: at least in the developed world. In these places
column46: ‚Äúself-custodying‚Äù one‚Äôs fiat savings would entail a much bigger risk. So another important question for crypto users to answer is: to what extent are they protected by law? In this regard
column47: they need to think about not just their own home country
column48: but also about which jurisdiction the institution they may be trading with is based in. Users can more likely have some trust in the law when they are dealing with an institution that‚Äôs physically based in the country where they live
column49: not offshore. It is also very important to consider whether that institution is licensed by local regulatory authorities who provide oversight. In the case of Coins
column50: we are regulated by the Philippines‚Äô central bank
column51: and hold a variety of licenses which are also held by local financial institutions. We‚Äôre audited regularly
column52: and we comply with the rules. That‚Äôs what happens in places where there is real regulatory oversight ‚Äì you follow the rules or you go to jail. It‚Äôs pretty simple. Of course
column53: there are still criminals in this world who choose to break the law
column54: in finance and in every other area of life. As with ‚Äútrust the code‚Äù
column55: when you are relying on the law to protect your investment
column56: there is always some degree of trust in institutions and people. It will be important to watch how legal authorities respond to the recent breaches of trust in the crypto space. I‚Äôve established that in crypto
column57: as in any other financial endeavor
column58: there is almost always going to be some level of needing to trust your counterparty. We are not yet living in the totally trustless world envisioned by Satoshi Nakamoto. What crypto users must not do is place their trust entirely in a group of people
column59: or even worse
column60: a single powerful individual. If a counterparty is a centralized institution that takes custody of your assets
column61: and does so offshore
column62: potentially beyond the reach of regulators and law enforcement
column63: then they are essentially asking you to trust a person. If you wouldn‚Äôt agree to that with your fiat savings
column64: you should think twice about doing it with your crypto assets. If any good comes out of the recent negative events in the crypto markets
column65: hopefully consumers think more carefully about the risks they are exposed to. And as crypto companies continue to build through the current bear market
column66: let‚Äôs hope that both capital and customer interest flow to platforms and products that offer consumers some level of code-based or law-based protection beyond simply telling them: ‚Äútrust me‚Äù. By Elijah Tan
column67: VP of Exchange
column68: Coins.ph and ex-Binance Fiat Lead Disclaimer In compliance with the Trust Project guidelines

column26: ‚Äô like this is my profile

MITH‚Äôs founders believe the best uses of blockchain tech for fan engagement will ultimately emerge down the road. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre meeting with some heavy hitters in the digital identity space that are tied to [layer-1s] and we‚Äôre saying

column1: 176::https://theconversation.com/ftx-and-binance-how-latest-crypto-scandals-could-influence-public-opinion-on-digital-currency-regulation-218939::The Conversation::article::FTX and Binance: how latest crypto scandals could influence public opinion on digital currency regulation::The general public may want tighter crypto regulations but is the UK government listening?::True believers in cryptocurrency have had a rough few weeks. The US government just fined Binance ‚Äì the world‚Äôs largest crypto exchange ‚Äì US$4.3 billion (¬£3.4 billion) for its involvement in money laundering. It forced the firm to accept intrusive monitoring and demanded that its secretive boss
column2: Changpeng Zhao
column3: step down and pay a personal fine of $50 million. Zhao
column4: known as CZ
column5: has been called the most powerful man in crypto. The industry is still reeling from the conviction of Zhao‚Äôs bitter rival
column6: Sam Bankman-Fried
column7: earlier in November on seven counts of fraud and conspiracy. His company FTX ‚Äì previously the second-largest crypto exchange in the world ‚Äì collapsed in November 2022. SBF
column8: as he is commonly known
column9: could theoretically face more than 100 years in jail when he is sentenced in March 2024. Several other former leading crypto executives are also under investigation or being prosecuted. Crypto has just squared off against the US state
column10: and at halftime the result is state power 2 ‚Äì crypto 0. After this display of muscular regulation on one side of the Atlantic
column11: what is the future of crypto regulation in the UK? The UK government has repeatedly vaunted its ambition to make the UK a global crypto hub. The new minister for the City of London
column12: Bim Afolami
column13: doubled down on this message shortly after taking up his post
column14: warning regulators against going overboard. Speaking at a Financial Times event on global banking
column15: he said: ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre regulating a market
column16: in any area
column17: there‚Äôs no point in having the safest graveyard‚Äù. And then added: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really important that we don‚Äôt tar every crypto business as being like FTX or Binance.‚Äù This attitude could put Afolami and the government on a collision course with UK regulator the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA). Former FCA chair Charles Randell recently criticised the government‚Äôs plans for treating crypto like any other financial investment
column18: saying they risked normalising crypto even though fraud ‚Äúis a feature
column19: not a bug‚Äù of much of the sector. Read more: What Binance's US lawsuit says about the future for cryptocurrency regulation The government would say that its view is the democratically legitimate one ‚Äì no one has elected the FCA. But research shows British people may respond to revelations of wrongdoing in the sector by wanting to regulate crypto more severely. Through the Banklash research project
column20: my colleagues and I have studied what happens to public opinion about financial regulation when people are exposed to news about financial scandals
column21: such as the payment protection insurance scandal in the UK. We found that in multiple countries
column22: the public has clear views about financial regulation
column23: and that when they read about scandals
column24: their demand for regulatory stringency increases. Such changes in public opinion are not simply abstract experimental effects. In a separate article
column25: Harvard professor Taeku Lee and I have shown how a US Congress investigation of Goldman Sachs‚Äô role in the global financial crisis drew public attention to malfeasance by big banks and the position of political parties on it. In the wake of this explosion of publicity
column26: Republicans dropped their filibuster of the 2010 Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act
column27: which was the biggest reform of US financial regulation since the 1930s. Two years after the financial crisis
column28: defending the unpopular big banks was not a hill the Republicans wanted to die on. Read more: Crypto: what could more regulation mean for the future of digital currencies? We have followed up this research with a study this year of British attitudes towards cryptocurrency. Our new work
column29: which has not yet been published in an academic journal
column30: suggests that the FCA is more in tune with British public opinion than the government. Among the four countries we surveyed in March 2023 ‚Äì with responses from more than 36
column31: 000 people ‚Äì British respondents expressed the highest level of support for crypto regulation. Americans want the least
column32: while France and Germany fall in the middle. As part of the same study
column33: we also investigated how consuming media coverage of the FTX scandal affected those attitudes. Reading about the scandal caused a significant increase in the appetite to regulate crypto among Brits
column34: starting from an already high base. This is the same effect we found in other areas of financial regulation in our earlier research. It seems reasonable to expect that the recent demonstrations of malfeasance by CZ and SBF will lead to a toughening of public attitudes about the regulation of crypto. Despite the fact that cryptocurrency is perceived as an esoteric topic
column35: people have views about it. UK politicians would be well-advised to take these views into account when trying to balance demands for regulatory stringency and the economic defence of London‚Äôs status as an international financial hub. The US government has flexed its regulatory muscles without concern for damaging the appeal of its crypto market
column36: although of course that market is much larger. Political leaders in the UK should not deceive themselves that the general public doesn‚Äôt understand these issues. There will be an election next year. And as Bankman-Fried and Zhao have discovered
column37: you can fool some of the people some of the time
column38: but you can‚Äôt fool all the people all the time. Even on a subject as apparently baffling as crypto.::2023-12-01T12:14:48Z::Big banks

column5: parent company AgoraDesk
column6: which is also winding down
column7: said in a statement. ‚ÄúAfter almost seven years of operation
column8: due to a combination of internal and external factors
column9: we have made the difficult decision to close our platform. ‚ÄúWe're extremely thankful for the love and support we've received over the years. We couldn't have done it without you. We love you all
column10: ‚Äù the statement read. This is an excerpt from The Node newsletter
column11: a daily roundup of the most pivotal crypto news on CoinDesk and beyond. You can subscribe to get the full newsletter here. As mentioned in the announcement
column12: the peer-to-peer exchange created to trade the eponymous privacy coin monero (XMR)
column13: LocalMonero has been around for most of Monero's existence. Although AgoraDesk did not provide a specific reason for shutting down
column14: it‚Äôs easy enough to intuit why. In recent months
column15: a slew of P2P crypto trading platforms including LocalBitcoins and Paxful have called it quits ‚Äì a trend largely driven by regulatory headwinds. To wit: ‚ÄúRegulatory challenges for the industry continue to grow
column16: especially in the paper-to-peer market and most heavily in the U.S. While we work through these issues

column18: ‚Äù Ray Youssef

column20: said in a statement at the time the now defunct platform closed. Problems for LocalMonero were largely compounded by pressure from regulatory authorities on privacy coins. Crypto exchanges OKX
column21: Binance and Coinbase have all proactively delisted privacy-preserving tokens like monero and zcash (ZEC)
column22: leaving services like LocalMonero one of the few places to purchase XMR. LocalMonero functioned a bit like Craigslist
column23: providing a place where individuals could post an ad to either buy or sell XMR via a variety of different methods ‚Äì essentially any payment method the counterparties agreed upon would work. One ad was for someone looking to trade cash for monero in person listed Detroit Zoo as a meeting point. There was generally a slight markup on LocalMonero token sales because users were willing to pay a premium to buy the token on a platform that asked for limited identification (though it was customary for sellers to request ID as a kind of failsafe.) The platform also offered ‚Äúarbitration bonds‚Äù that would hold an equivalent amount of monero in escrow so that if a seller failed to send the funds
column24: LocalMonero could reimburse users. LocalMonero has been ‚Äúa cornerstone of the no-KYC Monero ecosystem
column25: ‚Äù semi-pseudonymous privacy advocate Seth For Privacy said on X
column26: adding that with its closure monero users are left with few fiat-to-crypto rails for the token. It is an ‚Äúincredibly sad day
column27: ‚Äù he said. On Reddit and the LocalMonero forum
column28: users discussed alternative means of buying XMR
column29: which
column30: with a $2.5 billion market cap

column32: sending it to the privacy-focused Cake Wallet and then swapping for XMR. The Bisq peer-to-peer network also enables swaps between cryptocurrencies into monero. Kraken also still offers monero purchases
column33: though it excludes users from certain countries including the U.K. and Australia and will extend that list to Ireland and Belgium in June. Less secure buying options include purchasing directly from someone on messaging apps like Telegram. For its part
column34: LocalMonero recommended the non-custodial

column36: which are open-source alternatives that have yet to fully launch. Haveno runs on the Tor network and functions using atomic swaps
column37: while Serai will use a multisignature setup. While the old adage that ‚Äúif there‚Äôs a will
column38: there‚Äôs way‚Äù will likely always remain true for those looking to make anonymous transactions is cryptocurrencies like monero
column39: it is undoubtedly the case that blockchain-based privacy tech is becoming harder to access. And it‚Äôs hard to see this trend reversing. But

column1: 178::https://beincrypto.com/yes-we-need-bitcoin-for-defi-without-bridges/::BeInCrypto::article::Yes
column2: We Need Bitcoin For DeFi Without Bridges::Some of the greatest challenges in DeFi‚Äîand smart contract technology in general‚Äîare security threats when transacting...::We use cookies to improve your experience. Some of the greatest challenges in DeFi‚Äîand smart contract technology in general‚Äîare security threats when transacting between blockchains. Last year
column3: over a billion dollars was lost due to ‚Äúblockchain bridges‚Äù that are notoriously insecure and prone to technical errors. That being said
column4: demand for Bitcoin liquidity on DeFi platforms is unrelenting
column5: as Bitcoin currently accounts for nearly 40% of crypto‚Äôs total market cap.* Widespread adoption of Bitcoin suggests that a smart contract solution that eschews bridge-related security concerns could unlock billions of dollars of capital on DeFi platforms. Last month
column6: the Internet Computer blockchain (ICP) introduced a game-changing advancement in this arena‚Äîan elegant and bridge-less solution to the challenge of cross-chain smart contracts. Through the power of threshold cryptography
column7: ICP smart contracts can now operate keys to move Bitcoin directly on its network without the need for intermediaries to exchange value between chains. By coordinating signatures amongst multiple computers holding shares of private keys
column8: keys remain fully secure throughout the entire smart contract execution process. In other words
column9: smart contracts on the Internet Computer can now hold
column10: send and receive Bitcoin natively at the protocol level without the need for bridges or trusted third parties. Users can send and receive Bitcoin to addresses directly controlled by smart contracts on ICP‚Äîallowing for trustless movement of funds in and out of DeFi protocols. As Bitcoin remains a primary settlement asset for all sorts of crypto trading activities
column11: the market for safe and secure smart-contract functionality for Bitcoin is paramount‚Äîand the Internet Computer is poised to lead the way. Furthermore
column12: the implications of being able to ‚Äúcode‚Äù Bitcoin‚Äîthat is
column13: bring smart contract functionality to the Bitcoin blockchain‚Äîextends far beyond DeFi and financial services. In addition to using native Bitcoin integration
column14: developers can build decentralized web applications (Dapps) on the Internet Computer‚Äîallowing for end-to-end decentralized payments services. For instance
column15: ICP developers can now build Bitcoin payments APIs fully on chain without the need for Web2 integrations of any kind
column16: or even centralized servers. Using the ICP blockchain
column17: Bitcoin payments can be securely integrated into any number of Web3 applications. Imagine sending Bitcoin through on-chain chat services
column18: like OpenChat
column19: with messages like ‚ÄúHappy Birthday! Here‚Äôs 1
column20: 000 satoshis!‚Äù This is a massive step forward in the fight for a truly decentralized internet as other smart contracts platforms rely heavily on Web2 interfaces throughout their user journey. Other use cases for the integration of native Bitcoin into Web3 services include things like Bitcoin gaming rewards
column21: decentralized marketplaces
column22: SocialFi
column23: and peer-to-peer payments services. The possibilities for integrating native Bitcoin into Dapps mirror that of any Web2 payments integrations you can think of. Additionally
column24: ICP developers will soon be able to integrate Ether (ETH) and other ECDSA-based tokens into Dapps as well. Direct interaction with tokens on a variety of blockchains will soon be streamlined on the Internet Computer‚Äîmaking truly trustless cross-chain interoperability a reality. This is the future of Web3 and Web3 payments‚Äîthe ability to use funds from any blockchain trustlessly within Web3 apps and services. Dominic Williams is the Founder and Chief Scientist at the DFINITY Foundation‚Äîthe primary contributor to the Internet Computer blockchain (ICP). The Internet Computer aims to develop a World Computer blockchain that could replace traditional centralized IT
column25: such as cloud computing services. As builders on the Internet Computer develop end-to-end
column26: fully on-chain applications and services‚ÄîDominic Williams continues his leadership as a distinguished crypto theoretician and serial entrepreneur focused on the Internet and distributed systems. For more details about the Internet Computer blockchain
column27: review key metrics and other ICP information here. Disclaimer In compliance with the Trust Project guidelines

column1: 179::https://blockworks.co/news/obligate-blockchain-bonds-base::Blockworks::article::Protocol Obligate ramps up push to boost institutional blockchain use::On-chain debt capital markets platform deploys on Coinbase-incubated layer-2 after structured investment products push.::On-chain debt capital markets platform deploys on Coinbase-incubated layer-2 after structured investment products push Obligate and Adobe modified by Blockworks On-chain debt capital markets platform Obligate has launched on Coinbase‚Äôs layer-2 network. This new deployment aligns with the protocol‚Äôs strategy to increase institutional engagement with blockchain-native assets. It comes just after the Switzerland-based firm made its initial entry into on-chain investment products; a decision that aligns with a larger trend across the industry. Obligate lets companies issue on-chain bonds and other debt securities to receive funding from investors. These bonds
column2: initially issued via smart contracts on Polygon
column3: have now expanded to another venue. The deployment on Base ‚Äî a Coinbase-incubated layer-2 built on the Optimism stack and launched in July ‚Äî ‚Äúrepresents a paradigm shift in the integration of blockchain technology into institutional finance
column4: ‚Äù according to Matthias Wyss
column5: Obligate‚Äôs head of strategic partnerships. Read more: The ‚Äòcrypto degen crowd‚Äô has settled in on Coinbase layer-2
column6: Base ‚ÄúOur capabilities are especially relevant in the current macro environment as they allow small- and medium-sized enterprises cheap and efficient access to debt capital
column7: which is crucial in the rising interest rate environment
column8: ‚Äù Wyss told Blockworks. Obligate issued its first bond on the Polygon blockchain in March. Investors in the protocol include Blockchange Ventures
column9: Circle Ventures
column10: Earlybird and SIX Fintech Ventures. Investors fund their orders into escrow before capital and bonds are exchanged
column11: according to the company‚Äôs site. From issuance to maturity
column12: investors hold ERC20 bond tokens in their wallets and ‚Äî unless transfer limitations are set by the issuers ‚Äî can move or sell them to other wallets. Users receive payment redemption tokens at maturity
column13: at which time the investors can burn their tokens for the final payments. Issuers can also secure their bonds with collateral
column14: leading to the liquidation of that collateral in the case of default. The deployment to Base comes a couple weeks after STS Digital issued a structured investment product ‚Äî a barrier reverse convertible linked to bitcoin ‚Äî on Polygon as an Obligate eNote. Obligate said in a Nov. 15 blog post that it intends to build ‚Äúan extensive product suite alongside a broad spectrum of digital asset services‚Äù ‚Äî including products with ‚Äúbespoke payoff profiles.‚Äù Moving real-world assets onto the blockchain via tokenization has gained steam in recent months as financial players and investors seek to boost efficiency and lower costs. Read more: BlackRock CEO touts tokenization
column15: warns US ‚Äòlagging‚Äô in innovation Various projects have sought to offer on-chain access to US Treasury securities
column16: for example ‚Äî the largest and most liquid government bond market globally. Traditional finance giants
column17: such as JPMorgan
column18: continue exploring ways to use blockchain technology. The company most recently carried out tests designed to let fund managers tokenize their portfolios on chosen blockchains. Wyss said all institutional blockchain applications reaffirm the path to a future where all capital market transactions are issued and settled on-chain. ‚ÄúWe already see an expansion of blockchain native assets along the risk curve from payment to debt to equity and

column1: 182::https://theconversation.com/cryptocurrencies-why-binances-failed-ftx-rescue-deal-could-mean-crypto-winter-is-coming-194313::The Conversation::article::Cryptocurrencies: why Binance‚Äôs failed FTX rescue deal could mean ‚Äòcrypto winter‚Äô is coming::The latest market chaos is set to continue and could result in more regulatory scrutiny.::Life in the cryptocurrency industry is rarely quiet for long
column2: and after a tumultuous summer
column3: it seems the market is now entering a ‚Äúcrypto winter‚Äù. Over the past week
column4: the founders of two of the largest cryptocurrency exchanges ‚Äì Binance and FTX ‚Äì have had a public Twitter spat that triggered the collapse of one exchange and a failed bailout deal from the other. Unsurprisingly
column5: these events have caused widespread panic across a market that has barely recovered from several major failures earlier this year. You can listen to more articles from The Conversation
column6: narrated by Noa
column7: here. Binance
column8: which is estimated to be worth more than US$300 billion (¬£263 billion)
column9: was actually FTX‚Äôs first investor in December 2019. Since then
column10: FTX has grown to be worth more than US$32 billion as of last January
column11: counting mainstream finance giants such as BlackRock and SoftBank among its many backers. Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao and FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried (often referred to as CZ and SBF
column12: respectively) are two of the most influential people in the cryptocurrency exchange world where investors can buy
column13: sell and store digital currencies. While Zhao has been associated with regulatory concerns around Binance
column14: Bankman-Fried was seen as a relatively stable and ambitious figure in the wild west world of cryptocurrencies. He swooped in to rescue failing companies during last summer‚Äôs crypto bust and has made a point of speaking with the media and US policymakers. Bankman-Fried‚Äôs empire included the FTX exchange business
column15: as well as Alameda Research
column16: a trading firm that was supposed to be separate from FTX. But a recent story by industry news site Coindesk reported that Alameda‚Äôs balance sheet was dominated by FTT. This is the crypto token or coin issued by the FTX exchange
column17: which grants holders a discount on trading fees on the marketplace. FTT is entirely controlled by FTX
column18: Alameda‚Äôs sister company and can be ‚Äúprinted‚Äù as FTX wishes. Alameda also held US$3.37 billion across a range of other cryptocurrencies
column19: such as Solana and Serum
column20: which means that any cryptocurrency collapse could severely affect the company. While there is nothing illegal or wrong with these holdings ‚Äì particularly in the notoriously unregulated crypto industry ‚Äì the report showed Alameda‚Äôs heavy reliance on a coin invented by its sister company and not one issued by an independent backer or as legal tender by a government. If a company in such a position gets into trouble
column21: such assets would be useless in shoring up the business and protecting users because they would also fall in value. This discovery about Alameda‚Äôs balance sheet led to liquidity concerns about the entire company. Indeed
column22: after the Coindesk news story was published
column23: Binance CEO Zhao tweeted plans to liquidate the remaining FTT on Binance‚Äôs books. In another post a few hours later he called the move ‚Äúpost-exit risk management
column24: learning from LUNA‚Äù (a reference to a roughly US$60 billion crypto crash that happened earlier this year).  Zhao has 7.4 million followers on Twitter so his tweets affect the market. The value of FTT fell from US$22 on Sunday to US$4 on Tuesday afternoon
column25: while FTX was flooded with a reported US$6 billion in withdrawal requests. Some customers were unable to access their cryptocurrency holdings on the exchange due to the number of requests. Bankman-Fried responded on Monday by saying a ‚Äúcompetitor is trying to go after us with false rumours‚Äù and adding that ‚ÄúFTX is fine‚Äù (he later removed the tweet). But it seems this was too little
column26: too late: total cryptocurrency market capitalisation dropped from more than US$1 trillion to around US$830 billion in a matter of days.  In a surprise move
column27: just days later both Zhao and Bankman-Fried (above) tweeted details of a deal for Binance to acquire FTX. But the Wall Street Journal reported the following evening that Binance had decided not to proceed with the deal after reviewing FTX‚Äôs finances and business structure. A tweet from Binance (below) said ‚Äúthe issues are beyond our control or ability to help‚Äù. Further
column28: Bloomberg reported that US regulators
column29: the Security and Exchange Commission and Commodity Futures Trading Commission
column30: have both been investigating FTX over its handling of customers funds.  The cryptocurrency industry has struggled in the last year
column31: particularly since the failure of Terra and Luna tokens in May
column32: the collapse of lender Celsius Network in June and the subsequent bankruptcy of hedge fund Three Arrows Capital in July. The near-collapse of one of the biggest names in crypto
column33: followed by the will-they-or-won‚Äôt-they nature of the Binance bailout has had an effect right across the crypto industry
column34: with Bitcoin falling by more than 18% during these events. The failure of this rescue deal will do little to boost confidence in the sector and could accelerate a crypto winter by stoking fears of price volatility and the need for future bailouts. The value of the FTT coin is down by nearly 90% and trading volumes at FTX fell by more than 70% in the 24 hours around the rescue deal discussions. Much of this lost activity will move elsewhere
column35: meaning the collapse of FTX could make Binance larger. This could encourage regulators to start looking much more closely at the space. Of course
column36: the ultimate irony is that one of the main characteristics of cryptocurrencies is supposed to be decentralisation
column37: but recent events may well lead to more centralisation as activity consolidates around one exchange. This could discourage some crypto-enthusiasts from using Binance in the future.::2022-11-10T13:27:13Z::Audio narrated

column1: 183::https://www.coindesk.com/opinion/2024/05/16/crypto-custody-for-advisors/::CoinDesk::article::Crypto Custody for Advisors::Financial advisors seeking to navigate the crypto custody landscape must understand the full spectrum of crypto custody options
column2: balancing innovation with risk management to optimize client portfolios. Crypto Custody for Financial Advisors Ask an Expert Keep Reading::Crypto custody can be a challenging topic
column3: as there are many options investors and advisors face when considering the storage
column4: security and accessibility of digital assets. In today's main article
column5: Todd Bendell
column6: from Amphibian Capital
column7: discusses the different custody options financial advisors need to know. Meredith Yarbrough from LaHoja Capital Partners answers questions about bitcoin custody and collateral in today‚Äôs Ask an Expert. ‚ÄìS.M. You‚Äôre reading Crypto for Advisors
column8: CoinDesk‚Äôs weekly newsletter that unpacks digital assets for financial advisors. Subscribe here to get it every Thursday. In the dynamic world of cryptocurrency
column9: strategic foresight is a necessity. Financial advisors seeking to navigate this volatile landscape must understand the full spectrum of crypto custody options
column10: balancing innovation with risk management to optimize client portfolios. Self-Custody: The Ultimate Control Opting for self-custody equates to holding the reins of responsibility. This approach involves securing private keys through cold storage ‚Äì hardware wallets isolated from online threats. It‚Äôs a fortress of solitude for crypto
column11: offering maximum security but requiring technical acumen. For the savvy investor or the privacy-centric individual
column12: self-custody is best suited for those prioritizing absolute control over their digital assets. On-Exchange Custody: Convenience with a Catch The convenience of on-exchange custody cannot be overstated. Cryptocurrencies remain readily accessible
column13: facilitating swift transactions. However
column14: this method is not without its pitfalls‚Äîsecurity is only as robust as the platform‚Äôs weakest link. Here lies a paradox: the more convenient the access
column15: the greater the vulnerability. The collapse of FTX highlighted the potential vulnerabilities and the importance of selecting platforms with strong
column16: transparent security practices and regulatory compliance. Advisors must thus choose platforms with military-grade security protocols
column17: yet even the most fortified castles have fallen. Off-Exchange Solutions: Institutional Assurance For those managing substantial assets
column18: off-exchange custody solutions represent a strategic chess move. This type of arrangement can include additional verification layers by involving a third party in the authorization of transactions
column19: aligning with the stringent demands of institutional investors. It represents a strategic blend of old-world banking safety and new-tech efficiency. Investing in Crypto Quant Funds Venturing into crypto quant funds offers a compelling narrative. These funds utilize algorithms for high-frequency trading and other market-neutral strategies
column20: potentially reducing risks through diversification and sophisticated strategies. This method can allow for diversified
column21: long-term exposure to flagship cryptocurrencies while minimizing the typical complexities and risks associated with direct crypto asset management and custody. Navigating the Regulatory Landscape Advisors must also master the complexities of regulatory frameworks governing digital assets. The landscape is as politically nuanced as it is technologically advanced
column22: requiring a judicious balance of compliance and strategic innovation. Concluding Thoughts In summary
column23: integrating cryptocurrencies into investment portfolios requires a confluence of knowledge
column24: strategic acumen and a keen understanding of risk. The paths of self-custody
column25: on-exchange custody
column26: and innovative off-exchange solutions offer diverse strategies that cater to different needs. Whether directly holding assets or investing in algorithmically driven funds
column27: the key lies in leveraging these tools to achieve superior outcomes
column28: reminiscent of digital assets‚Äô ethos of bold
column29: strategic innovation. - Todd Bendell
column30: co-founder and managing partner
column31: Amphibian Capital Q. What do credit fund managers look for when choosing a custodian for bitcoin collateral assets? Credit fund managers prioritize minimizing business risk when selecting a custodian for bitcoin collateral. Since bitcoin collateral is typically held for the duration of the loan
column32: custodians are evaluated for their long-term viability
column33: including their audit practices and business continuity plans. Safety is also a key concern; managers assess both general safety policies and specific procedures tailored to bitcoin
column34: along with any additional services the custodian might offer. The biggest challenge in choosing a custodian is lack of standardization as many institutions retrofits traditional frameworks to include bitcoin programs. Q. How does custody of bitcoin collateral differ from traditional asset custody? While there are shared concerns like cybersecurity risks across both traditional and digital assets
column35: bitcoin custody carries unique challenges. For example
column36: the cyber risks associated with digital assets can potentially translate into physical risks through the unauthorized access to keys. Competent bitcoin custodians mitigate this risk by implementing robust key ceremony procedures
column37: where the keys controlling the assets are distributed across multiple geographic locations with strict protocols governing their access and use. Q. Is it possible to insure bitcoin assets? Obtaining insurance for bitcoin assets is possible
column38: though not commonly practiced among credit managers handling bitcoin collateral
column39: similar to the lack of standard insurance policies for traditional financial assets. Instead
column40: managers rely heavily on stringent security protocols and existing regulatory frameworks to protect these assets. - Meredith Yarbrough

column1: 184::https://beincrypto.com/decentralizing-social-media-can-web3-empower-users/::BeInCrypto::article::Decentralizing Social Media: Can Web3 Empower Users?::Decentralizing social media has the potential to revolutionize the industry by empowering users and promoting free speech
column2: but it also comes with its own set of challenges. The rise of social media has completely transformed how we communicate and interact online
column3: with over five billion daily active users worldwide. However
column4: centralized social media platforms have ‚Ä¶ Continued::We use cookies to improve your experience. Decentralizing social media has the potential to revolutionize the industry by empowering users and promoting free speech
column5: but it also comes with its own set of challenges. The rise of social media has completely transformed how we communicate and interact online
column6: with over five billion daily active users worldwide. However
column7: centralized social media platforms have been criticized for handling user data despite their success
column8: as evidenced by the Cambridge Analytica scandal. In recent years
column9: decentralizing social media has gained significant momentum as a potential solution to the centralization
column10: censorship
column11: and data handling issues plaguing social media platforms. Decentralization has the potential to empower users by giving them greater control over their data and privacy. By allowing users to own their data
column12: decentralization can offer a viable solution to the growing demand for privacy and data protection. Additionally
column13: decentralization can prevent power concentration in a few entities‚Äô hands
column14: promoting free speech and reducing censorship. Decentralized social media platforms are a critical component of the future vision of Web3. Currently
column15: social media users spend an average of 2.5 hours per day scrolling through content without receiving any compensation. However
column16: by tokenizing content and marking ownership
column17: Web3 can create an economy that benefits all ecosystem participants and distributes wealth across industry participants. However
column18: decentralization also has its drawbacks. The biggest concern is the potential for misinformation to spread more easily without a centralized entity to regulate content. Additionally
column19: decentralization can lead to further fragmentation and isolation of communities
column20: with limited exposure to diverse perspectives. Ultimately
column21: the debate around whether Web3 can truly empower users or whether stricter regulations are necessary to prevent the spread of harmful content is ongoing. Recently
column22: Elon Musk highlighted that Twitter could be run with just a handful of team members while easing censorship and eliminating most manual content approvals. Still
column23: even with centralization
column24: social media‚Äôs role in the spread of fake news has been significant
column25: and measures to address this issue will continue to evolve. In conclusion
column26: the application of blockchain technology and decentralization is a crucial conversation about the future of social media. While it can potentially transform how we interact online
column27: decentralization comes with its own challenges. Regardless
column28: Web3 will revolutionize the industry
column29: and social media will be one of the most significant beneficiaries. (L-R) Vugar Adigozalov ‚Äì Chief Marketing Officer

column1: 185::https://blockworks.co/news/blockchain-audit-security-standards::Blockworks::article::Blockchain needs standards::Opinion: Without security audit standards
column2: apps built on blockchain will continue to fall prey to hacks and exploits.::Without security audit standards
column3: apps built on blockchain will continue to fall prey to hacks and exploits Frame Fusion Art/Shutterstock modified by Blockworks The 2023 crypto winter has been challenging for many
column4: not least the thieves who target crypto wallets
column5: platforms and token protocols. So far this year
column6: they‚Äôve only managed to steal $1 billion in crypto assets ‚Äî a steep fall from 2022‚Äôs record $3.8 billion. Unfortunately
column7: the decline appears to have more to do with a reduction in available capital than with stronger defenses. And while the scale of attacks has fallen
column8: their frequency has in fact risen sharply: from 60 hacks in 2022 to 75 as of the end of October. And the year isn‚Äôt over. If decentralized finance is ever to be widely accepted by retail and institutional investors
column9: then it needs to achieve its goal of democratizing global finance. We must collectively do better at closing the loopholes that malicious actors are forever looking to slip through. The key to locking the door against bad actors? We need to vastly improve security auditing
column10: which
column11: at present
column12: is inconsistent at best and a rubber-stamp exercise at worst. Specifically
column13: our industry as a whole needs to adopt a consistent auditing methodology for decentralized technology that is rigorous
column14: standardized and repeatable ‚Äî as robust as what protects traditional finance. Such an auditing standard
column15: coupled with a public commitment by auditing firms to the principle of responsible disclosure ‚Äî the willingness to call out projects that refuse to listen to or act on recommendations ‚Äî will encourage projects themselves to raise their security standards. Atomic Wallet‚Äôs refusal to heed a February 2022 public disclosure of serious security vulnerabilities by auditor Least Authority resulted in the loss of more than $100 million to hackers in June 2023. At its best
column16: a third-party security audit is a thorough investigation by a skilled team that analyzes every aspect of a system‚Äôs design and implementation
column17: seeking out weaknesses and flaws that could affect operations or users ‚Äî or offer bad actors access to sensitive data or assets. A good audit also carefully assesses whether developers and designers have adhered to best practices in a system‚Äôs creation and roll-out. Vulnerabilities come in many forms; incorrect or insufficiently secure cryptography
column18: sensitive information leaks
column19: unprotected system parts
column20: inconsistencies between system design documentation and the code used in implementation. Weaknesses like these can result in anything from the exposure of sensitive and secret user data to the loss of user and system assets. That audits are as detailed ‚Äî and consistent ‚Äî as possible is therefore essential to both a project and its users‚Äô safety. There are dozens of firms out there offering audit services
column21: but with no industry standard
column22: quality can and does indeed vary drastically. Even within reputable firms
column23: there is neither consensus on what should be audited nor a consistent set of yardsticks. There is
column24: of course
column25: no guarantee that even the most experienced auditors will either sniff out every weakness in a system or protect every user from loss. But if they are thoroughly and regularly carried out
column26: security audits have been proven to sharply reduce the risk of a serious vulnerability going undetected. Read more from our opinion section: It‚Äôs time for blockchain security firms to join forces However
column27: audits can‚Äôt stop social engineering attacks ‚Äî those that involve the manipulation of human beings ‚Äî such as when North Korean group Lazarus convinced engineers at an unidentified crypto exchange earlier this year to download malware disguised as an arbitrage bot. Preventing that type of attack only comes from vigilance and team training. It is true that every audit will be different
column28: just as every project is different. But my long experience in the security auditing space has taught me there are specific steps an auditor must take to maximize the effectiveness of the security audit for the benefit of clients
column29: users and the ecosystem. What are these requirements? An auditing standard that aims to make decentralized systems more resilient and protect their users from potential losses must include an exhaustive assessment of the following: To ensure that any improvement in standards benefits blockchain as a whole
column30: we also advocate knowledge-sharing and the creation of public goods such as research
column31: tooling and training. By working together to improve the standards of the security auditing industry as a whole ‚Äî and thus the decentralized technology sphere ‚Äî we can go a long way toward stopping the blockchain black hat hackers from breaking 2022‚Äôs record for crypto assets stolen. And that‚Äôs one record we don‚Äôt want to see broken again. Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. The Lightspeed newsletter is all things Solana

column1: 188::https://theconversation.com/crypto-crash-market-volatility-is-testing-investor-will-but-crypto-enthusiasts-still-see-a-future-for-the-asset-class-185339::The Conversation::article::Crypto crash: market volatility is testing investor will but crypto-enthusiasts still see a future for the asset class::Are we witnessing the beginning of the end for crypto or is this just another crash in a volatile market?::Bitcoin
column2: the original cryptocurrency
column3: remains a bellweather for the sector. It hit an all-time high of more than US$68
column5: 600) in November 2021
column6: when the overall value of the cryptocurrency market was close to US$3 trillion. In the months since
column7: however
column8: most major cryptocurrencies have fallen by more 70% and bitcoin itself has dropped below US$18
column9: 000. Is this just another crash in the volatile cryptocurrency market
column10: or is this the beginning of the end for this alternative asset class? When bitcoin was first introduced in early 2009
column11: it was a new type of asset. While trading was thin initially
column12: price appreciation drove its value to nearly US$20
column13: 000 in late 2017. This happened as more retail investors were drawn to cryptocurrencies as a supposed hedge or safe-haven versus other asset classes. And as the market grew
column14: so too did the range of investment opportunities. Futures and options ‚Äì financial contracts to buy or sell an asset or security at a specific price or date ‚Äì are a common hedging tool used in other markets such as oil or the stock market. In December 2017
column15: the first bitcoin futures on a regulated exchange were listed by the Chicago Board Options Exchange. Bitcoin options followed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in January 2020. This period of expansion was topped by the launch of the first bitcoin exchange-traded fund (ETF) in October 2021
column16: providing investors with exposure to bitcoin without having to buy it on a crypto exchange. At the same time
column17: the traditional financial sector was becoming increasingly accepting of cryptocurrencies as a legitimate asset class. A 2021 study of institutional investors found seven in 10 expected to buy or invest in digital assets in the future. This combination of maturity and acceptance
column18: however
column19: also increased the correlation between the stock market and cryptocurrencies
column20: leading to a decline in their safe-haven properties. Bitcoin was fairly disconnected from traditional financial markets in its early days. But as it became ‚Äújust another asset‚Äù
column21: the sector began to be affected by the same macroeconomic factors that influence traditional markets. The US Federal Reserve‚Äôs decision to raise interest rates by 0.75% in June to combat growing inflation
column22: the ongoing war in Ukraine
column23: and the subsequent rise in oil prices have all acted as a drag on cryptocurrencies in recent months. Moves to regulate the sector have also had an impact. But it isn‚Äôt only macroeconomic factors that have caused this crypto downturn. In May and June this year
column24: stablecoin values plummetted
column25: major cryptocurrency exchange Binance paused bitcoin withdrawals due to a ‚Äústuck transaction‚Äù
column26: and lending platform Celsius Network froze withdrawals and transfers citing ‚Äúextreme‚Äù market conditions. Amid this disruption
column27: users of public blockchain platform Solana have reportedly voted to temporarily take control of a so-called ‚Äúwhale‚Äù account ‚Äì the platform‚Äôs largest at around US$20 million ‚Äì to stop the account owner liquidating its positions and driving prices down even further. Together
column28: these factors have caused investor confidence to drain from the sector. The Crypto Fear & Greed Index is almost at an all-time-low of 9/100
column29: which indicates ‚Äúextreme fear‚Äù. The index was at 75/100 when bitcoin reached its November 2021 high. So what does the future hold for this alternative asset class? As can only be expected in the cryptocurrency ecosystem
column30: the range of views is extreme. Some see this market correction as a great time to ‚Äúbuy the dip‚Äù. Others believe this is the end of the party for cryptocurrencies. Resolute bitcoiners can always find positive signs in the market and many use on-chain metrics (trading signals based on data gleaned from public blockchain transactions) to determine good times to buy. Recently
column31: popular metrics including market value to realised value (MVRV ‚Äì a ratio showing current versus average coin prices) suggest bitcoin is about to start an accumulation period based on past history. On the other hand
column32: this may be an indication of confirmation bias as investors search for signals that confirm their beliefs. Others argue this is just one more instance in a long line of bursting cryptocurrency bubbles ‚Äì a typical crypto market cycle. Comparisons with the dotcom crash of 2000 have been rife in the market
column33: but crypto enthusiasts argue the basic premise of dotcom stocks was correct ‚Äì in that the internet was the future. They believe the same is true of bitcoin
column34: predicting that the sector will recover. Economists have studied bubbles for centuries
column35: however
column36: and evidence shows many assets never recover nominal price highs after the market bubble bursts. Some of these economists
column37: including former US secretary of labor Robert Reich
column38: have equated cryptocurrencies to Ponzi schemes that
column39: unless regulated
column40: will go the way of all such schemes and eventually collapse. Certainly
column41: the vision of cryptocurrencies as a decentralised asset available on a peer-to-peer network with no barriers to entry goes against recent actions such as the freezing of withdrawals by some platforms. These moves will not go down well with crypto-enthusiasts. Further
column42: the increased correlation of cryptocurrencies to other asset classes is diminishing their value as a diversification tool
column43: while growing interest in Central Bank Digital Currencies threatens to further erode crypto‚Äôs attractiveness to its core investors. Cryptocurrencies also face challenges around energy use
column44: privacy and security. It is not clear if these issues can be solved without eroding the elements that made cryptocurrencies popular in the first place. The recent US launch of a short Bitcoin ETF
column45: which enables investors to gain from declines in the bitcoin price
column46: will allow investors to hedge their positions and trade against bitcoin. Investing in cryptocurrencies is like riding a rollercoaster with large appreciations followed by sudden dips. Volatility is endemic
column47: bubbles and crashes are commonplace
column48: and there are divisive opinions on environmental
column49: ethical and social benefits. The major correction in this market has tested the will of even the most avid crypto-enthusiast. Buckle up because this story is not over yet.::2022-06-22T13:36:33Z::Binance

column2: government prosecutors find that exploiting code is a crime. CoinDesk reached out to several experts in the Ethereum community to get their views on the case.::The U.S. Department of Justice charged two brothers with orchestrating an attack on Ethereum trading bots
column3: charging them with conspiracy to commit wire fraud
column4: wire fraud and conspiracy to commit money laundering. In essence
column5: the brothers found a way to target bots that were frontrunning transactions in a process called maximal extractable value
column6: or MEV
column7: which refers to the amount of money that can be bled out of the block production process by ordering transactions. Note: The views expressed in this column are those of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of CoinDesk

column12: which is partially why so many in the crypto community have rushed to denounce the DOJ‚Äôs complaint. However
column13: this is hardly a Robinhood situation
column14: where two brothers
column15: Anton and James Peraire-Bueno
column16: of Bedford
column17: Massachusetts
column18: were stealing from the rich to give to the poor. As indicated by the DOJ‚Äôs filing
column19: the brothers brought in approximately $25 million in at least eight separate transactions in what
column20: according to the DOJ
column21: was a highly orchestrated and premeditated plot. They set up shell companies and searched for ways to safely launder funds to avoid detection. The highly technical complaint spells out the process by which the exploit occurred
column22: which the DOJ calls ‚Äúthe very first of its kind.‚Äù ‚ÄúThey used a flaw in MEV boost to push invalid signatures to preview bundles. That gives an unfair advantage via an exploit
column23: ‚Äù former employee of the Ethereum Foundation and Flashbots Hudson Jameson told CoinDesk in an interview. Jameson added that the Peraire-Bueno brothers were also running their own validator while extracting MEV
column24: which violates something of a gentleman‚Äôs agreement in MEV circles. ‚ÄúNo one else in the MEV ecosystem was doing both of those things at once that we know of
column25: ‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúThey did more than just play by both the codified and pinky promise rules of MEV extraction.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt's not some kind of robin hood story as they didn't return the money to people MEVers extracted it from
column26: ‚Äù pseudonymous researcher Banteg said. At a more technical level
column27: the brothers were able to exploit an open-source built by MEV firm Flashbots called mev-boost that gave them an unequal view into how MEV bots were ordering transactions. (Mev-boost is an open-source protocol that allows different actors to compete to ‚Äúbuild‚Äù the most valuable blocks by ordering transactions.) ‚ÄúHaving access to the block body allowed the malicious proposer to extract transactions from the stolen block and use them in their own block where it could exploit those transactions. In particular

column29: ‚Äù according to a Flashbots‚Äô post-mortem in 2023. In particular
column30: and central to the DOJ‚Äôs case

column32: and did

column1: 191::https://blockworks.co/news/biggest-blockchain-developments-2023::Blockworks::article::3 of the biggest blockchain tech developments in 2023::Protocols continued to build in the blockchain space this past year despite a tumultuous 2022.::Protocols continued to build in the blockchain space this past year despite a tumultuous 2022 Google‚Äôs head of strategy and Web3 Rich Widmann | Permissionless II by Blockworks The crypto ecosystem has achieved an array of major technology milestones over the past year. Despite a series of unfortunate events in 2022 ‚Äî with the collapse of the Terra ecosystem
column2: and then later the bankruptcy of Sam Bankman-Fried‚Äôs FTX ‚Äî the blockchain tech space proved resilient in 2023. In particular
column3: we‚Äôve seen developments in the infrastructure and technology sectors with new innovations designed to make blockchains faster
column4: more secure and private. This year marked the launch of a series of zero-knowledge (zk) rollups. First
column5: we saw the launch of zkSync Era
column6: followed closely by Polygon‚Äôs zkEVM
column7: later Linea
column8: and more recently
column9: the =nil; Foundation ‚Äî just to name a few. Rollups share the same goal: make blockchains operate more efficiently by reducing the amount of block space needed to make a transaction by executing more transactions off-chain. This will
column10: as a consequence
column11: also reduce gas fees and fixed costs. Zero-knowledge rollups
column12: in this particular case
column13: are not only able to perform off-chain executions
column14: but they are also able to determine if the information is accurately executed without disclosing the information on the mainnet. This differs from optimistic rollups
column15: which automatically presume that information is accurate and rely on fraud proofs to challenge suspicious transactions. It is important to note that more work still needs to be done to ensure zkRollups are completely decentralized and permissionless. Existing zero-knowledge technology is subject to upgradability risks. These risks refer to whether or not a blockchain can be upgraded or subject to changes ‚Äî with blockchains being more secure if they can not be upgraded. Blockchain interoperability also made some impressive improvements this year. From the introduction of Chainlink‚Äôs CCIP to LayerZero‚Äôs recent partnership with Google Cloud and JPMorgan
column16: cross-chain interoperability protocol teams are actively working on connecting various private and public blockchains. Blockchain interoperability protocols enable smart contracts across different blockchain networks to communicate with each other and facilitate the transfer of liquidity. This is typically achieved through burning tokens in the smart contract of a source chain and then minting new
column17: corresponding tokens on a destination chain. Another way to transfer tokens is through bridging
column18: where tokens are locked on a source chain and then minted natively on the destination chain. Such tools can enable users of various blockchains to seamlessly swap
column19: lend and stake their tokens across various ecosystems for a small gas fee. To bring more liquidity on-chain
column20: developers real-world asset (RWA) protocols are also looking at ways these assets could serve as collateral through tokenization. RWAs in the space could include assets such as cash
column21: gold
column22: real estate and US treasury bonds
column23: for example. One of the most well-known RWAs today would be stablecoins ‚Äî like Circle‚Äôs USDC and Tether‚Äôs USDT
column24: which are widely used across DeFi protocols. Some of the protocols behind on-chain financing include Centrifuge

column1: 194::https://theconversation.com/stablecoin-volatility-shows-an-urgent-need-for-regulation-to-protect-consumers-182886::The Conversation::article::Stablecoin volatility shows an urgent need for regulation to protect consumers::Uncertainty is affecting what used to be the safer end of the market.::Some cryptocurrencies have always been fairly volatile
column2: with values soaring or plunging within a short space of time. So for the more cautious investor
column3: ‚Äústablecoins‚Äù were considered the sensible place to go. As the name implies
column4: they are designed to be a steadier and safer bet. At the moment though
column5: that stability is proving hard to find. The value of one of the most popular stablecoins
column6: Terra (also known as UST)
column7: has fluctuated wildly in the last few days
column8: before dropping dramatically ‚Äì and is yet to recover. Before the crash
column9: Terra was in the top 10 cryptoassets
column10: with a value of over US$18.7 billion. At the time of writing
column11: this had collapsed to less than US$7 billion. Investors have taken to social media to lament this development. Some spoke of lost life savings and the devastating impact of the currency‚Äôs collapse. And they are right to be worried. The impact of volatility in the stablecoin arena should not be underestimated and could destabilise the entire sector. For in theory
column12: stablecoins are supposed to offer the transactional benefits of more traditional cryptoassets (such as Bitcoin) but with a predictably stable worth. Many stablecoins are backed by other assets (typically the US dollar) or commodities (often gold) and involve the stablecoin provider buying ‚Äì and then holding ‚Äì the equivalent amount of their chosen asset to ensure the coin remains stable. So while the value of the underlying asset might increase or decrease
column13: the value of the stablecoin should at least remain at a consistent ratio with whatever underpins it. But ‚Äúalgorithmic stablecoins‚Äù like Terra work differently. Terra holds no reserve asset or commodity
column14: and instead is meant to hold its value using an algorithm
column15: which is designed to maintain a balance between the stablecoin and a partner coin (a more traditional cryptocurrency). In this case Terra is tied to a partner coin called Luna ‚Äì and the value of Luna has crashed. Its value is now less than US$0.06 having been trading at around US$82.00 just seven days earlier. In a climate where the value of Terra and Luna are both drastically declining
column16: the algorithm cannot solve the issue of decreasing faith in the paired currencies ‚Äì and the stabilisation feature simply does not work. As a result
column17: fear kicks in and more people sell
column18: just like a traditional bank run
column19: where there is mass withdrawal of funds and sudden drastic loss in value. Stablecoins backed by assets tend to avoid this
column20: due to the long term steady value of their peg which builds consumer confidence. But they have issues too. Tether
column21: a coin pegged to the US dollar
column22: has had bumps in the road amid questions over whether the company which issues the coins hold the reserves it claims to have. And in recent days Tether too has seen its value fall. All of this undermines the basic premise of these coins ‚Äì that they will remain stable. Customers choose to buy them to either shield against volatility in traditional crypto markets until they rise again
column23: or to use them as a more traditional account (like a regular bank account) and take advantage of the benefits they offer with regard to speed
column24: cost
column25: and ease of international transactions. But investors with their funds in Terra have seen their savings drop by around half. The fact it has still not stabilised does little to alleviate worries. In simple terms
column26: the potential for a cryptocurrency crisis is very real. This is why the approach of governments worldwide needs to change. While plenty has been said about regulation in the UK and the US
column27: there has been little meaningful action. If they fail to act
column28: it will be difficult to advocate the use of stablecoins if they continue to expose consumers to the very volatility and risk they are supposed to avoid. The time for allowing the sector freedom to innovate seems to have passed. Regulation is essential ‚Äì to offer consumer protection
column29: and ban excessively risky practices ‚Äì if the potential of stablecoins is to be realised. That potential is something that many feel could revolutionise the global economy
column30: speeding up transactions
column31: reducing costs and increasing transparency. But allowing the sector the opportunity to innovate should not come at the expense of people‚Äôs savings. If withdrawals persist
column32: it will test both the stability of a particular stablecoin
column33: and more broadly
column34: whether the entire sector has a future. One stablecoin struggling is bad news. But two or more could be catastrophic for customer confidence.::2022-05-12T14:16:25Z::Crypto regulation
