column1: 232::https://www.coindesk.com/opinion/2024/05/13/why-for-some-crypto-is-the-defining-political-issue-of-our-times/::CoinDesk::article::Why
column2: for Some
column3: Crypto Is the Defining Political Issue of Our Times::It‚Äôd be foolish for people to vote against their own interests.::With all due respect to Molly Jane Zuckerman and Jeff Albus
column4: the co-authors of a recent Blockworks column discounting the idea of voting for pro-crypto politicians in the upcoming election in the U.S.
column5: voting your conscience is a good thing. Despite the headline (‚ÄúOnly a fool would vote on crypto alone‚Äù)
column6: the piece was fairly measured ‚Äì but it certainly struck a nerve. Note: The views expressed in this column are those of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of CoinDesk
column7: Inc. or its owners and affiliates. This is an excerpt from The Node newsletter
column8: a daily roundup of the most pivotal crypto news on CoinDesk and beyond. You can subscribe to get the full newsletter here. ‚ÄúVoting for a candidate you would not otherwise support
column9: simply because they favor the deregulation of a sector in which you hold a profit motive
column10: is a compromise that you should not make
column11: ‚Äù editors Zuckerman and Albus wrote. They certainly aren‚Äôt the first to express this sentiment. Fortune editor Jeff John Roberts has argued that crypto‚Äôs increasing alignment with Trump supporters like Sen. Tom Emmer is a bad deal. While all these folks are right to some extent that political support for crypto is often more about peoples‚Äô bags rather than a moral crusade
column12: it is undeniable that crypto is an increasingly relevant political issue. And for some
column13: it is the defining issue of our times. Crypto isn‚Äôt just an investment opportunity
column14: it‚Äôs a movement
column15: a philosophy and a way of life ‚Äì and there are true believers. Zuckerman and Albus‚Äô issue is nominally about crypto becoming a ‚Äúsingle-issue vote
column16: ‚Äù whether cast in favor of Democrat or Republican candidates ‚Äì but in reality
column17: the whole conversation they tapped into is really about whether to vote for Trump. For some crypto supporters
column18: the issue is existential; another four years of Biden means more wanton regulation by enforcement
column19: more gridlock preventing actual crypto legislation and more anti-crypto rhetoric coming from the highest political office. During President Biden‚Äôs reign
column20: U.S. legislators and regulators have become increasingly hostile to crypto
column21: and their actions are undeniably having an outsized impact on the direction of an entire global industry. Just last week
column22: for instance
column23: re-staking platform EigenLayer
column24: called one of the most important blockchain innovations since the launch of Ethereum a decade ago
column25: was heavily criticized for designing a highly restrictive airdrop. But
column26: under the current regulatory regime
column27: it was essentially EigenLayer‚Äôs only move unless it wanted to invite a U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission lawsuit. It is true that crypto has bipartisan support
column28: however it is clear (and frankly has been for years) that crypto gets more love from Republicans. Politico reports that a critical vote ‚Äì ‚Äúthe first time a full chamber of Congress has taken up a big crypto policy bill‚Äù ‚Äì is essentially dead on arrival with a Democrat controlled House and Senate. Meanwhile
column29: the most vocal supporters of crypto in office today are Republicans
column30: figures like Sens. Emmer and Cynthia Lummis. So can you really blame people like Ryan Selkis
column31: Mike Dudas or Mark Cuban for thinking if they want decent crypto policy in the U.S.
column32: the industry has to align itself with Republicans? Critics might be right in saying that former President Donald Trump
column33: who gave a ringing endorsement of crypto at a Mar-a-Lago dinner last week
column34: only recently took a shine to crypto because he‚Äôs made millions selling NFTs or because it‚Äôs another way for him to paint President Biden as out of touch. But these moments count. At a time when the entire U.S. crypto industry feels like it‚Äôs under assault by the government
column35: it is likely a welcome feeling knowing someone with as much influence as Trump is willing to speak out in support. See also: Will Biden Get the Final Say Over a Controversial Crypto Rule? | Opinion I understand that many people think crypto‚Äôs vote being cast for Trump is like drinking from a poisoned chalice. After all
column36: when in office
column37: Trump‚Äôs cabinet tried (and failed) to push through emergency rules that would have banned ‚Äúself-hosted wallets
column38: ‚Äù i.e. exactly what makes crypto a viable technology in the first place. There is no guarantee that if reelected Trump would actually be any more favorable to crypto than Biden is currently; and it seems highly unlikely that either candidate fully understands or appreciates why crypto is technologically potent. I understand that
column39: ideally
column40: voters should care more about things like abortion
column41: environmental and immigration policy than crypto. (Most probably do.) I understand Zuckerman and Albus‚Äô distaste for Trump
column42: his sexual assault charges
column43: alleged fraud and election denialism. I understand why
column44: optically
column45: crypto casting itself as conservative is a dubious proposition
column46: an expedient way to get 40+% of the population to turn their minds against it
column47: as Laura Shin astutely pointed out. See also: Crypto Is an Election Issue This Year. Is That a Good Thing? | Opinion But I also understand why figures like Selkis are championing crypto into a political cause. Actually
column48: they are simply noticing that crypto already was a partisan issue and acting in accordance. It‚Äôs common to hear that because blockchains strive to be ‚Äúcredibly neutral‚Äù that the industry itself is apolitical
column49: but that simply isn't true. Crypto is a check on the government; it is and always has been a political project. As I wrote in 2021: ‚ÄúIf Bitcoin solved the climate crisis
column50: it would be through successful
column51: freer markets ‚Äì not progressive planning. If Bitcoin expands access to basic financial services
column52: it could never solve economic inequality ‚Äì you cannot redistribute early Bitcoiners‚Äô massive holdings without destroying the system‚Äôs technologically protected property rights. If Bitcoin prevents war by diminishing the power of the state
column53: it will also dismantle the progressive welfare state.‚Äù To be clear: I‚Äôm not arguing for anyone to vote in any particular way. Frankly
column54: I agree that ideally crypto wouldn‚Äôt be an election issue. I wish it weren‚Äôt politicized. But crypto exists in the context of all other issues
column55: and is currently being affected by politics. And it‚Äôs perfectly natural that people who think about and use crypto everyday would elevate it as the most important issue ‚Äì especially considering that it‚Äôs not only a philosophy but an investment. It is unclear why anyone would suggest people vote against their interests. For some
column56: crypto is a microcosm of all else that‚Äôs important ‚Äì because in the end
column57: it‚Äôs all about letting people determine for themselves what to value. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column1: 233::https://beincrypto.com/boosting-ownership-and-interoperability-in-blockchain-gaming/::BeInCrypto::article::Fostering Ownership and Interoperability in the Blockchain Gaming Ecosystem::Here
column2: we discuss how blockchain gaming is transforming the gaming industry by enhancing ownership and interoperability.::We use cookies to improve your experience. The once-niched gaming world and its very peculiar demography are completely metamorphosing and adapting to blockchain technology and its immense potential. While ‚Äúplay-to-earn‚Äù models have understandably garnered the most attention
column3: the impact of blockchain reaches far beyond mere financial incentives. A paradigm shift is what we are witnessing. Blockchain goes beyond financial incentives
column4: enabling ownership
column5: interoperability
column6: trust
column7: transparency
column8: and impactful community-driven development. It is no longer fancy to own cartridges and controllers because the future of gaming is being built on the blockchain
column9: and this is an adventure beyond what any pixelated screen could ever offer you. It isn‚Äôt about grinding for gaming assets
column10: it‚Äôs about owning them
column11: wielding them across gaming worlds
column12: and reshaping the way gameplay is experienced. In this article
column13: we‚Äôll delve into the diverse ways blockchain technology is revolutionizing the gaming industry
column14: unlocking captivating possibilities for players
column15: developers
column16: and the industry. Remember the days when you played games dedicatedly and meticulously upgraded your avatar only to see it disappear when the game servers shut down? That feeling of fleeting ownership is something blockchain-powered gaming has erased. Blockchain‚Äôs immutable ledger empowers players with verifiable ownership of virtual items. Imagine wielding a legendary sword in a game that you can transform from just pixels and excitement into a prized possession
column17: imbued with digital ownership and tradable on decentralized marketplaces. Just like that
column18: your virtual possessions hold real value
column19: fostering a sense of pride and investment in your digital identity. This shift towards true ownership is transforming the industry
column20: with the market for utility-driven Non-Fungible Tokens (NFTs) estimated to grow by 35% to $13.6 billion by 2027. Blockchain technology also enables a true sense of scarcity via the creation of scarce assets represented as NFTs. The limited supply of NFTs ensures their rarity and value
column21: just like limited editions of comic books or games. Imagine owning a unique spaceship in a space exploration game
column22: knowing only a handful of others ‚Äîor none ‚Äî exist in the entire game‚Äôs ecosystem. This scarcity adds a layer of excitement and exclusivity
column23: fueling a thriving digital economy where players can truly own and monetize their in-game achievements. Games like Citizen Conflict are a good example of such NFT-based game model. This model allows players to interact with unique digital assets
column24: which demonstrates the broader trend of integrating blockchain technology into gaming to enhance ownership and value. Blockchain-based games are shattering boundaries. They are allowing players to move their assets and achievements across different platforms. This was unthinkable some ten years ago. But in an era of interoperability
column25: you can now flourish in a vast interconnected ecosystem of games with the assets you own. Imagine utilizing resources you‚Äôve gathered in a thriving virtual farm to build your dream home in a bustling cyberpunk metropolis. What used to be a fantasy is now reality. One fueled by blockchain technology. With the help of standardized protocols and tokenized assets
column26: different block-based games can connect and interact
column27: creating a seamless experience for players and unlocking a universe of possibilities. Interoperability fosters a richer
column28: more interconnected gaming ecosystem
column29: breaking down barriers and creating exciting possibilities for collaboration and innovation. With the global blockchain gaming market projected to grow from $154.46 billion in 2023 to $614.91 billion in 2030 at a CAGR of 21.8% during 2023-2030
column30: interoperability is poised to play a vital part in this market. Traditionally
column31: game development has been an exclusive club where wealthy technology companies play. The blockchain has decentralized the field and empowers independent developers and communities with innovative tools and funding mechanisms. Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs) allow passionate groups to collectively fund and govern game development
column32: fostering greater transparency and shared ownership. Imagine a community funding and actively participating in the development of a unique game
column33: fueled by collective passion and the blockchain‚Äôs inherent transparency. In March 2023
column34: the value of DAOs reached a record $25.1 billion. This immense value is paving the way for diverse and innovative experiences driven by the power of community. Beyond funding
column35: this democratization empowers independent minds to bring their visions to life. It creates a future where anyone with a spark of creativity can join the game development revolution and improve on the models already existing like play-to-earn
column36: NFTs
column37: etc. We are fast moving away from the era of blindly trusting in developers. That era is being replaced by an era of transparency and trust built on the immutable foundation of blockchain technology. The blockchain transparently displays every random number generation algorithm and every governance decision. It is this transparency that the blockchain is bringing to the gaming industry. With every action and transaction verifiable on the blockchain
column38: players can gain unprecedented insight into the inner workings of the games they play. This eliminates concerns about manipulation and pay-to-win mechanics
column39: fostering a level playing field where skill reigns supreme. Players now no longer have to blindly accept hidden mechanics. They can actively participate in shaping the game‚Äôs future through on-chain governance proposals and transparent decision-making processes. This collaborative approach proves how the blockchain paves the way for a gaming future built on trust
column40: transparency
column41: and empowered communities. Beyond just grinding and finding excitement
column42: blockchain opens doors to innovative play models beyond just play-to-earn. Guilds are forming and pooling resources to tackle challenging in-game tasks as seen during the period when Axie Infinity was a prominent game in the industry. Players can get exclusive access to content or early game participation through subscription models. Tokenized economies can reward players for contributing to the game world. These diverse models cater to different player preferences and create exciting new ways to engage with games. The blockchain
column43: especially its integration into the gaming industry
column44: is still in its early stages. This means that challenges remain
column45: and there are scalability
column47: and user education hurdles to overcome. Yet
column48: the potential is undeniable. By fostering ownership

column1: 237::https://theconversation.com/bitcoins-high-energy-consumption-is-a-concern-but-it-may-be-a-price-worth-paying-106282::The Conversation::article::Bitcoin‚Äôs high energy consumption is a concern ‚Äì but it may be a price worth paying::Bitcoin may have a large carbon footprint
column2: but cleaner digital currencies aren‚Äôt going to prevent an environmental disaster.::Bitcoin recently turned ten years old. In that time
column3: it has proved revolutionary because it ignores the need for modern money‚Äôs institutions to verify payments. Instead
column4: Bitcoin relies on cryptographic techniques to prove identity and authenticity. However
column5: the price to pay for all of this innovation is a high carbon footprint
column6: created by Bitcoin mining. Fundamental to that mining process is a peer-to-peer network of computers
column7: referred to as validators
column8: who perform Proof of Work. In essence
column9: this involves computers solving computationally-intensive cryptographic puzzles that prove blocks of transactions
column10: which are recorded in a public asset ledger
column11: known as a blockchain. This ledger is publicly viewable by all computers
column12: which helps the system achieve consensus in an unreliable network of participants. Validators are called miners because the computer
column13: or node
column14: that successfully validates one of those blocks is rewarded with ‚Äúmined‚Äù Bitcoin. Thus mining is also the process by which Bitcoin adds new coins to the network. But these processes consume a vast amount of power. In my 2016 article
column15: Socialism and the Blockchain
column16: I estimated Bitcoin mining‚Äôs annual energy use at 3.38 TeraWatt hours (TWh)
column17: which I equated to the total 2014 annual consumption of Jamaica. Recent estimates show the currency‚Äôs annual consumption rising exponentially
column18: currently reaching an incredible 55TWh. Indeed
column19: a new paper in Nature Sustainability suggests that the energy costs of mining cryptocurrencies exceed the costs of mining physical metals. Furthermore
column20: the paper estimates that Bitcoin emitted between 3m and 13m metric tonnes CO‚ÇÇ in the first half of 2018. A team in Hawaii even suppose that
column21: if Bitcoin‚Äôs adoption continues to rise
column22: within a couple of decades
column23: such emissions could help push global warming above 2¬∞C. However
column24: both the study in Nature and the team in Hawaii make assumptions about the means of energy generation. In the light of the recent disturbing UN 1.5¬∞C Report
column25: humanity would be wise to act on the recommendation for an ‚Äúunprecedented shift in energy systems‚Äù. The hope is that such a shift towards large-scale renewable energy does occur
column26: thus invalidating the assumptions made in those papers. Nevertheless
column27: concerns over Bitcoin‚Äôs energy consumption remain
column28: so Ethereum
column29: another cryptocurrency
column30: is investigating a more energy efficient consensus algorithm known as Proof of Stake. This method differs from Proof of Work because miners on this network use their economic stake to prove transactions and therefore
column31: they are not performing energy intensive calculations. That introduces some complications ‚Äì not least
column32: how to ensure that people in this network act honestly
column33: as they would have nothing to lose by behaving dishonestly? Ethereum‚Äôs proposed solution is to introduce penalties through measures such as penalising miners for simultaneously producing blocks on two versions of the blockchain. After all
column34: only one of those blockchains is valid. Bitcoin‚Äôs Proof of Work overcomes such problems implicitly because it includes natural penalties since miners have to expend energy to prove transactions. In economic game theory
column35: a Nash Equilibrium is said to be reached when a system stabilises because no one gains by changing strategy from that which produces the stable state. Since Bitcoin rewards are given to miners only if their blocks help form the valid Bitcoin blockchain
column36: the most profitable outcome
column37: or the Nash Equilibrium
column38: is for each miner to act in consensus with the majority. As a result
column39: Bitcoin‚Äôs Proof of Work algorithm has proven effective
column40: despite the excessive energy consumption. In essence
column41: my work looks at whether blockchains are a rebuttal to the hierarchies of capitalism. If Bitcoin promotes a way of organising that does not rely on capitalist consumption
column42: might that indirectly drive down society‚Äôs energy use and help lessen its environmental impact? After all
column43: consider the recent alarming WWF report
column44: which all but blamed capitalism for the dramatic decline in wildlife populations. We need alternatives. Perhaps
column45: then
column47: as an alternative to capitalism
column48: means its energy use is a price worth paying? That argument holds some weight if it drives down consumption in other areas of society because Bitcoin mining is not the primary driver behind climate change. However
column49: even then
column50: given the urgency of environmental degradation
column51: if we continue to produce energy in a manner that creates so much warming CO‚ÇÇ
column52: that argument may provide scant consolation. Perhaps alternative consensus schemes
column53: such as Ethereum‚Äôs Proof of Stake
column54: provide part of the solution. However
column55: Bitcoin or not
column56: if humankind is to avoid climate catastrophe
column57: we need to take urgent action and find solutions that produce clean
column58: sustainable energy. If we do that
column59: humanity will benefit
column60: and as a by-product
column61: so will Bitcoin.::2018-11-07T12:30:02Z::Bitcoin

column1: 238::https://www.coindesk.com/opinion/2024/05/13/ai-agents-will-drive-the-next-wave-of-crypto-adoption/::CoinDesk::article::AI Agents Will Drive the Next Wave of Crypto Adoption::Crypto agents are here already and they will get more and more advanced until we use them to run our financial lives
column2: says Luke Saunders
column3: CTO at Delphi Labs. How we get there::In the 2000s
column4: we stopped going into bank branches and started banking online. In 10 years time
column5: do you think we will still be managing our finances this way? I predict today‚Äôs online financial tools will soon look archaic as we increasingly manage our finances via agents - intelligent bots that conduct financial operations on our behalf. Luke Saunders is a Partner at Delphi Ventures and CTO at Delphi Labs. That may sound far-fetched
column6: but agents are already here. A liquidation bot is an agent. An arbitrage bot is an agent. The person who created it can chill on their sofa while the agent runs in the background making them money. They are niche but there are thousands of such things performing on-chain actions today on behalf of others. Bots/agents are not people. The world of aesthetically pleasing apps with nice buttons to click does not work for them. TradFi provides APIs
column7: but these are often half baked
column8: closed-source
column9: with limited documentation and inconsistent with each other. It‚Äôs very difficult for an agent (or anyone honestly) to figure out how to use them. As I wrote in a recent post on X
column10: while crypto UX is cumbersome for humans
column11: its transparent
column12: open-source
column13: and programmable nature is absolutely perfect for agents. Code is a first class citizen here. Everything an agent needs to figure out how to achieve a goal ‚Äî the source code and the data ‚Äî is public. Half-baked TradFi APIs can't compete with this. The best agents will be built on the best platform and there is no better platform than crypto. This isn‚Äôt our reality yet
column14: but there is a path to get us there. Let‚Äôs jump back to the agents that exist today and explore how we get from here to there. The agents mentioned earlier (liquidation bots
column15: etc) meet the definition of an agent
column16: being autonomous software entities
column17: but they are still very basic. They are usually coded specifically for a single
column18: narrow task and without any ChatGPT-like interface to receive instructions and deliver feedback. Big firms like Jump and GSR are able to build more complex systems able to autonomously move money around and handle problems to some extent. But these companies have a lot of money and big teams of devs. It‚Äôs not so feasible for the little guy. Technology always progresses to lower the barrier
column19: though. What previously took a computer the size of a house and a team of scientists is later achievable by a teenager and a phone. As AI becomes more prevalent
column20: the nuts and bolts of which smart contract functions to call
column21: or comprehending the data within the contract‚Äôs state
column22: can be abstracted away. This leaves the creator/owner able to give much higher level instructions while the agent figures out how to execute them. We can see today that LLMs like GPT-4 are already capable of understanding the intent behind a user‚Äôs message
column23: and reason intelligently about how to respond
column24: while at the same time having read all of the text on the internet to inform its answer. So it‚Äôs not a big leap to imagine a text-based interface to an agent that has read all relevant crypto media
column25: ingested and understood all the data from all the blockchains
column26: AND has the ability to execute actions on-chain. Think about what people in crypto are spending all their time doing today: The airdrop hunter who is spending all day finding promising new projects which seem like they might do an airdrop
column27: guessing which actions might be rewarded and then doing them. An agent can do all that. The meme hunter who is following some internal algo for finding new meme-coins with signs of cultish community
column28: then buying them
column29: then selling when interest seems to wane. An agent can do all that. But more importantly consider how the new AI agent interface paradigm simplifies the basics of finance: You: ‚ÄúI have 100
column30: 000 USDC. Get me the best low risk yield you can find. I need instant access to it so don‚Äôt lock it up for more than a week.‚Äù Agent: ‚ÄúNo problem. I recommend an initial distribution of 50% in Aave
column31: 20% in Ethena
column32: 20% in X and 10% in Y. I will monitor rates and watch for changes in their risk levels
column33: rebalancing as necessary.‚Äù You: ‚ÄúSounds good
column34: do it.‚Äù People wonder how MetaMask will ever get unseated
column35: or how frontends can be decentralized. Perhaps the answer is in the future we don‚Äôt need frontends anyway
column36: and MetaMask will be replaced by your in-agent wallet. TradFi agents will exist
column37: but agents built on crypto will be better. And that‚Äôs why this is important: if agents become more and more common as I expect they will
column38: and crypto agents offer a better experience for users
column39: then this drives more and more users
column40: activity and value on-chain. Crypto sometimes feels like a solution searching for a problem
column41: but maybe it just happens to be the perfect financial system for the machines. Note: The views expressed in this column are those of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of CoinDesk

column1: 239::https://beincrypto.com/how-protocols-are-interconnected-on-the-blockchain/::BeInCrypto::article::How Protocols Are Interconnected on the Blockchain::Even though the blockchain industry is still in its nascent stages
column2: plenty of sub-niches and narratives have come to the fore.::We use cookies to improve your experience. With over ten years of investing and building in fast-growing technology products and the blockchain industry
column3: I‚Äôve come to understand that to stay ahead
column4: providing innovative solutions that can affect the industry and the world at large. I should know. I have invested in many companies with this characteristic. Even though the blockchain industry is still in its nascent stages
column5: plenty of sub-niches and narratives have come to the fore. These technologies are reshaping the blockchain landscape
column6: and in this article
column7: we will delve into this subject
column8: taking you through some of the niches that are revolutionizing their respective areas and how interconnected they are. This sector has seen consistent growth because of its importance to the entire industry. Data privacy and security are vital in today‚Äôs blockchain world for obvious reasons. The risks associated with data breaches and cyber-attacks have increased as personal
column9: financial
column10: and confidential information gets increasingly stored and transferred digitally. In 2023
column11: the global average cost of a data breach reached a record high of $4.45 million. This rise in these attacks can be attributed to how the blockchain is structured. It is a ledger containing a record of all transactions taking place on a network. A key feature of blockchain technology is its immutability. Once a block (containing a unique code known as a hash) gets added to the chain
column12: it can neither be altered nor deleted. This provides data stored on the blockchain with tamper-proof security. However
column13: despite what seems to be an airtight layer to the blockchain
column14: some bad actors have succeeded in exploiting the system. In the fight to counter these blockchain exploitations and hackings
column15: privacy-focused protocols have become popular. Think of them as installing a sophisticated alarm system for your digital assets
column16: utilizing clever incentives and independent reputation systems to deter unwanted intrusions. Because we operate in an industry where data breaches cost projects millions
column17: the importance of privacy-focused companies cannot be overstated. COIIN Network Protocol‚Äîthe parent company of Raiinmaker‚Äîis a good example of a company playing in the privacy landscape. Scalability in blockchain refers to the speed of transactions. The ability to support high transaction throughput is both critical and a significant challenge for the blockchain and cryptocurrency industry. And this makes it a very essential aspect in the future growth of blockchain. Achieving an improved level of scalability comes at the cost of reduced decentralization and to a large extent
column18: security. As you note these
column19: it is also important to note that scalability is vital in helping blockchain networks compete effectively with conventional platforms. The question here should now be: how possible is it to provide effective blockchain scalability solutions that do not affect the core tenets of blockchain which are decentralization and security? I present to you layer-1 solutions. Also known as the ‚Äúfirst layer
column20: ‚Äù it requires changes in the code base of the blockchain network. One reason they‚Äôre dubbed on-chain scaling solutions. They focus on improving the main features and characteristics of the blockchain network like increasing the block size limit or reducing the block verification time. Ethereum has a transaction speed of around 15 Transactions Per Second (TPS)
column21: and Bitcoin is around 7TPS. Both blockchains now have scalability solutions in Sharding and Lightening network respectively
column22: but other solutions are popping up. A popular one is the layer-1 platform Self Chain. It is a Modular Intent-Centric Access Layer-1 blockchain and keyless wallet infrastructure service using MPC-TSS/AA for multi-chain Web3 access. This sector has changed the way the world sees gaming forever. I say this because it is our reality now. Play-to-earn games are a set of blockchain-powered games that allow players to earn in-game rewards represented by Non-Fungible Tokens (NFTs) and tokens. These rewards have real-world value and players can earn them by progressing through the different levels of a game. The in-game assets earned can be weapons
column23: tokens
column24: lands
column25: and skins. Players can trade or transfer these assets on open marketplaces in exchange for real fiat currencies. The gaming industry is huge and boasts an impressive number of people actively participating in it. There were over 3 billion gamers in the industry in 2021. This number of people actively engaged in games helped the industry generate hundreds of billions of dollars in revenue. That revenue has been projected to reach $533 billion by 2027. In 2022
column26: the P2E market size was valued at $32.9 billion
column27: and it is expected to grow to $88.6 billion by 2028
column28: at a Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of 17.93%. Some of the best P2E platforms in the industry include Axie Infinity
column29: Creo Engine
column30: The Sandbox
column31: Splinterlands
column32: Decentraland
column33: etc. How we carry out transactions and store data has changed since the advent of blockchain technology. Blockchains have their own standards and set of rules that govern them. In most cases
column34: these are rarely compatible with other chains and have led to an ecosystem where blockchains cannot interact due to their silo-styled operation. A solution to this issue is blockchain bridges. These are known as cross-chain bridges because they allow the transfer of tokens and data from blockchain to blockchain. A benefit of bridging in blockchain is being able to expand the functionality of a chain. This is an important tool for communication among different blockchains. A good example of this would be Dechat Protocol
column35: which prides itself as an open
column36: secure web3 communications protocol that powers decentralized user interactions. The largest asset class in the world
column37: the Real Estate sector is another industry where blockchain technology is having a significant impact. A large portion of the world‚Äôs economic assets and transactions is constituted by commercial real estate. According to the Boston Consulting Group (BCG)
column38: the total size of tokenized illiquid assets
column39: including real estate and natural resources could reach $16.1 trillion by 2030. This proves how big the real estate market is. While traditional real estate investment can be a daunting maze
column40: with high entry barriers and limited accessibility
column41: blockchain technology is slowly demystifying it. Blockchain protocols are now being used to process securities
column42: documents
column43: and accounting
column44: and manage liability. With blockchain technology
column45: you can also own a fraction of a property
column46: which reduces the barrier of entry massively
column47: thereby giving small-scale investors a chance to get into the real estate market. Fractionet is a good example of a protocol currently doing this. While these various niches might seem very distinct
column48: they are all part of the same vibrant ecosystem that‚Äôs the blockchain. The privacy-focused protocol can be used to protect sensitive data used in DeFi transactions‚Äîa technology that backs the entire play-to-earn gaming economy. The scalable blockchain facilitates seamless communication that the bridge encourages. And think of the fractional ownership platform offering investment opportunities fueled by DeFi liquidity. My point is that these projects intertwine
column49: and they create a synergistic ecosystem where innovation thrives. Disclaimer In compliance with the Trust Project guidelines

column1: 242::https://cryptobriefing.com/bluesky-decentralization-dorsey/::Crypto Briefing::article::Jack Dorsey criticizes Bluesky for straying from decentralized ethos::Dorsey advocates for alternative revenue models to counter the flaws of advertising-based social media.::Join the hunt for $12
column3: 000+ in NEXO Tokens! Share this article There‚Äôs always one or more reasons behind a company board member‚Äôs departure. With Jack Dorsey and Bluesky
column4: it‚Äôs all about direction. Speaking with Pirates Wires this week
column5: Bluesky‚Äôs inventor said the company is straying from its original decentralized ethos and resembling a conventional social media app
column6: the type of app he intended to avoid at the beginning. ‚ÄúThis is literally repeating all the mistakes we made as a company. This is not a protocol that‚Äôs truly decentralized. It‚Äôs another app. It‚Äôs another app that‚Äôs just kind of following in Twitter‚Äôs footsteps
column7: but for a different part of the population
column8: ‚Äù Dorsey stated. Dorsey‚Äôs initial vision for Bluesky was to create a social media protocol that could overcome the challenges faced by centralized platforms
column9: such as those he encountered at Twitter (now X). He expected that Bluesky would support free speech and not be beholden to the constraints of a publicly traded company dependent on advertising revenue. However
column10: as Bluesky developed
column11: it began incorporating more traditional corporate elements
column12: including forming a board and seeking venture capital funding. For a person deeply committed to decentralization
column13: it‚Äôs a clear departure from his original goals for the project. ‚ÄúEverything we wanted around decentralization
column14: everything we wanted in terms of an [open-source] protocol
column15: suddenly became a company with VCs and a board. That‚Äôs not what I wanted
column16: that‚Äôs not what I intended to help create
column17: ‚Äù Dorsey remarked. According to him
column18: this shift
column19: combined with a growing emphasis on app development and moderation tools
column20: moved Bluesky away from being a truly decentralized protocol. Commenting on the public perception of Bluesky as ‚Äúanti-Twitter
column21: ‚Äù Dorsey said it was not the foundational intention. Bluesky was meant to be a neutral protocol rather than a direct competitor. Dorsey also noted the limitations of the advertising-based revenue model for social media platforms
column22: which he believes compromises content policies and platform governance. He suggests alternative revenue streams
column23: such as subscriptions and commerce
column24: could provide a more sustainable and less compromising approach. Earlier this week
column25: the team behind Bluesky announced that Dorsey was no longer on the board of directors. At the time
column26: neither Dorsey nor Bluesky commented publicly on the departure. After leaving Bluesky
column27: Dorsey has turned his attention to Nostr
column28: a protocol he considers a more accurate reflection of his decentralized social media aspirations

column1: 243::https://theconversation.com/how-are-bitcoin-cryptowallets-and-blockchain-related-some-jargon-busted-88906::The Conversation::article::How are bitcoin
column2: cryptowallets and blockchain related? Some jargon busted::Using metaphors for cryptocurrencies helps people feel more familiar with the technology. But there‚Äôs a downside ‚Äì we expect it to work just like regular money.::When the bitcoin was first introduced eight years ago
column3: it promised to change payments. People would be able to transact directly with each other
column4: without needing to place their trust in banks ‚Äì but that promise still hasn‚Äôt materialised and adoption of bitcoins is low. We were first told in 2009 that many transactions would be verifiable and validated by the bitcoin protocol. However
column5: as we argued in a recent study
column6: a significant adoption barrier to bitcoin is the lack of usability. Since the inception of cryptocurrency
column7: developers and researchers have been using metaphors to explain bitcoin in a clear effort to help people feel more comfortable with the technology. A secure application for holding bitcoins is dubbed a ‚Äúcryptowallet‚Äù
column8: the trading platforms where people can buy and sell bitcoins are called ‚Äúexchanges‚Äù
column9: and in several locations around the world
column10: ATMs have emerged for bitcoin-based transactions. The production of bitcoins is described as ‚Äúmining‚Äù
column11: but the only similarity between this and mining for gold or valuable gems
column12: is that both processes are very
column13: very difficult to achieve. Finally
column14: bitcoins are called ‚Äúcoins‚Äù
column15: even though they are entirely digital. Using metaphors to refer to these technologies helps people feel more familiar with the technology. But there is also a downside: people expect that the technology can be used as regular money. One could easily believe that
column16: in fact
column17: such ‚Äúcoins‚Äù are stored in a ‚Äúwallet‚Äù
column18: which leads to further misinterpretations: if these are coins
column19: what do they look like? if it‚Äôs real money
column20: how do I get refunds for paying for stuff? and do I get change if I don‚Äôt have the exact amount? But the coins don‚Äôt exist. They are merely entries in a highly secure
column21: very restricted database. There are no wallets
column22: crypto or otherwise. These are either software applications that may or may not connect to the internet
column23: or hardware-based solutions (similar to USB sticks). ATMs can be used to buy and sell coins
column24: but teller machines do not hold ‚Äúcoins‚Äù. And
column25: in the bitcoin world
column26: there are many transactions that can‚Äôt mimic how regular money works. If I pay for something with pound notes and then regret my purchase
column27: I can return the item to the shop and the shop may or may not issue a refund. But the bitcoin protocol doesn‚Äôt allow this. If a transfer of bitcoins has been broadcast to the network
column28: by design that transaction is final. It means that
column29: had I paid for that item with bitcoins
column30: the shop can‚Äôt issue a refund but instead has to process a new payment
column31: or a charge back ‚Äì which incurs additional processing fees. This isn‚Äôt a refund ‚Äì as some money would be deducted from the full amount I originally paid. To support the adoption of bitcoin as an alternative payment
column32: we need to have a system that is cheaper
column33: better and more desirable compared with other forms of payments
column34: such as debit cards. The bitcoin is cheaper
column35: because ‚Äì even when paying by debit or credit cards ‚Äì there is always a fee involved for processing such transactions. Some merchants will pay the fee themselves
column36: or roll this cost over to the consumer
column37: as an extra charge for paying by card. Paying in bitcoins has zero cost or very low cost
column38: subject to how much of a hurry the consumer is in. Everyday transactions in bitcoins are fairly straightforward and security is robust: if I need to pay somebody in bitcoins
column39: I can send the exact amount to that other person‚Äôs bitcoin address (a randomly generated sequence of characters
column40: that changes every time there is a transaction) by confirming it with my unique PIN-like number. The rest is done by the miners (more about which later) who need to verify that the transaction is unique and genuine. Despite these clear advantages
column41: bitcoin‚Äôs desirability factor remains low. And there is little we can do (at least for now) to increase its uptake. Notably
column42: adoption is also affected by trust perceptions. People are more likely to trust the technology if they have a better understanding of how the bitcoin protocol works. This can be achieved without forcing everybody to become an expert in cryptography. What is bitcoin? It‚Äôs one of many cryptocurrencies ‚Äì but the only one that has grabbed the headlines. It is a type of digital currency
column43: created and regulated by a network of thousands of computers (known as peers) using encryption techniques. Because of this
column44: its production is independent from any authority
column45: such as banks and sovereign states ‚Äì and trust in the bitcoin is produced by the technology itself. How does this happen? Meet the blockchain: Simply put
column46: the blockchain is a very restricted database
column47: whose entries are the bitcoin transactions. The blockchain operates as a digital ledger of transactions. Just like regular businesses that keep a record of money coming in and going out
column48: users of the cryptocurrency need to record all bitcoin-based transactions. The difference is that the blockchain is a decentralised and distributed
column49: open-access ledger whose records are permanent and verifiable by the network of peers. So everybody can view past transactions
column50: but nobody can alter them without having the consent of the majority. This means that the blockchain doesn‚Äôt exhibit weaknesses associated with traditional ledgers. The blockchain technology is secure by design. How are bitcoins produced? Through mining
column51: which is undertaken by the peers of the network. The miners are people and organisations that connect their computers in the network to offer processing power
column52: using special software to solve very difficult algorithms
column53: while leveraging the power of advanced computers and graphic cards. In return for their services (creating new bitcoins
column54: authenticating transactions
column55: maintaining the blockchain)
column56: they get rewarded with new bitcoins. Where are bitcoins stored? A cryptowallet ‚Äì which is a software application that stores private keys (code that looks like a very long PIN) ‚Äì is where all bitcoins are stored. These private keys are connected to public keys (code again
column57: but the equivalent would be a bank account). The best way to understand how a cryptowallet works is to think of it
column58: in similar terms
column59: as a secure connection between a person‚Äôs PIN to their bank account
column60: which then allows them to check balances and make payments. The bitcoin hasn‚Äôt become the alternative payment system for consumers that was promised eight years ago. Widespread adoption of the cryptocurrency is hobbled by a number of factors: its reputation is associated far too often with alleged bad boys
column61: and talk of a bubble that‚Äôs about to pop persists even as bitcoin continues to surge. But
column62: above all else
column63: few people can cut through the jargon to understand how it actually works. These perceptions can shift if bitcoin-based transactions become easier to comprehend in a way that will help people build trust in the technology. Instead of replicating old paradigms
column64: bitcoin should be embraced as a fresh new way to pay for stuff.::2017-12-15T13:54:55Z::Bitcoin

column1: 244::https://www.coindesk.com/opinion/2024/05/10/was-sam-bankman-fried-proven-right-about-ftxs-solvency/::CoinDesk::article::Was Sam Bankman-Fried Proven Right About FTX‚Äôs Solvency?::No.::Bankrupt crypto exchange FTX has recovered billions of dollars more than it needs to make the victim‚Äôs of Sam Bankman-Fried‚Äôs theft whole
column2: according to the latest bankruptcy plan announced on Tuesday. Customers will receive $1.18 for every dollar‚Äôs worth of crypto assets they held on the exchange at the time of collapse in November 2022
column3: plus interest. This result ‚Äì rare in the world of bankruptcies
column4: where creditors typically receive pennies on the dollar ‚Äì has raised a poignant question for some: Was Sam Bankman-Fried right all along? Note: The views expressed in this column are those of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of CoinDesk
column5: Inc. or its owners and affiliates. This is an excerpt from The Node newsletter
column6: a daily roundup of the most pivotal crypto news on CoinDesk and beyond. You can subscribe to get the full newsletter here. For instance
column7: Bloomberg‚Äôs Matt Levine opened a recent edition of the (always excellent) ‚ÄúMoney Stuff‚Äù newsletter getting straight to the point: ‚ÄúFTX was ‚Ä¶ illiquid but solvent?‚Äù That is
column8: in a way
column9: a very simple and direct way of stating what SBF
column10: who was recently sentenced to 25 years in prison for one of the largest financial heists ever
column11: has been saying for years. See also: Could Sam Bankman-Fried's Saga Happen Without Crypto? To make it brief
column12: in the days leading up to FTX‚Äôs bankruptcy on Nov. 11
column14: SBF was frantically trying to shore up a gigantic hole in his company‚Äôs balance sheet by raising funds basically from anyone he could. This reportedly includes everyone from Silicon Valley VCs
column15: Saudi money men and even SBF‚Äôs archrival ex-CEO of Binance Changpeng Zhao (who reneged on a handshake buyout deal after reviewing the state of FTX‚Äôs finances
column16: only speeding up the ongoing run on the exchange). He was trying to raise this money 1) because SBF and his inner circle had become painfully aware of a shortfall in capital needed to meet all customer withdrawals (a balance reportedly shown to prospective investors showed the exchange only had $900 million in liquid assets) and 2) because (and this is debatable) he believed ‚Äì or said he believed ‚Äì that there actually was enough capital
column17: it was just illiquid. To wit: "FTX is fine. Assets are fine
column18: ‚Äù Bankman-Fried infamously tweeted out on Nov. 7 after being confronted by FTX co-founder Gary Wang about the exchange‚Äôs $8 billion hole as customer withdrawals began to pick up following Zhao‚Äôs announcement that he‚Äôd sell Binance‚Äôs FTT stack. From the beginning of his ill-fated ‚Äúmedia tour‚Äù to the end of his trial
column19: SBF routinely characterized FTX‚Äôs implosion as due to an accounting error ‚Äì in particular a "confusing internal account‚Äù that made it seem to him that FTX was on more solid footing. Plus
column20: as Michael Lewis noted in the hagiography ‚ÄúGoing Infinite
column21: ‚Äù SBF privately estimated his personal worth at over $100 billion
column22: though that was before the price of FTT
column23: SOL and other ‚ÄúSam Coins‚Äù cratered. It was actually this insistence that he could have rescued FTX had he not declared bankruptcy
column24: and unwillingness to take responsibility for his crime
column25: that led to his lengthy sentence. ‚ÄúIn 30 years
column26: I‚Äôve never seen a performance like that
column27: ‚Äù Judge Lewis Kaplan said during the sentencing hearing
column28: describing SBF‚Äôs evasiveness and remorselessness. But just because someone believes something doesn‚Äôt make it true
column29: no matter how many Substack posts they write or spreadsheets they create. John J. Ray III
column30: current FTX CEO overseeing the bankruptcy
column31: says over the past 17 months the firm was able to recover between $14.5 billion and $16.3 billion in assets that weren‚Äôt on the exchange at the time it collapsed. While it will likely take access to documents that aren‚Äôt actually publicly available
column32: including FTX‚Äôs (abysmal) financial statements before the collapse and for today to conclusively prove this; it‚Äôs likely this recovery is due mostly to the rising price of crypto assets. Although JJR‚Äôs well-paid legal team likely put in a lot of effort to recover funds from ‚Äúdozens of private entities
column33: ‚Äù it likely doesn‚Äôt add up to billions and billions of dollars. See also: The Downfall of FTX: The Crypto Industry Reacts Anthropic
column34: for instance
column35: one of SBF‚Äôs lucky bets in AI
column36: got the firm a return of $884 million ‚Äì a windfall
column37: but likely the biggest non-crypto sale FTX made. FTX also sold off 38 Bahamian properties for around $199 million
column38: and was able to recover nearly $2.6 billion in cash. In comparison
column39: the estate sold off $1.9 billion worth of deeply discounted SOL recently
column40: and apparently still holds $7.5 billion worth of locked-up tokens. Those tokens were worth less than $500 million at the time of FTX‚Äôs collapse. In total
column41: FTX raised about $5 billion by selling tokens
column42: and it expects to raise another $4.4 billion over the next few months. This to me all seems like FTX wasn‚Äôt actually solvent at the time it collapsed and that it could repay the $8 billion in missing customer funds if only SBF had the ability to quickly sell off all of its property
column43: equity investments and crypto (without tanking prices even further). But instead due to the subsequent bull run
column44: FTX became solvent. Customers are being made whole
column45: not in crypto assets
column46: of which there is still a shortfall (i.e. there is not enough BTC to go around to pay back all customer BTC claims)
column47: but in the dollar value of their accounts in November 2022 prices. It‚Äôs a lucky break that the market rebounded enough so that the fraction pays for the whole. But SBF didn‚Äôt have the benefit of waiting several months to see if crypto would rise from the ashes. And his argument that FTX only had an illiquidity problem is patently absurd. Edited by Benjamin Schiller. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column1: 245::https://beincrypto.com/ai-rwa-defi-evolution/::BeInCrypto::article::Exclusive Redefining Finance: How AI and Real World Assets are Shaping DeFi‚Äôs Evolution::Claude Eguienta
column2: a driving force behind Mimo Capital
column3: shared his thoughts on the current and future state of DeFi and RWA with BeInCrypto.::We use cookies to improve your experience.  Claude Eguienta
column4: a driving force behind Mimo Capital
column5: shared his thoughts on the current and future state of DeFi with BeInCrypto. With a focus on integrating Real World Assets (RWA) and leveraging Artificial Intelligence (AI)
column6: Eguienta‚Äôs work promises to usher in a new era for decentralized finance. Claude Eguienta is the Chief Executive Officer at Mimo
column7: leading the charge in creating protocols that provide tokenized real-world assets and enabling the minting of multiple price-stable currencies against collateral. Previously
column8: Claude co-founded Telcoin
column9: a startup focused on financial inclusion through blockchain-based remittances. Claude opens the discussion by reflecting on the trajectory of RWAs within the decentralize finance ecosystem. Initially
column10: there was a surge of enthusiasm as platforms like Ondo Finance introduced novel protocols

column1: 249::https://theconversation.com/why-bitcoin-fraud-suspect-alexander-vinnik-looks-set-to-be-extradited-to-the-us-89054::The Conversation::article::Why bitcoin fraud suspect Alexander Vinnik looks set to be extradited to the US::Allegations bring to the fore questions over the legitimacy of bitcoin ‚Äì a sound investment tool or a massive scam?::Everyone is going crazy about bitcoin
column2: yet very few people understand what it is
column3: how it relates to blockchain and whether this is a legitimate investment tool or a massive scam. The extradition case of Alexander Vinnik ‚Äì the alleged Russian mastermind of a US$4 billion digital money laundering scheme ‚Äì brings all this to the fore. Vinnik
column4: who was arrested in northern Greece
column5: describes himself as a bitcoin consultant and denies all charges brought against him by US officials who have accused him of running the BTC-e exchange and laundering billions of dollars via bitcoin transactions. He had been waiting for Greece‚Äôs Supreme Court to decide whether he could be extradited to the US
column6: where he faces a cybercrime trial. On Wednesday
column7: the court ruled that Vinnik can be extradited to face charges in the US. It‚Äôs now up to the Greek justice minister to determine whether the extradition will take place ‚Äì but it is likely Vinnik will be facing US authorities before long. Vinnik
column9: is one of seven Russian suspects arrested or indicted worldwide this year on US cybercrime charges. He has fought hard against extradition to the US
column10: deploying an expensive team of Greek criminal attorneys before the court. Vinnik has said he is willing to be extradited to his home country of Russia
column11: where he is sought on lesser fraud charges. If the Greek justice minister decides to send Vinnik to Russia instead it will be a diplomatic issue between Greece and the US. Some might bristle at the idea of getting involved in bitcoin
column12: given the Vinnik allegations and other not-so-pretty news stories around the bubbling cryptocurrency that is waiting to burst. But you might still be wondering how it works
column13: and whether you can make some money out of it. A good starting point is to reflect briefly on the value of money. What do you understand by value? Take this year‚Äôs must-have Christmas toy ‚Äì a programmable robot made of little bricks. Your kids want one
column14: you want one
column15: it is in short supply and out of stock pretty much everywhere. Its price is climbing outside standard toy stores. You can buy it for multiples of its retail price on online auction sites. This is a valuable commodity. Perhaps one you could invest in. If you can obtain some of these scarce items at normal price
column16: you could make a killing auctioning them online. Now consider this
column17: what if the toy wasn‚Äôt a physical item? What if the sought after product was a game app? You can download it
column18: but you need an activation code to use it
column19: and codes aren‚Äôt easy to come about. Scarcity would be due to rationing in supply
column20: not due to physical lack of stock. Assuming you could buy multiple activation codes and auction them online
column21: you could treat these as an investment. Never mind for a second who makes the app and why there are limited activation codes. It is considered a valuable asset. Could it be a commodity
column22: a source of value
column23: a store of such value? Could it be used as currency? Substitute the toy robot or app with bitcoin and you get an idea of what is happening. Bitcoin is a type of software. Think of it as a digital token that can be programmed to do various things
column24: containing a variety of information. Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies are based on blockchain technology
column25: an information storage system which works as a decentralised ledger. Information is not held on a central server
column26: but is duplicated and dispersed across a huge network. Every time this information is updated
column27: a corresponding change is made across the network. What is the benefit of this decentralisation? Blockchain enthusiasts will tell you that the system is impossible to corrupt or manipulate. Any attempt to ‚Äúhack‚Äù information will be rejected by other nodes in the system that hold the true copy of the information. If you have been awarded a digital token
column28: a bitcoin
column29: you can be sure (we are told) that it is genuine. Great
column30: so we have a supposedly impenetrable digital ledger that evidences little bits of software that people think are valuable. Sounds benign
column31: so why is Vinnik facing allegations of money laundering? Law enforcement officers have realised that the decentralised nature of the ledger and the anonymous nature of the originators and holders of bitcoin potentially make it a wonderful conduit for illegally obtained funds. Remember
column32: the ledger is currently beyond the control
column33: or knowledge of governments and state authorities. Rightly or wrongly
column34: bitcoins are considered valuable and people exchange them for real money. The value of bitcoin has well exceeded US$10
column35: 000 and financial firms are set to start trading futures ‚Äì which are bets on the price of upcoming contracts to exchange bitcoin. Blockchain could be a revolution not only in finance
column36: but also in money laundering. But the era of cowboy cryptocurrency trading is set to come to a grinding halt. Regulators worldwide are reacting to soaring values with attempts to inject a degree of transparency in these trades. Starting with the EU
column37: legislation is planned to force online platforms where bitcoins are traded to carry out due diligence on customers and report suspicious transactions. It will bring trades within the network of rules that try to prevent money laundering and dealing in proceeds of crime
column38: including terrorist financing. If you are thinking of speculating on bitcoin
column39: should you do it? Before you make up your mind
column40: remember this: the last innovation in finance promising incredible rewards with appropriately apportioned risks was the creation of synthetic CDOs and derivative-laden layercakes in the mid noughties. And we all know how that went.::2017-12-13T13:00:56Z::Bitcoin

column5: and the Decentralized World" (available at www.thecryptolegalhandbook.com). The question seems almost rhetorical: Should lawyers deeply engaged in the cryptocurrency or digital asset industry understand the technologies they are paid to represent before regulators and courts? Surprisingly
column6: many legal professionals
column7: including those actively tasked with navigating existential threats to the cryptocurrency industry or their crypto-wielding clients
column8: treat cryptocurrency more as a novel curiosity than a transformative technology that requires intricate understanding and thoughtful consideration. I've listened to presentations by highly sought-after attorneys with large ‚Äúcrypto practices‚Äù who charge thousands of dollars for an hour of their time and joke that they are "not a crypto person" when pressed on a question about the uses of the technology during formal proceedings. They treat the practicalities of using digital assets as an irrelevant afterthought that only complicates their other arguments. This detachment between the industry and its advocates is not merely unhelpful ‚Äì ‚Äîit's harmful. The industry tasks its lawyers with representing its interests before courts and regulators
column9: who often need to consider the complex interplay of crypto applications and existing regulations for the first time. If these advocates are unwilling to engage seriously with what the industry is building
column10: how can they effectively persuade a court or regulator that their legal interpretation aligns with the realities of the technology or convey the philosophical foundations upon which the broader cryptocurrency space is built? Top law firms charge thousands of dollars per hour for their services
column11: yet too often
column12: the senior-most partners on a case treat engaging deeply with their client‚Äôs crypto business as beneath them. This attitude forces clients to rely on the hope that some crypto-native associate will step in to prevent egregious errors or inefficiencies caused by the lack of interest from those at the top. This dynamic is inefficient and can be financially and strategically costly for those navigating the complicated regulatory challenges inherent to most projects in the space. Fortunately
column13: as crypto-native associates become more senior
column14: the dynamics within law firms are beginning to change. Truly adept "crypto lawyers" have emerged at many prestigious law firms
column15: and there are lawyers at specialized boutiques who certainly know their stuff
column16: but this phenomenon remains surprisingly rare. This shift is crucial
column17: as lawyers who understand and can innovate within the framework of cryptocurrency law are critical for the industry's future. A cynical response might equate demanding that a lawyer representing a crypto company have meaningful experience using cryptocurrencies to a tobacco company requiring that their lawyer smoke. But such glib comparisons reveal a misunderstanding of what cryptocurrency represents ‚Äì ‚Äîa potential paradigm shift in how we structure society and handle value
column18: privacy
column19: and trust that relies on first-of-its-kind technologies to further goals that were
column20: until recently
column21: confined to science fiction. Lawyers are free to spend their time as they see fit
column22: but those who believe they can coast on a superficial understanding of Bitcoin that hasn‚Äôt been expanded since 2017 and an attitude that "everything old is new again" will find their pool of clients diminishing as the industry progresses and demands more from them. I‚Äôm not suggesting that a lawyer needs a computer science degree to be a successful advocate or that they must be a ‚Äúdegen‚Äù with their personal finances
column23: but they should put in enough time learning about the industry and interacting with the different projects and protocols that make up the space so that they can speak authoritatively on what their clients do
column24: how they do it
column25: and why it matters. Passion is a valuable asset for any professional
column26: particularly in an industry that evolves as rapidly as cryptocurrency does. Lawyers wishing to stay up-to-speed with the continuous legal and technological changes that are characteristic of the cryptocurrency space must engage in continuous self-study ‚Äì ‚Äîa task that is incredibly difficult without a genuine interest in the subject matter. This isn't just about maintaining relevance; it's about providing the best possible representation for clients who rely on their attorneys to understand not just the law but the essence of the technology they are dealing with to ensure their advocacy considers a comprehensive understanding of the facts
column27: rules
column28: and circumstances at play. See also: Fatemeh Fannizadeh on Crypto Law
column29: Switzerland and How KYC Is Failing I get asked all the time by young lawyers or law students what they can do to start a career in crypto law. My advice is always to start using crypto and to see if they believe that technologies that permit people to interact without intermediaries are important and should be protected. If so
column30: start reading about the industry‚Äôs history
column31: and if you are still convinced this is a good thing for the world
column32: develop expertise in the various areas of law and financial regulations that impact the field. On the other side
column33: I get asked by non-lawyer entrepreneurs or developers what they can do to ensure their relationship with their lawyers is successful. My answer is to make sure your lawyer understands what you‚Äôre trying to build and why and to learn enough about the rules regulating your business so that you can have critical conversations with your legal team about their understanding of the law and their strategy. During conversations with young lawyers or entrepreneurs
column34: I would be asked where they should start developing these informational skills
column35: but I didn‚Äôt have a great answer. I put together a resource called ‚ÄúThe Crypto Legal Handbook‚Äù to address this gap and serve as a primer on cryptocurrency's technological and historical aspects
column36: as well as a comprehensive overview of the various laws that govern the field. The text is designed to
column37: on the one hand
column38: spur lawyers to engage with the crypto world actively
column39: enhancing their ability to serve as true advocates for technological advancement and
column40: on the other hand
column41: to provide entrepreneurs with the tools they need to understand the state of crypto regulations. I believe that most of us working in the crypto industry understand that it is more than just a niche asset class within the financial sector. The proliferation of technologies that allow for a variety of peer-to-peer financial and non-financial communications is a pioneering movement capable of reshaping our understanding of money
column42: privacy
column43: and governance that could substantially impact how we govern our economy and society at large. Isn‚Äôt it time we started demanding all these so-called ‚Äúcrypto lawyers‚Äù be able to effectively articulate this vision for the future? Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column1: 252::https://blockworks.co/news/zk-decentralized-identity-verification::Blockworks::article::Aleo blockchain adds zPass
column2: a ZK protocol for verifying identities¬†::zPass is based on a research paper on ‚Äúzk-creds‚Äù designed to use zero knowledge proofs for age verification.::zPass is based on a research paper on ‚Äúzk-creds‚Äù designed to use zero knowledge for age verification nuruddean/Shutterstock modified by Blockworks A protocol designed to use zero knowledge cryptography to verify identities has landed on the Aleo blockchain
column3: a zero knowledge privacy (ZKP) network. The protocol
column4: called zPass
column5: enables users to upload identity documents offline to privacy servers and share anonymous ‚Äúproofs‚Äù to organizations. As a result
column6: these companies do not need to store this data themselves. Users who generate their own proofs can then determine exactly who they share their information with and just how much personal data they wish to reveal. Alex Pruden
column7: Aleo‚Äôs CEO
column8: told Blockworks in an interview that zPass represents the implementation of a research paper into zk-creds. ‚ÄúThe idea of zk-creds was to take a US passport
column9: create a digital record from it
column10: then use that record for age verification purposes
column11: ‚Äù Pruden said. Pruden explained that on zPass
column12: a two-step process helps ensure that individual identities are safely verified. First
column13: the issuance of the record on-chain is based on the existence of a physical record
column14: and then it is the ability for each individual to control their own privacy keys which generate the proof of identity. Read more: Mastering decentralized identity: The pillar of Web3 ‚ÄúThe key piece of what zk-creds and zPass does is to issue the identity
column15: and the identity is the document based on a real-world physical document
column16: ‚Äù he said. John Reynolds
column17: a product manager for Aleo
column18: noted that existing zk identity systems either rely on centralized proving schemes
column19: or are decentralized but not private. ‚ÄúA lot of zk identity systems use a centralized proving system or have centralized sequencers ‚Äî we have a leveraged tailored [layer-1]
column20: we have the ability for users themselves to act as provers
column21: they can generate proofs
column22: send those proofs to Aleo
column23: decentralized validators can validate those proofs
column24: and the Aleo blockchain will not push all of this overhead verification to third party systems
column25: ‚Äù Reynolds told Blockworks in an interview. On the note of decentralized identity solutions
column26: Reynolds said that because they are not private and information is publicly available on a database
column27: users can be tracked. ‚ÄúThey may not be able to see all your information
column28: but they can see who you‚Äôre sharing it with and how often you‚Äôre sharing it with them
column29: and can target you as a result of that
column30: ‚Äù he said. At launch
column31: zPass will focus primarily on providing zk age verification and creating child-safe spaces online
column32: Reynolds said. ‚ÄúWe want to create a space that supports children and avoids them from being exposed to potential predators or [predatory] content
column33: ‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSo our main goal [for now] is to lean into age verification.‚Äù Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. The Lightspeed newsletter is all things Solana

column3: 000+ in NEXO Tokens! Share this article Bankrupt crypto exchange FTX unveiled yesterday a new plan to pay out at least 118% of recognized claims to 98% of its creditors. However

column8: 2024 Kavuri said the pricing in the petition for repayment underestimated the actual value of FTX customer holdings. column1: 255::https://theconversation.com/bitcoins-surge-intensifies-need-for-global-regulation-of-cryptocurrencies-86893::The Conversation::article::Bitcoin‚Äôs surge intensifies need for global regulation of cryptocurrencies::Crypto cash is catnip for criminals and a huge challenge to law enforcement ‚Äì so it‚Äôs time to bring in a tough
column2: jurisdiction-busting regulatory body.::The news that bitcoin had broken the $10
column3: 000 barrier reflects the way that mainstream investors have been flocking to cryptocurrencies over the past year. But amid the excitement
column4: regulators are fretting about criminals who are increasingly using cryptocurrencies to escape detection from law enforcement. Why is digital currency so appealing to miscreants? Cryptocurrencies are a recent phenomenon and ‚Äì as with all new technology ‚Äì it takes time for regulators to catch up. Bitcoin was the first to gain an international reputation as a digital currency that could be used to settle transactions after it was anonymously created in early 2009. Cryptocurrencies are decentralised
column5: meaning that they are issued without a central administering authority. They are cryptography-based
column6: distributed open source and function on a peer-to-peer basis. Significantly
column7: the underlying protocols on which most cryptocurrencies are based do not require or provide user identification and verification. Also the historical transaction records generated on the blockchain (the technology behind bitcoin
column8: which serves as a public ledger of all cryptocurrency transactions) are not necessarily associated with an individual‚Äôs identity. Cryptocurrencies are also ‚Äì by definition ‚Äì convertible virtual currencies
column9: as they can be exchanged for fiat money such as pounds
column10: dollars and euros and this facilitates their use for settling commercial transactions. Bitcoin is now an acceptable form of payment in exchange for goods and services by household names such as Microsoft
column11: Expedia and Subway. At the same time
column12: blockchain technology is being adopted by more businesses. Private transactions enabled by the use of bitcoin are key to understanding the growth of cryptocurrencies among consumers. However
column13: this advantage is keeping regulators and law enforcers awake at night. The infamous Silk Road case drives this point home. Bitcoin was used to purchase drugs through the dark web ‚Äì transactions that weren‚Äôt spotted by the authorities. But hard-to-track criminal activity isn‚Äôt the only threat from the use of cryptocurrencies ‚Äì there‚Äôs also the possibility of their use to finance terrorism
column14: given that the formal banking sector is now adept at spotting suspicious movement and mobilisation of monies through the banking system The fact that they can be converted into pounds
column15: dollars and euros does make regulation of cryptocurrency more feasible. It can be done at the point of their conversion through virtual currency exchanges ‚Äì which
column16: as financial institutions
column17: can be regulated. International financial regulation and a growing number of national measures across the globe
column18: such as ‚ÄúKnow Your Customer‚Äù (KYC) and anti-money laundering (AML) directed at financial institutions
column19: have been strengthened. And
column20: when implemented effectively
column21: it‚Äôs now easier to track down individuals engaging in illegal transactions. But the global nature of this payment mechanism is the biggest challenge. Payments can be easily affected cross-border because conversion of the likes of bitcoin through currency exchanges can be transacted in different parts of the world ‚Äì including in jurisdictions with lax financial regulatory regimes and weak KYC/AML measures. This means that
column22: while jurisdictions with stronger regulatory powers may clamp down on criminal activities
column23: such efforts can be easily wiped out because perpetrators are likely to migrate to countries with lax regimes. Nonetheless
column24: positive steps are being taken to regulate financial technology (fintech) products such as cryptocurrencies. Emerging challenges within this sector has led to the arrival of regtech ‚Äì which
column25: among other things
column26: is regulatory technology adopted to address fintech risk issues. Regtech covers artificial intelligence
column27: big data and machine learning ‚Äì technology that enables detailed data analysis on platforms such as blockchain. Again
column28: regtech is only likely to be adopted effectively in jurisdictions with advanced regulatory regimes
column29: so the extent of its effectiveness in policing the global cryptocurrency phenomenon appears limited. Another challenge is the investigation and prosecution of illegal activities perpetrated with payments using cryptocurrencies
column30: with semi-anonymity of the blockchain making it difficult to monitor transactions and identify suspicious behaviour
column31: such as drug sales. Law enforcement agencies find it incredibly difficult to trace illicit proceeds that are laundered using cryptocurrencies and ‚Äì once again ‚Äì are scuppered by different legal systems around the world. Different jurisdictions have their own approaches to regulating cyber-related transactions
column32: which makes international cooperation deeply challenging. In some countries
column33: such as North Korea and China
column34: regulation of web-based transactions is significant for national security policy. Legal mechanisms are in place to allow extensive government intrusion into the sender and recipient details of every single transmission. Other countries
column35: such as the US and the UK
column36: cautiously approach online regulation to balance security concerns against constitutionally protected freedoms and to preserve privacy and data protection laws. It means that a worldwide effort is needed to regulate this global payment mechanism. Governments
column37: financial regulators
column38: financial intelligence units and law enforcement agencies must all agree to a unified approach in tackling cryptocurrencies. Without this
column39: effective regulation of bitcoin and similar currencies is unattainable. A starting point could be instituting minimum regulation
column40: such as currently exists in some international financial standards including the Basle Committee‚Äôs Core Principles for Effective Banking Supervision and the IOSCO principles of securities regulation. Countries across the world are encouraged to implement these provisions
column41: which indicates that they embrace investor-friendly policies. A similar standard applied to cryptocurrencies would be a sensible way forward
column42: given the patchwork approach to regulating cyber-related transactions around the globe.::2017-11-29T14:49:31Z::Bitcoin
