column1: 256::https://www.coindesk.com/opinion/2024/05/09/how-the-us-should-regulate-stablecoins/::CoinDesk::article::How the U.S. Should Regulate Stablecoins::To properly regulate stablecoins in the U.S.
column2: look at e-money abroad
column3: says Marcelo Prates
column4: a speaker at Consensus 2024.::In a recent podcast
column5: Hilary Allen
column6: a law professor at American University
column7: painted stablecoins as a dangerous threat to the banking system and
column8: ultimately
column9: to the public at large. In her view
column10: stablecoins could destabilize banks and eventually require a government bailout. Her comments come amid a new push in the U.S. Congress for regulating stablecoins at the federal level. Although the chances of any stablecoin bill being enacted into law in a year of presidential elections are slim
column11: Allen is concerned that these bills are ‚Äúgiving public backing to stablecoins.‚Äù For her
column12: ‚Äústablecoins serve no important purpose and frankly just should be banned.‚Äù Marcelo M. Prates
column13: a speaker at Consensus 2024
column14: is a financial policy and regulation expert writing about money
column15: payments
column16: and digital assets. Are her concerns valid? Only for those who are against competition and don‚Äôt like regulatory clarity. What Allen depicts as a scary and useless fad is an upgraded version of one of the most revolutionary financial innovations in the last 25 years: electronic money
column17: or simply e-money
column18: issued by non-banks. In the early-2000s
column19: the European Union decided it was about time for more people to have access to faster and cheaper digital payments. With that in mind
column20: E.U. legislators developed a regulatory framework for e-money and allowed start-ups making the most of technology
column21: the so-called fintech
column22: to provide payment instruments in a regulated and safe way. The idea behind it was simple. As banks are complex institutions providing multiple services and are subject to higher risks and increased regulation
column23: opening a bank account to make digital payments was usually difficult and costly. The solution was to have a separate licensing and regulatory regime for non-banks focused on one service: transforming cash they received from their customers into e-money that could be used for digital payments either through a prepaid card or an electronic device. In practice
column24: e-money issuers work like narrow banks. They are legally required to safeguard or insure the cash they receive from their customers so that e-money balances can always be converted back to cash with no loss of value. As they are licensed and supervised entities
column25: customers know that
column26: aside from gross regulatory failure
column27: their e-money is safe. It's thus easy to see that the vast majority of existing stablecoins
column28: those denominated on a sovereign currency like U.S. dollars
column29: are just e-money with a kick: as they are issued on blockchains
column30: they are not restricted to a national payments system and can circulate globally. Instead of a scary financial product
column31: stablecoins are really ‚Äúe-money 2.0
column32: ‚Äù with the potential to keep delivering on the original e-money promises of increasing competition in the financial sector
column33: lowering costs for consumers
column34: and advancing financial inclusion. But for these promises to be fulfilled
column35: stablecoins do need to be properly regulated at the federal level. Without federal law
column36: stablecoin issuers in the U.S. will continue to be subject to state money transmitter laws that aren‚Äôt uniformly designed or consistently enforced when it comes to segregation of clients‚Äô funds and integrity of assets kept in reserve. Considering the decades-long experience of the European Union in e-money and improvements brought by other countries
column37: an effective stablecoin regulation should be built around three pillars: granting of a non-bank license
column38: direct access to central-bank accounts
column39: and bankruptcy protection for backing assets. First
column40: it‚Äôd be contradictory to restrict stablecoin issuance to banks. The essence of banking is the possibility of holding deposits from the public that aren‚Äôt always 100% backed
column41: which is traditionally known as ‚Äúfractional reserve banking.‚Äù And that happens so that banks can make loans without using only their capital. For stablecoin issuers
column42: on the other hand
column43: the goal is that each stablecoin is fully backed with liquid assets. Their sole job is to receive cash
column44: offer a stablecoin in return
column45: hold safely the cash received
column46: and return the cash anytime someone comes with a stablecoin to redeem. Lending money isn‚Äôt a part of their business. Stablecoin issuers
column47: much like e-money issuers
column48: are meant to compete with banks in the payments sector
column49: especially in cross-border payments. They‚Äôre not supposed to replace banks or
column50: worse
column51: become banks. That‚Äôs why stablecoin issuers should be granted a specific non-bank license
column52: as happens for e-money issuers in the E.U.
column53: U.K.
column54: and Brazil: a simpler license with requirements
column55: including capital requirements
column56: that are proportionate to their limited activity and lower risk profile. They don‚Äôt need a banking license
column57: nor should they be required to get one. Second
column58: and to reinforce their lower risk profile
column59: stablecoin issuers should be able to have a central-bank account to hold their backing assets. Transferring the cash received from their customers to a bank account or investing it in short-term securities are typically safe options
column60: but both can become riskier in times of stress. Circle
column61: a U.S. stablecoin issuer
column62: had a hard time when Silicon Valley Bank (SVB) failed
column63: and $3.3 billion of its cash reserves (almost 10% of the total reserves) that had been deposited with SVB were temporarily unavailable. And several banks
column64: including SVB
column65: that were holding U.S. treasuries suffered losses after interest rates rose in 2022
column66: and the treasuries‚Äô market price declined
column67: leaving some of them short on liquidity and unable to face withdrawals. Read more: Dan Kuhn - What Visa‚Äôs ‚ÄòOrganic‚Äô Stablecoin Report Misses To avoid problems in the banking system or the treasuries market spilling over to stablecoins
column68: issuers should be required to deposit their backing reserves directly with the Fed. This rule would effectively eliminate credit risk in the U.S. stablecoin market and enable real-time supervision of stablecoins‚Äô backing ‚Äî no need for deposit insurance and no bailout risk
column69: just like e-money and contrary to bank deposits. Note that central-bank accounts for non-bank institutions wouldn‚Äôt be unprecedented. E-money issuers in countries like the U.K
column70: Switzerland and Brazil can keep users‚Äô funds safeguarded directly with the central bank. Third
column71: customers‚Äô funds should be considered by law segregated from the issuer‚Äôs and not subject to any insolvency regime if the stablecoin issuer were to fail ‚Äî for example
column72: because of the materialization of operational risks
column73: like fraud. With that additional layer of protection
column74: stablecoin users could quickly regain access to their funds during a liquidation process
column75: as general creditors of the bankrupt issuer wouldn‚Äôt be able to seize customers‚Äô funds. Again
column76: something like what‚Äôs considered the best practice for e-money issuers. In the public debate about stablecoin regulation
column77: alarming takes might impress a distracted audience. But
column79: balanced arguments based on successful examples and experiences from around the world should prevail. Edited by Benjamin Schiller. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column1: 258::https://blockworks.co/news/blockchain-security-experts-team::Blockworks::article::Blockchain security experts team up to improve industry threat response::Shield3‚Äôs Isaac Patka has been working alongside Paradigms Samczsun to bolster cybersecurity threat responses after hacks.::Shield3‚Äôs Isaac Patka has been working alongside Paradigms Samczsun to bolster cybersecurity threat responses after hacks DM7/Shutterstock
column2: modified by Blockworks Since the spring of this year
column3: Isaac Patka of AI security firm Shield3 and Paradigm research partner Sam
column4: better known as Samczsun
column5: have been working alongside blockchain projects to improve security in the wake of cyber threats that have continued to plague the industry. The duo launched SEAL 911 in early August
column6: a Telegram bot designed to connect users with vetted security experts aiming to enhance cybersecurity disclosure and swiftly prevent DeFi hacks potentially worth hundreds of millions of dollars. That initiative was established in the hopes of countering multiple industry-related hacks that have taken place this year
column7: including Curve Finance‚Äôs $70 million exploit in July. Now the pair are hoping to up the ante
column8: establishing a new emergency drill initiative designed to assist budding blockchain protocols in their fight against malicious hackers and potential attack vectors. Blockworks reached out to Patka to get a better sense of their undertaking and the lessons they have learned over the past few months. Blockworks: Can you walk us through the inception of this emergency drill initiative? What was the driving force behind it? Patka: I first met Sam through our mutual friend Jeanne. I met Jeanne at DWeb camp 2022 when I was presenting some of my previous open source & standards projects. I heard that Sam was looking for some help in building some training infrastructure for protocol teams to practice being in a war room prior to a real emergency. The idea resonated with me because at that time I was working on some research and tools related to identifying and avoiding social attacks and dependency failures in decentralized communities. I volunteered to help get a proof of concept off the ground and after a quick brainstorming call in the spring
column9: I got to work on outlining the drill framework for Compound Labs
column10: which was the first team that offered to participate in a drill. Blockworks: You mentioned the role of ‚Äúcomprehensive recon‚Äù in your drills. How does this initial step set the stage for the rest of the exercise? Patka: In the recon phase I get up to speed with all of the features
column11: smart contracts
column12: documents and publicly available information about the target protocol. I‚Äôm trying to figure out what the ‚Äúcontrol surface‚Äù is for any privileged users [or] admins
column13: how the protocol interacts with [or] relies on other protocols
column14: how they monitor the health of the system
column15: what risk processes exist
column16: how they introduce things like protocol upgrades or new feature releases
column17: and if there are inconsistencies in the system if it‚Äôs deployed across different networks. This recon becomes the foundation for the tabletop scenarios where we talk through potential issues. Blockworks: The use of tabletop simulations seems like an interesting approach. Could you elaborate on what goes into these simulations and how they inform the subsequent steps? Patka: After the recon phase
column18: I put together a script with a few scenarios and talk through them with the whole team on a call. These scenarios help us understand their incident response procedures
column19: their monitoring and their social/ comms style. The questions we‚Äôre asking at this point are: All of this helps us find potential ‚Äúhot spots‚Äù or things that we want to stress test in a live scenario. Blockworks: What criteria do you use to select the protocol teams you‚Äôre going to drill with? Do you have any prerequisites? Patka: At this phase
column20: we‚Äôre trying to work with teams where we think we can both help them by providing some training
column21: but also learn from them about how the top protocol teams in the space operate
column22: and share those practices with the wider community. So while we don‚Äôt have specific prerequisites
column23: a good fit now is a team that contributes to a protocol with fairly widespread adoption and has been through a few incidents already so we can learn about a variety of team styles. However
column24: as our infrastructure is becoming more robust and easier to set up
column25: I would enjoy working with some teams earlier on in their protocol to provide some training to people who have never been in a war room before. Blockworks: Your first test was with the Compound protocol. Can you delve into some of the unique challenges or lessons learned from that initial test? Patka: The biggest planning challenge was identifying a scenario that was not too catastrophic to be frustrating
column26: but interesting enough to be engaging and would involve some diagnosis and coordination. We considered a variety of things like external protocol failures
column27: governance attacks and contract upgrade issues. We ended up simulating a bug that made the protocol slowly start losing funds so that we could see how their monitoring would pick up on the process and how they would respond. One of the biggest lessons here was on the social
column28: coordination layer. I was impressed with the close collaboration between the protocol devs and the auditors and protocol guardians in diagnosing the issue. On a technical level
column29: the first drill also involved a lot of late-night debugging infrastructure
column30: getting the network fork
column31: and block explorer
column32: and monitoring infra stability. Blockworks: You talked about avoiding zero-day vulnerabilities in your drills. Can you explain the reasoning behind this decision and how it affects the integrity of the exercise? Patka: The reason we avoid ‚Äúzero-day‚Äù vulnerabilities or other very widespread catastrophes is so that we can engage the protocol team in something they could reasonably respond to
column33: and something contained within their protocol‚Äôs ecosystem. For example
column34: we haven‚Äôt done drills around things like compiler bugs
column35: or consensus layer failures. However
column36: I think these widespread issues would be interesting to simulate in cross-protocol drills where we could get multiple teams and perhaps users of the protocols all interacting with a forknet where something has gone wrong to make it realistic and build social resiliency. Blockworks: You mentioned Yearn‚Äôs ‚Äúemergency procedure cards‚Äù during your test with them. How common is this practice across other protocols
column37: and would you recommend it as a standard? Patka: I haven‚Äôt seen other protocols that implement emergency procedure cards like Yearn yet
column38: but I‚Äôd highly recommend it. In many protocols
column39: but especially with Yearn
column40: there are many external integrations that require specific context and subject matter expertise. When some incident happens
column41: you don‚Äôt want to be spending time re-reading your own docs & contracts instead of taking action. Having emergency procedures for specific scenarios helps teams make decisions quicker and more confidently. Writing these emergency procedures is a mandatory step of the risk [and] diligence process of deploying Yearn strategies. I‚Äôd recommend adding emergency procedures to the risk/diligence processes for other protocols
column42: for example when deciding whether or not to integrate with various assets as collateral sources or adding them to markets. Blockworks: What are some key performance indicators you look at during and after a drill to measure its effectiveness? Patka: I look for some indicators of both our performance as organizers of the drill and how well the team did. For our side
column43: I‚Äôm looking at the stability of our infrastructure and how well the team adapts to the simulated environment. On the project side
column44: I‚Äôm keeping a timeline of at what point issuers are discovered
column45: how long until there is a diagnosis
column46: and how long until there is some consensus around the action to take. We also send out a postmortem survey to teams to find out what they learned
column47: what they plan to improve in their processes
column48: and how we can improve our simulations. Blockworks: Can you share some overarching trends or common gaps you‚Äôve noticed in protocol security as a result of these drills? Patka: I‚Äôm not sure if it‚Äôs a gap but there seems to be less of a formal ‚Äúon-call‚Äù system across various protocols than I expected. There is an ‚Äòalways online‚Äô aspect of the crypto culture where people seem to just assume the right developer or multi-sig signer will be available when needed. This generally seems to work but I‚Äôm curious to explore if some more formalization of roles and schedules would help. I‚Äôve also noticed that monitoring and governance varies for protocols across different [layer-1s/layer-2s] where they have code deployed. I think there is room for improvement across the industry on how protocols that straddle multiple networks manage their contracts. Blockworks: Looking ahead
column49: are there plans to broaden these drills to include more protocols or even different types of tests? Patka: For sure
column50: we are looking to broaden drills to include different types of protocols
column51: or perhaps multiple protocols at the same time. We also want to get to the point where these are easy enough to run that teams can hold regular training for community contributors to build their experience in incident response. I‚Äôd also love to engage with new security engineers who might want to learn about security by designing scenarios and configuring simulations. This interview has been edited for brevity and clarity. Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. column1: 260::https://cryptobriefing.com/lagrange-crypto-startup-raises-13m-thiel/::Crypto Briefing::article::Lagrange Labs closes $13.2M to build out ZK proofs based on EigenLayer::The startup's flagship product is a zero-knowledge "coprover" slated for release towards the end of this month.::Join the hunt for $12
column3: 000+ in NEXO Tokens! Share this article Lagrange Labs
column4: a cryptography startup specializing in zero-knowledge (ZK) proofs
column5: has raised $13.2 million in a seed funding round led by Peter Thiel‚Äôs Founders Fund. The startup is based on Ethereum‚Äôs EigenLayer restaking platform and is aimed at providing decentralized applications with efficient and secure access to otherwise resource-intensive onchain computing power. Lagrange‚Äôs flagship product comes in the form of a zero-knowledge ‚Äúcoprover
column6: ‚Äù slated for release later this month. According to the press materials
column7: the coprover is operates as an offchain network of specialized nodes that could execute intensive computations and generate ZK proofs based on the results. Such a setup allows for decentralized applications to verifiably access the computations without requiring trust between the initiated task and the offchain prover. Founder Ismael Hishon-Rezaizadeh explained that Lagrange‚Äôs proving systems and proof constructions can scale to ‚Äúvery big-data scales of verifiable computation‚Äù that otherwise would have been ‚Äúinfeasible.‚Äù This approach enables blockchains
column8: which are often expensive and sluggish for certain kinds of activities
column9: to run some computations cheaply and quickly off-chain. Lagrange‚Äôs security will be based on EigenLayer
column10: a platform on Ethereum that allows users to ‚Äúrestake‚Äù ether (ETH) tokens to help secure upstart blockchain apps in exchange for extra rewards. According to Hishon-Rezaizadeh
column11: some $6 billion worth of restaked assets has already been allocated for the security of Lagrange. Lagrange claims that they will be working to continually develop their operators and match improvements from EigenLayer‚Äôs core stack. The startup is partnered with Kraken
column12: a crypto exchange
column13: and Galaxy
column14: a crypto-financial firm. Aside from the Founder‚Äôs Fund
column15: the recently closed seed round also saw participation from Archetype Ventures

column1: 261::https://theconversation.com/four-factors-driving-the-price-of-bitcoin-87244::The Conversation::article::Four factors driving the price of Bitcoin::The price of Bitcoin has declined significantly in the past couple of days
column2: after rising 1
column3: 850% in the past two years. Here are four reasons why.::The price of Bitcoin has dropped to around A$8
column4: 000 in the last few days
column5: after almost hitting A$10
column6: 000 in the past month
column7: and rising over 1
column8: 850% since 2015. All of this shows how volatile the currency is
column9: prompting the question
column10: what leads to such huge movements? Our ongoing research reveals four factors that affect the price of Bitcoin. These include media hype and uptake by peers
column11: political uncertainty and risk (such as the election of Donald Trump or the vote for Brexit)
column12: moves by governments and regulators
column13: and the governance of Bitcoin itself. It is likely the last factor that has driven the latest drop in the price
column14: as a proposed Bitcoin split (or ‚Äúfork‚Äù) failed to gain support from developers towards the end of last week. The split would have doubled the number of coins in circulation (as previous splits have) and increased transaction speed.  Economists have long had a notion that psychological factors affect investor decisions. This is called ‚Äúanimal spirits‚Äù and refers to investors making decisions based on the behaviour of other market participants and their own intuitions
column15: rather than hard analysis. Analysis of the price of Bitcoin shows that positive media coverage is one of the main factors driving the price. Positive media coverage of new technologies causes a well-known hype-cycle ‚Äì a peak of hype is followed by a ‚Äútrough of disillusionment‚Äù. This was most apparent in the early days of Bitcoin
column16: when mainstream press started to report on the new currency and caused a number of short price spikes and collapses. As media coverage increases and other factors are brought in
column17: it is harder to distil the effect of the media alone. Something similar happens when high-profile companies go public
column18: as investors ‚Äúpile in‚Äù and the value rapidly increases from a low base. Think of a company like Twitter
column19: which saw a huge sharemarket ‚Äúpop‚Äù when it went public. Political risk around national currencies can also affect the price of Bitcoin as people use it to hedge against price movements in a particular currency
column20: or they need to quickly move large amounts of value out a country or currency. The economic crisis in Greece in 2015 was followed by reports of increased buying of Bitcoin by Greek citizens wishing to protect their wealth. This did not seem to affect the price of Bitcoin on global markets
column21: however
column22: which remained steady between A$300 and $400 for most of that year. But nervousness about the national referendum for Britain to leave the European Union (Brexit) on June 23 2016 did lead to an increase in the price of Bitcoin alongside a decrease in the value of the British pound. The pound started plummeting around May 20 2016. By July 25 it was more than 10% below its pre-Brexit value. For the same period the price of Bitcoin increased by over 65% (from ¬£302 to ¬£502). The election of Donald Trump as US president was also followed by two months of steep rises in the price of Bitcoin. Many attributed this to uncertainty in the US economy.  Regulators around the world have had to catch up to the rise of Bitcoin. They must decide
column23: for instance
column24: how it will be treated by the tax system
column25: or whether and what regulation applies to its use. Two events in particular highlight the impact regulations can have on the price. The announcement that Bitcoin would be considered legal tender in Japan pushed the price of Bitcoin up by 2% in just 24 hours
column26: and increased the price globally by 160% for the next two months. China‚Äôs decision to shut down several Bitcoin exchanges and ban initial coin offerings (a form of crowdfunding often paid for with cryptocurrencies) sent the price of Bitcoin plummeting by 29% in 24 hours. Although Bitcoin is a decentralised currency
column27: some decisions about how it will work or evolve need to be made from time to time. These also have an impact on the price. The software used to verify Bitcoin transactions is created by developers and is run by miners (the global network people who verify Bitcoin transactions). To change the software used to mine and authenticate transactions developers need more than 50% of the global network of miners to agree with that change. When they get that support they can create a ‚Äúfork‚Äù. On August 1 2017 Bitcoin underwent a ‚Äúhard fork‚Äù. A new cryptocurrency ‚Äì Bitcoin cash ‚Äì was created and given to everyone who owned Bitcoin. Bitcoin cash software can process 30 transactions per second
column28: four times more than Bitcoin. Not many investors in Bitcoin are coders
column29: however
column30: or knew what the fork would entail. There was a period of uncertainty before the fork
column31: and a period of rapid price rises afterwards. Since then there has been another fork ‚Äì to create Bitcoin gold. The attempt at a third fork was the one that failed to get support last week. This seems to be the cause of the correction in the price of Bitcoin late last week (at the time of writing the price is down almost 20% from a peak of A$9
column32: 925 on November 8). However
column33: the price of Bitcoin cash has simultaneously risen from A$818 to A$1
column34: 850. Read more: Australian regulators have finally made a move on initial coin offerings Although we can point to these four factors as affecting the price of Bitcoin over its short life
column35: it is a volatile and experimental technology
column36: and is still in development. Over the longer term it is likely to gain acceptance among investors for other reasons. For instance
column37: it is deflationary ‚Äì because there is a limited supply both in the total number of Bitcoins that can ever be created as well as the rate they can be created
column38: the purchasing power of Bitcoin will increase over time. This differs significantly from currencies like the Australian dollar. If you store national currencies under your bed they will
column39: over time
column40: become worthless.  For other investors
column41: the volatility of Bitcoin makes for a good trading environment (e.g. lots of price movements give opportunities to make money buying or selling). You can see this in the above comparison with gold. Bitcoin can also be a long-term investment due to it being unregulated in supply and having some huge benefits over some national currencies: it is global
column42: untied to supply of currencies by central banks
column43: easily transferable across borders
column44: and doesn‚Äôt suffer from the considerable transaction and administration costs paid to banks
column45: currency markets and financial traders. Being a relative new market
column47: with no mathematical mechanism to predict how it will act in the future
column48: it really it is a case of buyer beware. Our only tip would be ‚Äì don‚Äôt put in more than you can afford to lose.::2017-11-13T18:59:41Z::Bitcoin::Alicia (Lucy) Cameron::Business

column1: 266::https://theconversation.com/explainer-what-are-initial-coin-offerings-icos-and-why-are-investors-flocking-to-them-84330::The Conversation::article::Explainer: what are initial coin offerings (ICOs) and why are investors flocking to them?::Within the world of cryptocurrencies
column2: ICOs are the way to raise funds ‚Äì¬†but without any government oversight.::Initial coin offerings ‚Äì or ICOs ‚Äì have become enormously popular with investors. They have raised more than US$1.8 billion so far in 2017 and one recent ICO raised US$35m in under 30 seconds. But they are proving unpopular with governments around the world. The Chinese and South Korean governments have shut them down
column3: while US regulators have issued a warning that ICOs may be subject to securities laws. This is all part and parcel of the rise in cryptocurrencies in recent years. Bitcoin is the most famous
column4: as the original and still dominant iteration. It was created as a form of digital cash
column5: with a unique property: it is not backed by any bank or government. And it was specifically designed not to be centralised. For this reason it has always had a certain lawless aspect to it and has become the currency of online digital crime. But it is also having a real moment ‚Äì one bitcoin is currently worth more than US$5
column6: 000. Within the cryptocurrency space ICOs have become the favoured way to raise funds in a manner akin to venture capital funding ‚Äì but without any of the oversight normally found in that process. ICOs are typically built on the technology of another cryptocurrency called Ethereum. Created by a programming prodigy
column7: 23-year-old Vitalik Buterin
column8: Ethereum was designed as a ‚Äúworld computer‚Äù rather than simply a form of money. Like Bitcoin
column9: Ethereum is a decentralised payment network with its own cryptocurrency (technically called Ether) that allows anonymous transactions to be sent across the internet without the need for a bank or other middleman. Instead
column10: transactions are stored on the blockchain
column11: a decentralised ledger. Where it differs from Bitcoin is that
column12: as well as allowing currency to run on its network
column13: Ethereum can run all sorts of things including ‚Äúsmart contracts‚Äù
column14: which are a form of digital contract that executes automatically once a certain set of conditions is met. ICOs are built on these contracts. An ICO involves creating a sellable token (or coin) that can be purchased with existing cryptocurrencies (such as Bitcoin or Ether). The investor effectively purchases digital tokens that can be used within a specified ecosystem. Take this made-up example: an ICO for a new online betting venture
column15: ‚ÄúConversation Casinos‚Äù
column16: might issue coins
column17: ‚ÄúConversation Coins‚Äù
column18: which investors could buy and then use to make bets in Conversation Casinos (which would only accept and pay out Conversation Coins). Investors could also decide to hold onto their coins
column19: speculating that the business will be successful
column20: which will increase the demand for the coins and their market value. In many ways
column21: these tokens are not unlike the virtual currencies found in computer games like World of Warcraft and Second Life. They have a utility value
column22: in that they are the digital venture‚Äôs medium of exchange (the money). But
column23: often what attracts investors is the speculative value of tokens on cryptocurrency exchanges
column24: rather than the originally intended use. The ICO model has attracted scammers who lure gullible investors into ICOs that are unlikely to ever generate a return. And
column25: since ICOs are completely unregulated
column26: investors have no recourse should the project not deliver or simply disappear. Some ICOs do not allow citizens from certain countries
column27: specifically the United States
column28: to participate
column29: in order to avoid coming under the radar of law enforcement agencies. They are also subject to the volatility that blights cryptocurrencies in general. All cryptocurrencies and tokens are tethered to the price of Bitcoin
column30: the coin that acts as the crypto-economy‚Äôs reserve currency. While the Chinese regulators did not explain why they banned ICOs
column31: they were probably most concerned about the danger to investors
column32: given the prevalence of ICO scams. And they probably should be banned if they are merely schemes to avoid securities laws that exist for good reason. Nevertheless
column33: it is clear that ICOs are an interesting innovation. They allow people without access to traditional investment opportunities a chance to invest in companies that appeal to them
column34: without the requirement of a broker (and broker fees). In turn
column35: this allows companies to bypass the traditional venture capital scene and to get their projects in motion quicker.::2017-10-16T14:54:19Z::Bitcoin

column1: 267::https://www.coindesk.com/consensus-magazine/2024/05/09/reimagining-female-empowerment-in-the-age-of-digital-influence-and-crypto/::CoinDesk::article::Reimagining Female Empowerment in the Age of Digital Influence and Crypto::Despite the democratization of technology and access
column2: systemic barriers persist. Stefania Barbaglio has a call to action for Gen-Z women.::In an era where digital natives reign supreme
column3: Gen-Z women are navigating a landscape vastly different from any preceding generation. Born into a world where social networks are as essential as the air they breathe
column4: these individuals wield technology with finesse
column5: utilizing it not only to communicate their identities
column6: engage with others but also to sculpt their public personas. However
column7: amidst the allure of infinite opportunities and the tantalizing prospect of global connectivity lies a paradox: while Gen-Z women are adept at leveraging technology to enhance their personal brands
column8: they may be inadvertently neglecting a crucial opportunity to effect positive change in society. Stefania Barbaglio is the founder of public and investor relations company Cassiopeia. For many young women of this generation
column9: the digital realm serves as both a canvas and a stage. Social media platforms offer a medium through which they can curate their image
column10: projecting an idealized version of themselves to the world without the need for physical alteration. With the rise of influencer culture
column11: these individuals find themselves thrust into the spotlight
column12: their online personas meticulously crafted to garner attention
column13: recognition and status. Yet
column14: in the pursuit of visibility and validation
column15: are they overlooking the broader implications of their digital influence? The proliferation of non-fungible tokens (NFTs) has only served to amplify this phenomenon. For some young women
column16: their digital avatars or profile pictures serve as more than just a representation of self; they are symbols of status within specific online communities. However
column17: in their quest for belonging and recognition
column18: are they sacrificing genuine connections for fleeting virtual validation? Indeed
column19: the sense of community fostered by online interactions can be both empowering and isolating. While digital networks offer the promise of global connectivity
column20: relationships formed in this virtual realm may lack the depth and authenticity of their real-world counterparts. As interactions become increasingly mediated by screens
column21: the nuances of human connection risk being lost in translation. Moreover
column22: while the digital landscape presents boundless opportunities for self-expression and entrepreneurship
column23: it also reflects and perpetuates existing disparities. Women remain underrepresented in industries such as finance and technology
column24: and the world of crypto is no exception. Despite the democratization of technology and access
column25: systemic barriers persist
column26: hindering the full participation of women in these male-dominated spaces. See also: Women Who Web3 Amid these challenges lies a unique opportunity for Gen-Z women to rewrite the narrative. With the power of technology at their fingertips
column27: they possess the tools to dismantle patriarchal structures and create a more inclusive future. The time is ripe for them to seize this opportunity
column28: to harness their collective voices and drive meaningful change. However
column29: as we navigate this pivotal moment in history
column30: it is essential to ask: do Gen-Z women truly grasp the magnitude of the opportunity before them? Are they cognizant of the power they wield as agents of change
column31: or are they too preoccupied with crafting the perfect Instagram post? While the allure of digital influence may be intoxicating
column32: it is imperative that Gen-Z women recognize their capacity to effect real-world change. By leveraging their online platforms not only to cultivate their personal brands but also to advocate for social justice and gender equality
column33: they can redefine what it means to be empowered in the digital age. The women of Gen-Z stand at a crossroads
column34: poised to shape the future in ways unimaginable to previous generations. It is incumbent upon them to embrace their potential as catalysts for change
column35: to transcend the confines of virtual validation and embark on a journey toward meaningful impact. For in the convergence of technology and empowerment lies the promise of a more equitable and inclusive world for all. Edited by Daniel Kuhn. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column1: 272::https://theconversation.com/with-a-new-futures-market-bitcoin-is-going-mainstream-86852::The Conversation::article::With a new futures market
column2: Bitcoin is going mainstream::The introduction of Bitcoin futures contracts will remove a lot of the financial risk associated with the cryptocurrency.::The Chicago Mercantile Exchange will soon begin trading Bitcoin derivatives (futures contracts)
column3: signalling the cryptocurrency is now a mainstream asset class. Bitcoin has had limited use in the mainstream economy in part because the volatility of its price. The value of the currency might go up or down significantly between the time a deal is struck and delivery. The introduction of Bitcoin futures contracts will allow investors to manage this risk
column4: and make it safer to hold and trade in Bitcoin. This will make the cryptocurrency more accessible to individuals and businesses
column5: and encourage developers to build more products and services on top of the technology.  Futures and other derivatives are contracts between two parties to fix the price of an underlying asset (currencies
column6: shares
column7: commodities etc.) over a period of time or for a future transaction. The buyer of these contracts commits to purchase the underlying asset at a set price and at a certain date
column8: and the seller commits to sell. There are two main uses for these contracts. First
column9: to reduce price risk by freezing future prices. The second use is speculation. For instance
column10: a speculator would commit to buy a commodity/share/currency at a certain time
column11: hoping that the market price at the time of delivery is higher than the price set in the contract. Airlines commonly buy long term oil future contracts to hedge against the potential increase in fuel price
column12: or to take advantage of what they believe to be a low price. Similarly
column13: future contracts will enable traders to lock in the value of Bitcoin for a defined period of time. This effectively removes the risk associated with fluctuation in value. In addition
column14: since these contracts will be traded on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange
column15: the exchange effectively guarantees that both buyers and sellers will abide by the agreement. Read more: Price hikes in Ether and Bitcoin aren't the signs of a bubble In 2010
column16: one Bitcoin was worth less than one hundredth of an Australian cent. As of Monday the 6th of November
column17: the price is near A$10
column18: 000. The market capitalisation of Bitcoin is now well over A$160 billion
column19: which is larger than the GDP of most small countries. As the price of Bitcoin has grown
column20: so too have transaction volumes
column21: showing an increasing use of the cryptocurrency. As a result
column22: Bitcoin is starting to look like a credible investment in any respectable financial portfolio. Although
column23: this is not the first futures contract for cryptocurrency. Futures contracts already exist for both Ethereum and Monero. But the Chicago Mercantile Exchange‚Äôs futures contract is significant as the CME group manages not only the Chicago Mercantile Exchange
column24: but also the Chicago Board of Trade and New York Mercantile Exchange and Commodity Exchange. Combined
column25: these exchanges represent the largest derivative market in the world. The decision to issue futures contracts on Bitcoin rather than another derivative is also significant. So far Bitcoin derivatives have mainly been swap agreements. A swap is a commonly used financial tool where two parties agree to swap financial instruments
column26: such as interest or currencies. The key point is that the two parties
column27: the buyer and seller
column28: make a deal directly with each other. As a swap agreement is not done through an exchange
column29: the risk of a party not delivering on the agreement can be quite high. If one party decides to opt out
column30: the agreement has to be terminated. This leaves the other party exposed. Futures contracts eliminate this ‚Äúcounterparty‚Äù risk
column31: as the exchange clears the transaction and guarantees delivery. And unlike swaps
column32: futures contracts are standardised (in term of size
column33: how much is going to be traded
column34: and maturity date etc.). This means futures contracts can be traded at any time until maturity
column35: making them very liquid and accessible. Read more: Taking Bitcoin to the stockmarket won't do much for its risky image The lack of a futures market in Bitcoin was a significant barrier to it becoming a mainstream asset class. You can buy and sell forward contracts on the Fijian dollar
column36: for instance
column37: meaning that institutional funds anywhere in the world can hold Fijian dollars in their portfolio and manage the risks of that asset. But they cannot yet do that with Bitcoin. Until now
column38: there has been no way to offload the risks associated with fluctuating prices. An investor could always hold the cryptocurrency
column39: but they would do so fully exposed to price volatility. The introduction of Bitcoin futures contracts will allow traders to hedge against this volatility and eliminate the currency risk. This will make Bitcoin more attractive for both individuals and corporations. As crypto-assets become a mainstream investment class
column40: other products emerge around them (such as exchange traded funds). It will also have a similar effect to that of mainstreaming share ownership - enabling a much larger fraction of the population to diversify their asset portfolios and income streams. This will unlock some of the value currently being built on cryptocurrencies and blockchain technology - new products and services - that are currently only accessible to a relatively small number of the early enthusiasts and those helping build the technology. The increased flow of investment funds into Bitcoin will likely push prices up further
column41: but it will also incentivise more work to build products and services on the technology. Bitcoin just went mainstream.::2017-11-06T19:20:21Z::Bitcoin

column1: 273::https://www.coindesk.com/business/2024/05/09/crypto-for-advisors-defi-yields-the-revival/::CoinDesk::article::Crypto for Advisors: DeFi Yields
column2: the Revival::Crews Enochs
column3: from Index Coop
column4: discusses the revival of DeFi Yields and D.J. Windle answers questions about DeFi investing in Ask an Expert. 2024's Revival of DeFi Yields: This Time It's Organic Ask an Expert Keep Reading::In today‚Äôs Crypto for Advisors newsletter
column5: Crews Enochs
column6: from Index Coop discusses the revival of of DeFi Yield and how it will be organic this time. DJ Windle answers questions about DeFi investing in Ask an Expert. - S.M. You‚Äôre reading Crypto for Advisors
column7: CoinDesk‚Äôs weekly newsletter that unpacks digital assets for financial advisors. Subscribe here to get it every Thursday. In past cycles
column8: yields in DeFi have largely been paid in novel
column9: valueless and inflationary governance tokens. The result was initial bursts of unsustainable activity on new protocols and gains for early entrants. Everyone else was left holding the bag. As digital asset yields have soared in recent months ‚Äì stablecoin and ETH yield rates hovered above 20%
column10: far exceeding the base rate in traditional finance ‚Äì some have evinced skepticism about this new cycle of yield farming. But while inflationary dynamics impact current points farming trends
column11: overall the increasing rates are driven by organic and more sustainable demand than in past cycles. Up until early 2023
column12: liquid staking yield was the benchmark rate for digital assets and the only organic yield left
column13: as borrowing demand dried up during the bear market. While the liquid staking rates exceeded federal funds rate for much of 2022
column14: rate hikes last year rendered liquid staking unattractive. Nevertheless
column15: liquid staking remained a solid organic option for digital asset users who didn‚Äôt want to move their capital off-chain. As market conditions began to improve in Q1
column16: digital asset yields began to climb. At the end of April
column17: enterprising digital asset users could earn over 31% APY on Ethena
column18: Maker moved the DAI savings rate up to 15% and lending protocols Aave and Compound offer 6-10% to lenders. While these opportunities are undeniably attractive
column19: digital users who recall previous cycles may wonder where these yields come from. For the most part
column20: stablecoin and ETH yields are sourced from interest paid to lenders by overcollateralized borrowers. Stablecoins in particular are the most liquid and in-demand asset in the digital asset ecosystem
column21: and users are borrowing them to lever up exposure to their favorite asset. On the higher end of the risk/reward continuum
column22: some of the biggest opportunities come from points speculation. The enthusiasm for EigenLayer points
column23: most notably
column24: has driven up yield rates for lending ETH
column25: as speculators anticipate an EIGEN token airdrop later this month. Interest in a potential Ethena drop has driven demand for stablecoins. While airdrop speculation is undeniably inflationary
column26: borrowers are paying real interest in stablecoins or ETH that lenders can realize as profit now. Read more about Airdrop points here. Digital asset users who are interested in lending directly to EigenLayer and Ethena points farmers can utilize protocols like Gearbox. Given the extreme enthusiasm for points farming
column27: borrowers are not cost-sensitive and willing to pay upwards of 30-40% to fund their leveraged points farming. Users who are uncomfortable lending against exotic new assets
column28: like Ethena‚Äôs sUSDe or liquid restaking tokens
column29: can lend via tried-and-true protocols like Compound and Aave. The Ethena and EigenLayer assets have not been onboarded as collateral for Aave and Compound
column30: where ETH
column31: staked ETH
column32: and USDC remain the primary forms of collateral. Nevertheless
column33: Aave and Compound have enjoyed the second-order effects of the interest in points farming
column34: as well as overall price improvements in Q1. Regardless of platform or protocol
column35: all lending in crypto is overcollateralized
column36: mitigating risk for lenders. That said
column37: lenders do run the risk that borrowing could dry up on whatever protocol they use
column38: resulting in lower yields. Overall
column39: market watchers anticipate that speculative fervor will drive borrowing demand through the next few quarters. Given the cost-insensitivity of borrowers participating in leveraged points farming and other speculative investments
column40: the opportunities for lenders are significant. While conservative digital asset users are understandably concerned about unsustainable yields
column41: current lending infrastructure better isolates risk. For digital asset users who are uncomfortable engaging directly with novel primitives
column42: lending offers an opportunity to benefit from borrower enthusiasm. ‚Äì Crews Enochs
column43: Ecosystem Growth Lead
column44: Index Coop Q. How might new government regulations affect DeFi investing? As DeFi platforms mature
column45: government oversight is expected to increase. This could lead to the implementation of standardized regulatory frameworks
column46: which may include stricter KYC and AML policies. While these measures are designed to protect investors and prevent illicit activities
column47: they could also limit the anonymity and flexibility that many DeFi users currently enjoy. For the average investor
column48: this means a safer but potentially more cumbersome investment process. Q. What changes with traditional banks' get involved in DeFi? The involvement of traditional financial institutions in DeFi could bring a blend of innovation and stability to the ecosystem. Banks can provide expertise in risk management and access to a broader customer base
column49: which could lead to more capital flowing into DeFi. However
column50: this might also result in lower yields due to the conservative nature of traditional banking. Q. Do DAO's impact DeFi yields and security? DAOs (Decentralized Autonomous Organizations) are integral to the governance of many DeFi protocols
column51: offering a level of transparency and community involvement not seen in traditional finance. They allow stakeholders to vote on key decisions
column52: including those affecting yield rates and security measures. This can lead to more aligned interests between users and developers
column53: potentially resulting in more robust and user-centric platforms. - D.J. Windle

column1: 275::https://blockworks.co/news/kevin-owocki-permissionless-gitcoin::Blockworks::article::Kevin Owocki on building a ‚Äòpro-topian‚Äô future for blockchains::Gitcoin founder Kevin Owocki is all about regenerative crypto ecosystems that are pro-social
column2: pro-environmental and pro-topian.::Pro-topianism is the belief in improving systems with every new iteration Permissionless II by Blockworks Kevin Owocki
column3: the founder of Gitcoin
column4: has a bold vision for blockchains. After recently revealing his intentions to return to Gitcoin
column5: an open-source software funding platform
column6: the founder has been looking into different ways to innovate the space. Since its genesis in 2019
column7: the platform claims it has funded over 3
column8: 000 different projects
column9: donating over $50 million to fund public goods with a cumulative grantee market cap of $28.2 billion. In an interview with Blockworks at Permissionless II
column10: Owocki spoke about his vision for the future of blockchains and his plans to continue growing the public goods sector. Keep reading for more excerpts from Blockworks‚Äô interview with Owocki. __________________________________________________________________________ Blockworks: You have previously mentioned that you believe in a ‚Äúpro-topian‚Äù‚Äô future. Could you tell me what that means and how it differs from a
column11: let‚Äôs say
column12: utopian future? Owocki: The movement that I am trying to stimulate is about regenerative crypto ecosystems that are pro-social
column13: pro-environmental and pro-topian. This means that it gets better with every iteration
column14: whereas utopian is some ultimate destiny of where the world could go that is positive. I think in order to do that
column15: you can look at it from a game theory perspective. If you can have positive sum games instead of negative sum games
column16: if you can have repeat interactions between participants instead of no-repeat interactions
column17: you can have low miscommunication and you can evolve trust and pro-social behavior. The one that I want to focus on for this conversation is repeat interactions
column18: [and] the reason why is because it evolves pro-social behavior. If you [screw] me over once I‚Äôm not going to do business with you again
column19: but if Ethereum is a dark forest and every address looks like every other address
column20: then you‚Äôre not going to get these repeat interactions where we can evolve with trust for each other. You‚Äôre going to get people who [screw] you over and they‚Äôre going to be able to hide amongst everyone else. So
column21: what we need to do is enable the ability to track individual actors in the system so that we can evolve repeat interactions. Read more: Gitcoin‚Äôs co-founder wants to return from the sidelines I took an Uber here today. I don‚Äôt want to know the guy
column22: where he lives
column23: how old he is
column24: or his birthday
column25: but I do want to know if he‚Äôs going to get me there safely and reasonably quickly. So
column26: I think a lot about how our financial lives are intertwined with our identity. The whole line that we‚Äôre walking in Web3 is that we want to do privacy-preserving identity. Blockworks: How do you think you can achieve privacy-preserving identity in Web3? Owocki: The problem I‚Äôm focused on is Sybil resistance
column27: which is one human
column28: one vote DAOs as opposed to one token
column29: one vote DAOs. If we want Web3 to scale to the people whose financial lives are not their investments or their houses in the Hamptons
column30: if we want Web3 to scale the labor
column31: we have to build more democratic Web3 ecosystems as opposed to plutocratic
column32: one token
column33: one vote ecosystems. The way I explained that
column34: you could be led into thinking that it‚Äôs binary
column35: but it‚Äôs actually a spectrum. The thing is that once you have a primitive for one human one vote
column36: you can build things that are a spectrum between one token
column37: one vote and that‚Äôs what Gitcoin is. It‚Äôs quadratic funding and quadratic voting
column38: which is between one human
column39: one vote and one token
column40: one vote. Blockworks: What exactly is quadratic funding? Owocki: So the way quadratic funding works at Gitcoin
column41: is every quarter we have a million dollar matching pool
column42: and that million dollar matching pool is allocated to the results of a crowdfunding campaign ‚Äî we‚Äôre matching contributions from the crowd. The thing is
column43: we‚Äôre not matching off the base amount of capital that is put in. Primarily
column44: we‚Äôre matching on the base number of contributors to that grant. So basically
column45: if you raise a $100 grant with 100 contributors
column46: and a whale raises a $100 grant
column47: the individual contributors will get 95% of the matching pool. To put simply
column48: what quadratic funding does is it weighs the votes of the people who have a lot of capital less than the projects that have a lot of small contributions that are funding them. So basically
column49: it becomes something that is in between one token
column50: one vote
column51: and one human
column52: one vote. Blockworks: How do you see all of this playing out in the Web3 ecosystem space? What do you envision will happen in the future? Owocki: So here‚Äôs the take: In nature there‚Äôs natural selection
column53: which is the survival of the fittest species according to which organisms survive or which group of organisms survive. In crypto
column54: we have market selection
column55: which is basically capital flow. You‚Äôve got these crazy summer
column56: winter cycles in which you have had 1
column57: 000x growth
column58: and you get all these scams and viruses that are self consuming
column59: and then you get the extinction events where only the strong survive. Because it‚Äôs an evolutionary ecosystem
column60: it‚Äôs changing so much
column61: and the most effective tactic available evolutionarily changes over time. In the early days
column62: it was just forking Bitcoin
column63: and adding privacy
column64: then it became Ethereum forks
column65: then it became ICOs and alt layer-ones. Later the meta became PFP projects and DAOs
column66: and now we‚Äôre at a point where ordinals
column67: and Friend.Tech are the latest meta. What I think is interesting is that as the ecosystem evolves
column68: the meta is always changing. Read more: Bitcoin Ordinals creator wants to clean up BRC-20 standard The cool thing about meta is once someone figures out what the new meta is
column69: there‚Äôs a bunch of copycat projects that just replicate it. The cool thing about evolution is that you get this punctuated equilibrium where someone discovers a new meta
column70: then everyone copies it until that meta is no longer the most effective tactic available and the ecosystem moves onto something else. What that does is create a lot of advantages for people who are going to be the first to discover some new punctuated equilibrium. This is my big bet. It‚Äôs that the next layer of ecosystems is going to be whatever the next cycle is
column71: and then another layer out from that
column72: we‚Äôre going to finally get to a point where funding public goods and democratic DAOs are going to be their own evolutionary tree. I want Gitcoin to be a keystone species that every other project in the ecosystem depends on in order to enable Sybil resistance
column73: and in order to enable public goods funding. So for now

column3: 000+ in NEXO Tokens! Share this article Cryptocurrency startups are increasingly adopting an aggressive form of fundraising known as open-ended or rolling funding rounds. This approach allows startups to continuously raise capital and rapidly boost their valuations
column4: in contrast to the traditional venture capital model of discrete funding rounds spaced over several years. According to a report from Bloomberg
column5: the rise of open-ended funding rounds in the crypto industry reflects both the sector‚Äôs recovery from the 2022 bear market and venture funds‚Äô desire to deploy previously static cash. With this fundraising model
column6: earlier investors benefit from the rapid increase in a startup‚Äôs valuation driven by commitments from later backers. While some investors and industry experts view these ‚Äúfluid valuations‚Äù as perplexing and potentially lacking in fundamental drivers
column7: the report claims that the traditional approach to venture capital formation may not be suited to digital-asset companies. ‚ÄúCapital formation in crypto is always evolving ‚Äî governance

column1: 278::https://theconversation.com/beyond-bitcoin-the-power-struggle-over-trust-based-technology-84367::The Conversation::article::Beyond Bitcoin: The power struggle over trust-based technology::The development of distributed trust technologies is making traditional institutions like banks
column2: corporations and governments nervous. Those who have power like to hold onto it. What‚Äôs next?::Technology blogs and financial news networks are buzzing about blockchain
column3: a cryptographic
column4: distributed trust technology. The key innovation is how it reduces the need for central third-party institutions to serve as central authorities of trust ‚Äî banks
column5: courts
column6: large corporations
column7: stock markets and even governments
column8: for example. Distributed trust enables co-operative forms of organization without a centre. It can distribute power away from centralized institutions to those that traditionally have less power. Such powerful institutions do not let go of their influence easily. The ongoing debate about how to regulate distributed trust technologies assumes that the advocates of the technologies will seek both legal status and enforceability. Scholars propose that such developments in distributed trust are a competitive threat to nation-state paper currencies. Much of the current
column9: popular focus is on cryptographic currency ‚Äî or cryptocurrency ‚Äî applications such as Bitcoin. Regulators are struggling to deal with a fundamental shift in market structure. National central banks are implementing policies to keep control and regulate distributed trust technology. For example
column10: the Chinese government has banned several types of distributed trust activities
column11: and is launching its own non-distributed
column12: centralized digital currency. The Japanese government has made Bitcoin a legal payment method
column13: and major Japanese banks are planning to launch a J-Coin digital currency pegged to the Yen which may be built on a blockchain. Russia initially treated non-approved currency trades as illegal
column14: but is now determining how to regulate them. In fact
column15: traditional centralized
column16: powerful organizations like banks
column17: governments
column18: regulators and technology behemoths are all spending billions figuring out how to use and control distributed trust technologies. But distributed trust technologies have many uses beyond cryptocurrency. Organizational theory has a lot to say about this transition. Distributed trust technologies are organized in what we call a Community Form (C-Form) of organization. C-Forms are not new. They have been around since the 1800s when the Oxford English Dictionary was created by a distributed community of volunteers. The growth of C-Forms was accelerated by technological developments enabling inexpensive peer-to-peer communication. C-Forms came into focus with the last internet-enabled major organizational shift to distributed information-creation platforms. As a result of that innovation
column19: we have seen many forms of information production shift to C-Forms. Open source software such as the Linux computer operating system
column20: which competes with Microsoft Windows and Apple macOS
column21: is produced and shared by individuals in C-Forms instead of centralized software companies. Encyclopedias such as Wikipedia are created by individuals in a C-Form instead of a centralized publishing house. Video content on Vimeo is produced and shared by individuals in a C-Form instead of centralized studios. Similarly
column22: distributed trust technologies are shifting the organizational landscape of how trust is produced and managed from centralized institutions to a C-Form. The development of distributed trust technologies is having a similar enabling effect on the growth of C-Forms replacing the trust functions of centralized institutions. Fundamentally
column23: this is a decentralization of power. Many of our previous assumptions about formal organization are being challenged by shifts to distributed forms of trust. Individuals can now enter into direct peer-to-peer trusted exchanges with strangers. They no longer need a central institution to vouch for the other party. A blockchain-enabled microgrid in Brooklyn is already allowing individuals to sell their excess solar energy directly to neighbours without involving a central utility company. This is a drastic shift to many of the underlying assumptions about how markets and society are organized. As power centralizes
column24: opportunities emerge. Many Silicon Valley success stories are simply centralized platforms. They capitalize on the power and legitimacy of enabling trusted interactions for others. Just as Uber matches riders to drivers
column25: Facebook matches consumers to advertisers. This centralization of power has created an opportunity for distributed trust. The major platforms stand to lose their power as distributed trust takes hold. Such powerful organizations will no longer be needed. But those in power tend to try to hold onto power. Microsoft faced a challenge to its centralized market power as open-source software C-Forms grew. The ‚ÄúHalloween Documents‚Äù were internal Microsoft communications about responding to the strategic threat of open-source software. One tactic detailed was ‚ÄúFUD‚Äù (fear
column26: uncertainty
column27: and doubt). We are now seeing similar responses to distributed trust technologies. JPMorgan Chase & Co. CEO Jamie Dimon called Bitcoin a ‚Äúfraud
column28: ‚Äù and claims governments are going to close down ‚Äúcrypto things.‚Äù He is being accused of market abuse in Sweden by a company called Blockswater. Blockswater alleges he ‚Äúdeliberately spread false and misleading information.‚Äù In other words
column29: Dimon is being accused of creating FUD. We used to assume that large centralized organizations had legitimacy and power. But that‚Äôs starting to change. As distributed trust technologies develop
column30: we will continue to see this power shift. We must question the role of centralized organizations in a time of distributed trust. The key now is to ensure that we use insights from organizational theory
column31: and sociology
column32: to shape our joint societal future in a world of distributed trust. It‚Äôs a world where the role of powerful central institutions will be greatly diminished. With such insight
column33: we will be able to design a more equitable future for all.::2017-10-01T23:03:49Z::Bitcoin

column1: 279::https://www.coindesk.com/consensus-magazine/2024/05/08/kgothatso-ngako-how-i-brought-the-machankura-bitcoin-app-to-africa/::CoinDesk::article::Kgothatso Ngako: How I Brought the Machankura Bitcoin App to Africa::Ngako is a speaker at this year's Consensus festival
column2: in Austin
column3: Texas
column4: May 29-31.::Ever since Satoshi Nakamoto dropped the white paper
column5: one of the selling points of bitcoin has been
column6: ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need a bank. All you need is a smartphone.‚Äù But what if you don‚Äôt have a smartphone? This is the case for millions of people in Africa
column7: which is why Kgothatso Ngako
column8: a former software developer for Amazon
column9: created the no-frills app called Machankura. Kgothatso Ngako is speaker at this year's Consensus festival
column10: in Austin
column11: Texas
column12: May 29-31. Or maybe ‚Äúapp‚Äù is misleading
column13: as it‚Äôs designed to work on simple phones that lack touchscreens or cameras or the bells and whistles of an iPhone. All you need is the ability to text. Using the Lightning Network
column14: Machankura (slang for ‚Äúmoney‚Äù) lets users send and receive bitcoin
column15: with or without the internet. This is something most of us take for granted. Consider a bitcoin wallet address: Usually it‚Äôs something that looks like ‚Äú37LaxH5ihB5hZMXs72fofA8qzanipuWTF!‚Äù Typing it in manually would ruin your week. If you make a typo ‚Äì and you‚Äôll make a typo ‚Äì your bitcoin is lost forever. Thankfully we can copy and paste this monster using our laptop or smartphone. But without a smartphone? ‚ÄúThe user may not have copy-and-paste-functionality
column16: ‚Äù says Ngako. ‚ÄúBut bitcoin has these wonderful things called lightning addresses
column17: which are like an email.‚Äù Now
column18: users of Machankura can use bitcoin by just typing in normal-looking numbers and email addresses. Before heading to Austin for Consensus
column19: Ngako shares how Facebook did something smart that inspired Machankura
column20: how its 15
column21: 000 users are spending bitcoin
column22: and why the usage patterns in Africa are
column23: in a sense
column24: surprisingly similar to the patterns in the United States. Interview has been condensed and lightly edited for clarity. Before creating Machankura
column25: you helped spread the word about bitcoin in Africa. How so exactly? Kgothatso Ngako: I grew up in a township called Mamelodi. So the main barrier at the time was that a lot of the literature that explains Bitcoin is in English
column26: right? But we have all these different African languages. So if somebody is intrigued by Bitcoin and they don't speak English
column27: how would they get content to learn about it? So we started an organization called Exonumia. Its aim is to translate Bitcoin literature into African languages. What Bitcoin literature did you use? I‚Äôm guessing the white paper? Yeah
column28: the white paper. A few simple ones. The email Satoshi sent out when Bitcoin version 0.1 released
column29: and Hal Finney's reply to that. And
column30: of course
column31: the "I Am Hodling" post. Classic. And a few others
column32: like Understanding Lightning Network and The History of Bitcoin and the Kenya Government. We're also translating a few books
column33: like ‚ÄúThe Blocksize War" and "21 lessons." And then eventually you launched Machankura. What was the goal? So I‚Äôm trying to tell as many people as I can about Bitcoin with my translated articles
column34: but I‚Äôm met with all these problems. A person may not have a smartphone. If they have a smartphone
column35: they don‚Äôt have data bundles on it. If they do have interest or you give them a Wi-Fi hotspot
column36: they don‚Äôt have enough space on their phone. All of these problems are solved by having a service that a person does not have to install on their phone
column37: and does not have to pay to use. So USSD [Unstructured Supplementary Service Data] is pretty much that. It‚Äôs like a website that is reverse-billed. Look at what Facebook does in developing countries
column38: and I think Twitter did as well. Facebook is available for free
column39: right? People on a mobile cellular connection can access Facebook without paying to access Facebook
column40: because Facebook will settle the bill with the telecom at a later time. So most USSD interfaces work on a similar principle. So what does that look like from the user‚Äôs experience
column41: exactly? Especially if they‚Äôre not using a smartphone? The user may not have copy-and-paste-functionality. But bitcoin has these wonderful things called lightning addresses
column42: which are like an email
column43: but for human-readable addresses. So mine is kgothatso@8333.mobi. I can share this with pretty much everyone. And alternatively
column44: if someone has my number
column46: they could also use that as my lighting address. This is your phone number? Yeah. So whether or not you have copy-and-paste functionality
column47: if you have Bitcoin
column48: you can type out either of the two. And then you can send me Bitcoin. Amazing. How many users do you have
column49: and where are they? So we‚Äôre at almost 15
column50: 000 users now. We‚Äôre in a few countries ‚Äî South Africa
column51: Nigeria
column52: Kenya
column53: Ghana
column54: Malawi
column55: and so on and so forth. What are some of the things people are doing with it? In South Africa
column56: we have a concept called Stockpile. In other places it has other names. In Kenya they call it a ‚Äúchama.‚Äù Effectively
column57: it‚Äôs a tabletop accounting. You come together as a group of people in somebody‚Äôs home
column58: and you put money on the table. And if we all contributed an equal amount each month
column59: we‚Äôre going to distribute it at the end of the year
column60: or maybe buy groceries or whatever in bulk. Interesting. So this is a way to nudge people to save money
column61: through positive peer pressure and accountability? Yes. And also it can be an economic ‚Äústarter pack‚Äù for people in the group
column62: to help them buy in bulk. This would satisfy a minimum purchase order that one person couldn‚Äôt do on their own
column63: but the group can. Am I right that instead of trying to get merchants to accept Bitcoin ‚Äî which can be tricky ‚Äî they‚Äôre mostly using bitcoin to purchase gift cards? And where are they spending it? Yes. The top culprits are [internet] airtime
column64: electricity
column65: and groceries. And if you have a gift card for a grocery store in South Africa
column66: you effectively have so much you can do with your bitcoin. You can pay your bills because some grocery stores let you pay your bills at the till
column67: you could book a bus trip
column68: you can even pay for a flight at the grocery store. How many users
column69: from what you can tell
column70: are using Bitcoin as the primary way to pay their bills and get through life? That's not a lot of users. That's a very small number of users from the total. And a lot of people are still working normal jobs that do not pay Bitcoin
column71: right? So maybe it‚Äôs like 10% or 20% of the total users. So what‚Äôs the main thing that people are using it for? Exploration
column72: I think. That's the major thing. A lot of people are saying
column73: ‚ÄúOkay. I've heard about this Bitcoin thing. So how do I use it?" So a lot of people create an account and then look around
column74: and then you're like
column75: "Oh
column76: okay. This person hasn't came back." And then an all-time high comes around
column77: and then that person is back again. Honestly
column78: that sounds very similar to how people use bitcoin in the U.S. That‚Äôs exactly how it is. Thanks Kgothatso
column79: good luck with the project and see you at Consensus. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column1: 280::https://ambcrypto.com/dogecoin-price-prediction-all-the-reasons-why-0-12-is-still-a-target/::AMBCrypto::article::Dogecoin price prediction ‚Äì All the reasons why DOGE can still fall to $0.12::Dogecoin's price depends on a host of different factors - This may be one of them::Dogecoin‚Äôs price depends on a host of different factors ‚Äì This may be one of them  Not many would expect that development activity would have an impact on Dogecoin‚Äôs [DOGE] price. Funnily enough
column2: however
column3: AMBCrypto found that assertion to be untrue. We realized this after examining the metric in question. At press time
column4: development activity on the network was flat. This has been the case since 24 April. However
column5: DOGE has also been consistently consolidating between $0.13 and $0.16 during this very period. Development activity measures the rate at which engineers publicly improve a project‚Äôs network. Looking back
column6: the metric jumped from 0.39 to 16.24 back in February.  At the time
column7: DOGE‚Äôs price skyrocketed from $0.08 to $0.14 to correspond with the aforementioned uptick. Something similar transpired between October and November 2023 too
column8: with both the price and development activity moving hand in hand on the charts. Source: Santiment Therefore
column9: it might not be out of place to assume that a hike in the metric might offer a price hike too. Also
column10: if development activity falls
column11: so will Dogecoin‚Äôs price. Now
column12: DOGE could face a hard time reproducing its performance in February and March. Still
column13: it is important to assess other metrics too. This would tell if the prediction is valid or not. One indicator AMBCrypto looked at was the liquidation levels. This indicator shows estimated price levels where liquidation events might occur. A liquidation event occurs when a trader‚Äôs open position is forcefully closed. Most times
column14: this happens because the trader can no longer meet the requirements of keeping the position open. At press time
column15: we noticed that the only possible liquidation points between $0.15 and $0.16 were scanty. This lack of liquidity could put DOGE‚Äôs price at risk. This could be the case because Dogecoin‚Äôs price might not move to the upside as the zone is not magnetic. Hence
column16: a possible move for DOGE could be a potential sideways movement. In a worst-case scenario
column17: the price might drop to $0.12. Apart from this indicator
column18: AMBCrypto looked at Dogecoin‚Äôs Cumulative Liquidation Levels Delta (CLLD) as well. Source: Hyblock Positive values of the CLLD indicate more long liquidations. On the other hand
column19: Negative values suggest that there are more short liquidations. At press time
column20: the CCLD was positive. From a price perspective
column21: the reading indicates that Dogecoin might undergo a full retrace. If this remains the case
column22: the $0.12 bearish prediction might be validated. In addition to the analysis above
column23: AMBCrypto also evaluated active addresses. At the time of writing
column24: DOGE‚Äôs 24-hour active addresses were 54
column25: 600. Three months ago
column26: this same figure was over 250
column27: 000. Simply put
column28: the decline was proof of decreasing network activity. Beyond that
column29: the one-day circulation was 325.94 million as well. Source: Santiment Is your portfolio green? Check the Dogecoin Profit Calculator Concerning the price
column30: this fall in activity could stop DOGE from exponential growth on the charts. However
column31: if things change for the better
column32: DOGE might make a move towards $0.12.   Disclaimer: AMBCrypto's content is meant to be informational in nature and should not be interpreted as investment advice. Trading

column3: 2020. Accountless cryptocurrency exchange Flyp.me is launching an all-new cryptocurrency exchange platform for Android users that doesn‚Äôt require an account to exchange your crypto. With the help of this platform
column4: crypto users and traders can easily ‚Äúflyp‚Äù cryptocurrencies in a borderless way securely. The exchange offers a unique experience that will help the crypto industry grow and increase its accountless capacity. The Flyp.me platform is a unique option available in the crypto world as it doesn‚Äôt require users to make an account before exchanging/trading cryptocurrencies. The service has been available for crypto users since 2017 and has now been made available on Android phones. Due to this approach
column5: many useful key features of cryptocurrencies are preserved and the control is handed back to the user. Flyp.me allows users complete control over their private keys. This is an extremely important functionality extended to the user. The private keys allow the users complete control over their cryptocurrency holdings and diminishes the power of the exchange in the spirit of the decentralization philosophy. Conventional cryptocurrency exchanges are popular right now but they are also receiving criticism for their continuing demise of the rights and functionalities of cryptocurrencies. By giving users control of their private keys
column6: Flyp.me helps protect users‚Äô rights while providing the functionality needed. Key features of the new accountless crypto exchange include: ‚Ä¢ Support for over 30 cryptocurrencies. ‚Ä¢ 24-hour availability for users around the world. ‚Ä¢ Fast transactions and the ability to flip between different popular cryptocurrencies supported in the platform. ‚Ä¢ Private operations as the exchange don‚Äôt require an account to start trading. ‚Ä¢ Safe operations as the operations are end-to-end supported by state-of-the-art security protocols and measures. ‚Ä¢ Open API integration for other websites and crypto services platforms. This allows other platforms to have a useful symbiotic relationship with the Flyp.me exchange. Flyp.me allows businesses and users to accept or send cryptocurrency with ease
