315::https://theconversation.com/bitcoin-might-not-change-the-world-but-the-blockchain-that-makes-it-work-might-52516::The Conversation::article::Bitcoin might not change the world, but the blockchain that makes it work, might::Digital cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin may have failed to unseat their more traditional rivals, but the technology that underpins Bitcoin may yet bring about a revolution in finance and other industries‚Ä¶::Digital cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin may have failed to unseat their more traditional rivals, but the technology that underpins Bitcoin may yet bring about a revolution in finance and other industries. This technology is called the ‚Äú[blockchain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Block_chain_(database)‚Äù. The blockchain acts as a public database or ledger, and is the technology that stores the details of every exchange of bitcoins. What makes it particularly clever is that it is designed to stop the same bitcoin being spent twice, without the need for a third party (like a bank). Even from the early days of Bitcoin, it was believed that the blockchain could be used for much more than recording Bitcoin transactions. What the blockchain does is record a set of details that include a time, a cryptographic signature linking back to the sender and some data that can represent almost anything. In the case of Bitcoin, it is the number of bitcoins being sent but it could be a digital cryptographic signature, called a ‚Äúhash‚Äù, of any electronic document. One of the earliest demonstrations of the potential of using the blockchain in this way was ‚Äúproof of existence‚Äù, a website that allows a user to upload any document and have its signature recorded for ever on the Bitcoin blockchain. What this does is prove that the person who uploaded the document had that specific document in their possession at a specific time. It can also be used to prove that the document had not been altered in any way from that time. Proof of existence was intended as a demonstration of the potential of the blockchain technology. Startup Stampery has turned this service into a business that allows other companies to ‚Äúdigitally stamp‚Äù any of their electronic documents or emails in order to prove ownership and integrity. This week the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) approved the use of the blockchain as a share ownership register for online retailer Overstock.com. Overstock plans to use alternative trading system technology provided by T0.com, to enable people to buy and sell these shares. The attraction of this system is that it provides instant settlement as opposed to the traditional three day settlement for traditional company stock. T0‚Äôs implementation of its share register uses an extension of the Bitcoin blockchain called ‚ÄúColored Coin‚Äù that was originally seen as adding a ‚Äúsmart contract‚Äù functionality to Bitcoin. One scenario where this could be used would be where someone was sending Bitcoins for the purchase of a house for example, and the currency would only be released if the contracts for the sale went through. Whilst Overstock‚Äôs SEC filing does highlight the advantages of having a public ledger that is theoretically secure, it also stresses the risks. One of those is the fact that Overstock has chosen to make the information stored on the the blockchain ledger accessible by anyone, so investors may have concerns about the privacy of their holdings. However, the main risk is one that is a general issue with all blockchain applications, including Bitcoin. This is the fact it is still not known exactly how secure the system is and whether it has any flaws that could be exploited by hackers. One potential issue around the use of the blockchain is the fact that there are now a large number of different implementations, all based on different technological approaches. IBM, JP Morgan, Intel and a group of other companies have just launced the ‚ÄúOpen Ledger Project‚Äù. Open Ledger does not use the Bitcoin blockchain but implements a different scheme that is more suited to companies wanting to restrict access to the blockchain ledger. There is no doubt that the ideas behind the blockchain are clever ones and were critical to enabling a digital currency like Bitcoin to operate with many of the same properties as cash does in the physical world. When the technology is used for other applications, though, it is not absolutely clear that it actually does anything that can‚Äôt be achieved with other, more conventional technology. It is not the technology that is stopping shares from being settled instantly. It is regulators and the issues they are dealing with in terms of this type of settlement are social and legal ones, not technical. In the hype that surrounds companies that are working on blockchain products, the real challenges facing the actual use of these products are often glossed over, with the main objective being to get rid of third parties but without necessarily replacing all of the positive things those third parties may actually have been doing. It is inevitable that blockchain technology will become a mainstream technology. The level of interest being shown in this technology demonstrates its potential for enabling the development of applications that will bring new approaches to old business problems. It is the social, legal and financial challenges that these changes will surface that may prove a much harder problem to solve.::2015-12-17T13:52:39Z::::David Glance::Home::https://images.theconversation.com/files/106506/original/image-20151217-8112-1nlvbd3.jpg?ixlib=rb-4.1.0&q=45&auto=format&w=1356&h=668&fit=crop
316::https://www.coindesk.com/business/2024/05/14/insider-at-solanas-cypher-protocol-admits-to-stealing-300k/::CoinDesk::article::Insider at Solana's Cypher Protocol Admits to Stealing $300K Consensus 2024: All Eyes on Regulation::Core contributor Hoak blamed his actions on a crippling gambling addiction."::Solana-based crypto trading protocol Cypher has endured its share of hacks and heists. But its latest loss ‚Äì of money meant for down-bad customers ‚Äì was an inside job. On Tuesday
column28: a pseudonymous developer known as Hoak admitted to stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of cryptocurrencies from Cypher's hack reimbursement fund. "I took the funds and gambled them away
column29: Hoak said in a statement, blaming his activity on a crippling gambling addiction." Hoak's admission comes one day after Cypher's founder Barrett accused him of systematically draining troves of valuable cryptos from the protocol's redemption contract over multiple months
column30: beginning in December. Citing on-chain data
column31: Barrett said Hoak ultimately sent assets worth around $300
column32: 000 (at current market prices) to Binance
column33: presumably to cash them out. Hoak broadly stated Tuesday that "the allegations are true." In a tweet
column34: he said he doesn't expect anyone "to let this go unpunished." Barrett told CoinDesk he had sent information about the heist and Hoak's true identity to law enforcement and was following their lead. "This is incredibly saddening to me. I never thought this would be a possibility
column35: having a core contributor who stayed on after the exploit to try and rebuild the project be the one who rugged funds from the redemption contract
column36:
Barrett wrote. Cypher contributors created the redemption contract to reimburse customers who shouldered a $1 million loss in an exploit in August. Barrett said the team discovered the funds were missing after one user reported issues in claiming their redemption. Edited by Nick Baker. 317::https://beincrypto.com/coincall-launches-call-token/::BeInCrypto::article::Coincall Launches CALL Token, Revolutionizing the Virtual Currency Derivatives Platform::Coincall, a leading cryptocurrency derivativies exchange, proudly announces the launch of its native token, CALL.::We use cookies to improve your experience. Coincall, a leading cryptocurrency derivativies exchange, proudly announces the launch of its native token, CALL. CALL is based on the Solana standard protocol, which can be traded freely like other cryptocurrencies and supports derivative settlement services on the Coincall platform starting April 29th, 2024. Designed to enhance user experience and revolutionize the virtual currency derivatives trading landscape, CALL represents a significant milestone for the Coincall ecosystem. CALL token serves as the backbone of Coincall‚Äôs ecosystem, offering a wide range of utilities and benefits to its holders. As a governance token, CALL empowers users to participate in platform decision-making processes, including voting on proposals and shaping the platform‚Äôs future direction. One of the key features of CALL is its utility in the Coincall ecosystem. Holders of CALL tokens enjoy various privileges, including reduced trading fees, access to exclusive features, and participation in reward programs. With CALL, Coincall aims to empower their users and strengthen their connection to the platform. By offering a wide range of benefits and incentives, they are confident that CALL will drive greater engagement and participation within the community. To celebrate the launch of CALL token, Coincall will be hosting various promotional events and giveaways, offering users the opportunity to earn rewards and experience the benefits of CALL firsthand. Limited Time Offer: here CALL Community Airdrop Plan: here Coincall‚Äôs vision extends beyond a DEX confined to a single blockchain. To offer a broader trading market for global users, they plan to launch a cross-chain DEX on the Solana and Ethereum Layer 2 networks. Coincall DEX, a high-performance decentralized derivatives trading platform within the Coincall ecosystem, focuses on options and perpetual contracts, aiming to address liquidity and trust issues in cryptocurrency derivatives trading. In the current market environment, Automated Market Makers (AMMs) use algorithms and machine learning to provide continuous quoting and trading services, alleviating liquidity shortages. However, existing AMMs still have limitations, including dependence on liquidity sources, susceptibility to market price fluctuations, and inadequate adaptability to market trading rules. By efficiently connecting trading users and multiple platforms, Coincall DEX will aggregate decentralized orders to meet user demands and provide security, creating a more transparent and efficient trading environment. This injection of vitality and opportunities will revitalize the cryptocurrency derivatives market, providing users with richer and deeper liquidity, while enhancing trading speed and efficiency. Furthermore, Coincall DEX will employ advanced smart contract technology and security measures to ensure the safety of user assets and fair trading. Coincall DEX is expected to launch within 2024. 318::https://blockworks.co/news/hong-kong-crypto-vc-titan-blockchain-fund::Blockworks::article::Billionaire-backed Hong Kong crypto VC pours $100M into blockchain fund::The Titan Fund will focus on early-stage startups in gaming, metaverse and NFTs, and will prioritize equity investments rather than digital assets.::The Titan Fund will focus on early-stage startups in gaming, metaverse and NFTs, and will prioritize equity investments rather than digital assets weerasak saeku/Shutterstock, modified by Blockworks CMCC Global, a blockchain-focused venture capital firm backed by Hong Kong billionaire Richard Li, aims to provide support for entrepreneurs building companies in the industry. Called the Titan Fund, it has a particular focus on early-stage startups operating in the blockchain verticals of infrastructure, fintech and consumer applications such as gaming, metaverse and non-fungible tokens (NFTs). The Titan Fund‚Äôs investments will be directed towards equity investments in blockchain companies, not digital assets, according to a statement released on Wednesday. Block.one served as the anchor investor, pledging $50 million. CMCC Global, the fund‚Äôs initiator, also contributed a 15% general partner commitment. Other notable investors include Richard Li‚Äôs Pacific Century Group, Hong Kong‚Äôs Jebsen Capital, Winklevoss Capital and Animoca Brands‚Äô co-founder Yat Siu. ‚ÄúThe Titan Fund will empower great entrepreneurs to build the next wave of Web3 and blockchain powered fintech applications,‚Äù Gemini co-founder Cameron Winklevoss said in a statement. ‚ÄúThe last five years have seen a set of new unicorn companies emerge, the next five to ten years will see this trend continue to accelerate as mainstream adoption of blockchain technology proliferates,‚Äù he added. The fund‚Äôs management is a collaborative effort between CMCC Global‚Äôs co-founders Charles Morris and Martin Baumann. This institutional-grade fund is entrusted to State Street as the fund administrator, and EY assumes the role of auditor. Among the fund‚Äôs initial five investments, two have been directed towards Hong Kong-based companies, Baumann told the South China Morning Post. Although there isn‚Äôt a strict mandate specifying the allocation of capital to Hong Kong companies, the primary focus remains on investing in the most promising entrepreneurs globally, Baumann added. The Titan Fund‚Äôs investment portfolio already includes various noteworthy ventures. It played a leading role in backing Mocaverse, an NFT project by Animoca Brands in December. Additionally, the fund invested in Terminal 3, a Hong Kong-based company specializing in blockchain-driven digital identity solutions. Beyond these domestic investments, the Titan Fund ventured into international territory, supporting projects like Informal Systems, co-founded by seasoned crypto expert and Cosmos co-founder Ethan Buchman, as well as the NFT-focused ecommerce platform KickzMeta and its affiliated project, Mooncourt. Further, it engaged with a San Francisco-based Y-combinator team dedicated to innovating in the realm of tokenization of enterprises and assets. With Hong Kong‚Äôs recent introduction of a regulatory licensing program for digital asset operators, there‚Äôs been a surge in interest from various players, especially cryptocurrency exchanges. However, it‚Äôs worth noting that crypto transaction volumes in Hong Kong dropped by about $6 billion between July 2022 and June 2023 compared to the previous year, following a tumultuous period for the industry. This decline also made Hong Kong drop one place in Chainalysis‚Äô most recent global crypto adoption ranking. Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. 319::https://cryptobriefing.com/ey-blockchain-contract-solution-ethereum/::Crypto Briefing::article::EY launches new blockchain solution to manage business contracts on Ethereum::EY's OCM uses Ethereum for streamlined, secure contract execution.::Join the hunt for $12,000,000+ in NEXO Tokens! Share this article EY has launched a new blockchain-based contract management tool, EY OpsChain Contract Manager (OCM), on the Ethereum public chain. The OCM is designed to help businesses execute complex agreements securely, efficiently, and at a lower cost, the company shared in a press release on Wednesday. As noted, the OCM uses smart contracts on the Ethereum public blockchain to automate contract execution and enforce agreed-upon terms. It also uses zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs) to keep confidential data private. With the new solution, EY aims to eliminate the challenge of managing business agreements across numerous operational and technological divisions within and outside organizations. Traditionally, managing complex contracts across different parties and systems can be slow, expensive, and error-prone. By utilizing EY OCM, companies can synchronize data with business partners and uniformly enforce key business terms, such as standardized pricing and volume discounts, the company noted. The solution is expected to create a secure and transparent environment for all parties involved. According to the team, EY‚Äôs solution can integrate with existing enterprise systems via a standardized API, supporting a wide range of business contract types. In other words, enterprises of all sizes can use OCM to manage various types of business contracts. Early adopters are currently testing the system with complex Power Purchasing Agreements that incorporate market prices and strike prices. Paul Brody, EY Global Blockchain Leader, highlights the efficiency of contract automation. He stated: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve identified from past client work that contract automation can improve accuracy while cutting cycle times by more than 90%, and overall contract administration costs by nearly 40%. With our zero-knowledge privacy technology, we have industrialized this capability, and we can now get these benefits at a fraction of the up-front cost. Deploying on a public blockchain is not only cheaper, but also much more scalable, helping enable many-to-many integrations on an open platform with no one company having an unfair advantage by controlling the network. The latest move follows EY‚Äôs debut of a beta version of Nightfall in September 2021 in collaboration with Polygon. Nightfall is a privacy protocol that employs an Optimistic Zero-Knowledge Roll-Up to facilitate private transactions on Ethereum. Nightfall concentrates on enabling private transactions for enterprises on Ethereum, addressing concerns like network congestion and high transaction costs. Its primary use is safeguarding transaction privacy while benefiting from the public Ethereum blockchain‚Äôs security features. 320::https://theconversation.com/the-halving-sounds-like-a-horror-story-and-may-well-turn-out-to-be-one-for-bitcoin-57194::The Conversation::article::The ‚Äúhalving‚Äù sounds like a horror story and may well turn out to be one for Bitcoin::Bitcoin relies on the participation of people and organisations to act as the ‚Äúbankers‚Äù of the system. Called Bitcoin miners, they effectively record each transaction on a ledger called the Blockchain‚Ä¶::Bitcoin relies on the participation of people and organisations to act as the ‚Äúbankers‚Äù of the system. Called Bitcoin miners, they effectively record each transaction on a ledger called the Blockchain and in return, they are awarded with bitcoins. The process of mining is to do a series of calculations to discover a specific number, and the first one to do so gets the reward of 25 bitcoins (valued at approximately US $10,500). In order to increase their chances, Bitcoin miners have large numbers of computers with specialised hardware that consume significant amounts of electricity. The entire Bitcoin system has been estimated to use about 350 Megawatts of electricity which is the same demand as 280,000 US homes. For miners, electricity usage is the majority of the cost of producing bitcoins and this is why China, with its relatively low energy costs, has become the country of choice for this type of operation. The economics of Bitcoin mining only make sense if the price of Bitcoin is maintained. Around July 18th however, Bitcoin will go through a process whereby the reward allocated to Bitcoin miners is halved. This happens every 4 years and was added into the design of Bitcoin as a way of slowly reaching the limit of the total number of Bitcoins to 21 million. The design also assumes that as the production of new Bitcoins from the mining process slows down, the incentives for mining will be made up by adding transaction costs to the process. Of course, unless the price of Bitcoin goes up, more pressure will be put on Bitcoin miners to continue operating after their profits have been slashed. Although anything could happen, Bitcoin miners could potentially decide that mining an alternative cryptocurrency like Ethereum might be easier than continuing with Bitcoin. The uncertainty of what will happen after Bitcoin goes through this ‚Äúhalving‚Äù process has already had one significant casualty. Bitcoin Group, an Australian Bitcoin mining company was hoping to list on the Australian Stock Exchange this year but last month abandoned its plans for an IPO. The Australian Securities and Investment Commission (ASIC) didn‚Äôt believe that Bitcoin Group could assure its capital adequacy after the Bitcoin halving process and so clearly ASIC at least didn‚Äôt think that the price of Bitcoin was going to go up as a result. The truth of the matter is that nobody really knows what will happen. On the one hand, there will be fewer bitcoins being generated each day and some people have argued that this will create a shortage of supply that will drive prices up. This of course assumes that supply of bitcoins is constrained in any way which it is not clear that it is. On the other hand, Bitcoin miners will be making fewer bitcoins and may have to sell more bitcoins to pay their expenses which could drive the price of bitcoins down. Ultimately, if the process of mining bitcoins becomes too unprofitable, they will stop altogether and switch to another cryptocurrency and this would largely spell the end of Bitcoin. Unfortunately, predicting anything about Bitcoin is made more difficult because of a number of factors involved in how the mining process works and ultimately what is actually driving the Bitcoin market. Given that Bitcoin is largely an experiment in creating a novel form of currency, the uncertainty is unsurprising. The designers of Bitcoin possibly expected that the community would be able to respond to knowledge gained as the experiment ran, but that hasn‚Äôt turned out to be the case. Instead, the Bitcoin community has been fractured with an ongoing argument of how to modify one aspect of the Blockchain, what size the blocks that make it up should be. Given that achieving any sort of compromise on this question proved so difficult, the interest in cryptocurrencies is rapidly shifting away from Bitcoin to the Blockchain and to other currencies like Ethereum. Ethereum is like the version 2 that Bitcoin should have had. It has a range of new features that make the Ethereum Blockchain capable of supporting so-called ‚Äúsmart contracts‚Äù but more importantly, it is moving away from the extremely wasteful mining process of Bitcoin to another system that promises to be much more efficient. Given that by 2020, Bitcoin is predicted to be globally using more electricity than the entire country of Denmark currently does, a more efficient system can not come too soon. The halving is another bump in the technological and social experiment that has been the evolution of Bitcoin. Whether it derails the project entirely will only become apparent in the months that follow.::2016-04-03T14:31:21Z::::David Glance::Home::https://images.theconversation.com/files/117200/original/image-20160403-6797-1db503u.jpg?ixlib=rb-4.1.0&q=45&auto=format&w=1356&h=668&fit=crop

column1: 326::https://theconversation.com/the-big-business-revolution-why-the-future-is-blockchain-78409::The Conversation::article::The big business revolution: why the future is blockchain::Blockchain technology is familiar to us in the form of digital currency bitcoin. And if it makes it way to the mainstream
column2: could it change the way the world does business forever?::The value of one bitcoin recently hit a record high of US$3
column4: a staggering rise of over 200% in value this year alone. Aswath Damodaran
column5: professor of finance at the New York University
column6: known as Wall Street‚Äôs ‚Äúdean of valuation‚Äù
column7: has said that among the younger generation
column8: digital currencies have replaced gold as a choice of investment and that
column9: sooner or later
column10: currencies such as bitcoin and ethereum will compete against nation-state paper currencies. So could bitcoin become a popular currency and decrease the popularity of euros
column11: dollars
column12: pounds
column13: roubles and others? For anything to be seen as ‚Äúmoney‚Äù it needs to meet three functions ‚Äì a store of value
column14: a measure of value and a medium of exchange. Bitcoin‚Äôs volatility shows that it is an infant in meeting these three criteria
column15: but has the potential to do so. However
column16: digital currencies like bitcoin are just one application of the blockchain technology that makes them possible. Blockchain
column17: as the BBC explains
column18: is: Blockchain combines the security of cryptography
column19: the storage and transmission of data in coded form
column20: with peer-to-peer networks to create a shared database of transactions that is trusted
column21: yet controlled by no one. If blockchain finds uses in various industries we could see a more digitally integrated global economy
column22: something that could enhance economic growth and decrease poverty. In business today
column23: we still require trusted administrators to manage and record the numbers and databases ‚Äì auditors
column24: supervisory boards and so on. The potential of blockchain is that it offers the chance to ‚Äúdistribute‚Äù these digital ledgers to others through a network of computers across the world. It could actually dispense with those businesses that are based on trusted relationships ‚Äì such as banking
column25: auditing
column26: solicitors
column27: even aspects of government. For example in Sweden
column28: Georgia and Ukraine property registers are being moved on to the blockchain. In finance
column29: people rarely lend directly to each other
column30: hence the need for banks as trusted go-betweens. The beauty of cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin or ethereum is that they remove the need for the trusted third party
column31: using instead an encrypted
column32: secure database. This has huge implications for any business that requires the verification of payments and performance of contracts ‚Äì that is
column33: most businesses. The beauty of blockchain is that something can be unique and stored digitally with ease
column34: without needing an equivalent in the real world. For example
column35: things like contracts
column36: wills
column37: deeds and share certificates might only require a piece of code stored on the blockchain that represents the exchange. Instead of a trusted intermediary verifying transactions
column38: the computers of the shared network of bitcoin users themselves perform the verification at no cost to those involved in the transaction. This verification process holds the seeds of change across huge numbers of industries. The distributed ledger ‚Äì the blockchain ‚Äì offers the chance to enhance truth and trust in every system to which it is applied. It can prove who owns what at any given moment. Anything that currently exists to verify contracts
column39: ownership
column40: payments and even performance can be shifted to the blockchain. This would transfer power away from those who currently manage or verify transactions ‚Äì a seismic change to the way the world currently operates. As with any power shift
column41: those holding power are reluctant to surrender it. The ‚Äúwinners‚Äù in this scenario will come from existing companies rather than start-ups
column42: given that for this new system to work
column43: it requires buy-in and trust ‚Äì existing brands already have this advantage. So what are blockchain‚Äôs main advantages? By performing the functions of record keepers and managers it would enhance decentralisation
column44: reduce the amount of intermediaries involved and provide an alternative to how value can be stored. Physical as well as digital assets could be uniquely verified online to prove ownership. As transactions stored on the blockchain could be independently verified and traced
column45: it would be easier to fight crime
column47: reducing systemic risk in the financial system. A distributed digital ledger would make it near impossible to change or falsify data
column48: because data would have to be altered across all the related ‚Äúblocks‚Äù in the digital chain
column49: so any tampering would be exposed. Consequently associated costs would fall
column50: enhancing economic growth and prosperity. A dramatic disruption is happening already in the financial industry: the world‚Äôs largest custodian bank
column51: BNY Mellon
column52: is using a blockchain based platform for government bond settlement. And one of the Bank of England‚Äôs research focus areas is based around financial technology or ‚Äúfintech‚Äù and how it affects the way markets and society function. Another benefit would be to make micropayments possible digitally. A country such as India
column53: where huge number of people still do not have access to banking
column54: could experience profound economic change if brought within their reach
column55: helping them save
column56: borrow and plan for their future. The online marketing and advertising industry has feasted on data generated by internet users
column57: and social media platforms such as Facebook ‚Äì with more than two billion users ‚Äì Google and Amazon collect considerable amounts of individualised data on us to target adverts at us. Blockchain could enhance our online privacy
column58: by allowing us to store our digital footprint on our own unique blockchain and control who has access to it. Rather than these massive organisations building up records of our tastes and preferences
column59: this data would be decentralised and within our own control. Blockchain could enhance entrepreneurship in developed and developing countries
column60: breaking down barriers built from embedded bureaucracy and corruption by providing a means to bypass existing power structures. For example
column61: the digital ledger Everledger is tracking a real-life object ‚Äì diamonds ‚Äì to prove their provenance and ownership. As a result
column62: trust in the system is enhanced. When the internet came into being
column63: it was a disruptive
column64: game-changing force for many industries ‚Äì blockchain technology holds the same potential. In moving trust from the current ‚Äúverifiers‚Äù to a distributed blockchain system
column65: the world could see a massive shift in power to the masses ‚Äì a truly revolutionary idea.::2017-07-25T13:33:04Z::Bitcoin

column1: 327::https://www.coindesk.com/learn/how-to-buy-solana/::CoinDesk::article::How to Buy Solana::Buying solana (SOL) is straightforward
column2: but with numerous crypto exchanges on the market
column3: it's crucial potential investors consider other key factors before making a purchase. Understanding Solana and SOL Choosing the right platform to buy SOL The purchasing process for buying SOL Buying Solana meme coins Securing purchased SOL::Cryptocurrency exchanges spend millions of marketing dollars convincing potential customers that purchasing solana (SOL)
column4: or any other cryptocurrency is quick and easy. They aren‚Äôt wrong. The act of purchasing cryptocurrency is quite simple. However
column5: it is vital that potential investors have a thorough understanding of solana (SOL)
column6: the native token of the Solana blockchain
column7: including how the Solana blockchain works and which purchase methods are best for their geographic location when designing an investment strategy. Solana is a smart contract-compatible blockchain platform that distinguishes itself from competitors with its hybrid consensus mechanism
column8: a combination of proof-of-history and proof-of-stake. Solana‚Äôs unique consensus mechanism allows nodes
column9: devices which validate and store transaction information on the blockchain
column10: to process transactions without the need to communicate with one another
column11: significantly reducing transaction processing time. With its ability to theoretically process up to 65
column12: 000 transactions per second
column13: Solana has been dubbed by the Blockchain Council as one of the fastest and most efficient blockchains in existence. This efficiency has an impact on network fees. A network fee in the Solana ecosystem is the amount of SOL that an individual will pay to compensate node operators to process and validate their transactions. Solana‚Äôs efficiency reduces transaction costs
column14: making it a preferred blockchain for meme coins and NFT transactions. SOL has two primary functions in the Solana ecosystem. The first function
column15: as mentioned
column16: is to serve as payment to node operators for processing transactions and the second is to function as a mechanism to secure the Solana network via staking. However
column17: investors can also purchase SOL with the intention of holding
column18: hoping that the price will increase in value against fiat currencies. There are a variety of ways in which SOL can be purchased. While crypto exchanges may convince users that buying SOL is simple and easy
column19: the truth is that the best way to purchase the token depends on an investor's aptitude with cryptocurrencies and personal investment strategy. According to CoinMarketCap
column20: there are over 200 different centralized cryptocurrency exchanges in existence. With so many options
column21: it is imperative that potential SOL investors choose the right exchange for their geographic region
column22: their investment strategies and their comfort level with keeping ownership over their own digital assets. Due to regulatory restrictions
column23: not every cryptocurrency exchange operates in every country. It is always a good idea to check that the crypto exchange you plan to purchase SOL on is legally allowed to operate in the country you reside. There are also potential benefits to choosing a crypto exchange that is familiar with the tax and legal requirements of a specific country. For instance
column24: crypto exchanges that operate in the United States are likely to be more familiar with IRS tax reporting requirements and provide users with both information and documentation for tax reporting purposes. You may also want to consider using a decentralized crypto exchange to buy SOL. Decentralized crypto exchanges operate without a central authority
column25: where trades occur directly between users‚Äô wallets and liquidity pools. Decentralized crypto exchanges use smart contracts to automate order matching and settlement. In comparison centralized crypto exchanges are operated by a company that acts as an intermediary between buyers and sellers. They manage the order book
column26: match buy and sell orders and facilitate trading. Each platform has its benefits and drawbacks
column27: highlighted below. To purchase SOL on a centralized exchange
column28: first
column29: choose a reputable crypto exchange that supports it
column30: such as Coinbase
column31: Binance or Kraken. Create an account by providing your email address and setting a strong password. For security
column32: complete the identity verification process
column33: which typically requires a photo ID. After verifying your account
column34: secure it further by enabling two-factor authentication (like Google Authenticator). You can then deposit funds using a bank transfer
column35: credit card or other payment methods available on the exchange. Keep in mind that centralized exchanges can charge different fees based on the method used to fund the account. Once your account is funded
column36: navigate to the SOL trading section of the crypto exchange
column37: select the appropriate trading pair (like SOL/USD) and execute your purchase. Always review the transaction details before executing the transaction. To buy SOL on a DEX such as Jupiter or Raydium
column38: you will first need a wallet compatible with the Solana network. Ensure your wallet is funded with enough crypto to complete the purchase and cover the transaction fee. Connect your wallet to the DEX website; this often involves scanning a QR code or selecting a wallet connection option. Once connected
column39: choose the trading pair that matches your funding source (e.g.
column40: SOL/USDC). Set the amount of SOL you wish to buy and check the current liquidity and slippage to ensure you receive a fair exchange rate. Confirm the transaction
column41: and once it‚Äôs processed
column42: the purchased SOL will appear in your wallet. Remember
column43: trading on a DEX removes the intermediary but requires careful handling of your private keys and wallet security. According to data from Hello Moon
column44: the number of active daily users on the Solana blockchain reached an all-time high in mid-March of 2024. The price of SOL also experienced strong bullish momentum. What caused this surge in activity? In an interview with Solana co-founder Anatoly Yakovenko
column45: CoinDesk‚Äôs Sam Kessler highlighted that growth in activity was due to meme coin transactions. Meme coins are digital tokens on a blockchain that are often inspired by animals
column46: jokes or themes popular on the internet. Meme coin prices are often more volatile than other types of cryptocurrencies. The process of buying meme coins on Solana is relatively the same as purchasing SOL. However
column47: there are extra considerations that need to be made when purchasing meme coins. Meme coins are rife with scams but the allure of a quick pay day can blind some investors to the risks. It is strongly recommended that investors interested in diving into the meme coin game thoroughly assess their personal risk tolerance and devise a sound investment strategy. Never invest more than you are willing to lose. CoinDesk also offers a thorough explainer on purchasing meme coins safely. After purchasing SOL
column48: buyers need to protect their investment. If SOL was purchased on a centralized crypto exchange
column49: the crypto exchange acts as custodian of the cryptocurrency and users do not need to worry about securing their private keys but accounts still need to be protected. Ensure your account is protected with a strong alphanumeric password and turn on two-factor authentication (2FA)
column50: though preferably not SMS
column51: which lacks end-to-end encryption. It is wise to regularly update passwords. If purchased on a decentralized exchange
column52: the buyer acts as custodian of their private keys and needs to keep them secure. Private keys can be stored in either a cold wallet that is not connected to the internet or a hot wallet that is connected to the internet. It is recommended that investors planning on holding SOL over longer periods of time store their crypto in a cold wallet
column53: which are less vulnerable to hacks if never used to sign a transaction online. Never share your private keys with anyone
column54: ever. Editor's Note: This article does not constitute investment advice and is not intended to invite or induce investment in solana (SOL) or any other cryptocurrency. It is meant for factual and educational purposes
column55: with respect to certain aspects of SOL and its associated blockchain
column56: for those who might be interested. Cryptocurrency is a high-risk investment and you should not expect to be protected if something goes wrong. Edited by Daniel Kuhn. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column1: 328::https://beincrypto.com/landvaults-spinoff-matera-raises-3-6m-round-to-bring-defi-for-creators/::BeInCrypto::article::Landvault‚Äôs Spinoff Matera Raises $3.6m Round to Bring Defi for Creators::Web3 foundation Matera announced it has raised $3.6m in a strategic token round
column2: reserved to future users of the Matera technology.::We use cookies to improve your experience. Web3 foundation Matera announced it has raised $3.6m in a strategic token round
column3: reserved to future users of the Matera technology. Investors include Sidedoor Ventures
column4: backers of Sui‚Äôs Mysten Labs and Polygon; OG crypto syndicates HighCass Crypto and Medusa Ventures
column5: metaverse project The Sandbox
column6: blockchain advisory firm Saxon Partners
column7: APAC launchpad Enjinstarter
column8: various KOLs as well as long term backers Gemini and Kingsway Capital. Matera aims to solve a huge problem in the creator economy: the lack of liquidity for creators to monetize. But contrary to many SocialFi projects in the space
column9: Matera is a layer on top of existing social networks
column10: enabling creators to compute their ‚ÄòMatera Credit score‚Äô based on engagement on platforms they already use. They can then trade this score for liquidity and rewards in Matera‚Äôs DeFi ecosystem
column11: which is open for other DeFi projects to connect. ‚ÄúNo web3 SocialFi has reached major adoption because they underestimate the network effects of web2 platforms‚Äù
column12: says Sam Huber
column13: Matera CEO. Even if they get better economics
column14: the switching costs are too high for Creators to start building an audience from scratch on a new platform. Matera as a bridge
column15: enabling users to benefit from the scale of web2 and the economics of web3
column16: solving this dilemma.‚Äù Currently
column17: the platform supports X
column18: and will integrate other social platforms in the near future. Users creating content on X will be able to attract stakers to support them
column19: raise capital for their projects
column20: and monetize their superfans. Matera will be revealing their launch platform at Token2049 in Dubai
column21: enabling creators to sign up and start accessing the ecosystem. Over time
column22: Matera aims to build the entire infrastructure to support 100m creators on-chain: the DeFi platform
column23: the protocol layer
column24: and their own Layer 2. Matera has evolved since it was first revealed about a year ago. Originally

column5: depending on who you ask. Previously reported at Blockworks
column6: the Eclipse mainnet plans to use a hybrid ‚Äúbest of all worlds‚Äù approach ‚Äî combining Solana‚Äôs speedy execution with Ethereum‚Äôs secure settlement. The idea is to take some of the best tech advantages of Solana and ‚Äútap into Ethereum‚Äôs liquidity
column7: ‚Äù Garrett Harper says on the Lightspeed podcast (Spotify/Apple). ‚ÄúAs an open-source zealot
column8: I am all for this
column9: ‚Äù says Asymmetric CEO Joe McCann. Being that the Solana Virtual Machine (SVM) is open-source and can be applied anywhere
column10: McCann says ‚Äúthat‚Äôs exactly what you should be doing.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really cool that the guys at Eclipse are taking the SVM and trying to apply it differently than its core use case today with Solana.‚Äù Read more: Eclipse is using Solana‚Äôs virtual machine to launch an Ethereum L2 McCann asserts that the broader implementation of the SVM contributes to the Lindy effect ‚Äî a theoretical phenomenon whereby a technology becomes more resilient the more it is utilized. ‚ÄúIf Eclipse is successful
column11: what are they dependent on? The SVM. That thing has to continue to survive and exist and persist and improve and squash bugs and fix security patches and security bugs.‚Äù McCann says the news is ‚Äúincredibly bullish‚Äù for Solana‚Äôs underlying technology
column12: ‚Äúbecause now you‚Äôre also going to be getting pressure-tested potentially in a new environment
column13: a new set of use cases that may not actually be the core use case of the SVM today.‚Äù 6th Man Ventures founder and partner Mike Dudas cautions that Eclipse is an early stage project
column14: noting that ‚Äî as is often the case in blockchain ‚Äî the narrative around the technology is ‚Äúlight years ahead of reality.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm excited to see how parallel processing works in an Ethereum environment
column15: but there‚Äôs just a lot that has to happen before we‚Äôre going to see that
column16: ‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúA lot of it is theoretical
column17: ‚Äù he says
column18: adding
column19: ‚Äúwe‚Äôll see what happens.‚Äù McCann warns that the vision for Eclipse exhibits a ‚Äúpath dependency that is multi-variate.‚Äù ‚ÄúSo many things have to go right
column20: ‚Äù he says
column21: adding that he really hopes that it does. But Asymmetric ‚Äúcouldn‚Äôt get there on the investment side‚Äù during last year‚Äôs seed round
column22: he says
column23: ‚Äúbecause I couldn‚Äôt size the risk of that.‚Äù  ‚ÄúThe path-dependent nature of how this thing actually plays out has so many branches in the way that it has to succeed that it was difficult for me at the time to secure an investment.‚Äù In the long term
column24: Dudas believes that Ethereum will exist as the largest layer-1 blockchain

column26: he suggests

column2: the President of El Salvador
column3: has officially submitted his candidacy for re-election in the forthcoming presidential election slated for February 2024. Bukele
column4: a staunch supporter of Bitcoin
column5: garnered substantial backing from the populace on October 26
column6: following his formal endorsement by his political party
column7: New Ideas
column8: to vie for a second term. Addressing [‚Ä¶]::Nayib Bukele
column9: the President of El Salvador
column10: has officially submitted his candidacy for re-election in the forthcoming presidential election slated for February 2024. Bukele
column11: a staunch supporter of Bitcoin
column12: garnered substantial backing from the populace on October 26
column13: following his formal endorsement by his political party
column14: New Ideas
column15: to vie for a second term. Addressing a massive crowd of Salvadorans
column16: Bukele expressed his desire for an additional five years in office
column17: stating
column18: ‚ÄúFive more [years]
column19: five more and not a single step backward. We require another five years to continue our progress in bettering our nation.‚Äù Bukele first ascended to the presidency in 2019
column20: leading the New Ideas party to break a thirty-year stranglehold on power held by the Nationalist Republican Alliance and the Farabundo Mart√≠ National Liberation Front (FMLN). Nonetheless
column21: Bukele‚Äôs candidacy has its critics. Alfonso Fajardo
column22: an El Salvadoran lawyer
column23: argues that the country‚Äôs constitution bars Bukele from seeking a second consecutive term
column24: emphasizing the prohibition on immediate presidential re-election as many as seven times. He voiced this reminder on October 26
column25: the same day Bukele received his party‚Äôs nomination. Contrary to this
column26: in September 2021
column27: the Supreme Court of El Salvador decreed that presidents are permitted to pursue consecutive terms in office. According to a survey conducted by a Salvadoran university and reported by Reuters
column28: New Ideas enjoys the support of a staggering 70% of the electorate
column29: leaving its nearest rival trailing with just 4% of the total votes. In June 2021
column30: FMLN
column31: one of New Ideas‚Äô competitors
column32: launched a legal challenge against Bukele‚Äôs Bitcoin adoption initiative
column33: claiming it to be unconstitutional. However
column34: their efforts were in vain as just three months later
column35: in September 2021
column36: Bitcoin was officially adopted as legal tender in El Salvador. Moreover
column37: Bukele‚Äôs administration has enacted a series of tech-centric policies aimed at bolstering the nation‚Äôs economy
column38: including the abolishment of all taxes on technological innovations. Gabor Gurbacs
column39: a strategy advisor at VanEck
column40: has recently expressed his belief that El Salvador has the potential to become the ‚ÄúSingapore of the Americas
column41: ‚Äù thanks to these initiatives. A significant portion of Bukele‚Äôs popularity can be attributed to his uncompromising crackdown on MS-13
column42: an international gang that was a key factor in El Salvador recording the world‚Äôs highest homicide rates six years ago. Since then
column43: the country has witnessed a remarkable 92.6% drop in its homicide rate
column44: plummeting from 106 per 100
column45: 000 inhabitants in 2015 to just 7.8 in 2022
column46: making it one of the safest countries in Latin America. However
column47: this success has not come without criticism. The United Nations
column48: among others
column49: has accused El Salvador of violating human rights laws by detaining 65
column50: 000 individuals without granting them the legal rights necessary to defend themselves. The presidential election in El Salvador is scheduled for February 4

column1: 331::https://cryptobriefing.com/binance-converts-1b-emergency-fund-to-usdc/::Crypto Briefing::article::Binance converts $1B emergency fund to USDC::The fund now represents roughly 3% of USDC's total circulating supply.::Join the hunt for $12
column3: 000+ in NEXO Tokens! Share this article Binance has converted $1 billion from its Secure Asset Fund for Users (SAFU) into Circle‚Äôs stablecoin USD Coin (USDC)
column4: effectively placing the fund to represent approximately 3% of the stablecoin‚Äôs total circulating supply. The SAFU was established in 2018 to protect Binance users in extreme situations
column5: such as exchange hacks
column6: by reimbursing them for unforeseen losses. The fund was previously held in three wallets
column7: denominated in Bitcoin
column8: Tether
column9: True USD
column10: and BNB. ‚ÄúWe are transferring 100% of SAFU‚Äôs assets to USDC

column12: adding that the move is aimed at ‚Äúmaking use of a trusted
column13: audited
column14: and transparent stablecoin
column15: ‚Äù to protect its users and enhance reliability. According to data from Etherscan
column16: the SAFU wallet address made a transaction of 800 million USDC on Ethereum at 02:35 UTC for a transaction fee of just $1.88. The conversion process also involved a transfer of 1.36 million BNB
column17: worth around $754 million
column18: and 16
column19: 277 BTC. This is the second conversion of the SAFU in just over a year. In March 2023
column20: Binance replaced the Binance USD (BUSD) holdings in the fund with Tether (USDT) and TrueUSD (TUSD) in response to a regulatory crackdown on BUSD issuer Paxos
column21: which announced that it would stop minting the exchange-backed stablecoin. With a circulating supply of $32.6 billion
column22: USDC is the second-largest stablecoin in the market
column23: commanding a market share of around 20%. The stablecoin‚Äôs supply has increased by 33% since December. Tether
column24: however

column1: 332::https://theconversation.com/bitcoin-a-pirates-booty-or-the-new-global-currency-3130::The Conversation::article::Bitcoin: a pirate‚Äôs booty or the new global currency?::On July 19
column2: Doctor Nefario
column3: founder of the Global Bitcoin Stock Exchange
column4: arrived at Seattle airport and was asked if he had enough money to cover his stay in the US. He replied that he did
column5: but that it‚Ä¶::On July 19
column6: Doctor Nefario
column7: founder of the Global Bitcoin Stock Exchange
column8: arrived at Seattle airport and was asked if he had enough money to cover his stay in the US. He replied that he did
column9: but that it was in Bitcoin
column10: an electronic cryptographic currency. Unfortunately
column11: not only did the Customs and Border Protection Authority not know what Bitcoin was
column12: they didn‚Äôt accept it as a valid currency and so refused him entry. This ignorance of Bitcoin is shared by many
column13: even though there is currently around US$63.6 million of Bitcoin in circulation (versus approximately US$950 billion in hard cash). Bitcoin is a ‚Äúcryptographic currency‚Äù that was first proposed in 2008 by a programmer using the supposed alias Satoshi Nakamoto. In early 2009
column14: Nakamoto released software that would implement the creation
column15: sending and receiving Bitcoins over a peer-to-peer network. His main motivation was to avoid the need for ‚Äúfinancial institutions serving as trusted third parties to process electronic payments‚Äù such as a bank or PayPal. The scheme allowed the receiver to be sure the Bitcoin received was genuine and hadn‚Äôt been sent elsewhere. Nakamoto also thought Bitcoins would be largely anonymous. Although theoretically possible
column16: the exact nature of this anonymity is still being debated and it‚Äôs clear that
column17: to achieve it
column18: users need to take a series of precautions. It was the anonymity of Bitcoin and its relation to an illicit online market place called Silk Road that really brought Bitcoins to the public‚Äôs and US Government‚Äôs attention. Silk Road can be used
column19: among other things
column20: to buy and sell drugs and other contraband. This led two US Senators to demand Silk Road be [shut down](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silk_Road_(bitcoin) and Bitcoin investigated. Further concern was expressed that Bitcoins could be used for money-laundering (although
column21: given the relatively illiquid nature of the currency
column22: this would be on a relatively small scale). The fact Bitcoin was adopted by organisations such as Wikileaks and LulzSec would not have surprised anyone. While the US authorities could bring pressure to bear on financial institutions such as Visa
column23: Mastercard or PayPal to stop payments going to Wikileaks
column24: there is no central authority in charge of Bitcoin
column25: making it very much more difficult to control. Having said that
column26: it‚Äôs not clear how much funding Wikileaks receives in the form of Bitcoins. You can get Bitcoins in two ways. The first
column27: and most difficult
column28: is through what is called Bitcoin mining. This involves using computers to perform some of the cryptographic operations involved in making the Bitcoin network work. If you are the first to solve the calculations
column29: you are rewarded with a certain number of Bitcoins. A simpler way of getting Bitcoins is to buy them through one of the many Bitcoin exchanges. One such exchange is Mt Gox
column30: which allows you to buy Bitcoins using funds transfers of ordinary cash and e-Cash. Once you‚Äôve added funds to your account
column31: buying Bitcoins is like buying shares: you can place an order to buy at the market rate or at a preferred rate. Once you have the Bitcoins
column32: you can leave them in your account on the exchange. You can also transfer them to a digital wallet on your computer or to an online e-wallet service. You can then use your Bitcoins to buy goods and services ranging from books to website development to legal services. It seems clear the majority of Bitcoin is being bought and sold for investment purposes. This is another underlying cause for some of the fluctuation in rates that have beset the currency
column33: which has seen its value go from US$1 to US $30 USD at its peak. It is currently around US $10. The underlying system of transferring Bitcoin may be secure enough
column34: but Bitcoin suffers from a number of vulnerabilities that have led to widely-publicised problems in the Bitcoin universe. One of the first Bitcoin incidents occurred in June 2011 when Mt Gox was hacked and the user database of 61
column35: 000 users was taken. The hackers used those usernames and passwords to transfer 25
column36: 000 Bitcoins ‚Äì approximately US$225
column37: 000 ‚Äì to an account. From there
column38: they then tried to sell them on
column39: but succeeded in only removing about $1
column40: 000-worth because of the daily limit imposed by Mt Gox. As a consequence of the hack
column41: the exchange rate for Bitcoin on Mt Gox plummeted before climbing back to the pre-hack level. The second event was when another Bitcoin service
column42: MyBitcoin.com
column43: was hacked resulting in the site closing down along with all of the account holders‚Äô Bitcoins. Approximately US$2 million of Bitcoin (valuation at the time) was lost
column44: with one account holder who helped promote the site to family and friends losing about $250
column45: 000. And then there was Bitomat
column46: another Bitcoin site. Based in Poland
column47: a technical error on the part of the operator caused the server to crash
column48: losing access to the Bitcoins in the process. Mt Gox has recently taken over the accounts of Bitomat and offered to refund the lost coins to those users to help ensure the continuation of Bitcoin. The ‚Äúidea‚Äù of Bitcoin clearly has resonance with certain groups of people. An electronic currency free from mediation and interference of governments and corporations
column49: and which can be anonymous
column50: is ideal for groups operating on the fringes of society ‚Äì activists (cyber or otherwise)
column51: libertarians and
column52: yes
column53: criminals. Whether the implementation of Bitcoin as it currently stands survives or it‚Äôs ultimately replaced by a variant will depend on how many other things go wrong
column54: and also on the development of more robust and easy to use software. Certainly
column55: the recent Bitcoin events are growing pains in comparison to the fall out of the Global Financial Crisis and what countries
column56: companies and individuals have lost as a result of a largely self-regulated financial industry. Ironically
column57: Bitcoin may end up being more resistant to national and corporate manipulation and possibly more robust as a result. Still
column58: if you‚Äôre going to use Bitcoins
column59: do so carefully and with small amounts of money that you can afford to lose. A version of this article appeared on David Glance‚Äôs blog Tech Muse. Do you use Bitcoin? Would you? Leave your comments below.::2011-08-30T20:42:26Z::Bitcoin

column1: 333::https://www.coindesk.com/learn/a-beginners-guide-to-ai-tokens/::CoinDesk::article::A Beginner‚Äôs Guide to AI Tokens::AI tokens will play an integral role in the adoption of machine learning models in the blockchain industry. Understanding AI Crypto Tokens How Do AI Tokens Work? Top 5 AI Tokens Final Words::Artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming many industries
column2: and the crypto space is no exception. With this convergence of blockchain and AI
column3: we‚Äôre seeing the rise of unique digital assets; AI crypto tokens. In this beginner‚Äôs guide to AI tokens
column4: we will explain what they are
column5: how they work
column6: and list some of the most prominent AI cryptocurrencies in the market. This is partner content sourced from Laura Shin‚Äôs Unchained and published by CoinDesk. AI tokens are cryptocurrencies that support AI-based projects
column7: applications
column8: and services within the blockchain ecosystem. AI tokens play three pivotal roles; the first is facilitating transactions. They are the medium of exchange within AI-powered platforms. With them
column9: users can pay for services
column10: access data
column11: and participate in the platform‚Äôs activities. Additionally
column12: they are crucial in enabling protocol governance. Some of these tokens confer governance rights to their holders
column13: empowering holders to participate in decision-making processes shaping the development and direction of the AI project or platform. Finally
column14: they incentivize users to contribute towards the growth of the AI protocol/project. These may receive rewards in tokens for contributing data
column15: providing computational resources
column16: or developing AI applications. AI crypto tokens typically work in the following ways: Specifics can vary widely depending on the project. Each AI token system is designed with its own rules and purposes. The crypto AI landscape is rapidly evolving
column17: and many projects are coming up to address various aspects of the space. Here are the top five leading AI tokens measured by market capitalization. The Injective Chain is a layer-2 decentralized exchange and derivatives trading platform powered by the INJ token. It enables advanced trading tools like margins/leverage
column18: using AI for optimized order execution
column19: strategy testing
column20: and predictive analytics. At the time of writing
column21: INJ was the biggest AI token with a market cap of $1.418B. The Graph (GRT) is an indexing protocol for organizing blockchain data
column22: allowing for its easy querying for AI analytics. GRT is the second-largest AI token by market cap ($1.379B at the time of writing) and coordinates the decentralized network of nodes (Indexers). These earn the rights to index and serve application data by staking their GRT. Render Token enables a decentralized GPU cloud computing network for high-demand AI/ML training/rendering tasks. Users stake and lock up RNDR for access to GPUs. The project rewards Render Farm suppliers in RNDR for leasing out graphics horsepower capacity. RNDR has a market cap of $1.22B at the time of writing. The Theta token (THETA) powers the Theta decentralized video delivery network and is the fourth largest AI and big data token
column23: with a market cap of $960M at the time of writing. It aims to provide improved video streaming quality and reduced costs through AI and ML innovations. Users and relay nodes earn THETA for sharing bandwidth resources. The Oasis Network uses a token-incentivized architecture to enable privacy-preserving AI computations on blockchain. ROSE tokens
column24: which have a market cap of $567M at the time of writing
column25: coordinate the network of nodes
column26: providing secure computing via technologies like Intel SGX
column27: differential privacy
column28: and federated learning. As blockchain platforms aim for large-scale adoption
column29: AI innovations will be critical for unlocking new capabilities and efficiencies. Specialized AI tokens help coordinate the incentives and collaboration necessary for advancing AI in a decentralized context. These have strong potential as the tokenization of ML processes grows on-chain. But the category remains technically complex and volatile
column30: as with most crypto. Therefore
column31: investor due diligence before their adoption remains vital. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column1: 338::https://theconversation.com/the-blockchain-could-have-better-security-than-the-banks-80748::The Conversation::article::The blockchain could have better security than the banks::Providing security in the blockchain would convert into a degree of predictability in the technology. If this was shown to work in the long term
column2: it would also create trust.::There are ways to improve the online ledger blockchain by taking some security notes from banks. If people could use both two-step verification and spending limits on the blockchain
column3: this would reduce any economic loss from cyber attacks and in turn encourage more users. The blockchain is a global network of computers that run the same blockchain software. Transactions on the blockchain are currently limitless and there is no one governing body. Introducing security measures could demonstrate a level of predictability in the blockchain that could build more trust. At the moment there are third-party sites that perform transactions with the blockchain on your behalf. They are owned and managed separately from the blockchain itself
column4: and this presents a single point of failure. These sites
column5: like Kraken
column6: Changelly and Shapeshift
column7: allow people to purchase
column8: as well as exchange
column9: blockchain assets. Activity on these sites includes purchasing Bitcoin with US dollars or exchanging Bitcoin for Ethereum assets. The blockchain ecosystem is by no means perfect. Many people shy away from using it due to its perceived volatility. There is no ‚Äúcode of conduct‚Äù protocol for the blockchain at the moment and it‚Äôs likely there never will be. In addition
column10: creating and maintaining blockchain software is arduous and managed by only a few people globally. These software developers
column11: who are the trailblazers of this technology
column12: are being disadvantaged by constantly being forced to respond to malicious attacks. There have been many malicious attacks on the blockchain including the very recent attack on a third-party online wallet. In this attack
column13: an unknown user was able to hijack the third-party site and redirect all transactions to their account. These and other malicious attacks have made blockchain assets either temporarily unavailable or permanently unrecoverable. It‚Äôs for these reasons that the solution to secure the blockchain can‚Äôt be owned and managed by third-parties
column14: and must be part of the blockchain itself. Security measures like the ones we‚Äôre proposing may reduce the severity and speed of any malicious attacks. Lowering the bounty for malicious attacks could also prove to be a disincentive for this behaviour. The mechanisms we use to build trust in the traditional financial institutions could be coded into the blockchain. It‚Äôs unlikely that a blockchain user will use the technology to spend 100% of the assets in their account
column15: with no notice whatsoever. This is why hacks of these accounts are so obvious
column16: just as they would be if your bank account was suddenly drained. Adjustable spend and transaction limits currently protect mainstream bank account users from one malicious transaction. There is no reason the same kind of consumer protection cannot apply to cryptocurrency users. In order for this to work
column17: the blockchain needs to verify that you are the legitimate user of the account
column18: who is wanting to raise and lower spending limits for the purpose of transferring funds. We propose this could work via voice authentication. This is where a blockchain user performs a transaction on the blockchain and is subsequently prompted to provide a single-use vocal passphrase ‚Äì this is the second step in the two-step verification process. This would be similar to the program Captcha
column19: but with one unique twist. Captcha is designed to discern legitimate users of the internet from online robots. It works by generating a one-time image of letters and numbers that the user has to type correctly to proceed. Captcha can verify if you are human
column20: but is unable to verify your individual identity. Using the human voice with this type of technology could be more commonplace in the future. It‚Äôs also less complex than other types of biometric verification
column21: which require sophisticated infrastructure such as retina- and iris-scanning hardware. More importantly
column22: the human voice shares blockchain attributes. Your voice and your public blockchain key are both public and unique. At present there is no guarantee of holding blockchain assets without disruption of some kind. Providing security in the blockchain would convert into a degree of predictability in the technology. If this was shown to work in the long term
column23: it would also create trust. Obviously
column24: we trust traditional currencies. For example
column25: laws provide a promise that a $20 note will result in a mutual exchange of goods and services to that value. So once a degree of predictability is established in a blockchain
column26: there will also be new business opportunities from traditional markets
column27: such as insurance in case of sudden undue economic loss. It‚Äôs in the interests of the majority stakeholders of blockchain to consistently look for responses and improvements that reduce the limitations of the technology. A malicious attack
column28: intent on bringing down the architecture of blockchain technology
column29: would unfairly relegate the blockchain to a history as another ponzi scheme.::2017-07-16T19:58:38Z::Banking

column1: 339::https://www.coindesk.com/learn/bitcoin-whales-what-they-are-how-to-spot-them/::CoinDesk::article::Bitcoin Whales: What They Are & How to Spot Them?::Bitcoin whales are major market players who can influence the price of bitcoin when they decide to buy or sell large volumes of the digital currency. What Are Bitcoin Whales? How Do Whales Influence the Market? Three Ways to Spot a Bitcoin Whale Biggest Bitcoin Whales in the Market::Bitcoin whales can significantly impact the price of bitcoin when they decide to buy or sell BTC in large quantities
column2: making them some of the most important Bitcoin market participants. Read on to learn more about bitcoin whales
column3: how they influence the market
column4: and how you can spot them. This is partner content sourced from Laura Shin‚Äôs Unchained and published by CoinDesk. Bitcoin whales are individuals or entities holding large amounts of the digital currency and have the potential to impact price movements with a single trade. The widely accepted minimum threshold for a bitcoin whale is 1
column5: 000 BTC. The term ‚Äúbitcoin whale‚Äù is a colloquial phrase to put the size of the holding in perspective when compared to other ‚Äúsmaller fish‚Äù in the market. The wallet owner can be an individual or a group pooling resources to make significant investments. Whales‚Äô position as the biggest players in the Bitcoin market makes them highly influential. Their significant holdings allow them to significantly affect bitcoin‚Äôs immediate demand or supply on exchanges (or via OTC trading desks) whenever they trade. As a result
column6: the market often responds with price movements. The price of bitcoin often rallies when a while decides to add to their bitcoin position due to the size of their trades. Conversely
column7: if a Bitcoin whale opts to exit their position by selling a portion of their holdings
column8: the price tends to respond with a decline. Moreover
column9: a lot of whales‚Äô wallets are publicly tracked
column10: which results in the wider Bitcoin trading community responding to whale‚Äôs trading decisions (or expected trades)
column11: often resulting in a large price movement as many traders mirror the whale‚Äôs (expected) trade. Consequently
column12: some whales prefer trading with others directly via OTC trading desks to limit their impact on the price. However
column13: some whales trading on exchanges may take the opportunity to move the market in the direction they want by signaling to the market that they are a large buyer or seller. Knowing how to spot a Bitcoin whale can be a helpful addition to your Bitcoin trading arsenal
column14: given its potential to impact the market with a simple buy or sell order. Let‚Äôs look at three ways you can spot a Bitcoin whale. According to this bitcoin whales chart
column15: as of July 2023
column16: there are 2
column17: 018 BTC wallets with balances of over 1
column18: 000 BTC. Some notable whales have held onto their bitcoin for the long term. Let‚Äôs look at five of the most notable
column19: publicly known bitcoin whales. Spotting a bitcoin whale‚Äôs activities can help you make shrewd moves in the market. However
column20: remember that even whales can make emotional decisions without rationality. Some may even seek to manipulate the market to benefit themselves. Ensure you go beyond tracking their activities and find their reasons before making decisions. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column2: a local South Korean outlet reported Thursday.¬†::Busan is South Korea‚Äôs second largest city with a population around 3.4 million CJ Nattanai/Shutterstock modified by Blcokworks Busan is well on its way toward building an urban blockchain and a digital asset exchange
column3: a local South Korean outlet reported Thursday. The South Korean city sits at the southeastern tip of the peninsula and has started to become something of a blockchain hub of the country. The purpose of the urban blockchain is to unify all the various blockchain services currently offered on chains such as Ethereum and Cosmos onto a single citywide platform
column4: News1 reported. One well publicized use case is an identity management program called BPASS. Busan and Coinplug pioneered the program
column5: which uses decentralized identifiers (DID) so residents can anonymously authenticate themselves when applying for public or private services. BPASS users can store their driver‚Äôs license
column6: library card and even university graduation certificates on mobile devices. There was no timeline given for the upcoming Busan blockchain
column7: but the city plans for it to be public and interoperable with Ethereum and Cosmos. Read more: South Korea passes crypto legislation to crack down on ‚Äòillegal trading practices‚Äô A city digital asset exchange
column8: initially announced sometime in January 2023
column9: is also part of Busan‚Äôs recent blockchain push. The exchange is set to debut tokenized precious metals and raw materials
column10: with full-scale operations launching in the first half of 2024. The corporation overseeing the exchange will launch in November 2023
column11: following a public offering in October. News1 reported that crypto assets won‚Äôt be available for trade initially
column12: but there are plans to expand tradable assets to global intellectual property rights

column2: the SEC has decided not to appeal the decision made by the District of Columbia Court of Appeals in [‚Ä¶]::The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has opted not to challenge a court ruling that supports Grayscale‚Äôs proposed spot Bitcoin exchange-traded fund (ETF). According to an October 14 update from an inside source cited by Bloomberg
column3: the SEC has decided not to appeal the decision made by the District of Columbia Court of Appeals in August. This court ruling argued that the SEC had made a mistake in rejecting Grayscale‚Äôs application for a Bitcoin exchange-traded fund. This case has garnered significant attention in the financial industry
column4: as various players have been competing for approval to launch spot Bitcoin ETFs. The SEC‚Äôs unexpected decision to step aside might pave the way for a thorough review of Grayscale‚Äôs ETF proposal. Grayscale
column5: a major investment firm
column6: has put forth an ETF designed to provide exposure to Bitcoin (BTC)
column7: the world‚Äôs leading cryptocurrency in terms of market capitalization
column8: without requiring direct ownership. Previously
column9: the SEC had denied all spot Bitcoin ETF applications
column10: including Grayscale‚Äôs
column11: claiming that the applicants couldn‚Äôt sufficiently protect investors from potential market manipulation. The situation escalated when Grayscale challenged the SEC‚Äôs decision in court
column12: arguing that the surveillance mechanisms previously approved to combat fraudulent activities in Bitcoin futures-based ETFs should also be applicable to their proposed spot ETF. The appeals court upheld Grayscale‚Äôs position
column13: stating that the SEC had failed to clarify the significant differences between the two setups. It is expected that instructions on how to implement the court‚Äôs decision will be issued
column14: likely directing the SEC to reevaluate Grayscale‚Äôs application. This development could also have implications for other financial giants
column15: such as BlackRock and Fidelity
column16: which have similar spot Bitcoin ETF applications pending. With the SEC expected to make decisions on these applications by 2024 at the latest
column17: the landscape for cryptocurrency-based financial products may be on the verge of a significant transformation. As of the time of writing
column18: neither Grayscale nor the SEC had issued any comments on this development. source Coinatory is a news portal dedicated to providing the latest updates on cryptocurrency
