column1: 344::https://theconversation.com/bitcoins-central-appeal-could-also-be-its-biggest-weakness-80486::The Conversation::article::Bitcoin‚Äôs central appeal could also be its biggest weakness::Bitcoin‚Äôs central appeal of anonymous
column2: irreversible transactions could become its biggest weakness.::Bitcoin reached a huge new peak in value in June 2017
column3: when one unit of the virtual currency was worth US$2
column6: up from around US$600 just a year earlier. More than 10m people worldwide are now thought to own bitcoin and more than 100
column7: 000 merchants accept it for goods (not counting all those using it to sell drugs and other illegal items on the black market). Part of bitcoin‚Äôs appeal for many of its users is the lack of centralised control or regulation by any government or bank. Instead it relies on a technology known as blockchain to underpin and secure transactions. But research my colleagues and I have conducted suggests that the lack of any social trust in the way blockchain operates poses a challenge for bitcoin‚Äôs further spread. Blockchain is a public database that records digital transactions. These are validated by computers working within a worldwide network that solve complex coded problems. Whereas traditional bank transactions are authorised by financial institutions and controlled by governments through taxation and contracts between parties with known identities
column8: blockchain is decentralised
column9: unregulated and anonymous. In our studies of blockchain‚Äôs users we found that these features appeal to bitcoin users because of increasing distrust of financial institutions and governments. The technology empowers people to regain control over their money
column10: with no restrictions over where and when they can send it. But our findings also indicate that two core aspects of blockchain‚Äôs design ‚Äì the fact that transactions are anonymous and irreversible ‚Äì pose significant challenges to the social trust among its users. Anonymity has an obvious appeal for people looking to avoid government control. And irreversible transactions were built into blockchain‚Äôs original design as a positive feature to address banks‚Äô privilege of reversing transactions
column11: even when the contract states that they were final. But in practice
column12: these features are a problem for many people. Most people are used to relying on the reputation of a seller to decide whether or not to buy from them ‚Äì and the ability of the financial and legal system to help them if something goes wrong. But neither of these things are possible through blockchain. Most transactions don‚Äôt just involve moving bitcoin from one electronic wallet to another. In practice
column13: they are often part of a larger
column14: two-way transactions where both parties send and receive assets such as bitcoins
column15: real world currency or physical goods. The issue is that the blockchain only records the movement of bitcoin
column16: not the movement of other currencies or goods. Because there is no authority to complain to
column17: this raises a major risk that users could fall prey to dishonest traders who fail to deliver their side of the deal. In our latest study
column18: we interviewed 20 bitcoin users recruited from five online groups from Malaysia
column19: most of them with more than two years experience of using bitcoins. Our research indicates that more than 50% of participants would prefer blockchain‚Äôs transactions to be regulated and identifiable
column20: so that transactions can be either reversed or the dishonest trader legally sanctioned. This shows there is a tension between the freedom and empowerment of blockchain‚Äôs unregulated nature
column21: and the lack of security that most people are accustomed to receiving from traditional financial institutions. If this is not addressed
column22: such tension may limit the spread of bitcoin beyond its current base. It could even reduce the number of bitcoin users involved in such two-way transactions
column23: as more people become aware of the risks of dishonest traders. In contrast
column24: the use of blockchain for one-way transactions such as remittance payments will continue to grow
column25: as they are less affected by dishonest traders. Even bitcoin‚Äôs current users still operate largely under the traditional mindset of centralised and regulated currencies. Bitcoin advocates may need to find ways to encourage users to develop a new mental approach to unregulated blockchain technology. But developers could also build tools to address some of bitcoin users‚Äô concerns. For example
column26: there may be a way to record whether the real-world elements of bitcoin transactions are also verified
column27: authorised and stored on the public ledger. Electronic wallets could be linked to a reputation file that users could view before agreeing to a deal
column28: much like sites such as eBay allow consumers to rate sellers. And new mechanisms built on top of the irreversible blockchain protocol could enable individual two-way transactions to be reversed. Without doing something to tackle these challenges
column29: the very thing that caught people‚Äôs attention about bitcoin in the first place could end up stifling its growth and eventually consigning it to history.::2017-07-07T11:01:48Z::Bitcoin

column1: 345::https://www.coindesk.com/learn/bitcoin-name-service-bns-explained-a-guide-to-btc-domains/::CoinDesk::article::Bitcoin Name Service (BNS) Explained: A Guide to .BTC Domains::Bitcoin Name Service (BNS) domains provide Bitcoin web3 users with human-readable .btc names for their wallets. What Is the Bitcoin Name Service? How Do .BTC Domains Work? How to Buy Bitcoin Domains::Bitcoin Name Service (BNS) enable crypto users to have an easily identifiable
column2: human-readable .btc domain name linked to their Web3 wallet
column3: increasing the user-friendliness of their Bitcoin Web3 experience. This guide looks at Bitcoin Name Service (BNS)
column4: how .btc domains work
column5: and how to buy a .btc domain. This is partner content sourced from Laura Shin‚Äôs Unchained and published by CoinDesk. Bitcoin Name Service is a decentralized naming database secured on the Bitcoin blockchain that supplies Web3 usernames registered by Stacks. BNS is the Web3 phonebook and provides a mapping between human-readable host names such as unchained.btc to cumbersome alphanumerical wallet addresses. BNS shares a similar purpose to the Web2 Domain Name System (DNS). It provides an interface to buy
column6: register
column7: manage
column8: and look up domain names. The two systems may fulfill the same need but differ in structure and architecture. Where DNS depends on centralized servers
column9: BNS runs on peer-to-peer server systems that are secure and censorship-resistant. BNS names have three properties: universally unique
column10: human-meaningful
column11: and strongly owned. The Bitcoin Name System leverages the security and resilience of the Bitcoin network to facilitate a seamless user experience for Bitcoin Web3 users within the Stacks ecosystem
column12: allowing users to send and receive STX as well as Stacked-based tokens and NFTs. A .btc domain is a specific type of blockchain name registered and stored on the Bitcoin network as an NFT. The .btc domains are held on the BNS and registered through a smart contract on Stacks. The domains utilize Bitcoin‚Äôs security features and implement Clarity smart contracting language to create a decentralized name registry. Ownership of every .btc name is documented on the Bitcoin blockchain as a hash. Every domain and subdomain on BNS has Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs) that provide an eternal identifier for public keys and is compatible with other systems that use DIDs. .BTC names are organized into a global name hierarchy in three layers; namespaces
column13: BNS names
column14: and BNS subdomains. You can register .btc names through a transaction with the BNS smart contract on Stacks. The smart contract ensures that BNS domains are synchronized and replicated to all other Stacks nodes worldwide. Before getting a .btc domain
column15: you‚Äôll need a wallet that supports .btc domains
column16: such as Hiro Wallet or Xverse. You will also need STX in your wallet to purchase a Bitcoin domain on BNS. New domains cost 2 STX. These costs don‚Äôt include transaction fees. You can buy STX from an exchange and send it to your Stacks-compatible wallet. The steps to buying a Bitcoin domain are as follows; Go to https://btc.us/ and write the name you want to register in the search bar on the landing page. A pop-up will tell you whether the name is available
column17: the rates you‚Äôll pay in STX
column18: and how long you‚Äôll have it (5 years for 2 STX). Once you‚Äôve confirmed the name is available
column19: you must create a Bitcoin-connected Stacks account to start the purchase. Connect your Stacks-compatible wallet to the site to log in. Once you‚Äôre logged in
column20: you will get a prompt to purchase the .btc domain you chose. Send in the 2 STX
column21: and you‚Äôll own the domain for five years. The transaction will incur a small gas fee. After the transaction is complete
column22: the Bitcoin domain name will appear in your Stacks wallet. You can also buy a second-hand Bitcoin domain in secondary marketplaces. BNS names give people unique web3 identities and make it easier to complete transactions without making any errors. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column80: the Bitcoin community introduced the OP_RETURN function in 2014 as part of the Bitcoin Core 0.9.0 release. This function enabled users to ‚Äústore‚Äù arbitrary data on a Bitcoin transaction output
column81: preserving it within the Bitcoin block space. In 2017
column82: the segregated witness (SegWit) update was activated on Bitcoin. Before SegWit

column85: the transaction time

column87: on Bitcoin. SegWit separated signature information from transaction data

column1: 349::https://coinatory.com/cryptocurrency-articles/are-crypto-airdrops-to-make-money-11993/::Coinatory::article::Are Crypto Airdrops a Good Opportunity to Make Money in 2024?::Think of a crypto airdrops as a free giveaway
column2: where new digital coins or tokens are handed out to people who already own some cryptocurrency::Think of a crypto airdrops as a free giveaway
column3: where new digital coins or tokens are handed out to people who already own some cryptocurrency or those who do a few tasks. Blockchain startups use this tactic a lot
column4: kind of like a promo
column5: to get the word out about their new projects. Moreover
column6: digital assets can have multiple use cases. Over different time spans
column7: they can grant users decision-making powers within a network or give them VIP access to content via NFTs. What‚Äôs cool about these assets? They can be swapped or sold super easily. That‚Äôs because they‚Äôre highly liquid. So
column8: if you get assets through an airdrop
column9: you could trade them for other cryptocurrencies or even cash them out into your local currency. There‚Äôs a variety of airdrops out there
column10: but a common thread is that you typically need to register in some way to get those free digital goodies sent to the right wallet address. For some airdrops
column11: you might need to do a task or two. Regardless of the requirements
column12: the end game is pretty much the same: make sure your wallet address gets noted down before the deadline. When a startup sets its sights on an airdrop
column13: the kickoff is usually a public campaign. To get the word out
column14: they often take to places like forums and social media like Discord and Twitter. Create a buzz around a new platform launch or a fresh feature
column15: and of course
column16: the juicy airdrop reward. As the hype builds
column17: the next move for these companies is to make a list of who‚Äôs getting the tokens. This isn‚Äôt one-size-fits-all; they might gather wallet addresses from those who show interest
column18: or they might take a ‚Äòsnapshot‚Äô at a specific moment. This snapshot helps them see who‚Äôs eligible based on certain criteria. For instance
column19: if they want to reward those who were using their platform before September
column20: they‚Äôll take a snapshot of all the active wallet addresses from that period. Related: Discover how to create NFT in just 6 easiest steps! Absolutely
column21: from a user‚Äôs point of view
column22: airdrops can be like hitting the jackpot without buying a ticket. First off
column23: it‚Äôs kind of like getting dividends on stocks. If the crypto airdrop project takes off
column24: those airdropped tokens that appeared magically in your wallet might appreciate in value. So
column25: by just sitting tight and holding onto them
column26: you could see a tidy sum down the road. Then there‚Äôs the extra layer of perks some airdropped tokens bring to the table. Imagine being handed a membership card to an exclusive club. On some platforms
column27: these tokens don‚Äôt just sit idly; they give you voting rights
column28: especially if they double as governance tokens. So you get to have a say in Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAO) decisions related to the platform. And it doesn‚Äôt stop there. Think of these airdrop tokens as seed money that you can invest to grow more digital crops. Advanced crypto farming techniques like yield farming or lending can help users expand their portfolios
column29: turning those ‚Äúfree‚Äù tokens into interest-earning assets. All in all
column30: airdrops are more than just freebies; they‚Äôre opportunities. And who doesn‚Äôt love a good opportunity
column31: right? When you think about crypto airdrops
column32: there‚Äôs a bunch to mull over. First off
column33: you‚Äôve got to be cautious about the safety of your network. When you‚Äôre trying to get these airdrops
column34: some dodgy ones might ask you to link your wallet to some sketchy websites. Once you‚Äôve done that
column35: you‚Äôre potentially giving a thief an all-access pass to your account info. Then there‚Äôs the fact that not all airdrops crypto are the real deal. I mean
column36: who doesn‚Äôt like free money
column37: right? But some of these projects are just baiting folks to buy more tokens to up the value of their airdrop crypto. What‚Äôs the catch? Well
column38: they could just flood the market with a ton of these tokens all at once
column39: causing the price to plummet and making the airdrops you got earlier pretty much worthless. Some folks might also see airdrops as kinda low-tier. Instead of giving out free tokens willy-nilly
column40: maybe it‚Äôd be better to reward the people actually doing the hard work
column41: like the miners or others putting in the effort on a project. Oh
column42: and here‚Äôs a kicker: even if you do get an airdrop
column43: you might not be able to do much with it. Sometimes these airdrops say they‚Äôre worth a boatload of money
column44: but if you can‚Äôt trade ‚Äôem because there‚Äôs no demand
column45: then they‚Äôre pretty much just fancy
column47: it‚Äôs always good to be a little wary and do your own research before diving in. This blog is for educational purposes only. The information we offer is not investment advice. column8: you had to row a canoe for 500km or so to Palau and chisel away at some local limestone. Then you needed to take the 3m-wide lump of rock back to Yap without sinking in the Pacific. No one is quite sure when it started
column9: but the practice is at least several centuries old. Yapese money had no inherent value. For everyone to respect the proof-of-work
column10: the process was deliberately inefficient and incredibly resource-intensive
column11: just like bitcoin. Instead of relying on intrepid voyagers
column12: bitcoin uses a global network of competing computers. Like safe crackers at a safe-cracking contest
column13: these bitcoin mining machines guess the combination to a digital lock (a long string of digits) with the correct combination winning a few new bitcoins. The combination changes every ten minutes
column14: and the contest continues. This might all sound like a harmless game of digital bingo. But with more and more people enticed by the heady rewards
column15: bitcoin mining on some days uses as much energy as Poland and generates 37 million tonnes of CO2 each year. New institutional investors
column16: like the carmaker

column18: are driving the asset‚Äôs price skywards while ignoring bitcoin‚Äôs climate-changing appetite. And to keep the bull market charging
column19: supporters are working hard to argue for bitcoin‚Äôs green credentials. For the sake of a stable climate
column20: these myths need debunking. Myth one: bitcoin mining is becoming more efficient Bitcoin‚Äôs carbon emissions are not the network‚Äôs only dirty secret. In 2011
column21: competing miners could win the bitcoin bingo with an average laptop. Today
column22: viable operations require investing in warehouses filled with specialised hardware known as Application Specific Integrated Circuits (ASIC). As the majority of mining costs come from energy to run these units
column23: bitcoin miners are always careful to use the cheapest. To avoid wasting energy
column24: the global arms race for bitcoin requires ASICs to be replaced for newer and more efficient models every year. ASICs can‚Äôt be easily repurposed for general computing. Redundant units create around 11
column25: 500 tonnes of hazardous electronic waste each year
column26: much of which is dumped on cities in the global south. Myth two: bitcoin encourages investment in clean energy Chinese hydroelectric power plants are popular spots for bitcoin mining. While China cracks down on the industry
column27: 61% of bitcoin mining is powered by fossil fuels. Cheap coal in Australia has found new buyers through bitcoin
column28: as formerly redundant coal mines are reopened to power mining. Miners are willing to move anywhere for residual energy
column29: increasing the profitability of natural gas in Siberia and supporting oil drilling in Texas. In Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo
column30: bitcoin miners are getting special access to cheap
column31: clean energy produced by an EU-funded hydroelectric plant. The plant was designed to help locals find livelihoods beyond poaching and stop them resorting to scouring parkland for wood fuel. Bitcoin miners employ armies of computer servers
column32: not the ex-combatants the plant could help. Myth three: bitcoin replaces the need for gold mining Gold mining is one of the world‚Äôs most destructive industries. Bitcoin was originally intended as a digital replacement for gold that was also a deflationary means of exchange
column33: capable of rendering wasteful banks and regulators redundant. But for many institutional investors
column34: gold is being bought to hedge against bitcoin‚Äôs volatility. Tesla poured US$1.5 billion into bitcoin
column35: but also declared an interest in gold. While bitcoin is currently experiencing all-time price highs
column36: gold hit one of its own in 2020. Read more: Gold mining leaves deforested Amazon land barren for years
column37: find scientists Nor has bitcoin displaced traditional finance institutions. Major banks are vying to get very rich indeed on the back of it. Myth four: corporate players will boost market for ‚Äògreen bitcoin‚Äô Some argue that institutional investors can turn bitcoin green. Yves Bennaim

column40: ‚Äúthere will be more incentive to make investments in renewable sources of energy‚Äù for bitcoin mining. But miners will always use the cheapest option to maximise returns. It‚Äôs not possible to allocate additional rewards to miners using renewables

column1: 352::https://www.coindesk.com/markets/2024/03/13/why-prime-brokers-could-be-a-source-of-crypto-contagion/::CoinDesk::article::Why Prime Brokers Could Be a Source of Crypto Contagion::Prime brokers are a new source of liquidity in this cycle

column3: says Phillip Moran
column4: CEO of the Digital Opportunities Group.::Digital asset markets have been vibrant recently
column5: and this has been a great respite after almost two years of crypto winter. I do not want to throw a wet towel on current sentiment
column6: but it is good to remember that the seeds of the next crash are often sown during the good times. Because risk management is the primary job of all portfolio managers
column7: here I want to opine on one potential scenario if this bull market continues for another 18-plus months. Here is why I think the potential nexus for future contagion could be prime brokers (PBs). Why? Because 1) PBs are emerging as a major player and lender in crypto markets and2) The current lending standards of PBs are tight
column8: largely lending to low drawdown strategies (like delta-neutral)
column9: and presents low systemic risk. But
column11: if expected returns of delta-neutral strategies decline
column12: then PBs may move out the risk curve in terms of who they are willing to lend to and what services they offer
column13: which could brew systemic risk. During the last bullish cycle
column14: lenders increased the violence of the implosions that we witnessed. Leverage was hidden across a network of entities (BlockFi
column15: Voyager
column16: etc.)
column17: with concentration at certain nodes (3AC
column18: Alameda). The lenders of the old-world are largely gone
column19: but there is a new source of liquidity: prime brokers (PBs). Currently
column20: PBs generate most of their revenues through 1) trading revenues from market access
column21: and 2) lending revenues from lending
column22: typically to delta-neutral strategies. Funding arbitrage is a strategy which benefits from market demand to go long via derivatives. This exploits the funding interest rates paid out from perpetual swaps (a crypto derivative product) by going long on spot and short perpetual swaps (or vice versa). This generates attractive yields and exploits market demand to go levered long
column23: while not exposing the strategy to directional market moves. If the strategy is implemented well
column24: the risk is very low
column25: which makes it a popular strategy for PBs to lend to. While funding rates are currently elevated from recent upside price action
column26: I believe it is reasonable to expect the returns to come down as more money flows into these lower-risk strategies. With returns declining in funding arbitrage
column27: we will likely see returns in other lower risk strategies fall. If expected returns decline below the borrow cost from PB loans
column28: then the PBs will be forced to make the decision to move out the risk spectrum or reconsider their product offerings. What could this apocalyptic future fueled by crypto PB collapse look like? What could it be fueled by? Here are a couple ideas: Further aggregation of liquidity through PBs: Increasing volume requirements for better fee tiers at centralized exchanges
column29: like Binance and OKX
column30: will push most traders to access the market through PBs instead of their own master accounts. Synthetics
column31: swaps

column33: or the PBs limiting access)

column35: or leverage shenanigans. We should enjoy the good times while they are here

column3: which comes from a source knowledgeable about the matter
column4: suggests a potential change in how regulators [‚Ä¶]::In a significant development
column5: the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has chosen not to challenge a previous court decision that deemed its rejection of Grayscale Investments‚Äô request to launch a spot Bitcoin ETF as unfair. This surprising decision
column6: which comes from a source knowledgeable about the matter
column7: suggests a potential change in how regulators view cryptocurrency products. Back in August
column8: the District of Columbia Court of Appeals thoroughly examined and overturned the SEC‚Äôs initial refusal of Grayscale‚Äôs proposed Bitcoin ETF. This case had drawn keen attention from the financial industry
column9: which has been eagerly pushing for such initiatives for the past decade. The court‚Äôs ruling asserted that the SEC had made a mistake in its judgment
column10: pushing the regulatory agency to reconsider Grayscale‚Äôs application. A spot Bitcoin ETF offers investors a unique opportunity to gain exposure to Bitcoin
column11: the leading cryptocurrency in terms of market capitalization
column12: without needing to own the cryptocurrency directly. Grayscale argued in court that the SEC had previously approved specific surveillance measures to prevent fraudulent activities in Bitcoin futures-based ETFs and that a similar approach should be suitable for their spot ETF. The main argument here is that both spot and futures funds are tied to the valuation of Bitcoin. According to the appellate court
column13: Grayscale‚Äôs application had been arbitrarily denied because the SEC failed to explain why the two setups (for futures and spot ETFs) displayed significant differences. A forthcoming directive from the appeals court will likely clarify how its decision should be implemented

column1: 357::https://theconversation.com/price-hikes-in-ether-and-bitcoin-arent-the-signs-of-a-bubble-79350::The Conversation::article::Price hikes in Ether and Bitcoin aren‚Äôt the signs of a bubble::While the current speculation in crypto-currency and assets should make us pause
column2: this is not a speculative driven bubble like tulips
column3: or gold mining stocks.::When there is a rapid growth in any of the crypto-currencies and assets such as Bitcoin
column4: Ether
column5: Zcash and others
column6: many will call it out as a bubble. Indeed
column7: on a relatively short time scale it clearly looks like a bubble. The entire crypto-currency market capitalisation currently stands at around US$100 billion; it was US$60 billion one month ago. But Bitcoin was worth 1/100 of a US cent in June of 2009
column8: 7 cents in June 2010
column9: and US$7 in June of 2012. Recently all eyes were on Ether. Over a 90 day period
column10: Ether appreciated twice as quickly as Bitcoin did in late 2013
column11: when Bitcoin crashed to around 35% of it‚Äôs highest value. Aside from the 2013 crash
column12: Bitcoin has experienced smaller crashes many times since
column13: but is now worth double its 2013 high. In the longer term
column14: these are fluctuations around a strong growth trend. Crashes will cause some to abandon the field. But signals of longer term growth in these crypto-currencies and assets point to a possible emergence of a new type of market
column15: through the building of a new economic infrastructure. Ether is the token of the Ethereum blockchain
column16: a platform that runs ‚Äúsmart contracts‚Äù through a distributed online ledger that records transactions. It‚Äôs second only to the crypto-currency Bitcoin in price. Some believe it will one day overtake Bitcoin (a process dubbed ‚ÄúThe Flippening‚Äù). Fundamental aspects of the technology that underpins crypto-currencies and assets are causing people to re-imagine
column17: and then enact
column18: new ways of creating and exchanging value online. The key difference between Bitcoin and Ethereum is that you can use Bitcoin for payments
column19: but you can use Ether to automate any number of processes using smart contracts. While many use cases for Ethereum are still at the proof-of-concept stage
column20: it is now attracting the attention of major banks
column21: businesses and governments
column22: all interested in the potential of the technology to provide greater efficiency and transparency in transactions. That normalisation has collapsed the implicit risk premium attached to this technology. Venture capitalist Albert Wenger describes the current activity in crypto-currencies and assets as ‚Äúfat protocol investing‚Äù. To explain what this is
column23: take the example of the underlying internet and web protocols (TCPI/IP and HTTP)
column24: used to build and run websites. These are not able to store value - therefore they are ‚Äúthin protocols‚Äù in Wenger‚Äôs terminology. So instead
column25: people invest in companies that make software (applications) and hardware that rely on these protocols. Companies such as Google and Facebook made a fortune by collecting and storing data generated by users through their online interactions. Meanwhile
column26: users
column27: and the developers who created internet and web protocol
column28: received nothing in return. Blockchain is a ‚Äúfat protocol‚Äù because it can be monetised
column29: including incentives for developers but also for users. For example
column30: the creator of JavaScript and co-founder of Mozilla Brendan Eich
column31: recently released an Ethereum-based web browser through which users can be paid for the attention they give to advertisements. What is making crypto-assets and currencies appear bubbly is the way in which many of these new platforms and applications have raised money through what are called initial coin offerings. An initial coin offering (a word play on ‚Äòinitial public offering‚Äô) is a mechanism by which developers sell the tokens associated with their platform to the public. Depending on the structure of the offering
column32: buyers can usually then trade the tokens
column33: creating secondary markets. As the founder of Ethereum
column34: Vitalik Buterin
column35: has noted
column36: no-one has figured out the right model for these offerings. This could be due to the immaturity of the Ethereum platform and ecosystem (which started development in 2013 and went live only in 2015). What we‚Äôre observing here is a new economic infrastructure being built and coming online. In tweets on Tuesday
column37: Buterin distanced himself from initial coin offerings
column38: stating he would no longer agree to be an advisor.  So while the current speculation in crypto-assets should make us pause
column39: this is not speculative like tulips
column40: or gold mining stocks. It is speculative like building a new city
column41: in that infrastructure needs to be developed first before you get to see who moves there. A further point to note is that investment bubbles are actually useful and important mechanisms for building new technologies because of the way they concentrate speculative resources on a new technology to facilitate exploration. There is an enormous effort proceeding to building new crypto businesses and infrastructure on the Ethereum platform. If this platform does indeed begin to carry large parts of the global economy as predicted by Deloitte
column42: a business consultancy
column43: then it‚Äôs still massively undervalued. These comments should not be construed as offering personal financial advice.::2017-06-19T20:01:29Z::Bitcoin

column1: 358::https://www.coindesk.com/business/2024/05/15/us-cpi-softer-than-expected-at-03-in-april-bitcoin-rises-to-635k/::CoinDesk::article::U.S. CPI Softer Than Expected at 0.3% in April; Bitcoin Rises to $63.7K::In a year of mostly bad news on inflation
column2: the government's Wednesday report gave some hope that Fed rate cuts might still be on the table.::The monthly pace of inflation in the U.S. eased a hair in April
column3: according to the government's Consumer Price Index (CPI)
column4: rising 0.3% versus 0.4% in March and economist forecasts for 0.4%. The rest of the report also showed small declines that were inline with expectations. On a year-over-year basis
column5: CPI was higher by 3.4% versus estimates for 3.4% and 3.5% in March. Core CPI ‚Äì which excludes food and energy costs ‚Äì rose 0.3% in April against estimates for 0.3% and 0.4% in March; on a year-over-year basis
column6: core CPI was higher by 3.6% versus forecasts for 3.6% and March's 3.8%. The price of bitcoin (BTC) jumped more than 1% in the minutes following the Wednesday morning report
column7: rising to $63
column8: 700. With the spot ETF catalyst sidelined for the past few weeks as inflows have slowed or even reversed
column9: bitcoin's price has been under pressure on the idea that interest rates were going to stay higher for longer. The consistent slide in inflation in 2023 had most
column10: including the U.S. Federal Reserve
column11: coming into 2024 expecting appreciably easier monetary policy throughout the year. Instead
column12: inflation has actual risen a bit thus far this year. Along with an economy that continues to grow
column13: it's put the kibosh on the thought of any imminent central bank rate cuts. Coming into Wednesday's CPI report
column14: the odds of a summer rate cut by the Fed were low and traders had priced in just a 50% chance of move in September
column15: according to the CME FedWatch Tool. Coming at the same time as the inflation numbers was retail sales data for April showing a flat reading versus forecasts for a rise of 0.4% and March's 0.6%. Retail sales ex-autos rose 0.2 in April
column16: in line with expectations
column17: but down from 0.9% in March. A check of traditional markets finds a positive reaction to the soft inflation and economic data
column18: with S&P 500 futures rising 0.5% and the 10-year Treasury yield sliding seven basis points to 4.37%. The U.S. dollar index has dropped 0.5% and gold has added 0.7%.  Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column1: 360::https://blockworks.co/news/empire-newsletter-crypto-in-congress::Blockworks::article::Empire Newsletter: Crypto‚Äôs day in Congress::Yesterday saw Congress‚Äô upper chamber side with the House on a measure aimed at overturning the SEC's SAB 121.::Yesterday saw Congress‚Äô upper chamber side with the House on a measure aimed at overturning SAB 121 US President Joe Biden | Paul Froggatt/Shutterstock modified by Blockworks Meet the US Senate‚Äôs new Democratic crypto caucus ‚Äî sort of. Yesterday saw Congress‚Äô upper chamber side with the House on a measure aimed at scuttling crypto accounting guidance created by the Securities and Exchange Commission. As Blockworks‚Äô Casey Wagner reported Wednesday
column2: the vote resulted from a behind-the-scenes lobbying campaign involving Republicans and industry advocates. In the end
column3: a dozen Democrats crossed the aisle for the 60-38 vote. When the House voted last week to undo Staff Accounting Bulletin 121
column4: 21 Democrats joined Republicans. What to make of this group
column5: and the relatively swift speed at which this effort took shape? Some of the group have been public about their crypto positions for some time. Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand of New York
column6: of course
column7: co-authored legislation with Sen. Cynthia Lummis of Wyoming. Others
column8: including Sens. Cory Booker of New Jersey and Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona
column9: have expressed support for the US crypto industry in the past. On the other hand
column10: some yes-voting members have taken positions less popular with the industry; Sens. Bob Casey of Pennsylvania
column11: Mark Kelly of Arizona and John Hickenlooper of Colorado have all scored ‚Äúvery anti-crypto scores‚Äù from Stand With Crypto‚Äôs political rankings. Read more: Stand With Crypto PAC launches as industry interest in campaign funding ramps up One has to wonder how much the Biden White House‚Äôs veto threat factored into the Democrats‚Äô decision to ‚Äúvote their conscience‚Äù ‚Äî that is
column12: not align behind a particular yea-or-nay group strategy. Remember
column13: several of the votes in question were cast by senators up for reelection this fall: Gillibrand
column14: Casey and Tester. For these members
column15: at least
column16: the vote provides a way to create some daylight between them and an unpopular incumbent. The glass-half-empty interpretation: Biden‚Äôs stated plan to veto the bill made it a somewhat ‚Äúsafer‚Äù bill to vote on
column17: given the preordained outcome. Of course
column18: it‚Äôs always possible that Biden will reverse course and side with a decidedly bipartisan movement in Congress
column19: but given that it‚Äôs an election year
column20: such a move would be a surprising one. I think there‚Äôs more going on here than political machinations
column21: however. Despite the memes to the contrary
column22: there‚Äôs always been Democrat support for crypto issues
column23: albeit not at the fervor expressed by Republicans. It‚Äôs possible
column24: quibbles aside
column25: that the popularity of crypto has broken through and created a moment when Congress actually
column26: against the odds
column27: saw fit to move forward with crypto legislation. Sure
column28: it took the form of an opposition measure
column29: and yeah
column30: it amounts to a won‚Äôt survive-a-veto messaging bill when Congress is essentially done working for the year. But they did it by a wider-than-expected margin
column31: and that means something. The upcoming election is about much more than crypto. But this week‚Äôs vote may mean that the next session of Congress could see real movement on crypto issues. And who knows ‚Äî there‚Äôs still a few more months to go. Maybe Lummis‚Äô and Gillibrand‚Äôs bill will get the attention and debate it has long deserved. ‚Äî Michael McSweeney There are some things crypto just does better. Want to transfer value almost instantly to the other side of the globe
column32: for a fraction of the cost of boring-ass fintech unicorns like Wise and Revolut? Use Tether on a network like Tron or Polygon: frictionless
column33: fast and easy. How about raising funds for a new venture? Like a goat farm. All good ‚Äî you can easily source liquidity and donations from around the world on social media and buy tons of goats
column34: no questions asked. It turns out crypto also does wanton pointless pumping much better than the stock market. The normie crowd has come back around to meme stocks
column35: about three years after the original /r/wallstreetbets craze. GameStop has pumped up to about 550% and dumped by nearly half over the past few weeks
column36: all because that Roaring Kitty guy tweeted some silly cryptic on Twitter. Other popular memestocks from the COVID era of free helicopter money (stimulus packages) haven‚Äôt yet had the same treatment
column37: for better or worse. Whether AMC
column38: Virgin Galactic and Kodak Eastman get their second moment is anyone‚Äôs guess. Still
column39: GameStop‚Äôs recent 550% is cute compared to what happens around these parts. So is its peak-2021 pump of more than 5
column40: 400% (54x). In the past five years ‚Äî the same period as memecoin mania #1 and #2 ‚Äî DOGE
column41: FLOKI
column42: WIF
column43: BONK and SHIB have all
column44: at their most
column45: multiplied in price hundreds of times. SHIB however takes the cake
column47: 000x (8 million percent). Sure
column48: there are some caveats: Many memecoins start trading from near zero
column49: so any real market movement sends prices practically off the chart. Hard to compare that with already-listed stocks within the same timeframe. And stock market circuit breakers do tend to put a damper on things. But don‚Äôt let that get in the way of a good time. DOGE
column50: for instance
column51: was launched in 2013 and it still went parabolic in 2021
column52: far more than GameStop
column53: Nikola or Hertz ever did. In fact
column54: if SHIB was included in the chart below
column55: it would turn the entire meme stocks sector into a tiny
column56: little
column57: insignificant bubble. Sounds about right. ‚Äî David Canellis Former Alameda CEO Sam Trabucco has been notably absent from the aftermath of FTX‚Äôs downfall
column58: though his name tends to pop up when discussing the collapse itself. Caroline Ellison
column59: his co-CEO prior to his departure
column60: took the stand at Sam Bankman-Fried‚Äôs trial though Trabucco didn‚Äôt appear once. He also hasn‚Äôt been publicly accused of any wrongdoing. But yesterday
column61: Trabucco broke his silence in a letter to the court ahead of ex-FTX executive Ryan Salame‚Äôs sentencing hearing. Trabucco‚Äôs letter is over three pages long and is‚Ä¶.interesting
column62: to say the least. Not only do we learn a lot about Salame‚Äôs home life (he hung 80 photographs of his new partner in his home after dating for a month) but we also get some insight into Trabucco‚Äôs time at Alameda. Simply put: Trabucco seemed unhappy with the hours and work at Alameda
column63: calling Salame his ‚Äúlifeline‚Äù through the ‚Äúhardest period of my life.‚Äù Obviously
column64: we can‚Äôt know what happened behind closed doors and there are still many questions that remain unanswered about Trabucco‚Äôs role and the millions of dollars he walked away with. But he‚Äôs made one thing clear: He‚Äôs a loyal friend. ‚Äî Katherine Ross Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. column5: 000+ in NEXO Tokens! Share this article Solana‚Äôs meme coin marketplace Pump.fun got exploited this Thursday after its bonding curve contracts have been compromised. In an X post
column6: the team behind the platform claimed to have upgraded the contracts so the attacker cannot withdrawl more funds
column7: and paused the trades for all the tokens. The X user identified as ‚Äústaccoverflow‚Äù claimed to be the author
column8: stating that he drained nearly $80 million from Pump.fun. However
column9: Wintermute‚Äôs head of research Igor Igamberdiev shared that the exploit drained almost 2
column10: 000 SOL
column11: which is roughly equivalent to $300
column12: 000. 1/6 It seems like @pumpdotfun lost ~2k SOL ($300k+) and a bunch of memecoins through a possible private key leakage So let me share evidence of itüëáhttps://t.co/yuuKYkamfZ ‚Äî Igor Igamberdiev (@FrankResearcher) May 16
column13: 2024 Igamberdiev explains that the attack started with flash loans
column14: which is a feature that lets investors borrow crypto
column15: execute an interaction with a platform with the funds taken
column16: and pay back to the lender all within the same block. Staccoverflow used this function to exploit Pump.fun‚Äôs model of bonding curve
column17: where tokens traded on the platform have liquidity pools created on the decentralized exchange Raydium after they reach a market cap threshold. Therefore
column18: he took SOL from Solana‚Äôs money market MarginFi
column19: used the funds to buy the tokens on Pump.fun until they reached the threshold to go live on Raydium
column20: and then dumped the assets in the same block. However
column21: a Pump.fun-tied wallet is responsible for moving liquidity from the meme coin marketplace to Raydium. This wallet is supposedly compromised
column22: as it was being used to send the liquidity to the exploiter
column23: who used the funds to repay his loan and sent the remaining amount to a random Solana address. Moreover
column24: Wintermute‚Äôs head of research doesn‚Äôt discard the possibility of an inside job. Share this article The information on or accessed through this website is obtained from independent sources we believe to be accurate and reliable

column1: 363::https://theconversation.com/alternative-currencies-are-the-future-why-it-matters-for-development-80036::The Conversation::article::Alternative currencies are the future: why it matters for development::All over the world people who have been harmed by the conventional money systems are devising alternative currencies
column2: challenging the centralised monetary policy approach.::When I began to teach in 2012
column3: I decided to start my course with an analysis of how money affects social order. What my students found particularly fascinating was the then-nascent world of cryptocurrencies
column4: which I described at length as a crucial feature in the future of money. Some colleagues criticised my approach. They accused me of indirectly encouraging students to invest in what they saw as a shady
column5: crime-ridden financial underworld. But I was simply exposing young minds to a fast-evolving
column6: complex phenomenon that in my view would have a major impact on power distribution in the global economy. Behind most cryptocurrencies is a simple technology known as ‚Äúblockchain‚Äù
column7: a system residing in multiple computers that allows for peer-to-peer financial ledger recording of all transactions occurring in a network. This results in a transparent open-access registry of monetary flows which makes the intermediation of banking authorities unnecessary. Thus it challenges the conventional belief that money can only work through central planning. As I explain in my book
column8: Wellbeing Economy: Success in a World Without Growth
column9: money systems are undergoing an unprecedented transition from centralised authority to decentralised networks. Conventional money is managed by states and banks
column10: with users on the receiving end of monetary policy decisions. By contrast
column11: most alternative currencies are peer-to-peer. That means they are managed by users themselves and do not require intermediaries. Some of them have global outreach thanks to digital technology
column12: while others are locally based. Take BitCoin
column13: the most popular peer-to-peer currency in the world
column14: with a market capitalisation above 40 billion US dollars. A person buying the equivalent of $1 in BitCoin in 2009 would now possess roughly $25 million. One BitCoin is currently equivalent in value to two ounces of gold. Other rising stars include Ethereum
column15: Litecoin and Ripple. Many of these currencies remain quite volatile in the short term. Their upward and downward swings reach over 10% of the value on a weekly basis. But the long-term trend is impressive. States are warming up to them. In April 2017
column16: Japan accepted BitCoin as a legal payment method for retail markets. After threatening digital currencies last year
column17: the Russian government took a U-turn. President Vladimir Putin met the developers of Ethereum and committed to recognising cryptocurrencies in 2018. Following an initial freeze
column18: the People‚Äôs Bank of China readmitted withdrawals in BitCoin in June 2017
column19: catapulting the currency to new heights. In the US
column20: cryptocurrencies are becoming increasingly accepted as both a method of payment and store of value. The Australian government will soon make it easier for new innovative digital currency businesses to operate
column21: exempting traders and investors from goods and services tax. It‚Äôs clear that cryptocurrencies will in the near future become much more common as methods of payment for a wide range of purchases
column22: from online shopping to the local supermarket. Developing economies
column23: too
column24: are opening up to cryptocurrencies. In Venezuela
column25: BitCoin has become the leading parallel currency. It provides millions of citizens with an opportunity to perform transactions and generate livelihoods
column26: including buying food and other basic necessities in a country where official money is worth almost zero. It also allows them to purchase goods from overseas
column27: overcoming ever-stricter capital controls. In East Africa
column28: local innovators have introduced cryptocurrency systems to support cross-border transactions
column29: as exemplified by initiatives like BitPesa. In South Africa
column30: cryptocurrencies are becoming particularly popular. In Nigeria
column31: local traders and activists believe this new money presents an opportunity to democratise the economy. This is propelled by the fact that people in Nigeria have been failed by conventional money. According to my colleague Verengai Mabika
column32: founder of BitFinance in Zimbabwe
column33: the collapse of his country‚Äôs formal financial system has made BitCoin an attractive alternative. This is especially the case for online payments
column34: which are restricted by banks
column35: and for remittances
column36: which constitute the backbone of the economy. A growing number of Zimbabweans are also using cryptocurrencies as a saving mechanism (37% of all Bitfinance customers use it for that purpose)
column37: Verengai tells me. This is after the massive loss of personal savings during the hyperinflation period of 2008
column38: which led to the collapse of the country‚Äôs banks. The decentralisation of money is indeed at the core of this new trend
column39: with potential repercussions in other fields. For instance
column40: Ethereum is designed as a smart contract platform
column41: that is a trading system completely based on peer-to-peer property rights. FairCoin was developed as the preferential currency for cooperatives
column42: social economies and fair trade networks around the world. Cryptocurrencies are just the tip of an iceberg. According to recent estimates
column43: there are over 6
column44: 000 complementary currencies in the world
column45: over 50 times the number of conventional money systems. Most of these are user-controllled and are interest-free. One cannot make money by simply trading in them. Hoarding makes no sense in this new world. This is because value is not in the accumulation but in the exchange. The scope is often limited to certain territories or types of transactions (for example
column47: sustainable mobility and local trade). This creates an incentive to support local economic development and forms of exchange that are valued by communities of users. Regiogeld
column48: a network of local currencies which I studied when I was a researcher in Germany
column49: has proliferated throughout the country. It has become the world‚Äôs largest system of local currencies
column50: supporting small businesses and empowering communities. In the near future
column51: we will have a variety of money with different qualities and different purposes. This will make economies more resilient against shocks and will support more equitable and sustainable development
column52: by putting users in the driver seat and reinforcing local economic development. As my research demonstrates
column53: a combination of regional
column54: national and local currencies could also be the best way forward for the European Union
column55: engulfed by its monolithic and unsustainable euro
column56: and for any other process of regional integration
column57: from Africa to other continents.::2017-07-02T08:37:19Z::Africa

column3: Digital Assets Council of Financial Professionals founder says Poetra.RH/Shutterstock modified by Blockworks Vanguard has said it doesn‚Äôt believe in crypto‚Äôs investment case
column4: and it doesn‚Äôt allow bitcoin ETFs to trade on its platform. But the fund giant‚Äôs new CEO
column5: Salim Ramji
column6: led BlackRock‚Äôs ETF business as the company spurred an industry double-take with its bitcoin ETF filing last year. So something‚Äôs got to give
column7: right? Maybe not soon
column8: but ultimately yes
column9: according to Ric Edelman
column10: founder of the Digital Assets Council of Financial Professionals (DACFP). Ramji was BlackRock‚Äôs global head of iShares and index investing before leaving the world‚Äôs largest asset manager in January. He started his career leading the firm‚Äôs corporate strategy and moved on to become its head of US wealth advisory. Vanguard said Tuesday that Ramji would succeed Tim Buckley as chief executive on July 8. The firm had revealed in February that Buckley was set to retire by the year‚Äôs end. Though Ramji left BlackRock the month that US spot bitcoin ETFs gained Securities and Exchange Commission clearance
column11: he was of course involved in the lead-up. Fast-forward four months
column12: and BlackRock‚Äôs iShares Bitcoin Trust (IBIT) has so far led the category with $15.5 billion of net inflows. IBIT trails the segment‚Äôs largest fund ‚Äî the Grayscale Bitcoin Trust ETF (GBTC) ‚Äî by less than $1 billion in assets under management. Read more: Strong start
column13: slowing demand: The first 4 months of US spot bitcoin ETFs In a July 2023 interview on Bloomberg TV
column14: Ramji said the company was ‚Äúincredibly excited‚Äù about blockchain technology given its ability to remove considerable ‚Äúfriction‚Äù across the financial ecosystem. The then-BlackRock executive likened the planned bitcoin product to its physical gold ETF ‚Äî the iShares Gold Trust (IAU) ‚Äî launched in 2005. ‚ÄúThe gold is held in custody in a vault
column15: which is remote from us
column16: but it‚Äôs now easier to transact in gold using our gold ETFs
column17: ‚Äù he said at the time. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre applying that same philosophy to other new and emerging asset classes like bitcoin
column18: just as we did to gold 20 years ago and just as we did to bonds 20 years ago.‚Äù The bitcoin ETF bid was an effort to ‚Äúhelp investors gain access to parts of the market that otherwise have been more difficult or really expensive or opaque for them to access otherwise
column19: ‚Äù Ramji added. For what it‚Äôs worth
column20: Vanguard‚Äôs Tuesday news release does not mention IBIT or crypto. A company spokesperson did not immediately return a request for further comment. While brokerage firms Fidelity and Charles Schwab
column21: for example
column22: give investors access to trade bitcoin ETFs
column23: Vanguard does not. The company has called the investment case for cryptocurrencies ‚Äúweak‚Äù ‚Äî noting that most crypto assets ‚Äúlack intrinsic economic value‚Äù and are highly volatile. Read more: As spot bitcoin ETF volumes soar
column24: Vanguard is blocking such trades DACFP‚Äôs Edelman
column25: who also founded Edelman Financial Services
column26: said he believes Ramji will bring a more ‚Äúmarket-focused approach‚Äù to Vanguard. After all

column6: 000 has excited traders especially considering the decreasing supply of Bitcoin on exchanges
column7: which is now at its lowest point in six years. Coinciding with this trend is an increase in whale activity. A recent analysis by Santiment highlighted these developments. Explored whether this upward momentum would sustain after breaching the $28
column8: 000 mark. Historically Bitcoin has experienced upward trends followed by minor setbacks. However the recent 6.6% monthly rise in BTCs value has generated enthusiasm among traders. This bullish sentiment was further reinforced by whale transactions exceeding $100 million particularly observed towards the end of September. The combination of these transactions and the limited availability of Bitcoin on exchanges presents an optimistic outlook. Interestingly a majority of these transactions were associated with self custody practices
column9: which aligns with a growing trend embraced by the cryptocurrency community. Santiment deduced from this data that October would witness a 6 week high for Bitcoin. The report suggests that three prominent categories of BTC whales and sharks‚Äîwallets holding 10 100 BTC
column11: 000 BTC and 1
column13: 000 BTC‚Äîhave played a role in driving this positive swing
column14: for Bitcoin since early September. The proactive behavior of these whales and sharks combined with the decreasing amount of Bitcoin on exchanges (which is currently at its lowest level since December 2017) has further boosted confidence in the positive trajectory of Bitcoin. Furthermore Santiment has highlighted the prevalence of trades on Bitcoin since mid August. However it appears that these short trades have ceased after Bitcoin initially surged to $28
column15: 000 on October 1st. Nevertheless caution is essential. There is still a possibility for short trades to resume
column16: especially if Bitcoins price drops below $27
column17: 000. This could potentially introduce volatility into the market. It‚Äôs important to keep an eye on trading volume trends and consistent on chain transaction volume as they have often been indicators of local peaks in the past and may indicate a continuation of the bearish market trend. The term ‚ÄúUptober‚Äù is gaining popularity across focused social networks as it reflects optimism regarding Octobers potential impact on prices. However Santiment reminds everyone to maintain expectations. While there is an air of optimism surrounding Bitcoin it‚Äôs important to remain cautious. With six months until the next Bitcoin halving and pending Federal Reserve interest rate decisions that could influence the crypto market it is advised to stay vigilant. As

column1: 368::https://theconversation.com/whats-holding-up-the-blockchain-79038::The Conversation::article::What‚Äôs holding up the blockchain?::The blockchain has been successful when it comes to cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin
column2: but we haven‚Äôt yet figured out other uses.::It‚Äôs not technology or regulation holding back the blockchain - software that stores and transfers value or data across the internet - we just haven‚Äôt figured out the next big use-case. Two reports released this week by the CSIRO‚Äôs Data61 not only inject some well-researched gravitas into the conversation
column3: they also provide insight into why some of the major blockchain projects have stalled. Since 2015
column4: banks
column5: regulators
column6: tech giants and startups all over the world have raised billions of dollars to explore the blockchain. But the only really successful
column7: scaleable use of the blockchain remains cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin. Bitcoins currently trade at almost AU$4
column9: with a total market cap of A$61.4 billion. Think of the blockchain as a type of transparent spreadsheet or ‚Äúpublic ledger‚Äù. When someone transfers a Bitcoin
column10: for example
column11: the transaction is verified by ‚Äúminers‚Äù
column12: encrypted and a ‚Äúblock‚Äù is added to the spreadsheet. Mining takes a lot of computing power
column13: and so miners are incentivised to participate in the system with a reward of bitcoin. It‚Äôs finding a way to put all these pieces together for purposes other than cryptocurrencies that has yet to be figured out. Because of all the computing power required to verify and encrypt new blocks
column14: running a blockchain network is expensive and consumes a lot of electricity. For this reason
column15: a blockchain should only be used if it solves particular problems. For example
column16: a blockchain could allow users to see each other‚Äôs ledgers and transactions
column17: negating the need for a trusted third party to manage risk. The blockchain itself
column18: through sophisticated cryptography
column19: would provide privacy and trust. Conversely
column20: if there is already a central third party managing trust between users and verifying transactions (something banks already do for consumers)
column21: then a blockchain is probably not needed at all. Failing that
column22: a sophisticated database or expert system would be a cheaper and simpler alternative. The Data61 reports describe some of the possible opportunities for the blockchain in Australia
column23: including monitoring the outbreak of pests or animal and plant diseases
column24: border surveillance
column25: tracking intellectual property
column26: and identity systems that provide greater certainty over entitlements
column27: benefits
column28: and tax obligations. The reports also identify some of the risks. The risks include both business and technical risks. For example
column29: public ledgers do not afford privacy and blockchains generally are not suitable for storing large volumes of high speed data. Bitcoin‚Äôs blockchain has been suffering from this very problem for more than a year. Finding a solution is a priority for any developers wanting to attract the number of users needed to make running a network profitable. The use of blockchain in financial transactions also poses problems for compliance with anti-money laundering legislation
column30: which requires that anyone providing financial services (for example) must satisfy themselves as to the identity of their client or customer. These shortcomings may explain why a number of high-profile blockchain projects have recently stalled. For example
column31: last week
column32: the Bank of Canada announced that its blockchain project
column33: Jasper
column34: is not yet fit to handle settlements. Citing transparency and privacy issues
column35: the bank found that the benefits of using blockchain did not outweigh the risks. But risk is not the only reason that blockchain projects are stalling. In February 2017
column36: the R3CEV consortium of banks and technologists announced after more than 18 months of investment
column37: innovation
column38: and testing
column39: that they would not be using blockchain for their project because they did not need it. Meanwhile
column40: in a speech delivered to the Africa Blockchain Conference in March 2017
column41: Andreas Antonopoulos warned that many recent ‚Äúblockchain‚Äù projects are fraudulent attempts to raise capital under the guise of innovation and disruptive technologies. While bitcoin has proven what the blockchain can do
column42: the technology still needs a killer app to justify the hype. The most likely contender is currently a ‚Äúsmart contract‚Äù. Smart contracts are programmable transactions with complex internal logic that can interact with internet-enabled devices and other smart contracts. At this time
column43: the problem with smart contracts is that they are susceptible to manipulation. What is needed to test the capacity of the blockchain is a small-scale low-stakes low-risk smart contract that (for example) regulates energy consumption
column44: manages permissions
column45: or ensures payment on supply. Data61‚Äôs Smart Contracts Report lists some contenders
column46: but first we need to manage the risk of fraud
column47: breach of privacy
column48: and blockchain bloat. Once these risks have been reduced to nil or negligible
column49: the real work can resume.::2017-06-08T07:10:01Z::Banking

column2: ending a 78-day outflow run.::Grayscale‚Äôs spot bitcoin ETF notched positive flows for the first time since becoming an ETF
column3: ending a 78-day outflow run Grayscale and Adobe Stock modified by Blockworks The Grayscale Bitcoin Trust (GBTC) converted to an ETF nearly four months ago. It took that long for the fund to see its first day of net inflows. That unprecedented event occurred on Friday
column4: when GBTC saw $63 million in net money enter the ETF
column5: according to Farside Investors data. Read more: Why tracking bitcoin ETF flows matters. And why it doesn‚Äôt. GBTC had suffered net outflows for 78 days before that ‚Äî piling up to equal $17.4 billion. Just don‚Äôt expect the GBTC inflows to become a regular thing
column6: one segment observer says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs difficult to discern what might be behind the flows into GBTC
column7: ‚Äù said Nate Geraci
column8: president of The ETF Store. ‚ÄúETF buyers are an extremely diverse group with varying motivations. That said
column9: I would be surprised if the inflows become a trend.‚Äù Part of the reason it will have a hard time consistently attracting new money? Its cost
column10: Geraci noted. Industry watchers have attributed GBTC‚Äôs constant asset spillage to the fund‚Äôs fee of 1.5% ‚Äî a much higher level than its 10 competitors in the US. Beyond the fee
column11: bankrupt lender Genesis was among those offloading its GBTC holdings
column12: contributing to the asset exodus from the fund. And still
column13: Grayscale holds the assets under management lead in the category. GBTC manages roughly $18.1 billion in assets
column14: while BlackRock‚Äôs iShares Bitcoin Trust (IBIT) is close behind with about $16.9 billion. Grayscale has defended its higher fee
column15: previously pointing out GBTC‚Äôs ‚Äúmarket-leading liquidity
column16: tight spreads
column17: high trading volumes and a decade-long track record of operational success.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhile GBTC can still hang its hat on ample liquidity and tight spreads
column18: there are now competing products which can boast the same
column19: ‚Äù Geraci told Blockworks. The crypto asset manager also filed to set up the Grayscale Bitcoin Mini Trust (BTC)
column20: which would cost a fraction of GBTC‚Äôs price. The company has not yet revealed a final proposed expense ratio. Read more: Grayscale‚Äôs planned GBTC sibling is a page from BlackRock‚Äôs playbook GBTC would seed the new fund as part of a ‚Äúspin off‚Äù mechanism unique to commodity ETFs
column21: according to Grayscale. In addition
column22: a portion of GBTC‚Äôs bitcoin holdings would be allocated to the proposed Mini Trust. Beyond Grayscale‚Äôs inflows on Friday
column23: it was a day of net inflows for most of the 11-fund US spot bitcoin ETF category ‚Äî amounting to $378 million collectively. The asset gains were an anomaly of late
column24: snapping a record seven-day net outflow streak for the segment. column1: 373::https://cryptobriefing.com/meme-coin-analysis-strategy/::Crypto Briefing::article::Meme coin traders can benefit from fundamental analysis
column2: says HashKey Capital's Jupiter Zhang::Narrative trading and fundamental analysis don‚Äôt lie in opposition
column3: as investors can use both to navigate the market
column4: says Jupiter Zhang. Why bother with fundamentals? More VCs into meme coins::Join the hunt for $12
column6: 000+ in NEXO Tokens! Share this article Meme coins registered 1
column7: 300% returns on average during the first quarter
column8: according to a report by CoinGecko. This made meme coins the most profitable narrative in that period and made the number of tokens issued on Solana
column9: the hottest blockchain for meme coin trading
column10: reach an all-time high of 14
column11: 648 tokens launched. In this landscape
column12: new investors might be tempted to spray their funds over different meme coins and hope for stellar growth. Jupiter Zhang
column13: head of liquid funds at investment firm HashKey Capital
column14: highlights that ‚Äúfor every success story there are dozens more failures.‚Äù ‚ÄúMarket fundamentals have never been more important. [‚Ä¶] FOMO is not a long-term strategy
column15: ‚Äù shared Zhang with Crypto Briefing. ‚ÄúFundamental analysis provides a structured
column16: analytical approach to investment
column17: especially crucial in a volatile market like crypto. While the high returns from meme coins might seem attractive
column18: they are often driven by hype and speculation rather than underlying economic value.‚Äù Recently
column19: HashKey Capital published a 217-page book titled ‚ÄúDigital Asset Valuation Framework‚Äù
column20: a guide to fundamental analysis in crypto. Zhang is the lead author
column21: and he says that by understanding fundamental analysis
column22: investors can identify assets with real potential and longevity
column23: reducing risk and fostering a more sustainable investment strategy. ‚ÄúThis is crucial because
column24: as the meme coin narrative shows
column25: not all that glitters in the crypto world is gold.‚Äù Meme coins
column26: as the name suggests
column27: rise by backpacking on a famous meme. Because of this
column28: most of them usually have short lifespans. Investors might not be inclined to learn how to do proper research since spreading money might be more profitable. ‚ÄúEven in the seemingly whimsical area of meme coins
column29: fundamental analysis can provide insights. For instance
column30: evaluating the community engagement
column31: development activity
column32: and use cases of the token can offer a glimpse into its potential sustainability and growth
column33: ‚Äù explains Zhang. Moreover
column34: fundamental analysis can be useful for identifying what meme coins have a strong enough narrative to sustain longer-term interest from those that are likely to fizzle out with the fading of initial hype. ‚ÄúFundamental analysis doesn‚Äôt necessarily lie in opposition to narrative-driven investing
column35: which focuses primarily on the stories and trends that capture market interest and investor sentiment. They can be used in tandem to provide a more well-rounded evaluation of a digital asset‚Äôs potential.‚Äù Zhang adds that while fundamental analysis aims for long-term growth against the market‚Äôs often emotional and speculative waves
column36: narrative-driven investments are useful to ride the waves of market enthusiasm and investor psychology
column37: potentially reaping quick rewards. However
column38: narrative-driven investing often leads to the fear of missing out (FOMO)
column39: and that usually ends in bad investments. In other words
column40: narrative-driven demands an effort to time the market and move swiftly before the narrative shifts
column41: while fundamental analysis delves into the intrinsic value of an investment
column42: looking to identify assets with strong fundamentals that suggest a higher intrinsic value than the market price. ‚ÄúThis is a more methodical path to potentially sustainable gains
column43: as it requires rigorous assessment of data. Some things we look at when evaluating the fundamentals of digital assets: a thorough evaluation of a token‚Äôs utility
column44: governance structure
column45: supply mechanics
column47: and potential innovations there.‚Äù The meme coin market was always a way for investors to bet without generating returns for VCs. That is because when a token from a protocol is made available to the public
column48: VCs already have their hands on it for a significantly smaller price. Consequently
column49: if this token gets popular and its price jumps
column50: VCs are the true winners. Meanwhile
column51: since meme coins are issued by the community
column52: this is one sector VCs can‚Äôt profit from. Or couldn‚Äôt until recently. Shiba Inu closed a $12 million funding round with the participation of Mechanism Capital
column53: Big Brain Holdings
column54: Cypher Capital
column55: and Shima Capital
column56: among others
column57: and this may turn the tide in the meme coin market. ‚ÄúAcross sectors
column58: industries
column59: and opportunities
column60: investors will seek returns in all corners of the market. So large-scale investments in meme coins are not really surprising
column61: ‚Äù says Zhang about the recent movement of VCs into these tokens. ‚ÄúThe fundraising success of Shiba Inu suggests that even meme coins can capture serious investor attention when they align with a compelling narrative and show potential for broader ecosystem development based on community engagement.‚Äù Therefore
column62: that‚Äôs where fundamental analysis shows its weight. Zhang believes that as more people get equipped with fundamental analysis tools
column63: the number of serious investments directed at selected meme coins will show sustained growth over time. ‚ÄúThese will likely be the ones that demonstrate real utility

Studies show our money carries everything from pet DNA and old food to E.coli and traces of cocaine.::We live in a dirty world. Wherever we go
column2: we are among microbes. Bacteria
column3: fungi and viruses live on our phones
column4: bus seats
column5: door handles and park benches. We pass these tiny organisms to each other when we share a handshake or a seat on the plane. Now
column6: researchers are finding we also share our microbes through our money. From tip jars to vending machines to the meter maid ‚Äì each dollar
column7: passed person to person
column8: samples a bit of the environment it comes from
column9: and passes those bits to the next person
column10: the next place it goes. The list of things found on our dollars includes DNA from our pets
column11: traces of drugs
column12: and bacteria and viruses that cause disease. The findings demonstrate how money can silently record human activities
column13: leaving behind so-called ‚Äúmolecular echoes.‚Äù In 2017
column14: a study identified over a hundred different strains of bacteria on dollar bills circulating in New York City. Some of the most common bugs on our bills included Propionibacterium acnes
column15: a bacteria known to cause acne
column16: and Streptococcus oralis
column17: a common bacteria found in our mouths. The research team
column18: led by biologist Jane Carlton at New York University
column19: also discovered traces of DNA from domestic animals and from specific bacteria that are associated only with certain foods. A similar study recovered traces of DNA on ATM keypads
column20: reflecting the foods people ate in different neighborhoods. People in central Harlem ate more domestic chicken than those in Flushing and Chinatown
column21: who ate more species of bony fish and mollusks. The foods people ate transferred from fingers to touchscreens
column22: where scientists could recover a bit of their most recent meals. We don‚Äôt leave only food behind. Traces of cocaine can be found on almost 80 percent of dollar bills. Other drugs
column23: including morphine
column24: heroin
column25: methamphetamine and amphetamine
column26: can also be found on bills
column27: though less commonly than cocaine. Identifying foods people eat or the drugs people use based on interactions with money might not seem all that useful
column28: but scientists are also using these types of data to understand patterns of disease. Most of the microbes the researchers in New York identified do not cause disease. But other studies have suggested that disease-causing strains of bacteria or virus could be passed along with our currency. Bacteria that cause food-borne illness ‚Äì including Salmonella and a pathogenic strain of E.coli ‚Äì have been shown to survive on pennies
column29: nickels and dimes and can hide out on ATM machines. Other bacteria
column30: such as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) which causes skin infections
column31: are found on bank notes in the U.S. and Canada
column32: but the extent to which they could spread infections is unknown. Try as we may to avoid exposure to germs
column33: they travel with us and on us. Even if disease-causing microbes can survive in places like ATMs
column34: the good news is that most exposures don‚Äôt make us sick. Disease transmission linked to money is rare
column35: and no major disease outbreaks have started from our ATMs. Although it doesn‚Äôt seem common for diseases to transmit through money
column36: there are ways we could make our money cleaner. Researchers are working on ways to clean money between transactions. Putting older bills through a machine that exposes them to carbon dioxide at a specific temperature and pressure can strip dollar bills of oils and dirt left behind by human fingers
column37: while the heat kills microbes that would otherwise linger. U.S. money is still made from a blend of cotton and linen
column38: which has been shown to have higher bacterial growth than plastic polymers. Several countries are transitioning from money made of natural fibers to plastic
column39: which may be less friendly to bacteria. Canada has had plastic money since 2013
column40: and the U.K. transitioned to a plastic-based bank note last year. Even if our money is not directly responsible for spreading disease
column41: we can still use the dollar‚Äôs travel history to track how we spread disease in other ways. The website WheresGeorge.com
column42: created in 1998
column43: lets users track dollar bills by recording their serial numbers. In the almost 20 years since the site‚Äôs creation
column44: WheresGeorge has tracked the geographic locations of bills totaling over a billion dollars. Now
column45: physicists at the Max Planck Institute and University of California
column46: Santa Barbara are using data from the WheresGeorge site to track epidemics. Information on human movement and contact rates from WheresGeorge was even used to predict the spread of the 2009 swine flu. Although we don‚Äôt know the extent to which money allows diseases to spread
column47: mom‚Äôs advice is probably best when handling cash: Wash your hands and don‚Äôt stick it in your mouth.::2017-06-21T10:31:20Z::50th anniversary of ATM

column2: Franklin Ethereum TR Ethereum ETF with ticker EZET
column3: is listed on DTCC
column4: signaling readiness for SEC's approval review slated for June.::Franklin Templeton
column5: a prominent asset management firm
column6: has introduced its Ethereum exchange-traded fund (ETF) called the ‚ÄúFranklin Ethereum TR Ethereum ETF
column7: ‚Äù bearing the ticker code EZET. This significant move involves the ETF‚Äôs listing on the website of the Depository Trust and Clearing Corporation (DTCC)
column8: a pivotal entity for securities transactions in the United States. The appearance of the ETF under the DTCC‚Äôs ‚ÄúCreate/Redeem‚Äù section is a crucial step in its operational deployment
column9: indicating that it is now set up for creation and redemption. It is important to note that this listing does not equate to an endorsement from the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)
column10: as approval from the agency is still pending. The presence on the DTCC platform implies that the ETF has met certain registration and compliance prerequisites
column11: thus qualifying it for trading and settlement within the DTCC‚Äôs frameworks. Yet
column12: the ultimate green light depends on the SEC‚Äôs evaluation based on comprehensive regulatory criteria. Franklin Templeton submitted a Form S-1 to the SEC in February
column13: aiming to launch a spot Ether (ETH) ETF. If sanctioned
column14: the ETF would trade under the name ‚ÄúFranklin Ethereum ETF‚Äù on the Chicago Board Options Exchange. In a recent update this April
column15: however
column16: the SEC disclosed a postponement in its decision regarding the application
column17: extending the review period by an additional 45 days to June 11. Several other major financial institutions
column18: including BlackRock
column19: Grayscale
column20: VanEck
column21: and ARK Invest
column22: are also in the pursuit to secure approval for their respective spot Ether ETFs. Nonetheless
column23: the pathway to approval for these Ethereum-based ETFs seems more complex compared to the earlier sanctioned spot Bitcoin ETFs
column24: which received approval in January. Eric Balchunas
column25: a Bloomberg ETF analyst
column26: estimated in March that the likelihood of a spot Ether ETF receiving approval in May stood at approximately 35%. He highlighted the SEC‚Äôs comparatively tentative approach toward Ethereum versus the Bitcoin ETF applications. Balchunas further mentioned that the perspectives of SEC Chair Gary Gensler on Ether
column27: particularly his hesitance to categorically classify it as a security
