501::https://cryptobriefing.com/opensea-considers-acquisition-nft-market-consolidation-continues/::Crypto Briefing::article::OpenSea considers acquisition as NFT market consolidation continues::Finzer stated in a recent interview that OpenSea has received offers and interest regarding an acquisition.::Join the hunt for $12,000,000+ in NEXO Tokens! Share this article Non-fungible token (NFT) marketplace OpenSea remains ‚Äúopen‚Äù to the prospect of an acquisition as the broader NFT industry sees increased consolidation, according to CEO Devin Finzer. ‚ÄúWe think that if the right partnership comes along, then that‚Äôs something we should certainly consider,‚Äù Finzer shares. Finzer stated in a recent interview that OpenSea has received offers and interest regarding an acquisition. Once a dominant player in the NFT sector, OpenSea has been overtaken by Blur, a rival marketplace. Despite having fewer overall users, Blur sees over five times more volume. OpenSea previously had a 90% dominance in the NFT sector. According to data from Dune Analytics, its monthly trading volume has plunged by 96% and is down to just $171 million, with an annualized revenue of $38.9 million. Finzer claims that Blur‚Äôs growth tactics involved cutting corners, particularly in terms of legal and regulatory compliance. Blur‚Äôs rapid growth is often attributed to its aggressive token airdrops and the marketing campaigns that push these. Market observers see parallels in crypto‚Äôs latest bull market resurgence, creating prime conditions for industry consolidation. Dealmakers seek bargains and synergies as prices recover from the crypto crash from the past two years. OpenSea itself stayed active via acquisitions in 2022, purchasing NFT data provider Gem, crypto wallet Dharma Labs, and NFT launch platform Mintdrop. Finzer cites gaining top talent as a key driver for such deals. OpenSea counts high-profile venture capital firms Andreessen Horowitz, Paradigm, and Coatue Management among its top investors. They participated in massive fundraising rounds in 2021, when OpenSea achieved a peak $13 billion valuation amid the NFT hype cycle. However, as the NFT market crashed, valuations also crashed. Coatue reportedly slashed the value of its OpenSea stake by 90% late last year. Andreessen Horowitz helped OpenSea raise $423 million in funding for three series in 2021. The prolific firm, led by Marc Andreessen and Ben Horowitz, has backed over 20 crypto startups at a valuation above $1 billion. In November 2023, OpenSea laid off approximately 20 employees, or 50% of its staff, amid plunging NFT sales. ‚ÄúThe restructuring that we did was really oriented around adjusting the team composition to be a much leaner, smaller team that can operate more nimbly in the market, as opposed to downsizing due to financial pressure,‚Äù Finzer said. Whether driven by financial duress or not, downsizing suggests the firm reset its operations to contend with new competitive and market realities. With OpenSea struggling to maintain market share versus rivals like Blur, its high-profile backers have seen the value of their stakes plummet. Significant dilution should OpenSea raise further rounds, which also presents downside risk. 502::https://theconversation.com/bitcoin-has-shot-up-50-since-the-new-year-but-heres-why-new-lows-are-probably-still-ahead-198682::The Conversation::article::Bitcoin has shot up 50% since the new year, but here‚Äôs why new lows are probably still ahead::There‚Äôs much excitement among bitcoiners right now ‚Äì¬†but are they about to be disappointed?::To the delight of investors across the cryptosphere, the price of bitcoin (BTC) has rallied over 53% since its low of US$15,476 (¬£12,519) in November. Now trading around US$23,000, there‚Äôs much talk that the bottom has finally been reached for the leading cryptocurrency after a year of painful decline ‚Äì in November 2021, the price peaked at almost US$70,000. If so, it‚Äôs not only good news for bitcoin but the whole market in cryptocurrencies, since the others broadly move in line with the leader. So is crypto back in business? The past is littered with various periods of market turmoil, from the global financial crisis of 2007-09 to the COVID-19 collapse in 2020. But neither of these is a particularly good comparison for our purposes because they both saw sharp drops and recoveries, as opposed to the slow unwinding of bitcoin. A better comparison would be the dotcom bubble burst in 2000-02, which you can see in the chart below (the Nasdaq is the index that tracks all tech stocks). Nasdaq 100 index 1995-2005 Look at the bitcoin chart since it peaked in November 2021 and the price action looks fairly similar: Bitcoin bear market price chart 2021-23 Both charts show that bear markets go through various periods where prices rise but don‚Äôt reach the same level as the previous peak ‚Äì known as ‚Äúlower highs‚Äù. If bitcoin is following a similar trajectory to the early 2000s Nasdaq, it would make sense that the current price will be another lower high and that it will be followed by another lower low. This is partly because like the 2000s Nasdaq, bitcoin seems to be following a pattern known as an Elliott Wave. Named after the renowned American stock market analyst Ralph Nelson Elliott, this essentially argues that during a bear phase, investors shift between different emotional states of disappointment and hope, before they finally despair and decide the market will never turn in their favour. This is a final wave of heavy selling known as capitulation. You can see this idea on the chart below, where bitcoin is the green and red line and Z is the potential capitulation point at around US$13,000 (click on the chart to make it bigger). The black line is the path that the Nasdaq took in the early 2000s. The blue pointing finger above that line is potentially the equivalent place to where the bitcoin price is now. Bitcoin now vs Nasdaq in the early 2000s The one other thing to note on the chart is the wavy line that‚Äôs moving horizontally along the bottom. This is the stochRSI or stochastic relative strength index, which is an indication of when the asset looks overbought (when the line is peaking) or oversold (when it‚Äôs bottoming). A sign of a coming shift is when the stochRSI moves in the opposite direction to where the price is heading: so now the stochRSI is coming down but the price has held up around US$23,000. This too suggests a fall could be imminent. Within markets, there is often a game that investors from institutions such as banks and hedge funds play with amateur (retail) investors. The aim is to transfer retail investors‚Äô wealth to these institutions. This is particularly easy in an unregulated market like bitcoin, because it is easier for institutions to manipulate prices. They can also talk up (or talk down) prices to stir up retail investors‚Äô emotions, and get them to buy at the top and sell at the bottom. This ‚Äútraps‚Äù the irrational investors who buy at higher prices, transferring wealth by giving the institutions an opportunity to convert their holdings into cash. It therefore makes sense to compare how the retail and institutional investors have been behaving lately. The following charts compare those crypto wallet addresses that hold 1 BTC or more (mostly retail investors) with those holding upwards of 1,000 BTC (institutional investors). In all three charts, the black line is the bitcoin price and the orange line is the number of wallets in that category. Retail investor behaviour Institutional investor behaviour pt 1 Institutional investor behaviour pt 2 This shows that since the FTX scandal back in November, which led to the world‚Äôs second-largest crypto exchange collapse, retail investors have been buying bitcoin aggressively, resulting in the highest number of addresses holding at least one BTC ever. On the other hand, the biggest institutional investors have been offloading. This suggests that the institutional investors agree with our analysis. There are those who argue that bitcoin is a bubble and that ultimately cryptocurrencies are worthless. That‚Äôs a separate debate for another day. If we assume there is a future for blockchains, which are the online ledgers that enable cryptocurrencies, the key question is when bitcoin will reach the accumulation phase that typically ends a bear phase in any market. Known as Wyckoff accumulation, this is where the price of the asset repeatedly tests two areas: the upper bound where traders previously sold heavily enough for the price to stop rising (known as resistance), and the lower bound where traders bought heavily enough that the price stopped going down (known as support). At the point where institutional investors decide the lower bound has proved to be sufficiently resilient ‚Äì in other words, they think the price is cheap at that level ‚Äì they will start buying the asset again. That moment is only likely to come after there has been a capitulation. Of course, history does not repeat itself exactly. It may be this is the first time that retail investors have outsmarted the large institutions, and that the only way is now up. More likely, however, there is more pain on the way. With a recession on the cards, unprecedented job layoffs and weak retail data coming out of the US, it doesn‚Äôt point to the kind of optimism that tends to move markets higher. It would therefore make sense to brace yourself for another plunge in the price of bitcoin and the rest of the crypto market.::2023-01-27T17:04:19Z::Bitcoin, Cryptocurrency, NASDAQ, bear market, dotcom bubble::James Kinsella::Business ,  Economy::https://images.theconversation.com/files/506823/original/file-20230127-16-4cgk1e.jpeg?ixlib=rb-4.1.0&rect=58%2C268%2C1769%2C883&q=45&auto=format&w=1356&h=668&fit=crop
503::https://www.coindesk.com/markets/2024/05/16/cme-looks-to-take-on-binance-and-coinbase-could-launch-spot-bitcoin-trading-report/::CoinDesk::article::CME Looks to Take On Binance and Coinbase, Could Launch Spot Bitcoin Trading: Report::The CME is already the top bitcoin futures exchange by open interest, while the offshore, non-regulated Binance dominates the spot market.::Futures powerhouse Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) plans to offer spot bitcoin trading to clients as demand for the product mounts among market participants, the Financial Times reported on Thursday. CME is already the top bitcoin futures exchange by open interest, while offshore, non-regulated Binance dominates the spot market. The exchange has held discussions with traders who want to trade bitcoin on a regulated marketplace, the FT reported, citing people with direct knowledge of the talks. CME's spot trading business could be run through the EBS currency trading venue in Switzerland, the report added. The exchange did not want to comment on the report. The spot market will complement the CME‚Äôs existing standard and micro futures contracts, which are widely considered a proxy for institutional activity, and help the exchange become more dominant in the crypto market. The CME is already the top bitcoin futures exchange by open interest, while the offshore, non-regulated Binance dominates the spot market. Coinbase (COIN), the only U.S. traded crypto exchange, is No. 3 by daily trading volume. The availability of the spot market means traders can now set up complex multi-leg strategies involving spot and futures markets in one regulated place. Carry traders are known to short CME futures against long spot market positions on other exchanges or in spot ETFs. ‚ÄúCrypto exchanges might lose some business with the potential debut of a bitcoin spot market on the CME, a global derivatives giant, as the present bull run is particularly driven by institutions, who prefer to trade on regulated avenues, Markus Thielen

Get the inside scoop and become a crypto master. Don't miss out
column2: start today!::A meme coin (aka memecoin) is a word used in the cryptocurrency world to refer to well-liked currencies that have ardent online supporters and traders and are occasionally portrayed with humorous or animated memes. Meme coins may be entertaining
column3: but they are also extremely risky investments that may or may not have any real value. This group includes currencies like Shiba Inu
column4: Dogecoin
column5: and other altcoins that may be more entertaining than practical. Understanding the dangers is essential while purchasing or trading meme coins so that you can steer clear of unforeseen volatility and losses. Meme coins are a type of cryptocurrency that has an enthusiastic online community that supports its development. They can occasionally be recognized by memes of animated animals or characters. Dogecoin and Shiba Inu were among the top cryptocurrencies to achieve meme coin status during the most recent cryptocurrency boom. Little-known currencies like Baby Doge and Dogelon Mars are included in this list. Baby Doge and Dogelon Mars still have market capitalizations in the nine figures despite receiving less media attention. Memecoins rely on blockchain technology
column6: like other cryptocurrencies
column7: which is a sort of distributed database used to track virtual assets
column8: such as cryptocurrencies and non-fungible tokens (NFTs). Unlike Ethereum and other utility currencies linked to specific blockchain characteristics
column9: the majority of meme coins are just used as trading platforms. Meme coins generally do not include popular cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin
column10: Ethereum
column11: Dollar Coin
column12: XRP
column13: Cardano
column14: Solana
column15: Polygon
column16: and Polkadot. More than 300 currencies are included in the Meme Coin section of the cryptocurrency website CoinMarketCap. Many
column17: however
column18: are not traded frequently and are hence worthless. Only Dogecoin
column19: Shiba Inu
column20: Dogelon Mars
column21: and Baby Dogecoin have a daily trade volume of more than $1 million in the meme currency category. All of them are typically regarded as volatile and dangerous trading assets. While ether is necessary for Ethereum blockchain transactions
column22: the majority of meme coins are just useful for trade and collecting. Some meme coins are actually tokens that operate on a different blockchain rather than actual currency. Shiba Inu
column23: for instance
column24: is an ERC-20 token that runs on the Ethereum network. Meme coins have been referred to as complex pump-and-dump operations by some in the media and investment community. Investors should be extremely cautious when entering these markets as a result of this claim and should be aware of meme currencies. Anyone with the necessary technical knowledge is easily able to create a cryptocurrency. However
column25: turning a coin or token into a popular meme coin is extremely difficult and has only been successfully achieved a few dozen times. There is no exact answer to this question. Meme coin can be both a very good investment and a regular scam. Don‚Äôt spend more money on this than you‚Äôre willing to spend. Better invest that money in something else. column1: 508::https://theconversation.com/can-blockchain-a-swiftly-evolving-technology-be-controlled-73471::The Conversation::article::Can blockchain
column2: a swiftly evolving technology
column3: be controlled?::Laws cannot keep pace with technological advances ‚Äì but that may not be a bad thing.::The headlong pace of technological change produces giant leaps forward in knowledge
column4: innovation
column5: new possibilities and
column6: almost inevitably
column7: legal problems. That‚Äôs now the case with blockchain
column8: today‚Äôs buzziest new tech tool. Introduced in 2008 as the technology underpinning Bitcoin
column9: a digital currency that is created and held electronically without any central authority
column10: blockchain is a secure digital ledger for any kind of data. It simplifies record keeping and reduces transaction costs. Its range of applications in commerce
column11: finance and potentially politics continues to widen
column12: and that has triggered a debate around how to regulate the tool. Because it does not require a centralised authority to verify and validate transactions
column13: blockchain enables people who may not trust each other to interact and coordinate directly. With blockchain
column14: there is no middleman in peer-to-peer exchanges; instead
column15: users rely on a decentralised network of computers that interact through a cryptographic
column16: secure protocol. Blockchain has the ability to ‚Äúcodify‚Äù transactions by deploying small snippets of code directly onto the blockchain. This code
column17: generally referred to as a ‚Äúsmart contract‚Äù
column18: executes automatically when certain conditions are met. An early example of smart contracts are the corporate-oriented digital rights management (DRM) systems limiting uses of digital files. Having DRM on your ebook may restrict access to copying
column19: editing
column20: and printing content. With blockchain
column21: smart contracts have become more complex and
column22: arguably
column23: more secure. In theory
column24: they will always be executed exactly as planned
column25: since no one party has the power to alter the code binding a given transaction. In practice
column26: however
column27: eliminating trusted brokers from a transaction can create some kinks. One high-profile smart-contract failure happened to the DAO
column28: a decentralised autonomous organisation for venture capital funding. Launched in April 2016
column29: the DAO quickly raised over US$150 million via crowdfunding. Three weeks later
column30: someone managed to exploit a vulnerability in the DAO‚Äôs code
column31: draining approximately US$50 million worth of digital currency from the fund. The security problem originated not in the blockchain itself but rather from issues with the smart-contract code used to administer the DAO. Questions arose about the legality of the act
column32: with some people arguing that since the hack was actually permitted by the smart-contract code
column33: it was a perfectly legitimate action. After all
column34: in cyberspace
column35: ‚Äúcode is law‚Äù. The DAO debate raised this key question: should the intention of the code prevail over the wording of the code? Blockchain proponents envision a future in which entire companies and governments operate in a distributed and automated fashion. But smart contracts pose a series of enforceability issues
column36: which are outlined in a recent white paper by the London law firm Norton Rose Fulbright. How can we resolve disputes arising over a self-executing smart contract? How do we identify what types of contractual terms can be properly translated into code
column37: and which ones should instead be left to natural language? And is there a way combine the two? It is not yet clear that code can address the necessary levels of complexity to replace legal language. After all
column38: the vagueness inherent in the language of law is a feature
column39: not a bug: it compensates for unforeseeable cases that must be assessed on a case-by-case basis in a court of law. Traditional contracts acknowledge that no law can index the entire complexity of life as it is
column40: let alone predict its future development. They also precisely define terms that can be enforced by law. Smart contracts
column41: by contrast
column42: are simply snippets of code both defined and enforced by the code underpinning the blockchain infrastructure. Currently
column43: they do not have any legal recognition. This means that when something goes wrong in a smart contract
column44: parties have no legal recourse. The DAO‚Äôs founders painfully learned this lesson last year. If blockchain technologies are ever to go mainstream
column45: governments will have to set up new legal frameworks to accommodate such complexities. Positive law prescribes behaviour and penalises non-compliance. It can encapsulate the normative ideal that a respective government seeks to achieve
column46: demonstrate an ethical vision for society or reify the power structure of the current regime. Technological developments
column47: on the other hand
column48: are often oriented toward profit and change. There‚Äôs an inherent tension here. Laws may delay the development of technology and hence hurt the competitive advantage of an entrepreneur or even a state. Take the case of nanotechnology regulation in the European Union versus in the United States. European law so mitigates risks that it may end up limiting the technology‚Äôs potential
column49: losing its competitive edge against the US. That‚Äôs another fact about the law: slow and reactive
column50: it can be a gross annoyance. But ever since technological advances began speeding along on an exponential curve last century
column51: the law has played a critical role in helping societies maintain certain previously negotiated standards for cohabitation. Our legal system may sometimes seem antiquated in today‚Äôs fast-moving world. But before changing our laws to accommodate new technologies that may (re)define our lives
column52: it is important to have room for debate and time for social struggles to take place. The law serves this function of creative friction. It can restore human agency against fierce technological development. Given all the excitement over blockchain technologies
column53: it is probable that interested parties will soon enough seek legal recognition and state-sanctioned enforceability of smart contracts. These emerging technologies are still too new to have been subjected to a sufficiently thorough analysis of their social
column54: economic and political implications. More time is also needed to assess how blockchain could be deployed in a socially beneficial way. Blockchain technology seems poised to constitute an important component of tomorrow‚Äôs society. The legal system ‚Äì slow-paced as it is ‚Äì might be just what we need at this juncture to ensure that this new tool is deployed in a way consistent with established principles and values
column55: with the common good at its core.::2017-05-03T06:26:38Z::Banking

column1: 511::https://blockworks.co/news/bitcoin-halving-impact-on-layer-2s::Blockworks::article::How will the Bitcoin halving impact Bitcoin L2s?::Bitcoin will likely grow to rely on its layer-2 infrastructure a lot more for most post-halving transactions this year
column2: experts say.::Bitcoin will likely grow to rely on its layer-2 infrastructure for most post-halving transactions this year
column3: experts say Artwork by Crystal Le The Bitcoin halving is anticipated to occur in the second half of April this year. Like real-world gold
column4: bitcoin is considered by many to be ‚Äúdigital gold
column5: ‚Äù with a maximum supply of 21 million coins. As the Bitcoin halving draws near
column6: many are concerned that miners will endure an inevitable revenue cut following the major event. Mining bitcoin has previously been a profitable way for people to earn rewards while simultaneously securing the network. Fisher Yu is the co-founder of Babylon
column7: a project aiming to create a Bitcoin-secured proof-of-stake economy. He noted the motivation behind early participation in Bitcoin‚Äôs proof-of-work security
column8: attributing it to the high amount of bitcoin rewards available when the blockchain was first created. ‚ÄúNakamoto‚Äôs hope is that
column9: over time
column10: Bitcoin becomes very well adopted so that the increase in transaction fee will outrun the reduction in mining rewards
column11: so that miners‚Äô operational costs are well covered
column12: ‚Äù Yu said. Read more: Why most bitcoin mining stocks are down amid a persistent crypto rally Although such a trend is observed
column13: Yu notes that existing transaction fees are not quite sufficient
column14: and there are growing concerns that miners may leave the network
column15: reducing the blockchain‚Äôs overall security. This belief is shared by Max Chamberlin
column16: the founder of next-gen EVM and layer-2 for Bitcoin
column17: Bitfinity
column18: who noted that many bitcoin mining businesses could become unsustainable following the halving. ‚ÄúWhile bitcoin‚Äôs mining difficulty is dynamic
column19: automatically adjusting to the current hash rate capabilities
column20: it would still be better for the network‚Äôs decentralization to have as many miners as possible
column21: ‚Äù Chamberlin said. Read more: 20% of bitcoin network hash rate could go offline after halving: Galaxy He notes that the emergence of Bitcoin Ordinals has boosted on-chain activity significantly and provided miners with a considerable new stream of income through transaction fees
column22: which have so far amounted to almost $240 million. ‚ÄúIn a broader sense
column23: the introduction of ordinals and Runes has sparked considerable excitement within the cryptocurrency community in general
column24: introducing a novel category of tokens ‚Äî assets that exist directly on the Bitcoin blockchain
column25: ‚Äù Chamberlin said. Despite this
column26: Chamberlin is aware that the Bitcoin ecosystem still needs to work on developing broad-spectrum
column27: general-purpose applications
column28: a challenge that stems primarily from the constraints of Bitcoin‚Äôs programming language
column29: Script. ‚ÄúThis predicament echoes a longstanding conundrum in finance ‚Äî the emergence of new assets begs the question of what to do with them
column30: ‚Äù he said. Read more: The history of Bitcoin halvings ‚Äî and why this time might look different He remarks that a potential solution to this concern is to integrate assets into DeFi services through Bitcoin layer-2 solutions
column31: which often enable a more complex ecosystem of decentralized applications. ‚ÄúBitfinity
column32: a next-gen EVM serving as a layer-2 for Bitcoin and other assets
column33: emerges as a strong contender in this regard. It provides developers with the familiar EVM programming environment but with access to Runes and other Bitcoin-native assets
column34: ‚Äù Chamberlin said. Yu agrees and explains that Babylon‚Äôs Bitcoin staking protocol could alleviate some of the growing concerns around cut rewards. He notes that miners could use their bitcoin to secure its proof-of-stake economy and be rewarded for their security. Read more: Let‚Äôs talk Bitcoin staking: Babylon‚Äôs litepaper Rena Shah shares this sentiment. Shah is the vice president of products and operations at Trust Machines
column35: a company that is building a decentralized economy on Bitcoin. She told Blockworks that Bitcoin will likely grow to rely on its layer-2 infrastructure a lot more for most post-halving transactions this year. ‚ÄúWhile the base layer will still focus on high-value settlements
column36: Bitcoin DeFi and other activities will no longer have to use the base layer
column37: as more [layer-2s] start unlocking frictionless usability
column38: ‚Äù she said. She added that ‚Äúsolving transaction times
column39: identity solutions and even wallet functionality between the [layer-1] and [layer-2s] are areas our team at Trust Machines has identified as most appealing to users. As well as DeFi opportunities
column40: which are of particular interest to users of other smart contract-based chains.‚Äù Updated April 3

column1: 512::https://coinatory.com/cryptocurrency-articles/invest-in-crypto-right-way-7367/::Coinatory::article::Smart Ways to Invest in Crypto: Essential Steps You Should Check Before Investing::Discover how to select the best cryptocurrency for buying and holding onto as a long-term investment. And learn how to avoid falling prey to scams.::‚ÄúInvest in crypto
column2: ‚Äù ‚Äì more and more people advice that nowadays. But is it easy to choose the best crypto to invest in? When many options are available
column3: how do you choose between them? Several factors must be considered when deciding which cryptocurrency to invest in. It can be challenging to navigate
column4: given the vast variety of available currencies. To help you find answers to this question
column5: we have put together this guide. Monitoring current market capitalization is one technique to decide which crypto to invest in next. This will not only show which cryptos are ranked the highest right now but also the curve of their value.Keep track of global events that have an impact on cryptocurrency pricing. For instance
column6: Elon Musk‚Äôs purchase of the social media site Twitter affected the price of other cryptocurrencies. Certain events make some cryptocurrencies more volatile than others do. Consider this when you decide ‚Äì it can be both a pro and con. The cryptocurrency‚Äôs utility
column7: or practical value
column8: is an essential element that can significantly affect its value. In simple terms
column9: if a cryptocurrency has more useful functions
column10: it is likely to be more valuable. Conversely
column11: if its use cases decrease
column12: its value is likely to follow suit. Identifying the most promising use cases and those with the most market traction are crucial for making informed investment decisions. A cryptocurrency with a wide range of potential use cases
column13: or those that have gained significant traction in the market
column14: can be a positive sign for the investment portfolio. However
column15: it is worth noting that the regulatory landscape of cryptocurrencies is constantly evolving. New regulations and restrictions can limit the use of cryptocurrencies. Therefore
column16: staying informed about the regulatory environment is crucial for informed investment decisions in the dynamic cryptocurrency market. In summary
column17: understanding the utility of a cryptocurrency is essential when deciding which crypto to invest in. Investing in a crypto with high-quality use cases or the potential for new ones can be a positive sign for your investment portfolio. However
column18: staying up to date with the regulatory environment is equally important in making informed investment decisions in the crypto market. Always check whether the cryptocurrency you are thinking about investing in has a white paper. The coin
column19: its uses
column20: and its goals are covered in detail in the white paper
column21: along with the technology that supports it. This will not only provide you with crucial details about the currency
column22: but also reassure you of its genuineness. Generally

column1: 514::https://theconversation.com/blockchain-is-useful-for-a-lot-more-than-just-bitcoin-58921::The Conversation::article::Blockchain is useful for a lot more than just Bitcoin::While Bitcoin gets all the attention
column2: the blockchain technology it‚Äôs based on could have applications across business and government.::Blockchain technology is not just useful for creating digital currencies such as Bitcoin or developing new financial technologies. Blockchains can be used for a wide variety of applications
column3: such as tracking ownership or the provenance of documents
column4: digital assets
column5: physical assets or voting rights. Blockchain technology was popularised by the Bitcoin digital currency system. But
column6: essentially
column7: a blockchain is just a special kind of database. The Bitcoin blockchain stores cryptographically signed records of financial transfers
column8: but blockchain systems can store any kind of data. Blockchains can also store and run computer code called ‚Äúsmart contracts‚Äù. What makes a blockchain system special is that it doesn‚Äôt run on just one computer like a regular database. Rather
column9: many distributed processing nodes collaborate to run it. There can be a full copy of the database on every node
column10: and the system encourages all those nodes to establish a consensus about its contents. This boosts our confidence in the database and its contents. It‚Äôs difficult
column11: if not impossible
column12: to meddle with the database without others finding out and correcting it. The global consensus among the nodes about the integrity and contents of the distributed database is why it‚Äôs often called a ‚Äúdistributed ledger‚Äù. In our society
column13: we normally rely on trusted third parties
column14: such as lawyers
column15: courts
column16: banks and governments to process and keep authoritative records about commercial transactions. These transactions aren‚Äôt just about financial transfers
column17: but also include the creation or transfer of physical assets
column18: shareholdings
column19: certifications
column20: digital rights
column21: intellectual property or even votes. These third parties are trusted because we rely on them. If they fail or lie
column22: we suffer. We tend to trust the third parties for reasons that are external to the database; lawyers are accredited; votes are counted by independent monitors; and courts run to established laws for matters such as oversight and the possibility of appeal. Blockchains are interesting because the integrity of the contents of the distributed ledger does not rely on any specific individual or organisation. So
column23: rather than relying on trusted third-party organisations to facilitate these commercial transactions
column24: we might instead rely on a trusted blockchain system. This means blockchains give us new opportunities to rethink how parts of our society work. Innovation here might reduce friction in the economy
column25: or create new kinds of services and ways of doing business with each other. Whether or not blockchain systems are trustworthy is an interesting question. The reasons for believing that blockchain systems won‚Äôt fail or lie would be based on our understanding of the underlying software technologies. It also depends on our understanding of market incentives that influence behaviour of the many distributed processing nodes that run blockchains. However
column26: blockchain technologies are still new in the scheme of things
column27: and the community is still discovering their risks
column28: limitations and potential economic and social impact. Because blockchain technology is so new
column29: it‚Äôs difficult to predict exactly how they will end up being used. This is why we at Data61 in CSIRO are exploring new ways blockchains can be used across industries. To understand the economic and societal opportunities presented by blockchain technology
column30: we also need to understand its technological risks and limitations. At Data61
column31: we plan to identify
column32: develop and evaluate some ‚Äúproof of concept‚Äù systems using blockchains to investigate them. A recent UK government report on blockchain technologies provides a good overview and examples of the use of blockchain. One of these is Everledger
column33: a company founded by Australian woman Leanne Kemp. Everledger uses a blockchain to record information about the provenance and ownership of individual diamonds and other valuables. Here
column34: rather than the blockchain recording transfers of digital currency
column35: it records transfers of ownership of identified physical assets. This globally accessible provenance trail could reduce fraud and theft
column36: and enable new or improved kinds of insurance and finance services. The same general idea could be used for any supply chain
column37: such as in retail
column38: agriculture or pharmaceuticals. The drivers for improving assurance of supply chain quality vary in different industries. It could be brand reputation in retail
column39: or safety in pharmaceuticals
column40: or a combination in agriculture. It is worth observing that blockchains don‚Äôt totally do away with the need for trusted third parties. A blockchain is only a digital record
column41: but we need others to determine if those records actually match the corresponding physical assets in the real world. Everledger relies on major diamond certification companies to measure identifying information about individual diamonds. These measurements can be independently cross-checked. But in some sense
column42: companies such as these become trusted third parties for this blockchain-based system. One can imagine the adoption of blockchain technologies creating opportunities for new kinds of trusted third-party organisations. Underlying all of these applications is the need for data integrity
column43: which is the key security property for commercial systems
column44: and the primary property for blockchain technologies. For financial transactions
column45: data integrity means you can‚Äôt spend money you don‚Äôt have
column46: and you can‚Äôt spend money twice. For physical supply chains
column47: this means you can‚Äôt fraudulently acquire record of ownership for an asset. However
column48: other security properties
column49: such as privacy and confidentiality
column50: are also important in many application areas. To achieve confidentiality
column51: other mechanisms such as cryptography must be used in conjunction with the blockchain. Part of our software architecture research at Data61 is to seek to understand how design choices for software-based systems affect tradeoffs for qualities including security (integrity
column52: confidentiality
column53: privacy)
column54: performance (latency
column55: throughput and scalability)
column56: and others. Good design choices can control risks to achieving these qualities
column57: and this is part of what is evaluated in our research using proof-of-concept systems. Computer programs are a special kind of data and so can be stored in a database. That means we can store programs in the distributed ledger of a blockchain system
column58: and execute those programs while later transactions are being processed. In the Ethereum blockchain
column59: these programs can be highly complex. These programs are normally called ‚Äúsmart contracts‚Äù. Smart contracts can carry value
column60: and can conditionally transfer that value according to complex business conditions based on the latest state of the distributed ledger. This means blockchain systems can do more than store information about commercial transactions; they can also process commercial transactions too. This greatly expands the opportunities for using blockchain systems. Although smart contracts are often thought of as standing for self-executing legal contracts
column61: they are written in a general purpose programming language and can be used to implement a wide range of business logic. Can smart contracts actually stand as legal contracts? This is an interesting question. For legal contracts to be enforceable
column62: they need to be understandable by reasonable persons. Can the bytecode of a program stored on a blockchain really be understood by any human? Perhaps only obsessive hobbyists might be able to develop that skill! Another thread of research in Data61 is investigating new ways of representing and analysing smart contracts
column63: using recent results from legal informatics. Blockchain technology is still in its infancy. There are a wide range of plausible future scenarios for their future impact
column64: ranging from efficiency improvements for commercial transactions through to a complete reinvention of the economy. As with any disruptive technology
column65: understanding the plausible
column66: possible and probable impacts ‚Äì the opportunities and risks ‚Äì will be vital for wise policy
column67: strategy
column68: and design choices by Australian governments and companies.::2016-05-09T20:04:28Z::Bitcoin

column1: 517::https://blockworks.co/news/bitcoin-halving-inflation-and-issuance-schedule::Blockworks::article::Why is 2140 the end of bitcoin inflation?::The final Bitcoin halving
column2: where the mining reward becomes smaller than one satoshi
column3: is expected to occur in 2140.::The final Bitcoin halving
column4: where the mining reward becomes smaller than one satoshi
column5: is expected to occur in 2140 Artwork by Crystal Le It‚Äôs well known that the Bitcoin network experiences a halving of supply approximately every four years. Less appreciated is that these are set to continue for over a century into the future. Bitcoin‚Äôs pseudonymous creator Satoshi Nakamoto programmed the year 2140 ‚Äî 30 halvings from now ‚Äî as the year that the block rewards (the subsidy paid to miners for processing transactions into blocks) would drop to less than one satoshi
column6: the smallest unit of bitcoin. The use of the term ‚Äúsatoshi‚Äù ‚Äî equivalent to 100 millionth of a bitcoin (or 0.00000001 BTC) ‚Äî emerged organically among early Bitcoin users and developers
column7: appearing in various forums and discussions starting in 2010 or 2011
column8: and became widely accepted in 2013. Read more: The Bitcoin halving is about a month away ‚Äî here‚Äôs what you can expect The halving is modeled after the physical mining of scarce resources
column9: according to Jameson Lopp
column10: co-founder and chief security officer at Casa. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing special about the year 2140
column11: ‚Äù Lopp told Blockworks. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just how the nature of halvings along with the level of precision of satoshis ended up working out.‚Äù Lopp notes that Nakamoto explained the supply schedule to Mike Hearn
column12: a former Google engineer who became an early Bitcoin contributor
column13: in 2009: ‚ÄúMy choice for the number of coins and distribution schedule was an educated guess
column14: ‚Äù Satoshi wrote. ‚ÄúI wanted to pick something that would make prices similar to existing currencies
column15: but without knowing the future
column16: that‚Äôs very hard.‚Äù Read more: Satoshi warned against labeling bitcoin as an ‚Äòinvestment‚Äô He picked 21 million
column17: but Satoshi added that the divisibility of a bitcoin in practice could be represented differently depending on how valuable one bitcoin gets. ‚ÄúFor example
column18: if 0.001 is worth one euro
column19: then it might be easier to change where the decimal point is displayed
column20: so if you had one bitcoin it‚Äôs now displayed as 1000
column21: and 0.001 is displayed as one.‚Äù For what it‚Äôs worth
column22: 0.001 BTC is worth about 65 euros (approximately $70) today. Why the rate of issuance would decline for 132 years
column23: however
column24: was never explained. ‚ÄúI expect it was more of a ‚Äòbetter safe than sorry‚Äô decision to give the system decades to bootstrap
column25: ‚Äù Lopp said. Unless the price of bitcoin (BTC) doubles every four years
column26: each halving brings less income from block rewards to miners. So to maintain the network‚Äôs hashrate
column27: which is important for Bitcoin‚Äôs security
column28: transaction fees will become more important over time. Whether that will happen in practice remains to be seen
column29: but Lopp is optimistic. ‚ÄúI expect that as we see the multi-layered Bitcoin ecosystem continue to expand
column30: the base chain will start to look more and more like a high-value cryptographic accumulator and it will make economic sense for on-chain transactions to pay relatively high fees
column31: ‚Äù he said. Start your day with top crypto insights from David Canellis and Katherine Ross. Subscribe to the Empire newsletter. The Lightspeed newsletter is all things Solana

column1: 518::https://coinatory.com/cryptocurrency-articles/crypto-lending-crypto-loans-7118/::Coinatory::article::Crypto lending - All you need to know about crypto loans::Looking to learn about crypto lending and how to profit from it? Discover what crypto lending is
column2: how it works
column3: and how you can earn money from it!::Crypto lending is the act of depositing cryptocurrency to be lent to borrowers in exchange for recurrent interest payment. Payments are made in the form of cryptocurrency
column4: which is commonly deposited and compounded every day
column5: every week
column6: or every month. Decentralized and centralized crypto lenders are the two primary categories of crypto lending platforms. Both provide access to high interest rates
column7: often as high as 20% annual percentage yield (APY)
column8: and both typically need depositing collateral in order to get a crypto loan. The opportunity to lend out cryptocurrency and earn interest in the form of cryptocurrency incentives is made available through cryptocurrency lending platforms for investors. In 2020
column9: lending platforms gained popularity
column10: and since then
column11: the total value of loans locked on different platforms has increased to billions. There are two parts to cryptocurrency lending: interest-bearing deposits and loans. Similar to a bank account
column12: deposit accounts have similar functions. The lending platform accepts cryptocurrency deposits from users and pays interest of up to 8% APY (depending on the platform and the cryptocurrency). Deposited money might be used by the platform to make loans to borrowers or for other kinds of investments. In order to borrow money or cryptocurrency
column13: borrowers normally have to deposit at least 100% (and sometimes up to 150%
column14: depending on the lender) in cryptocurrency as collateral. The interest rates differ by platform and require for monthly payments
column15: much like with traditional loans. In contrast to conventional loans
column16: cryptocurrency loans have durations as short as seven days and as long as 180 days
column17: with an hourly interest rate
column18: like Binance. Some lenders
column19: like Nexo
column20: which offers 0% APR
column21: provide an endless line of credit in their place. There are several types of cryptocurrency loans available: Some services provide a cryptocurrency line of credit rather than a standard loan with a defined term length. Users can borrow up to a specific amount of the deposited collateral using this kind of collateralized loan
column22: but there are no specified terms for repayment
column23: and they just pay interest on the money they withdraw. Collateralized loans are the most popular and require deposited cryptocurrency that is used as collateral for the loan. The majority of platforms demand overcollateralization
column24: which limits how much of the deposited collateral borrowers can access (usually below a 90% loan-to-value). The interest rate and the likelihood of having your margin called are both lower the lower the loan-to-value (LTV) ratio. Flash loans are typically available on crypto exchanges and are instant loans that are borrowed and repaid in the same transaction. These are very high-risk loans that are typically used to take advantage of market arbitrage opportunities
column25: such as buying cryptocurrency for a lower price in one market and instantly selling for a higher price in another
column26: all within the same transaction Uncollateralized loans are not as popular
column27: but they function similarly to personal loans. Borrowers must fill out a loan application
column28: pass identity verification
column29: and complete a creditworthiness review to be approved. These loans have a higher risk of loss for lenders because there is no collateral to liquidate in the event of a loan default. Due to the loans‚Äô and deposited funds‚Äô dependence on the constantly erratic cryptocurrency market
column30: lending in the cryptocurrency space is inherently dangerous for both borrowers and lenders. Crypto aficionados are less than thrilled as a result of the recent Celsius fiasco
column31: which resulted in the overnight freezing of billions of dollars in deposits. Here are a few of the risks of crypto lending: Though some crypto loans offer low rates
column32: most crypto loans charge over 5% APR
column33: with some charging up to 13% APR (or more). Crypto assets often become unaccessible and illiquid when they are deposited onto crypto loan services. While some cryptocurrency lending services permit lenders to access deposited funds reasonably quickly
column34: others may necessitate a protracted waiting period. A decrease in the value of the deposited collateral might result in a margin call when customers pledge collateral and borrow against it. When the LTV of a cryptocurrency loan falls below the agreed-upon rate
column35: this occurs. When this occurs
column36: borrowers have two options: they can either add more collateral to bring the LTV back down or they can risk liquidation. Platforms for crypto lending are unregulated and do not provide the same level of protection that banks do. For instance
column37: user money up to that amount are safeguarded in the event that a bank goes bankrupt since U.S. bank deposits are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) for up to $250
column38: 000 per depositor. There are no user protections for cryptocurrency lending platforms that have solvency problems
column39: and money may be lost. Users must register for a centralized lending platform (like BlockFi) or link a digital wallet to a decentralized lending platform in order to submit an application for a cryptocurrency loan (such as Aave). Users will next choose the type of loan and the desired loan amount before choosing the collateral to deposit. The amount that is available will change depending on the collateral and deposit. The borrowed cash will quickly move to the user‚Äôs account or digital wallet after the user deposits the collateral into the platform‚Äôs digital wallet. The majority of loans give quick approval
column40: and smart contracts are used to lock in loan conditions. Users must register for a lending platform
column41: choose a supported cryptocurrency to deposit
column42: then pay money to the platform in order to become a crypto lender. Interest can be paid in kind or with the native platform token on a centralized crypto lending platform. Interest is paid out in kind on a decentralized exchange
column43: but there may also be bonus payments. Lending cryptocurrency is a double-edged sword. On the one hand
column44: the majority of loans are secured by collateral
column45: so even in the case of a default
column46: lenders can recover their losses through liquidation. In comparison to conventional bank accounts
column47: they also offer deposits at substantially greater interest rates. On the other hand
column48: there are no legal safeguards for investors
column49: giving lending companies the authority to arbitrarily lock consumers‚Äô funds in place
column50: as Celsius has done. Borrowers run the danger of collateral losing value and having to be liquidated
column51: which would result in a substantially smaller return on their investment. Regulators from all around the world are focusing on lending platforms; rules are emerging around deposit accounts
column52: and the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) even fined BlockFi $100 million for breaking securities laws. Ultimately
column53: crypto lending can be secure for careful users
column54: but both borrowers and investors face significant dangers. A platform that provides lending and borrowing services that are controlled by smart contracts is known as decentralized finance (DeFi) lending. Decentralized apps (dApps) enable customers to link a digital wallet
column55: deposit collateral
column56: and instantly access funds. DeFi loans are instantaneous. DeFi lending enables customers to deposit cryptocurrency using a digital wallet and begin earning interest right away
column57: with the interest often compounding every minute. The majority of DeFi lending platforms mandate overcollateralization
column58: requiring deposits of at least 110% of the loan amount. The deposit of collateral receives income even when it is tied to a loan
column59: which is how DeFi differs from centralized systems. Users can earn a large amount of interest on their crypto deposits when they make them on a lending platform
column60: often more than they can at regular banks. The money that is deposited is loaned to borrowers who cover a portion of the interest
column61: and it can also be invested in other ways to increase yield. Coinatory is a news portal dedicated to providing the latest updates on cryptocurrency

column1: 520::https://theconversation.com/centrelink-data-matching-problems-show-the-need-for-a-government-blockchain-71156::The Conversation::article::Centrelink data-matching problems show the need for a government blockchain::The problems with Centrelink‚Äôs data-matching system stem from reconciling datasets held by different agencies. What if we used a blockchain to create a single source of data?::Governments across the globe are experimenting with the blockchain
column2: the technology behind Bitcoin
column3: as a way to reduce costs and provide more accountability to the public. In Europe alone
column4: the United Kingdom
column5: Ukraine and Estonia are experimenting with blockchains to fight corruption and deliver public services. Australia
column6: too
column7: is looking at what a blockchain might achieve. The recent problems with Centrelink‚Äôs automated data-matching system show precisely where a government blockchain would fit in. Rather than siloing our data in government agencies
column8: we could create a single source of information. This would speed up our interactions with government
column9: while reducing errors and fraud. The blockchain is a kind of public database
column10: one stored simultaneously on a bunch of different computers. When a new transaction occurs it is verified (otherwise known as ‚Äúmining‚Äù or ‚Äúconsensus‚Äù)
column11: encrypted and added to the database. The most famous example of the blockchain is Bitcoin
column12: a crypto-currency built upon the blockchain. However
column13: the blockchain is suitable for many other applications
column14: not just financial transactions. For example
column15: the blockchain could be used to authenticate that a diamond has not come from an illict source
column16: or for buying and selling property. For the government‚Äôs purposes
column17: the killer feature of the blockchain is that it is a way to record transactions so that they are transparent and cannot be altered or tampered with. When used to track fish through a supply chain
column18: for instance
column19: it allows customers and restaurants to follow where the fish has been and have confidence in the data. When applied to a government context
column20: these capabilities could be useful for collecting tax
column21: delivering benefits
column22: or regulating business. From the public‚Äôs point of view
column23: this could enable us to track government spending
column24: eliminate fraudulent transactions
column25: reduce errors in data processing and speed up service delivery to almost real time. It could be useful almost anywhere records are kept. All the while the public could be more confident about the accuracy and integrity of the data being held. The Australian government makes benefit payments and provides support services through Medicare
column26: Centrelink and Child Support services. It also collects information through numerous other agencies
column27: such as the Australian Tax Office. A government blockchain could record the transactions about a citizen and link together information about health
column28: welfare and child support. The information would be entered only once into the blockchain by any one of these agencies. There would be no need for the data to be re-entered or matched again. Thus errors that occur in data processing as information is passed on down the line will be eliminated
column29: avoiding some of the issues with the current Centrelink system. Further
column30: once data is entered it cannot be altered or changed in any way without proper authentication. Any authorised officer within the government could then access the information in the blockchain
column31: avoiding a paper-pushing exercise between government departments. All of your data would be in one place. We could go even further
column32: as the blockchain would also allow other services to be processed through an app
column33: as the UK is trialling with welfare payments. The overall cost savings
column34: reduction in bureaucracy and increased responsiveness to helping people in need could be immense. All we need is the government to invest in its own blockchain. The essence of a blockchain is to reduce the reliance on centralised systems (such as the government)
column35: replacing it with a system with inherent accountability
column36: transparency and trust. The original blockchain concept achieved this by being open
column37: like the internet (also known as unpermissioned)
column38: relying on independent
column39: anonymous ‚Äúminers‚Äù to validate transactions. This guarantees the integrity of the data as no-one knows who the miners are to bribe or bully them into underhanded actions. However
column40: some might view a government-run
column41: ‚Äúpermissioned‚Äù blockchain with suspicion. The trust of the public would need to be gained. A government blockchain would not be open
column42: and we would have to rely on the government to approve all of the transactions. This negates some of the benefit offered by a blockchain. The legitimacy and trust would have to come from the government itself. Thus a government-run blockchain would not be without its challenges. But if an Australian government blockchain is developed and allowed to succeed
column43: then the potential benefits could be enormous. Society as we know it will be disrupted!::2017-01-13T05:07:21Z::Blockchain

column1: 521::https://www.coindesk.com/markets/2024/05/16/ether-bitcoin-ratio-slides-to-lowest-since-april-2021-heres-why/::CoinDesk::article::Ether-Bitcoin Ratio Slides to Lowest Since April 2021. Here's Why::"Ether is a 'lightning rod' for negative sentiment from crypto native and external players and has several weak spots
column2: one observer said.::The ratio between ether (ETH) and bitcoin‚Äôs (BTC) dollar-denominated prices continues to slide, extending year-to-date losses as suggested by the bearish death cross pattern a month ago. ETH/BTC slipped to 0.04563 on crypto exchange Binance soon before press time, reaching the lowest since April 2021, according to charting platform TradingView. This year, the ratio has declined nearly 16%, indicating a bias for bitcoin or the leading cryptocurrency by market value. The slide to three-year lows follows reduced demand for exchange-traded products (ETPs) tied to ether. According to Bloomberg data quoted by ETC Group in its weekly report, global ether ETPs registered net outflows of around $63.5 million last week, with Hong Kong-listed exchange-traded funds (ETFs) losing the most. Meanwhile, bitcoin ETPs raked in $92.5 million last week. Several factors, including competing layer 1s and lingering uncertainty about the debut of spot ETH approvals in the U.S, are likely responsible for ETH falling out of investor favor. ‚ÄúThe approval of spot bitcoin ETFs in the U.S. has reinforced bitcoin‚Äôs store-of-value narrative and its status as a macro asset. On the other hand, open questions about ETH‚Äôs fundamental positioning within the crypto sector remain. Competing layer-1s (L1s) like Solana detract from Ethereum‚Äôs positioning as the 'go-to' network for decentralized app (dApp) deployment,‚Äù Coinbase Institutional‚Äôs Research analyst David Han said in a note Wednesday. Solana‚Äôs share in total decentralized exchange volumes has grown tenfold from 2% to 21% in one year, eating into Ethereum's market share. The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) green-lighted nearly a dozen spot BTC ETFs in January. Since then, these funds have drawn roughly $12 billion in net inflows, according to data source Farside Investors. Approval of spot ETFs tied to ether will open a similar pool of capital for Ethereum‚Äôs native token, although it‚Äôs unclear when the SEC will approve it. Traders on decentralized betting platform Polymarket see just a 10% chance of the SEC approving a spot ETF on or before May 31. The regulator has until May 23 to decide whether to approve or reject VanEck‚Äôs application to launch a spot Ethereum ETF. The deadline for BlackRock‚Äôs application is June 23. According to finance lawyer Scott Johnsson, the SEC is looking for reasons to deny ETH ETF applications by BlackRock and others on grounds that they have been improperly filed as commodity-based trust shares and do not qualify if they hold a security. Ilan Solot, co-head of digital assets at Marex Solutions, said ether is a lightning rod" for negative sentiment from crypto native and external players and has several weak spots. ‚ÄúCapital gets fragmented. There are proportionally greater numbers of ways to get exposure to the ecosystem through the many Layer 2s tokens (OP
column3: ARB‚Ä¶) and native protocol tokens in each one. The capital gets fragmented
column4: Solot said in an email. Solot added that strong anti-ETH sentiment from [rival] Solana community and Bitcoin propounders is driving negative ether narratives and the high beta cryptocurrency is a perfect vehicle" for external players to express bearish view given it trades on traditional exchanges such as the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Lastly
column5: Ether recently turned inflationary
column6: reversing the bullish deflationary supply trend seen consistently since its parent network Ethereum transitioned to a proof-of-stake consensus ecosystem in September 2022. Edited by Parikshit Mishra. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy

column2: political
column3: and technological factors that can affect it.::Bitcoin (BTC) is a cryptocurrency that Satoshi Nakamoto
column4: its unidentified creator
column5: created in 2009. A blockchain keeps track of all transactions
column6: displaying each unit‚Äôs transaction history and demonstrating ownership. Bitcoin is not backed by a government or issued by a central bank like conventional currencies are. Because Bitcoin is not a corporation
column7: investing in it differs from investing in stocks or bonds. As a result
column8: there are no corporate balance sheets
column9: Form 10-Ks
column10: fund results
column11: or other conventional tools for selecting an investment to analyze. Learn about the factors that influence the price of bitcoin to justify better your decision to invest in it. The monetary policy instruments
column12: inflation rates
column13: and economic growth measurements that generally affect the value of a currency do not apply to Bitcoin because it is neither issued by a central bank nor backed by a government. Bitcoin acts as more of a commodity being used to store value
column14: so the following factors influence its price: The supply of an asset is a key factor in setting its price. An asset in high demand is more likely to have high pricing than one in a large supply
column15: which will have low prices. Since there will only be 21 million manufactured and only a certain number made year
column16: the supply of Bitcoin is typically well publicized. Its protocol only permits the creation of new Bitcoin at a fixed rate
column17: which is intended to decrease over time. Bitcoin‚Äôs future supply is
column18: therefore
column19: dwindling
column20: which adds to demand. This is similar to a reduction in corn supply if harvests were to be reduced every four years until no more was harvested
column21: and it was publicly advertised that this would happen‚Äîcorn prices would skyrocket. Both regular people and big investors are starting to like bitcoin more because it‚Äôs getting a lot of attention in the news
column22: from people who give investment advice
column23: and from business owners who say bitcoin is valuable now and will be in the future. Countries like Venezuela
column24: where money is losing its value fast
column25: also like bitcoin a lot. People who need to move large amounts of money secretly or for illegal reasons also prefer it. This means that more people want bitcoin
column26: but there won‚Äôt be as much available in the future
column27: which has made its price go up. However
column28: the price of bitcoin still goes up and down a lot. For example
column30: its price went up a lot
column31: then it fell and stayed low for a while
column32: and then in 2021
column33: it quickly went up and down again. Similar to other commodities
column34: production costs are a major factor in setting the price of bitcoin. Research suggests that the price of bitcoin in cryptocurrency marketplaces is closely correlated with its marginal cost of production. The production cost for Bitcoin is essentially the sum of the direct fixed expenses for the infrastructure and electricity needed to mine the cryptocurrency and an indirect cost associated with the algorithm‚Äôs degree of difficulty. A network of miners competes to decipher an encrypted number in order to mine bitcoins. The first miner to accomplish so receives a reward of newly created bitcoins as well as any transaction fees earned since the last block was located. It takes a lot of processing power to use brute force to solve the hash in order to unlock a block and receive a reward. The miner will have to spend a lot of money on numerous pricey mining equipment. Also
column35: the bitcoin mining process uses a lot of electricity. According to estimates
column36: the bitcoin mining network consumes more electricity than certain small nations. Despite the fact that Bitcoin is the most well-known cryptocurrency
column37: there are hundreds of other tokens competing for capital. By 2022
column38: Bitcoin will control the majority of cryptocurrency marketplaces. But with time
column39: its power has diminished. Almost 80% of the total market capitalization of cryptocurrencies in 2017 was made up of Bitcoin. The proportion fell to less than 50% by 2022. The fundamental cause of this was growing acceptance of alternative currency and their potential. For instance
column40: due to a rise in decentralized finance
column41: Ethereum has become a fierce rival to Bitcoin (DeFi). Ether (ETH)
column42: the cryptocurrency that serves as ‚Äúgas‚Äù for transactions on its network
column43: has attracted investment from investors who see its potential for redesigning the rails of contemporary financial infrastructure. The popularity of other cryptocurrencies has increased as they are continually being introduced. Other coins like Tether
column44: Ethereum
column45: BNB
column47: and Solana are reducing the market share of Bitcoin. Competition has drawn investors to Bitcoin even as they have taken some of their dollars from the ecosystem. As a result
column48: there is now more demand for and knowledge about cryptocurrencies. Bitcoin has profited from the attention as a type of standard-bearer for the cryptocurrency ecosystem
column49: and its prices have stayed high. Bitcoin came out after a financial crisis caused by weak rules in the trading of complex financial products. The world of cryptocurrencies is known for not having many rules and being open across countries because it‚Äôs not regulated yet. The fact that Bitcoin doesn‚Äôt have strict rules has its good and bad sides. It can be used anywhere in the world without the usual government restrictions. However
column50: governments and other groups are still trying to figure out how to regulate cryptocurrencies. There‚Äôs a chance that new rules are coming
column51: but it‚Äôs not clear how they will affect Bitcoin‚Äôs price. For example
column52: decisions by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) can influence Bitcoin‚Äôs value. When the SEC approved the first U.S. bitcoin-related ETF

column60: as it tries to keep investors and others interested. When anything changes with things that affect Bitcoin‚Äôs price

column62: good news usually makes Bitcoin‚Äôs price go up

column1: 526::https://theconversation.com/how-blockchain-will-transform-our-cities-69561::The Conversation::article::How blockchain will transform our cities::If you think the internet has changed your life
column2: brace yourself for the next digital innovation that‚Äôs set to transform our world.::Many trends on the horizon offer opportunities that could transform our cities. From self-driving vehicles and the sharing economy through to cloud computing and blockchain technologies
column3: each of these trends is quite significant on its own. But the convergence of their disruptive forces is what will create real value and drive innovations. Take blockchain and the sharing economy as an example. Bringing these two forces together can potentially disrupt established companies like Uber and Airbnb. The success of these companies is largely due to their ability to make use of existing assets people owned
column4: that had been paid for
column5: but from which new value could be derived. Effectively
column6: these companies set up digital platforms that harnessed ‚Äúexcess capacity‚Äù and relied on other people to deliver the services. The same applies to other so-called ‚Äúsharing economy‚Äù companies that merely act as service aggregators and collect a cut off the top. In the process
column7: they gather valuable data for further commercial gain. But can this business model be challenged and enhanced for the benefit of those who are delivering the service and creating the real value? Can technology be used to bypass the third party and allow direct peer-to-peer collaboration within a distributed governance structure? What could a ‚Äúpeer-owned‚Äù and ‚Äúpeer-run‚Äù marketplace look like? Blockchain technology could just be the answer. You can think of blockchain as the second generation of the internet ‚Äì a transformation from an internet of information to an internet of value. Blockchain allows suppliers and consumers ‚Äì even competitors ‚Äì to share a decentralised digital ledger across a network of computers without the need for a central authority. The assets that can be described on the blockchain can be financial
column8: legal
column9: physical or electronic. No single party has the power to tamper with the records ‚Äì sophisticated algorithms keep everyone honest by ensuring data integrity and authentication of transactions. But the impacts of blockchain go well beyond financial services and transactions. Its real value is in establishing trust-based interactions and accelerating the transfer of governance from centralised institutions to distributed networks of peer-to-peer collaboration. The impact can be profound: a centralised institution acting as intermediatory in a transaction of value is now at risk of being disrupted because the same service can be provided on the blockchain through peer-to-peer interaction. Blockchain gives service providers a means to collaborate and derive a greater share of the value for themselves. Smart agents on a blockchain could do just about everything provided by a service aggregator. The technology‚Äôs trust protocol allows autonomous associations to be formed and controlled by the same people who are creating the value. All revenues for services
column10: minus overheads
column11: would go to members
column12: who also control the platform and make decisions. Trust is not established by third parties
column13: but rather through an encrypted consensus enabled by smart coding. We already have examples of this technology in action. Arcade City
column14: a global community of peer-to-peer services
column15: is planning to offer a ride-sharing service on the blockchain. To catch a ride
column16: the user buys digital currency (known as tokens)
column17: creates an offer and commits funds for the ride. A driver claims the offer
column18: matches the funds to signal their commitment to provide the service
column19: and picks up the passenger. The blockchain releases the funds as soon as the user acknowledges completing the ride. Arcade City has a city council
column20: which will overlook the system for three years until it is fully decentralised and up and running. The same concept of using distributed public record technology can be applied to a wide range of urban applications. For example
column21: an energy startup in Perth is looking to trial a peer-to-peer technology solution that would allow consumers to offer excess energy
column22: available through their solar panels
column23: on the blockchain. Clever code matches the suppliers with consumers without the need to go through the energy provider. The blockchain technology and ecosystem around it are evolving rapidly
column24: and are probably raising more questions than answers. How do we establish a system of transparent governance to ensure the longevity of the blockchain? What about security
column25: speed
column26: cost and
column27: more importantly
column28: regulations? As with other disruptive technologies
column29: there will be winners and losers. If the technology is successfully managed for scalable growth
column30: it could very well disrupt established norms and transform our societies. Large layers of data generated by consumers today
column31: which are controlled by hubs
column32: can become public. In a world driven by blockchain
column33: consumers can monetise their own data to derive greater value. By knowing when and how to take advantage of this technology
column34: we have an opportunity to transform the digital platforms for tomorrow‚Äôs cities. The blockchain becomes the city‚Äôs operating system
column35: invisible yet ubiquitous
column36: improving citizens‚Äô access to services
column37: goods and economic opportunities. Today
column38: the technology is yet to mature. It remains to be seen if the expectations can live up to reality. But
column39: in many ways
column40: this is quite reminiscent of the internet in the mid-1990s. Not many people would have predicted its significance back then. Had we understood the impacts of the internet 20 years ago
column41: what could we have done differently to create more value? That is where we stand today with blockchain. The power of this transformation will become more compelling as the hype settles down and we begin to unleash the possibilities.::2016-12-13T19:04:57Z::Blockchain

column55: right? And they‚Äôre just now coming to the public in early access or open beta. But I'd argue there are a handful of really good games out there that I'm excited to play. There‚Äôs MetalCore
column56: the mech shooter. There's Wildcard
column57: the card-battler game by the husband and wife team that did Words with Friends. I like Dead Drop. I like Off the Grid
column58: which has art direction by Neill Blomkamp. I fucking love Neill Blomkamp. So the short version is there are a handful of games that actually are going to be really good and break through
column59: and then of course there‚Äôs Shrapnel. Fair enough! There are some good games. But those seem to be the outliers. I think part of your lament for the earlier Web3 games is because of two reasons: A lot of the teams are not game development teams
column60: they're crypto development teams. Right? And two
column61: it‚Äôs production values. They haven‚Äôt had the money to put into the game to make it really great. What‚Äôs extra challenging about building a Web3 game
column62: compared to a traditional video game? What are the additional wrinkles caused by decentralization? Great question. I want to start by saying that it‚Äôs very important that it‚Äôs a great game
column63: period
column64: whether for Web2 or Web3. It‚Äôs easy to lose track of that. But to answer your question
column65: one simple thing comes to mind. Think about working on a database in a game. Think about
column66: for example
column67: all the items I can collect for my character ‚Äî my gear
column68: my helmet
column69: my weapon
column70: all that stuff. You have a pretty complex database and it has to provide for all this attribution. If I make a mistake in normal development
column71: you just reset the database and then start over again. But here with web3
column72: that has real-world value. Right? So if we fuck up and I delete your $1
column73: 000 worth of stuff
column74: I can't claim that I'm World of Warcraft and you never really owned it anyway. That‚Äôs a huge problem. So we have to be especially meticulous as we integrate any Web3 component. Then there‚Äôs the problem of potential exploits ‚Äî things that we miss could create a disaster for the economy. It takes longer to integrate the Web3 component. The code has to be audited at a level that game code never normally needs to be audited. That was all brand new to us. It slows down our roadmap. But as we get better at it and there‚Äôs more tooling APIs and SDKs available
column75: it will just get better and better. For many who are only casually following the Web3 gaming space
column76: they‚Äôve heard of the boom-and-bust cycle of ‚ÄúPlay to Earn.‚Äù There are concerns that this model is not sustainable ‚Äî it only works when the token price is rising
column77: but then
column79: the economy collapses. What‚Äôs the solve for this? What‚Äôs the trick for making Web3 games viable for the long-term
column80: and not relying upon price appreciation? So I would probably guess that for the economies that you‚Äôre thinking about that collapsed
column81: they‚Äôre kind of pyramid economies where you have to have a large number inflowing at the bottom
column82: and they grind and level-up assets or characters that then get sold to the person above them who‚Äôs also grinding. You need lots coming in at the bottom to do that. And then when the community collapses or the token price collapses
column83: nobody's playing because it's a fun game ‚Äî they‚Äôre there to make money off it. So they abandon it. Ah
column84: so the trick is the game quality itself‚Ä¶ What we think will happen in game economies like Shrapnel is the more players you have
column85: and the more engagement you have
column86: the more they‚Äôre using the token in-game. That‚Äôs driving the need for the token and it kind of has a burn effect. It‚Äôs consuming the supply
column87: and that means there's more buy pressure than sell pressure. If I hear you right
column88: it sounds like you‚Äôre saying there needs to be actual legit utility in these tokens. It‚Äôs not sham utility. People are using it. They're using it because they want to play the game and have fun. So the game needs to be good
column89: period. Am I getting that right? Yeah. Let's just use a rough order of magnitude example. The average paying player in Web3 might be $100 a month versus $10 a month on Web2. So every one of those new Web3 players adds $100 of consumption. Remember
column90: the economy is in the token
column91: so they are spending $100 of the token. Okay
column92: last couple of questions are about Consensus itself. What‚Äôs your favorite Consensus memory? Well
column93: you know
column94: last year we demoed the game for the first time at Consensus. We were right at one of the main entrances
column95: and by the end of the first day
column96: they had just moved the bar to our space because so many people wanted to play the game
column97: and were excited to get their hands on it. What are you most looking forward to at Consensus this year? It‚Äôs a really well-curated conference. I would call it a scholarly conference
column98: where the panels are well-vetted. Love it
column99: and thank you. On a less scholarly front
column100: what‚Äôs the best Consensus side-party? It'll be ours. Good answer. See you there! Edited by Benjamin Schiller. Disclosure Please note that our privacy policy
