605::https://beincrypto.com/bitcoin-onchain-activity-decline/::BeInCrypto::article::Runes Protocol Slowdown Coincides with Bitcoin On-Chain Activity Slump::Bitcoin's on-chain activity has plummeted to its lowest level since 2019, indicating a significant downturn in trader engagement.::We use cookies to improve your experience.  Bitcoin (BTC) kicked off the new year with a robust surge, breaching the $70,000 mark and witnessing significant engagement on its blockchain network. However, recent developments indicate a cooling trend in these metrics. Over the past two months, the price of the leading digital asset has faced challenges, and on-chain activity has declined. Data from blockchain analytics firm Santiment indicates that Bitcoin‚Äôs on-chain activity has reached its lowest point since 2019. This decline suggests diminishing interest among traders, contrasting starkly with the earlier fervor. The firm suggested that the slump may mirror market participants‚Äô broader sentiment of fear and uncertainty. This sentiment aligns with historical patterns, as transaction decreases often coincide with market volatility periods. Notably, BTC‚Äôs price has fallen by more than 11% during the past month to $61,205 as of press time. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt necessarily a sign of more BTC dips, but rather a signal of crowd fear and indecision,‚Äù Santiment analysts wrote. Read more: 8 Best On-Chain Analysis Tools in 2024 Meanwhile, some market observers pointed out that the dwindling on-chain activity coincides with the slowdown in Runes Protocol transactions after its initial surge. The protocol‚Äôs launch on BTC halving day triggered record transaction fees and volumes for the blockchain network. Despite this promising start, recent data suggests a noticeable decline in user engagement and transaction volumes. ‚ÄúAfter [Runes Protocol generated] a staggering $135 million in fees the first week, only 2 out of the last 12 days exceeded $1 million ‚Äì with May 10th seeing the lowest activity,‚Äù crypto analyst Budhil Vyas said. Furthermore, the enthusiasm surrounding spot Bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs) seems to be fading. CoinShares data reveals a notable slowdown in trading volume for spot Bitcoin ETFs. Over the past month, several funds have experienced outflows and days of no inflows. Amidst the sluggishness in the ecosystem, two long-dormant Bitcoin addresses, originating from Satoshi Nakamoto‚Äôs early days, recently sprung back to life. According to blockchain analysis platform ‚Äì Lookonchain, these wallets, inactive for approximately 11 years, transferred their entire holdings of 1,000 BTC, currently valued at a staggering $60.9 million. The wallets‚Äîlabeled ‚Äú16vRqA‚Äù and ‚Äú1DUJuH‚Äù‚Äî had received initial deposits of 500 BTC each in September 2013 when Bitcoin was valued at a modest $124 per coin. Read more: Satoshi Nakamoto ‚Äì Who is the Founder of Bitcoin? Today, these addresses have seen a remarkable surge in value, boasting an astronomical profit margin of nearly 50,000%. column1: 608::https://www.coindesk.com/policy/2024/05/14/tornado-cash-developer-alexey-pertsev-found-guilty-of-money-laundering/::CoinDesk::article::Tornado Cash Developer Alexey Pertsev Found Guilty
column2: Sentenced to 64 Months in Prison by Dutch Court::Alexey Pertsev was first jailed in the Netherlands in August 2022.::Tornado Cash developer Alexey Pertsev has been found guilty of money laundering by a Dutch judge at s-Hertogenbosch court on Tuesday. Pertsev has been given 64 months of prison time by the court. The 31-year old Russian was escorted after the session by police to the cells under the court. This is where he will remain until the public prosecutor finds a prison in the Netherlands that is appropriate for his crimes. "Tornado Cash does not pose any barrier for people with criminal assets who want to launder them
column3: according to the translated verdict seen by CoinDesk. That is why the court regards the defendant guilty of the money laundering activities as charged." Pertsev can appeal his sentence
column4: which starts today. It does not appear that the time he spent behind bars between his arrest in August 2022 and Tuesday's verdict will count against the time he now has to spend in prison. An indictment shared ahead of the trial said that between July 9
column5: 2019 and Aug. 10
column7: Pertsev made "a habit of committing money laundering" and that he should have at least suspected the criminal origins of illicit transactions on the Tornado Cash platform. The developer was first jailed in the Netherlands in August 2022 after Tornado Cash was blacklisted by the U.S government. At the time
column8: the U.S. Treasury had alleged that Tornado Cash was a key tool for the North Korean hacking group Lazarus. The Lazarus Group has been tied to a $625 million hack of Axie Infinity‚Äôs Ronin Network and other major crypto thefts. The trial result could play in future trials of other Tornado Cash developers. Other developers of the crypto mixer
column9: Roman Storm and Roman Semenov
column10: also face allegations of money laundering and sanctions violations in the U.S. Storm will go to trial this September
column11: but Semenov has not yet been arrested. Storm was arrested last year
column12: after the U.S. again added Tornado Cash to its sanctions watchlist. In the U.S.
column13: however
column14: Storm is not accused of being responsible for the laundering of $1.2 billion due to differences in how U.S. and Dutch laws address personal responsibility in this type of alleged crime. UPDATE (May 14

column1: 611::https://blockworks.co/news/trade-finance-might-not-be-sexy-but-its-blockchains-key-to-success::Blockworks::article::Trade finance might not be sexy
column2: but it‚Äôs blockchain‚Äôs key to success::Opinion: Dune‚Äôs Arrakis Freman and Shogun‚Äôs bustling markets of feudal Japan would have benefited from blockchain to solve their trading woes.::Dune‚Äôs Arrakis Freman and Shogun‚Äôs bustling markets of feudal Japan would have benefited from blockchain to solve their trading woes Midjourney modified by Blockworks In the sands of Arrakis and the bustling markets of feudal Japan
column3: trade is the lifeblood of society. Just as the characters in Dune and Shogun navigated intricate webs of alliances and commerce
column4: businesses face similar challenges in today‚Äôs complicated global trade landscape. Yet
column5: as supply chains become increasingly complex
column6: it‚Äôs blockchain technology that is up to the task of revolutionizing and modernizing trade finance
column7: offering a transformative solution to the persistent trade finance gap. While trade may sound like a complex conversation
column8: two recent releases covering the subject have drawn massive audiences. Dune: Part Two has generated over $490 million at the box office
column9: and Shogun garnered 9 million streaming views globally to become the best worldwide debut to date for a Disney General Entertainment scripted series. Today in the real world
column10: trade also stretches across the globe
column11: creating challenges for micro
column12: small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) who need funding to support their operations. The recent rise in interest rates and the tightening of credit has led to more difficulty in managing capital demands ‚Äî squeezing businesses on both sides of their ledger with higher costs to produce and higher costs to borrow. Current financial institutions are unable to adequately respond to these demands on their own
column13: especially in regions that lack adequate banking. Clearly
column14: the traditional banking system has not caught up with the needs of the global supply chain. Enter blockchain. Blockchain offers financial institutions the ability to leverage distributed ledger technology and digital asset solutions to meet the excessive demand for capital with sufficient supply. For that reason
column15: the most prevalent and impactful use case for blockchain will be in the trade finance industry. The $5 trillion trade finance gap represents the collective difference in the demand for capital and the supply of capital for global shipments
column16: obstructing the flow of funds to where it‚Äôs needed most ‚Äî MSMEs. Mirroring the struggles of those small traders in Shogun‚Äôs ancient markets
column17: MSMEs find themselves at a disadvantage due to inefficiencies
column18: lack of visibility and centralized systems that hinder their access to funding. Blockchain
column19: as a decentralized and transparent ledger
column20: emerges as a powerful tool to address the shortcomings of traditional trade finance. It‚Äôs clear that the most prevalent and impactful use case for the technology will be in the trade finance industry. Blockchain creates new opportunities ‚Äî for suppliers
column21: buyers
column22: banks and non-bank originators ‚Äî and new rails to conduct commerce in real time
column23: all the while carrying immutable data
column24: records
column25: capital and digital representations of real world assets. As governments around the world recognize this potential
column26: blockchain‚Äôs role in global trade will become increasingly indispensable. We are seeing this already with the United Nations‚Äô Model Law on Electronic Transferable Records (MLETR)
column27: which allows for transferable documents and instruments in electronic form
column28: and other regulatory advancements in Europe
column29: Asia
column30: the Middle East
column31: Africa and South America. Unlike in Dune‚Äôs Arrakis and Shogun‚Äôs shores of feudal Japan
column32: our modern trade networks can flourish and help solve suppliers‚Äô growing demands
column33: even easing pandemic-era disruptions. Blockchain also offers the greatest opportunity for MSMEs
column34: originators and investors ‚Äî who have been in the global supply chain trenches ‚Äî to rise above outdated models and create a new vibrant ecosystem for businesses. And when user-friendly interfaces are more widespread
column35: blockchain‚Äôs momentum will really be unstoppable. Read more from our opinion section: Blockchain really is better than middlemen With these opportunities
column36: one would think people across the blockchain and crypto spaces would embrace its power to create new rails for businesses to build on and economies to scale. But there seems to be a real misunderstanding of what blockchain‚Äôs opportunity holds. Or perhaps there is a lack of understanding of trade finance and its value proposition. By contrast
column37: investing in the hottest dog memecoin is an easy proposition to understand. This is the conundrum of blockchain. Users want the excitement of a fervent market over the slower path toward trade finance adoption. The route is more challenging for protocols to gain traction with those in the space who don‚Äôt understand blockchain‚Äôs trade finance value proposition. This limiting spirit won‚Äôt solve the problem of how to fund MSMEs across the globe and
column38: in turn
column39: feed value back to blockchain networks. In the end
column40: our ethos should be rooted in this question: How do we create a more egalitarian way to help all boats rise
column41: to ensure everyone succeeds? We do it by making blockchain more accessible to more people. Everyone will win ‚Äî those who want to own a memecoin and those who want to create a better way for businesses across the globe to grow and prosper. Or even those who want both. column1: 614::https://theconversation.com/behind-the-crypto-hype-is-an-ideology-of-social-change-177981::The Conversation::article::Behind the crypto hype is an ideology of social change::Many people promoting cryptocurrencies are looking for something bigger than the future of financial transactions. They‚Äôre aiming to break free of governments and corporations.::Ads for blockchain
column2: NFTs and cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin seem to be everywhere. Crypto technologies are being promoted as a replacement for banks; a new way to buy art; the next big investment opportunity
column3: and an essential part of the metaverse. To many
column4: these technologies are confusing or risky. But enthusiasts ardently promote them. As a cybersecurity and social media researcher
column5: I‚Äôve found that behind the hype is an ideology about social change: Hardcore enthusiasts argue that crypto will get people to trust in technology rather than government
column6: which they see as inherently untrustworthy. This ideology leads people to encourage its use while downplaying its risks. My colleagues and I studied almost three months of discussions on Reddit forums about cryptocurrencies to try to understand how people talk about crypto and Bitcoin. The loudest voices on the forum were a group of crypto enthusiasts who called themselves ‚ÄúTrue Bitcoiners.‚Äù Unlike technology enthusiasts or crypto marketers
column7: ‚Äútrue bitcoiners‚Äù didn‚Äôt talk about technology
column8: or about their own use of crypto. Instead
column9: they talked about trust and corruption. These crypto enthusiasts often cite examples of what they see as government corruption and corporate corruption. They recognize that society depends on governments and corporations setting and enforcing rules
column10: and they complain that people are stuck with these ‚Äúcorrupt‚Äù institutions. Corruption
column11: they say
column12: is an inevitable flaw in humanity and leads to trying to control and mistreat others. The enthusiasts see Bitcoin
column13: blockchain and other crypto technologies as providing an alternative to the corruption. They argue that these new technologies are ‚Äútrustless‚Äù and don‚Äôt depend on institutions. You can buy and sell things using bitcoin without checking with a bank or using government-issued cash. These two beliefs ‚Äì that governments are corrupt and that crypto avoids that corruption ‚Äì are common among the crypto enthusiasts we studied. But enthusiasts go one step further. They seek change. They want to change who has power and who doesn‚Äôt. They argue that crypto is how that change will happen. For crypto enthusiasts
column14: using crypto isn‚Äôt just a way to buy and sell things. By using crypto technologies
column15: they argue
column16: society will become less dependent on governments and corporations. That is
column17: using crypto ‚Äì and getting as many people as possible to use it as much as possible ‚Äì is a way to change the world and take power away from governments. These beliefs about who should and should not have power in society embody an ideology. An important part of the crypto ideology is that this change can‚Äôt happen unless people use crypto. The technology and the ideology are tied together. For many of these enthusiasts
column18: recommending crypto to other people is not just a technology recommendation. To them
column19: buying and selling crypto is a form of political and social activism. They argue that buying crypto will remove corruption and change society to trust technology over government. This ideology is a more extreme version of technolibertarianism
column20: which seeks to replace government with technology. Like technolibertarians
column21: true bitcoiners want technology to control society. But they focus on financial and economic control more than civil liberties. And because promoting crypto is part of this ideology
column22: crypto has often been compared with a religion. An important aspect of any ideology is the way it emphasizes some dangers and downplays others. True bitcoiners emphasize the problems with government corruption. But they downplay the financial risks of crypto. The price of Bitcoin fluctuates wildly
column23: and many people have lost money buying crypto. Crypto wallets are difficult to understand and use
column24: and fraudulent transactions are difficult to reverse. Crypto enthusiasts frequently downplay the technology‚Äôs risks to people and society. They also dismiss the valuable role that governments and corporations play in protecting people‚Äôs money
column25: providing insurance for bank accounts and returning money that‚Äôs been stolen. Beliefs in crypto‚Äôs ability to create social change are also overstated. Crypto technologies don‚Äôt necessarily eliminate corporations or avoid government control. There are private
column26: corporate blockchains and many government regulations about cryptocurrencies. As I see it
column27: simply using the technology doesn‚Äôt necessarily lead to the social change these enthusiasts seek. [Science
